あれは、サンシャイン六十です。
and, and then, after that, in addition

column2: This is one yen, a one yen coin. This is five yen, a five yen coin. Ten yen, a ten yen coin. Fifty yen, a fifty yen coin. One hundred yen, a hundred yen coin. Five hundred yen, a five hundred yen coin.

column2: Okay. One, five, ten, fifty, one hundred, five hundred.

column1: そうです。これは千円。千円札。二千円。二千円札。五千円。五千円札。それから、これは一万円。一万円札。
column2: That's right. This is one thousand yen, a thousand yen bill. Two thousand yen, a two thousand yen bill. Five thousand yen, a five thousand yen bill. And then, there's ten thousand yen, the ten thousand yen bill.
One thousand, two thousand, five thousand, ten thousand.

column1: あのぉ、日本の夏は何月から何月までですか。
column2: Umm, from what month to what month is summer in Japan?

column2: Um, Probably from July to September.

ええ？ちがいますよ。九月は秋ですよ。夏は、六月から八月までです。
column2: Huh? No that's not right. September is in autumn. Summer is from June to August.

column1: お会計、一万 三千 百 二十五 円です。

column2: OK, one hundred yen. Ten yen, twenty yen. Ummm...one yen, two yen, three yen, four yen...um, wait a minute please. Ah, ummm, can I pay by credit card?

column2: Examinations are from Monday to Friday, nine a.m. to one thirty p.m. and three thirty p.m. to six p.m. Saturdays and Sundays are holidays.

ビデオ付インターホン

column2: Oh, that's right. Thank you very much.

マーポー豆腐お願いします。

column1: 君はいつからこの仕事に入った？

column1: なるほど。普段は泥棒じゃない。よく風とか動物とかブザーを鳴らすんだ。今回もそれが原因だろう。ちょっと見せて。

あら、やっぱり来てくれましたね。

column2: No, no. It's good that you came. I can relax. It's good that such a good security company is with us.

column1: ありがとうございます。

column2: Mr. Takahashi, I'm so sorry for inconveniencing you. I set off the security alarm. And as I forgot the security code, I couldn't turn it off.

column1: 大丈夫です。すぐ消します！

column1: ありがとうございます！

No, that's no good. Akiko, hey. If it's alright with you, how about a stroll in Yamashita Park?

column2: Hey! Since when were you listening?

column1: もしよかったら、もしよかったら、明子さん、あたしの馬鹿なお兄さんと付き合ってあげて。ははははは！
column2: If it's alright, if it's alright, Akiko, please date my big brother? Hahahaha.

column1: はやかったな〜。なんでそんなに早いんだ？
column2: That was fast! Why was it that fast?

column1: 問題なかったからですよ。
よかった！やっぱりあの犬だよね。
column2: Good. It was that dog, right?

column1: いいえ。今回は小林さんが鳴らしてしまいました。
column2: No. This time Kobayashi set off the alarm.

column1: ああ、そう？それははじめてだね。すべてチェックした？
column2: Oh, is that right? That's a first. You checked everything right?

column1: もちろん！とても楽しかったです。
column2: Of course. It was really fun.

column1: うん、小林さんはとても優しい人でした。
そう？小林さんは去年奥さんがなくなってから、ちょっと冷たくなってきたけど。
column2: Really? Ever since his wife passed away last year, he's been a bit cold.

column1: ちょっと待って！何だって？彼の奥さんは去年なくなった？
column2: Hang on! What did you say? His wife passed away last year? Are you serious? And let me guess, he doesn't have a daughter.
I've been duped. Call the police!

column1: おはよう。今日の調子はどうですか。
column2: Good morning. How do you feel today?

column1: 今朝５時にカラスに起こされてから眠れないし、
column2: I was awakened by a crow at 5am, so I couldn't sleep at all. The train was really crowded, and my foot was stepped on. To top it all off, I was stabbed by an umbrella. I'm in a really bad mood today. It's just not my day.
Well, after your presentation at this morning's meeting, everything should be smooth sailing. Hang in there a bit longer.
Oh no!!!! I left my materials at home!

column1: まあでも、今朝の会議の発表が終わったら、もう心配ないね。もう少しだよ。
column2: Oh really? In that case, can I have your desk?

column1: to run somebody over (with a vehicle), to knock someone down
また怪我したの？足はどうしたの？
column2: You got hurt again? What happened to your foot?

column1: 今朝、自転車に乗っていて、車に轢かれて骨折したのよ。
column2: I was riding my bicycle this morning and was run down by a car. The bone is fractured.

column1: 一台だけ？僕は昔暴走族に次々に轢かれたことがあるよ。
column2: Only one car? A long time ago, I was run over by a whole gang of hot-rodders, one after the other.

column1: え～、一台だけじゃないの？
いいえ、違います。全員でございます。
じゃ、あなたの勝ちですね。
ありがとうございます。

column2: But, there was this one day...

column1: ね、宏、パパに手を貸して。
column2: Hey, Hiroshi, can you help me?

column1: やだ！そのかかしが怖い〜。
column2: Oh, no, I can't! It's scary.

column1: それが目的だよ。怖くないとカラスにとうもろこしを食べられるよ。
column2: That's the point. If it's not scary, it could not stop crows from eating sweet corn.

column1: カラスがとうもろこしを食べる？
そうだよ。全部！だから、このかかしがある。
column2: Yes, they do. They would eat everything! That's why we need this scarecrow.

column1: ね、パパ、カラスにとうもろこしを食べられるとカラスがとうもろこしを食べる。。。同じことを言ってるね。
column2: Hmm, Dad, you said sweet corn is eaten by crows and crows eat sweet corn. These are the same, right?

column1: 文法ってパパが高校卒業できないように、作られたものさ。
column2: Grammar was something made to prevent me from graduating from high school.

column1: 大尉、命令を待っています。
敵をそのまま見張って下さい。
column2: Continue to keep an eye on the enemy.

column1: ね、大尉、敵に見られてますけど。どうします？
column2: Captain, we're being watched by the enemy now. What should we do?
Okay, well... how about looking back at them?

column1: あれ、大尉は見ないんですか。
あ。どうしよう？あ、今マージャンで忙しいから。後で。
column2: Ahh, what should I do? I'm busy playing mah-jong. In a minute.

column1: 大尉！大変です！今敵に見られています！命令を！
column2: Captain! We have an issue! The enemy is watching us right now. Awaiting orders!

column1: ちょっと待って。今見てる方あるいは見られてる方？
column2: Wait a sec. We're watching or being watched?

column1: 敵を見てるけど、敵に見られてます！
column2: We're watching the enemy, but we're being watched by the enemy!

column1: ええと。。。まだわからない。戻って直接説明しろ！
column2: Well... I still don't understand. Return and explain it to me directly!

column1: 只今電話がありまして、高田さんは会社にもう来ません。
column2: There was a telephone call just now, and Mr. Takada isn't coming in anymore.

column1: うちのエースが会社来ないって？今日って言う意味？
column2: Our ace isn't coming? You mean today?

column1: あの会社、名前も言いたくない、あのライバル会社です。
column2: I don't even want to say the name - our rival company.

column1: あの裏切り者！もういい。高田さんはいらない！
column2: That traitor! That's it. We don't need Takada.
I'm promoting Takahashi. Where is she?

column1: 彼女もスカウトされました。
そうです。同じ会社です。
って言うか、営業部、誰もいないけど。
column2: So the sales department is empty.

column1: 全員です！営業部まるごとスカウトされました！
column2: They're all gone. Practically the whole department was recruited.

column1: 上原さん、大変です。社長が切れてます。
column2: Mr. Uehara, this is bad! The boss is really mad!

column1: ええどうしたんですか。
昨日最後の人が 電気と電気湯沸かしポットを消すのを忘れていました。
column2: The last person forgot turn off the lights and electric hot-water pot.

column1: でも、よくあることじゃないですか。
column2: But doesn't that happen all the time?

column1: それはそうですけど。鍵をかけるのも忘れてました！かなりやばい間違いですよ。
column2: That's true, but they forgot to lock the door as well! That's a real problem.

column1: まずい。実は、最後の人は私でした。
column2: That's bad. To tell the truth, I was the last person.
I thought someone else was still here. I've done it this time. What should I do?

column1: お母さん！お父さん！話があります！
column2: Mom! Dad! We need to talk!

column1: お母さん、知らないふりしないで。
column2: Mom, don't pretend like you don't know.

column1: 亮くん、ママに対してその態度はやめなさい。
column2: Ryo, don't use that tone of voice with your mother.

column1: じゃあ、尋問を始めましょう。昨夜、私が留守にしていたときに私のパソコンを勝手に使ってしまったのは誰ですか。
column2: Okay, let's start the examination. Who was it that felt compelled to use my computer while I was away last night?

column1: 亮くん、このばかばかしい質問をやめなさい。
亮くん！私達がそのパソコンを買ってあげたのよ。
column2: Ryo, we bought you that computer.

column1: やっぱり、お母さん。あげたとすれば、法律の上で私の許可が必要ですよ。
column2: That's just what you would say, mother. If you gave it to me then you need my permission according to the law.

column1: はい、はい。それで、どうするの？
column2: Okay, okay. So what happens next?

column1: 今回は警告だけです。以上です。失礼します。
column2: This time it's just a warning. That is all. I'm through here.

column1: あなたをロースクールに行かせたのは誰？
column2: Who was it that sent you to law school?

column1: 最近ユーチューブ、すごい人気あるじゃん？
column2: YouTube is really popular these days, right?

column1: 俺たちで番組を作ろうぜ！
心の準備はできた？アーユーレディー？
column2: Are you sitting down? Are you ready?

column1: 甘いのか。辛いのか。どっちか。
column2: Sweet one? Spicy one? Which one?
Sweet one? Spicy one? Which one?
We ask strangers which one they like. Something sweet or something spicy.
I don't know what to say.
Anyway, whatever.  When do we record?

column1: もちろん、今からに決まってんじゃん。
to kick, to refuse, to reject; V1
（サッカーの試合　ハーフタイム控え室）山田！さっきのプレー、なんで右サイドに蹴って、右に動かなかったのよ！
column2: (Soccer pitch, half-time break)Yamada!　In that last play, why (on earth) didn't you kick to the right side and move to the right?

column1: えーっ！あそこは左に球を出して、左サイドから攻撃するのが得策でしょう！
column2: What!  The best tactic was to kick to the left to make an attack from the left side!

column1: おいおい。二人とも大声だして、どうしたんだ。もっと落ち着いて、話し合いなさい。
column2: Hey! You guys are shouting, what's up?  Calm down, and talk each other.

column1: 左から崩すっていう監督の戦術通りにしたのに、島田が文句言うんです！監督、島田を叱ってください！
column2: I did it like you planned to attack from the left, but Shimada complained about me!  Coach, yell at him!

column1: 山田の奴が状況も考えずに、ずっと左にしかパスをださないのが問題なんです。あいつのせいで何度チャンスを潰したことか！
column2: The problem is Yamada always passes to the left in any situation without thinking.  How many chances have we missed because of him!

column1: （サッカーの試合中　後半）ちょっと山田！なんで左の私にボール出して、走らないのよ！
column2: (In the soccer game, the second half)Hey, Yamada! Why don't you kick the ball to the left and run?
Come on! You told me to kick the ball to the right just a minute ago, but now you tell me to kick to the left?  What do you mean!

column1: （コーチ二人を呼ぶ）どうしたのよ。二人とも落ち着きなさい。二人が力を合わせればきっと勝てるわ！勝って勝利の美酒に酔おうじゃないの！
column2: (Coach calls them)Hey, what's up.  Calm down, guys.  If you work together, we will definitely win.  Let's enjoy the sweet taste of victory!

column1: さあ、遊園地だぞ。たくさん遊ぶぞー。
column2: Here we are, at an amusement park. We're going to have lots of fun!

column1: お父さん、あれに乗ってみたい。
column2: Dad, I want to ride that!

column1: 空飛ぶじゅうたんか・・・どれどれ。あー、１０歳以上からじゃないと、乗れないんだよ。
column2: The flying carpet?...Let's see. Oh, you have to be over ten years old to ride that.

column1: えー。じゃあ、あそこに行ってみたい。
column2: What? Then I want to go over there!

column1: げっ。あれは、お化け屋敷じゃないか。怖いぞー。
column2: Uh...That's the Haunted House. It's scary!

column1: 大丈夫だよ。いつもゲゲゲの鬼太郎みてるもん。どんなお化けが出てくるか見てみたい。
column2: That's alright. I always watch (the TV series) Ge Ge Ge No Kitaro. I want to see what kind of ghosts pop out.

column1: 困ったなあ。お父さん怖いの本当に苦手なんだよ。
column2: That's a problem. I really don't like scary things.

column1: えーっ、お化けが恐いの？！お父さん、ダサすぎー！
column2: What? You're afraid of ghosts? You're so not cool!

column1: unfaithfulness (in a relationship), an (extramarital) affair, cheating (on someone)
while one has a chance ,use this chance to
どうしたの。そんな病人みたいな顔してー。
column2: What's wrong? You're pale. You look like a sick person.

column1: 昨日、太郎に浮気がばれて、大変だったのよ。
column2: Yesterday, Tarō found out I was cheating on him, and it was a mess.

column1: えーっ！ホストとの浮気ばれたの。なんで、ばれたの。
column2: What? He found out about you seeing a host? How did he find out?

column1: それが、携帯を見たみたいなのよ。私がお風呂に入っているすきに。
column2: I think he saw my cell phone, while I was taking a bath.

column1: メール消してなかったの。バカだなあ。メール消すのは鉄則でしょう。
column2: You hadn't erased your email messages? You fool! That's a golden rule!

column1: お風呂から出て来たらさ、太郎が、鬼みたいな形相で立っててさ・・・もう修羅場だったよ。
column2: When I came out of the bath, Taro was standing there with a look of a monster.  It was hell!

column1: それで、どうするの。やっぱり、ホストとは別れるんでしょ。
column2: And what you are gonna do? You're going to break up with the host, aren't you?

column1: う〜ん。ほんの遊びのつもりが、私、結構まじになっちゃったみたいなのよね。あー、私は一体どうしたらいいんだろう。
column2: Uhhh. Initially, I only wanted to have some fun. But I started to fall for him. Oh, what should I do?

column1: そんなの簡単じゃん。二股だよ、二股！
column2: That's easy. Just keep two-timing them, two-time them!

column1: Don't tell me that --, surely not, impossible
Don't rush, Keep your pants on
今日は、避難訓練がある。
column2: We have a disaster drill today.

column1: 緊急の場合に、守らないといけない、大切な言葉は何だったか、わかる人は手を上げて？
column2: Who remembers the important phrase we have to abide by in case of an emergency?　The person who knows, please raise your hand.

column1: えーっと、「オアシス」です。
「オアシス」ってどういう意味だ。
column2: And what does Oasis stand for?

column1: 「おさない」「あわてない」「静かに」「すばやく」の頭の文字をとったものです。
column2: It's the first letters from the (Japanese) words, Don't push, don't rush, be quiet but nimble.

column1: おおー、正解。まさか、山田が正解するとは・・・。
column2: Wow. That's correct. I never expected Yamada to give the right answer!

column1: 先生、山田くんは「オアシス」なんて、できないと思います。
column2: Teacher, I don't think Yamada can abide by the Oasis rule of emergency.

column1: 悪戯ばかりするし。女の子に意地悪ばかりするんです。
column2: Because Yamada is always pushing Mami in the corridor, or shouting and just being obnoxious. He always teases the girls.

column1: どうなんだ、山田。そうなのか。
column2: What do you think, Yamada? Is that true?

column1: えーっ！そんなことしないよ。
嘘だあ。いつも、ちょっかい出してるくせに。べー。
column2: You liar! You always bother the girls! (sticks out her tongue)

column1: うるさいな。のぞみには何もしてないだろっ！
column2: Be quiet! I haven't done anything to you!
Yeah, I gave you chocolate for Valentines and yet....(cries) You always tease other girls, never me....(cries) Yamada: ...

column1: なっなんなんだ、この二人は！？
column2: What's going on between these two?!?!?!

column1: すまないが、会議の資料を会議室に置いておいてくれ。
column2: Sorry to trouble you, but could you bring the documents for the meeting to the meeting room?

column1: 会議室に人数分、置いておきました。あのぉ・・・
column2: (10 minutes later...) I put enough documents for all the attendees. Say...

column1: 部長はモーニング娘のファンなのですか。机の携帯の着信音が「ラブ・マシーン」だったもので。
column2: Are you a fan of (the female idol group) Morning Musume? Your cell phone ring tone is the song Love Machine by Morning Musume.

column1: （小声で）そうなんだよー。孫の影響でね。最初は馬鹿にしてたんだが、今はファンなんだ。でもコンサートのチケットが、どうしてもとれなくてね。
column2: (whispering...) Actually, I am, thanks to my grandchildren. At first I made fun of them, but now I'm a fan. But I can't get tickets to their concert no matter how hard I try.

column1: モー娘のチケットなら、とれるかもしれませんよ。友達がレコード会社で働いているので。
column2: I might be able to get tickets for you. A friend of mine works at their label.

column1: 本当か？！桐原君、場合によっては、来月の人事会議で、君のことを係長に推薦してもいいんだが・・・。
column2: Really? Kirihara, at the next personnel meeting,  I could recommend that you be promoted to division chief...

column1: 予約を頼んでおきます！
column2: I'll reserve those tickets right away!

column1: 山田さんは明日の何時に着きますか。
column2: What time is Mrs. Yamada arriving tomorrow?

column1: 彼女は午後６時１５分前に到着します。
ああ、留守電にメッセージがあります。
もしもし、明日なんですが。

column2: I'll arrive an hour early. Thank you in advance.

column1: よろしくお願いします。
どうぞよろしくお願いいたします。
ふつう。こちらはたけです。中学校の友達。
column2: Same old, same old. This is Take, a friend from middle school.

column1: あ、初めまして。夏子です。よろしくお願いします。
column2: Oh, how do you do? I'm Natsuko. Please be kind to me.

column1: 初めまして。高見沢です。よろしくお願いします。
column2: Nice to meet you. I'm Takamizawa. Please be kind to me.

column1: はい、次のお客さんどうぞ。

column2: Yes, from 2000 yen. Your change is 743 yen.

column1: どうもありがとうございました。
皆さん、今日の試合はとても大事です。真剣にやりましょう！
column2: Everyone, today's game is very important. Let's play seriously.

column1: やあ、皆さん、今日はいい天気ですね。今日は楽しくやりましょう！
column2: Hey everyone, nice weather today, right? Today, let's have fun out there.
Everyone, win at all costs, win at all costs, win at all costs.

column1: 皆さん、気持ちよくやりましょう。
column2: Everyone, let's enjoy ourselves out there.

column1: それでは、今日のジュニアサッカーの試合を始めます。
column2: Okay everyone, today's PeeWee soccer game is about to begin.
It's the end of the year already, isn't it?

column1: 再来週は冬休みですね。石川さんは今年の冬休みをどこで過ごしますか。
column2: The week after next is winter vacation. Mrs. Ishikawa, where will you spend your winter vacation?

column1: そうですね。今年は家族が鳥取へ戻りますが、私は東京に残ります。仕事がありますから。長谷川さんはどうですか。
column2: Hmmm. My family is going back to Tottori, but I will remain in Tokyo. Because I have work. How about you, Mr. Hasegawa?

column1: 私たちは今年もハワイへ行きます。
column2: We're going to Hawaii again this year.

column1: いいですね。お土産、よろしくお願いします。
column2: Sounds nice. I'm looking forward to my souvenir.

column1: 川本首相おはようございます！

column2: Good morning. Ah, I'm so sleepy.

column1: ９時１５分にドイツの首相と朝御飯を食べます。
column2: You will have breakfast with the German Chancellor at nine-fifteen.

column1: それから、１２時半にイギリスの首相と銀座でお茶を飲みます。
column2: Then at twelve-thirty you will have afternoon tea with the British Prime Minister in Ginza.

column1: そして、６時３６分にロシアの大統領と晩御飯を食べます。
column2: After that, you will have dinner with the Russian President at siz thirty-six.

column1: 夜は、１０時２分前にパジャマを着て、ベッドに入ります。
column2: After that, you'll change into a pair of pajamas at 2 minutes before 10, and go to bed.

column1: その後、私が子守歌を歌います。
column2: Then, I'll sing you a lullaby.
It's going to be another tough day today.

column1: 楽器は高いですね！このギターは３万５千円ですよ！
column2: Musical instruments are expensive! This guitar is 35,000 yen

column1: ３万５千円は悪くないですよ。そちらを見て。
column2: 35,000 yen is not such a bad price. Look at that one.

column1: ギターとかバイオリンとか、弦楽器は結構高いですよ。
column2: String instruments, such as guitars or violins, are quite expensive though.

column1: 高いですね。今日はどの楽器を買いますか。
column2: They certainly are expensive. Which instruments will you buy today?

column1: 店では買いません。店でいろいろ見ますが、楽天で買います。かなりお得です。
column2: I don't buy at shops. I look at various instruments at shops, but I buy on Rakuten. They have good deals.

column1: ああ〜。楽しかった！K−１はなかなか面白いね。最高の大晦日！
column2: Ah. That was fun! K-1 is quite interesting. This New Year's is the best!

column1: はあ〜。全然楽しくなかった。切符はいくらだった？
column2: Huh? That wasn't fun at all. How much were the tickets?

column1: 俺の切符は５万２千円とお前の切符は５千円。。。
column2: My ticket was 52,000 yen, and your ticket was 5,000.

column1: 切符も高かったし。今日は超つまらなかった！
column2: The tickets were expensive, among other things. Today was painfully boring!

column1: でも、二人は一緒に大晦日を過ごした。
column2: But, we spent New Year's Eve together.

column1: ああ〜。思い出した。面白いところがあった。
column2: Ah. I remember! There was something interesting.

column1: bun filled with white bean paste
はい、どうぞ。コーヒーとあんパンです。
column2: Here you are. Coffee and a bun with bean paste.

column1: どうも。「噛む音から、吐き出す音」不味い！何これ？高橋さん！これは何！
column2: Thanks. (sound of chewing and then spitting out) This is terrible! What is this? Ms. Takahashi! What is this!
That's a bun with bean paste.

column1: これは木村屋のあんパンじゃない！それに、これはしろあんパンだよ！しろあんパンはすきじゃない！
column2: This isn't a Kimuraya bun with bean paste! Also, this is a bun with white bean paste! I don't like white bean paste!

column1: いらっしゃい！いらっしゃいませ！新鮮な蟹、エビ、ホタテ、どうぞ、どうぞ！
column2: Right this way! Over here! How about fresh crab, shrimp, and scallops? Right this way!
What can I do you for?

column1: この蟹はいくらですか。
その蟹は１万５千円ですよ。
column2: That crab is fifteen thousand yen.

column1: この蟹は美味しいよ。蟹の季節ですよ。
column2: This crab is delicious, and it's crab season!
Hmmm, please give me a better price.
Come on, it's still expensive. 500 yen!

column1: 叔父さん、頼むよ。まけてよ。
column2: Come on pops, I'm begging you. Drop your price.

column1: じゃ、しょうがない。一万でいいよ。
column2: Alright, what can ya do? Ten thousand yen it is.
I did it! Tonight it's crab stew!

column1: やった！新しい鍋という家が見つかった蟹！皆、さようなら。
column2: I did it! The crab who found a new home named pot. Goodbye everyone!

column1: あ〜たけしさん、こんにちは。今からどこへ行きますか。
column2: Hello, Mr. Takeshi. Where are you going now?

column1: えっ、名古屋？旅行ですか？
column2: Wow, Nagoya? Are you going on a trip?

column1: いいえ、旅行じゃありません。名古屋で友達の結婚式があります。
column2: No, actually it isn't a trip. I have a friend's wedding in Nagoya.
The marriage ceremony will take place at the Rokkosan hotel in Nagoya.

column1: 六甲山ホテルは１００万ドルです。
column2: The Rokkosan hotel is a million dollars.

column1: そう。ホテルで見る夜景は１００万ドルです。１００万ドルの夜景です。
column2: Yes, the night view from the hotel is a million dollar view!

column1: すばらしい！うらやましいですね。
head of a section or department
どうぞ！旨い！本当に旨い！これも。それも。バレンタイン・デー大好き！
column2: Come in! This is good! Really good! These, too. Those, too. I love Valentine's Day!

column1: 部長、チョコレートをいっぱいもらいましたね！
column2: Boss, you got a lot of chocolate!

column1: そうだね。田中さんからトリュフチョコレートをもらって、鈴木さんからこのケーキをもらって、
column2: Yeah, that's right. I got chocolate truffles from Tanaka. I got these cookies from Suzuki.
I got that handmade cake from... uhh, Take. But my favorite is this!

column1: 人面犬チョコ！あ...でもよく見るとキモカワ？
column2: Doggy-shaped chocolates with human faces? Hmm... but, if you look at it a while, it's gross, but kind of cute.

column1: ２５個以上もらった！自己新記録だ！今日は幸せ！世界中の男が幸せだ。聖バレンタインにお礼をしたい！
column2: I received over 25 things! A new personal best! I'm happy today! Men all over the world are happy. I wanna thank Saint Valentine!

column1: でも、西洋でバレンタイン・デーは逆ですよ。
column2: But in the west, Valentine's Day is the opposite.

column1: 男が女からもらうのではなく、女が男からもらいます。
column2: Guys don't receive from girls, but girls receive from guys.

column1: かわいそうな西洋の男達！ずっと日本にいたい。
column2: Poor western men! I wanna be in Japan forever.

column1: (hum) to visit, to ask, to hear
（ベルが鳴る）誰かな？ちょっと見てくる。
column2: (Door bell rings) Who could that be? I'll answer it.

column1: すいませーん。NHKでーす。受信料の徴収に伺いました。
column2: Hello, I'm from NHK and came to collect viewing fees.

column1: うん、受信料を取りにきた。
column2: Yeah, they came to collect viewing fees.
How long are we going to hide?

column1: 引っ越すまで、絶対支払わない！！
column2: Until we move out. I'm never paying!!

column1: デイブさん、いつ日本へ帰って来ましたか。
column2: Dave, when did you get back to Japan?

column1: 先週の木曜日に帰って来ました。
カナダはどうでしたか。
カナダのシロクマは元気でしたか。
いいえ、元気じゃありませんでした。
おいしいアザラシが捕れません。
カナダも暖冬です。海が全部凍りません。だから、アザラシが逃げます。
column2: It's also a warm winter in Canada. The ocean didn't freeze completely, so the seals escape.

column1: まあ、かわいそうですね。シロクマは。でも、アザラシにはよかったかも！
column2: Ah, poor polar bears. But, it may be good for the seals!

column1: ええ〜部長、どうしたんですか。大丈夫ですか。
column2: Umm, boss, what's wrong? Are you alright?

column1: ああ〜、今日は最悪だ。年に一番嫌いな日だ。ホワイト・デーだよ。
column2: Ugh, today is the worst. The worst day of the year! White Day.

column1: ああ、そういうことですか。
２５人にチョコをあげましたよ。自己新記録だ。今日はスッカラカンのからっけつだよ！誰がこの日を作ったんだ。ああ〜。
column2: I gave chocolate to 25 people! A new personal record. I'm broke today. Who made this day? Ugh.

column1: でも、先月いっぱいもらいましたよね。
column2: But last month you received a lot!

column1: でも、先月のことは先月だ。西洋はどうなってる？
column2: But last month is last month. What's going on in the west?

column1: 西洋にホワイト・デーはありません。
column2: In the west there is no White Day.

column1: いいな〜。やっぱり海外がいいな〜。
column2: How nice. I'd like to live in the west.
This guy must be kidding me!

column1: ワァーおじいちゃんだ！いらっしゃい。
オー花子、元気だったかい。
column2: Oh... Hanako, have you been well?

column1: 花子はいい子だね。はい、おみやげだよ。これは大きい箱、これは小さい箱。花子はどっちが好き？
column2: You're a good kid, aren't you. I have souvenirs. Here's a big box, and here's a small box. Which do you prefer?

column1: ワーイ、くまのぬいぐるみだ！！ありがとう、おじいちゃん。ところで小さい箱は何？
column2: Yay, a teddy bear!! By the way, what is the small box?

column1: えーっ。（小さい声で）それがいい…
column2: Whaaat! (In a small voice) I want that one...

column1: はい、大好きです。先週も映画を見ました。
column2: Yes, I love them. I watched a movie last week, and I watched a movie the day before yesterday. I'll watch one tomorrow, too.
I like animation. Last week was My Neighbor Totoro, the day before yesterday was Spirited Away, and tomorrow will be...
Oh really? That's good, here's a movie ticket. Please take it.

column1: そうですか。よかった！ここに映画のチケットがあります。どうぞ。
やったー！「もののけ姫」だ！ありがとう！！
column2: Whaaat? So what do you like?
I like sports. Baseball is my favorite.

column1: 金子:えー！私は野球が好きな人が嫌いです。
column2: Eww, I don't like people who like baseball.
Mr. Tanaka, long time no see!
Oh, yeah! Long time no see?  How are you?

column1: うん、元気よ。実は私、先週引っ越したの。
column2: Good! Actually, last week I moved!

column1: そうですか。新しい家はどう？
駅から近くて便利よ。そしてとても静かなの。それに、家賃も安いのよ。
column2: It's near the station, so it's convenient. And it's quiet. What's more, the rent is cheap!

column1: それはすばらしい！私の家は駅から遠くて、不便です。そして、うるさいです。それに、家賃も高いです。私も引っ越したい！
column2: That's wonderful! My house is far from the station, so it's inconvenient. And it's noisy. What's more, the rent is high. I wanna move too!

column1: でも.......私の新しい家は、茨城県よ！
column2: But... my new house is in Ibaraki Prefecture!

column1: serious, terrible, tough, in trouble; Adj(na)
to return, to go home; V1
（坂本さんと山下さんが道で偶然出会う 。）（弱々しく）あら、山下さんこんにちは。
column2: (Sakamoto-san and Yamashita-san meet up with each other on the street.)(lamely) Hey, Yamashita-san.

column1: あー！坂本さんこんにちは。元気ですか。
column2: Hey! Sakamoto-san, how are you doing?

column1: それが....クシュンクシュン（くしゃみ）、コンコンコン（咳）昨日から風邪をひいていて....コン！コン！.....元気じゃありません。
column2: Well... Achoo! Cough! I got a cold yesterday.  Cough! Cough!  I'm actually not fine.

column1: まあ、それは大変ですね。大丈夫ですか。
column2: That's too bad.  Are you OK?

column1: あんまり大丈夫じゃないです。これから薬屋さんへよって、家に帰ります。お粥を食べて、そして寝ます。おやすみなさい。
column2: Actually I'm not really fine.  I'm gonna go to the pharmacy and then head home. I'll eat some rice porridge and then just go to bed. Good night.

column1: おやすみなさい？まだ午後なんだけど。本当に大丈夫かな？
column2: Good night? It's still the afternoon. I wonder if she is really OK.

column1: あっ、もう１２時半ですね。田淵さん一緒に食事しませんか。
column2: Oh, it's already twelve thirty.  Tabuchi-san, why don't we eat lunch together?

column1: それはいいですね。この辺に岡田さんのお気に入りのレストランはありますか。
column2: I'd love to.  Do you have a favorite restaurant around here?

column1: え〜っと......じゃあ、あの郵便局の隣においしいスパゲティ屋さんがありますが.....どうですか。
column2: Well, there is a delicious spaghetti restaurant next to the post office.  Is that OK?

column1: そのスパゲティ屋さんにはどんなメニューがありますか。
column2: What kind of food do they have at the spaghetti restaurant?

column1: ナポリタン、ミートソース、ボンゴレ......何でもありますよ。
column2: Napolitano, bolognese, vongole.... they have everything.

column1: それはすばらしい。ピザはありますか。
あー、残念ですが、ピザはありません。スパゲティだけです。あっ、サラダもあります。
column2: Ah, unfortunately, they don't have pizza. Only spaghetti.  Oh yes, they also have salad.

column1: そうですか。じゃあ行きましょう。
二人ですが、席ありますか。
column2: There are two of us.  Do you have any seats available?

column1: すみません。今いっぱいで、席がありません。
column2: I'm sorry.  We are full now, so have no seats available.

column1: やっぱり、ここのスパゲティはおいしかったね。でももうお腹いっぱい！
column2: Obviously, this spaghetti place was delicious. But I'm already stuffed!

column1: 私もおなかいっぱい！ミートソーススパゲティたくさん残ったね〜。もったいないね。岡田さんの家に犬はいますか。
column2: Me too. We've got so much spaghetti bolognese left.  What a waste!  Hey, do you have a dog at your house?

column1: いいえ、犬はいません。でも猫はいますよ。
column2: I don't have a dog, but I have a cat.

column1: じゃあ、猫にこのスパゲティをもって帰りませんか。
column2: So, do you wanna take this spaghetti home?

column1: わぁ〜ありがとう。もちろん持って帰ります。今日、主人はいません。だから、このスパゲティは私の夕食です。ヤッター！
column2: Wow, thank you. Of course, I'd love to.  My husband won't be home today. So, I'll have this spaghetti for my dinner. Yay!!

column1: ねぇ、お母さん、携帯電話買ってよ～。
column2: Hey Mom. Buy me a cell phone!

column1: ダメ。小学生に携帯電話は必要ないでしょ。
column2: No. Elementary students do not need cell phones.

column1: みんな持ってるよ。いくつになったら買ってくれるの？
column2: But everybody has one. When will you get me one?

column1: 携帯電話で何をするの？
column2: What would you do with a cell phone?

column1: ゲームとか、メールするんだよ。
電話をするだけなら、買ってもいいわよ。
column2: If you're only going to make phone calls, I could buy you one.

column1: えー！！それなら、携帯電話いらないよ！
column2: What? In that case, I don't need a cell phone!

column1: 鳥のから揚げ、買ってきたわよ。
column2: I went and bought fried chicken!

column1: ふたりで分けて、食べてね。
column2: Split them between yourselves and eat them, OK?

column1: じゃあ、じゃんけんで勝った人が好きなのをとろう。
column2: OK, the one who wins by janken can take the ones he likes!

column1: わーい、勝った！じゃあ、これと、これと、これね。
column2: Yay, I won!  So, this one and this one, and this one, OK.

column1: ちぇっ、大きいのばっかりとったな！
column2: You took all the big ones!

column1: すいません。このジャケット着ていいですか。
column2: Excuse me, Can I try on this jacket?

column1: どうぞ。こちらに鏡がありますよ。
column2: Go ahead.  There's a mirror over here.

column1: とてもお似合いですよ。ダークグレーはお客様にピッタリです。
column2: Oh, it looks really good!  Dark gray is perfect on you.

column1: あわせて、あちらの黒いズボンもはいてみてはどうですか。
column2: How about combining them with those black pants?

column1: 素晴らしい。この色はお客様にピッタリでございますよ。
column2: Oh wonderful! This color is perfect on you!

column1: こちらの靴下を、はいてみてはいかがでしょうか。ズボンと、ばっちり合うと思いますよ。
column2: How would you like to try on these socks? I think they would look perfect with your pants.

column1: 素晴らしい。なんとお客様の足にフィットすることでしょう。
column2: Wonderful! They fit perfectly on your feet.
How would you like to try on this hat, too?

column1: （木ノ下、サングラスをかける）
column2: Well, how about trying on these sunglasses?

column1: お客様、素晴らしいです。とってもダンディーでございます。いかがでしょうか。
column2: Sir, they're wonderful!  They're so snazzy!  What do you think?

column1: 私は、あなたの着せ替え人形じゃありません！ただジャケットを着てみたかっただけなんです。
column2: I'm not your dress up doll! Just the jacket I tried on, please.

column1: 私は、嘘など申しません。
本当ですよ。サングラスをかけますと、どこぞの俳優さんかと思っちゃいます。
column2: Really! When you put on the sunglasses, I accidentally mistake you for some famous actor.

column1: まじですか。じゃあ、5点全部買います。
お買い上げありがとうございます！
column2: Thank you so very much for your patronage!

column1: 信号には、色が3つあるけど、何色かわかる人は手をあげてー。
column2: Traffic signals consist of three colors. Raise your hands if you know what colors they are.

column1: はいはいはいはいはいっ。
先生:じゃあ、マサル。青と黄色と赤、それぞれどんな意味かわかるかい。
column2: Very good. Everyone, let's give Masaru a round of applause.

column1: はい、先生。青色は進んでよい。黄色は止まれるなら止まれ。赤色は止まれ、です。
マサル、よくできました。よく知っていたなあ。
column2: Okay, then. Masaru, what do each color mean?

column1: 先生、先生。マサルくんは、わかっていないと思います。
column2: Yes. Green means go. Yellow means stop if you can. Red means stop.
Very good, Masaru. You know this very well.

column1: だって、マサルくんは「赤信号、皆で渡ればこわくない」って、いつも赤信号なのに渡ろうとするんです。
column2: Teacher, I don't think Masaru knows this very well.

column1: how long, how much, how many
to arrive at, to reach; V1
すみません。これをイギリスに送りたいのですが。
column2: Excuse me. I'd like to send this to the U.K.

column1: 航空便と船便とありますが、どちらになさいますか。
column2: There's airmail and surface mail. Which would you like to use?

column1: 着くのに、どれくらい差がありますか。
column2: How much difference will there be in the delivery time?

column1: 船便ですと、航空便より料金は安いですが、一ヶ月くらいかかります。航空便ですと、一週間以内には着きます。
column2: Surface mail is cheaper than airmail, but it will take about a month (for your package to reach its destination.) Airmail will get it there in about a week.

column1: どうしようかな・・・。
column2: I wonder what I should do...
How much difference will there be in price?

column1: 小包はちょうど5kgですので、航空便ですと10,150円、船便ですと4,000円になります。
正倫:じゃあ、航空便でお願いします。
column2: The package is exactly 5 kilograms, so it would cost 10,150 yen via airmail and 4,000 yen via surface mail.

column1: では、こちらの用紙に記入して下さい。
column2: Surface mail is less than half the price of airmail. But I'll choose airmail to get the package there by Mother's Day.
Alright. Please fill out this form.

column1: ビールを一杯ください。
column2: I'd like a glass of beer.

column1: キリンとハイネケンとサッポロがありますが。
column2: We have Kirin, Heineken, and Sapporo.
In that case, I'll have Heineken.

column1: かしこまりました。他には何か。
えーっと、ミックスナッツを一つと、ポテトチップスを二袋ください。
column2: Ummm. Please give me one bowl of mixed nuts and two bags of potato chips.

column1: かしこまりました。合計で1200円です。
あっ、後ハートチョコを三個追加で。
column2: Oh, and please add three pieces of heart-shaped chocolate.

column1: 山田さん、もしよかったら、クラシックのコンサートに行きませんか。
column2: Mr. Yamada, by chance would you like to go to a classical concert?

column1: 誰のコンサートですか。
小沢征爾のコンサートです。チケットを二枚もらったので、山田さんと行きたいなあと思って。
column2: It's a Seiji Ozawa concert. I happened to get 2 tickets, and I was thinking I'd like to go with you....

column1: 本当ですか。小沢征爾は大好きなんです。
じゃあ決まり。では、来週の日曜日の6時に上野駅の改札口の前で。
column2: Then it's a deal.  Next Sunday at 6 o'clock in front of the ticket gate in Ueno station.

column1: わかりました。楽しみにしてます。
column2: Got it.  I'm looking forward to it!

column1: 小沢征爾のコンサートのチケットを二枚お願いします。
column2: Two tickets for the Seiji Ozawa concert please.

column1: 申し訳ありません。前売り券はもう売り切れてしまいました。
column2: I'm terribly sorry. The advance tickets are sold out.

column1: すいません。大人気なので、もう手に入らないと思いますよ。
column2: I'm sorry, but I think that you won't be able to get your hands on them, since Seiji Ozawa is so popular.

column1: 困ったなあ・・・山田さんに、チケット二枚もらったって言っちゃったよ。あーどうしよう！
column2: Oh no. I told Ms. Yamada that I got 2 tickets! Ah...what am I gonna do??

column1: ねえ。美穂って太めの男の人が好みなのよね。
column2: Miho, you like guys that are kinda big, don't you?

column1: 太めっていうか、ガッチリした人がいいわ。
column2: Big, but a well-built guy is better.

column1: ガッチリしてるって・・・私はマッチョな人は嫌だわ。
column2: A well-built guy is good... but macho guys are gross.

column1: 少しくらいマッチョの方が、男らしくていいじゃない。
column2: I prefer kinda macho guys cuz I think they’re manly.

column1: えーっ。私は細くて痩せてる人の方がいいわ。
それは、あなたがデブだからよ。デブは痩せが好きなの！
column2: That's because you're fat. The fat always like the thin.

column1: ひっひどい・・・。気にしてるのに。
column2: That's harsh! I'm sensitive about that!

column1: （あれ。さっきはあのコースはストライクだったんだけどな。まあいいや、まだ２ストライク1ボール。気を取り直してと。）
column2: (Huh? Just a minute ago that same pitch was called a strike. Whatever, it's still two strikes and one ball. I've gotta focus).

column1: （えっ。ストライクだろう！。どこ見てんだ、あのアンパイア。これで三振だ。）
column2: What? I'm pretty sure that was a strike. Where is that umpire looking? This should be a strike out.

column1: （おいおい。あのボールがボールだって。直球だったのに。我慢にも程があるぞ、あの、へぼアンパイアー！）
column2: Now wait a minute! You're saying that ball was a ball? Even though that ball was straight!? My patience is running out. What a sad excuse for an umpire!

column1: ボール、フォアボール、ランナー一塁！
column2: Ball! Ball four, take your base.

column1: （大きい声で）おい、ふざけんなよアンパイア！今のがボールだって。さっきからどこに目つけてんだよ！何球ストライク・ボール投げてるとおもってんだ。
column2: (In a loud voice) Hey, Blue*, don't mess with me! You call that a ball? Where did your eyes go? How many strikes do you think I threw?

column1: 貴様、私を侮辱する気か。ピッチャー退場！
column2: Okay wise guy, feel like insulting me? You're out!

column1: 先生、砂漠ってどんな所ですか。
column2: Teacher, what kind of place is the desert?

column1: 面白そうだから、砂漠に行ってみたいんです。
column2: Because it seems interesting, I want to go to the desert to see what it's like.

column1: 大変な所だぞ。暑いし、乾燥するし、雨はふらないし、夜は寒いし。
column2: The desert is a harsh place. It's hot and dry. It doesn't rain, and the nights are cold.

column1: のどがカラカラになっても水が飲めないんですか。
column2: If you are dying of thirst, can you find water to drink?

column1: 難しいかもしれないな。
そんなー。先生、私やっぱり行きたくないです。
column2: It's like that. Teacher, I don't want to go after all.

column1: （腕を振り回す）。まわれ、まわれ、まわれ！
column2: (swinging his arm) Go, go, go around the bases!

column1: おおっと、二塁ランナー、三塁をまわったー。本塁間に合うかあ。
column2: Wow. The second-base runner has reached third base. Will he make it to home base? The ball has been passed around and reached home base. It looks like this will be a close one. (The runner and catcher crash into each other.)

column1: キャッチャーがボールを落としたー。
column2: The umpire has called it out. The third-base coach is furiously contesting the call. It looked like it was safe, but what do you think?

column1: おおっと、アンパイアはアウトのコールだあ。三塁ベースコーチがすごい形相でアンパイアに猛抗議だあ。見た感じですと、セーフに見えたんですがどうですかね。
column2: Well, timing-wise it looked like it was out because the catcher dropped the ball. But it looks like the umpire assumed the catcher dropped the ball after he touched the runner. This is a tough call. I don't blame the third-base coach for contesting it.

column1: そうですね。タイミング的にはアウトでしたが、キャッチャーがボールを落としてますからね。ただ、ボールを落としたのがランナーにタッチをした後と判断したようですね。微妙な判定です。抗議も当然ですね。
column2: Uh-oh. The third-base coach has just been kicked out of the game. That's the second person to be kicked out today. It's becoming a rough game.
At the library. A lost item

column1: すいません。忘れ物は届いていませんか。
column2: Excuse me. Have any lost items been brought in?

column1: オープン・エリアに財布を忘れてしまったんです。

column2: Aren't you done yet? Do your homework before you play video games. How many times are you going to make me say it?!
Alright. Alright. I'll wrap it up in 10 minutes.

column2: Oh no! What are you doing? I was doing great!

column2: Ma'am, are you okay?  It's very cold, isn't it?  Would you like to use a pocket warmer?  Please, be my guest.

column2: Thank you very much.  My boyfriend is always working, and I am always alone.  These days, all we do is argue.  And today's my birthday... (sob) Oh, sorry.  All I'm doing is complaining.
I'm sure your boyfriend will come.  Let's wait a little bit longer.

column2: When I was younger, I used to only think about work everyday.  Work was very fun.  All my wife did was take care of the kids.  Then my wife died, and my kids left home.  Now, it's just me.  It's sad.  The truth is, my family was the only important thing.

column1: 申し訳ございません！グレープフルーツジュースはいかかでしょうか。
大変、お待たせいたしました。

(try the salad) This is good. This salad is off the hook, yo!

column2: Thank you very much. How about the momonga?

column1: ありがとうございます。このモモンガはいかがでしょうか。
column2: (try the flying squirrel and wait a little bit...) What? (tries again...) hmmm (tries again...)

This is great!! I have never had food this good in my life! This is even better than the Yakiniku restaurant Keith Kim recommended! Yo, I will never go to any other restaurants. From now on, I will have every meal here.

column1: うまい!!こんなうまい料理は初めてだ！

column2: Yes, I have long been a big fan of him. I'm a member of his fan club and sometimes I write him fan-mails. I also go to his concert.
Golly, you are a ardent fan. I like Onigiri princess better than Onigiri prince.

column1: へー、熱烈なファンですね。
column2: what? the one I keep hearing about?
Yeah, the girlfriend of Onigiri prince. Because she is cute, isn't she?
Oh my god!! Could that be...

column1: Vienna sausage whose shape is like octopus

Really!! Can you make some octopus sausages too?

column2: But my mom always makes octopus sausages for my obento.

column2: I'm sorry. I can't do it. My company is fussy about giving autographs.
Who's this guy? Don't get  in on our date.

column2: What's with the attitude! I'm a 3rd degree judo belt. I can throw you to the ground!! Write an autograph for Ichiban-kun!
OK, OK, I'll give you my autograph.

あ、ありがとうございます。
じゃ、じゃあ、さようなら。

(at school) the sound of dismissal bell

column1: うん。そして、来年は私たちももう小学校卒業ね。
column2: Today is the last day of the 20th century.

column2: Yeah, and we're graduating elementary school next year.
Hey, let's bury a time capsule together in remembrance of the 20th century.
OK, so after school is finished, we go home,  pick up some things we wanna bury then we get together at Elephant Park!

みんなの持ってきた物を、ここに埋めておこう。
column2: Are you ready guys? Let's bury the things we brought here. And when we turn 40, we can dig them out.
This ginkgo tree is the landmark.

column1: to differ, to be different ; V1

column2: 2. the year 2028 (class reunion)Maki! Hajime! Long time no see!

column2: It's been a while since elementary school.

column1: そうよね。だから、２８年ぶりじゃない。
column2: That's right. So it's been 28 years. We're already 40.
Hey guys, we buried the time capsule, right? Let's dig it up!

column2: Oh, that's right! We buried it in Pig Park, didn't we?

column2: No, we didn't. It's in Elephant Park. So, let's go to Elephant Park then.

column2: I'm sorry. Cheeseburgers are sold out.
Then I'll have a large size of Fries.

column2: (mumbling) I'm done (go-chisou-sama) OK, I'm full now so let's go ask the clerk about Elephant Park. Excuse me.

column2: Yes, it did. But they tore it down to build this place three years ago.

column2: So it means the ginkgo tree is gone too.

あった！！あのイチョウの木よ！！
じゃあ、俺たちのタイムカプセルは、この木の下に埋めてあるんだね。
column2: So our time capsule is buried under the tree, huh?

何を入れたんだ？全然覚えてないよ。
column2: Let's open the can, shall we?

column1: あ、缶に何か書いてある...。
column2: I don't remember at all what we put in it.
Oh, something's written on the can...

column1: counter for how many people a dish serves
I really enjoyed the meal. Thank you for the meal.
to feel sick, to feel uncomfortable

(belch) I drank too much.  I don't feel so well.

column2: Hmmm. It's difficult to go in alone, and I feel lonely…(crying) And this Manga-kissa is located in a confusing area…

Senpai, what are you reading? Wall Street Journal? No way! My recommendations are “Nana” and “Nekomura-san”. Both of them are easy to read. (Hiccups)

ウォールストリートジャーナル？ダメダメ。僕のお勧めは「ナナ」と「猫村さん」です。
column2: By the way, we are gonna have performance evaluation tomorrow. Your chief loves Manga and Anime so you’d better study up on them. She always says “Nana and Nekomura-san are masterpieces. Your section chief is easy to talk to. I’m jealous. (Hiccups)
Excuse me, sir. Please be quiet.

No, sir. Actually, I stayed up all night reading manga.

column2: Yes. I read the entire series of Nana and Nekomura-san. They are very easy to read. I think both are masterpieces.

What? But I thought…what? You don’t like…

column1: 君、ふざけているのか？君をニューヨークの駐在員に推薦するつもりだったが、
column2: I hate manga. It’s worthless garbage.
Hahaha, I eliminated one of my rivals. He is too easy to get around.

column1: 皆さん、こんにちは。はじめまして。大空晴夜（おおぞらはるや）と申します。

My hometown is the Adachi ward in Tokyo.
My mother is my only family.  I have no father.
I'm a professional boxer, but I'm not famous.
This year I'm going to marry my girlfriend.
My girlfriend's name is Tendo Miu.  Her hometown is Narita city in Chiba prefecture.

column2: Hello!  My name is Tendo Miu.
My hometown is Narita city in Chiba prefecture.
My family is my father, my mother, and my dog named Dogi.
Oh, and I also have some piranha.
This year, I'm going to marry my boyfriend.
Tomorrow he'll meet my family.  I'm excited!
Everyone, from now on, please be kind to me.
Ah, Doggy, I’m home. Oh, It’s been a long time.

晴夜さんは、おいくつですか。
あら、三十一才？...ご兄弟がいますか。

column2: No. There is just my mother. I’m the only child.

column1: by far, all along, the whole time
I, me [Used by men only. More casual and vulgar than watashi or boku.]

Yes, I like walking around golf courses. Every weekend I play golf but it's difficult. I'm not good at putting.

スイッチを入れてください。

also, as I thought, in spite of

Tonight is the fireworks show at a nearby park, so the traffic will be pretty bad.

column1: 今夜、近くの公園で 花火大会が あって、道は 大渋滞ですよ。
column2: Let’s watch the fireworks from the veranda. You come too, Miu.

column1: さぁ、ベランダに行って、花火を 見ましょう。ほら、美雨も一緒に来て。
column2: Um, actually, forget the veranda. Let’s watch from the living room.
Dad, what’s wrong with the veranda?

column1: あ...ベランダは だめだ。やっぱり、リビングで見ましょう。
パパ？ベランダに 何が あるの？
column2: Nobody? A person?! Could it be…
There’s nothing there. There’s no one there. No! Don’t open the door.

column1: to invite, to call, to call out;V1
to search, to look for; class 1

column2: Haruya! Huh? There’s no one here…

column1: じゃ、ベランダで花火を見ましょう。
column2: (sigh) Well then, let's watch the fireworks from the veranda. Miu, bring some drinks and snacks from the kitchen.

column1: 美雨、台所から、飲み物とおつまみを持って来て。

column2: Also, bring an ashtray. And ask your mother if she wants to come outside, too.

column1: それから、灰皿を持って来て。
column2: Okey dokey. Mom. Mom? I'm going to look for Haruya, OK? (opens the door) Ah! Mom! Ah, Haruya!

column1: あ、あと、母さんも連れて来て。
column2: Miu, call the police and an ambulance! There's been a robbery!

column1: to calm down, to feel at ease; V1
to chase after someone; class2 verb
はい。119番です。火事ですか。救急ですか。
column2: This is 119. Is it a fire or an emergency?

column1: キッチンに行って、ママが倒れていて…。
column2: (crying) I went to the kitchen, and my mom was on the floor...Haruya ran after the intruder, but, I don't know…

column1: 晴夜は犯人を追いかけて、 よく分かりません。
column2: Please calm down, miss. Please tell me your name.

column1: 落ち着いてください。あなたのお名前を 教えてください。
天道　美雨（てんどう　みう）です。
場所は どこですか。
住所が 分かりますか。
to get on (a train), to take (a train); class 1 verb
to transfer, to change trains; class 2
first of all, to start with
どうしましたか。大丈夫ですか。どこへ行きますか。
column2: Is everything alright? Where are you headed?

column1: あ、あのぉ…京成成田駅へ。
ああ、京成成田駅ですね。山手線で 日暮里に 行って、日暮里で 京成線に 乗ってください。
column2: Keisei Narita station? Take the Yamanote line to Nippori, then at Nippori transfer to the Keisei line.

column1: はぁ…。すみませんが、もう一回、ゆっくり言ってください。メモをしますから。
column2: Hu—h. I’m sorry, can you say that one more time slowly? I’m going to write it down.

column1: まず、山手線に乗って、日暮里に行ってください。
column2: First, get on the Yamanote line. Then, go to Nippori.

column1: はい。はい。山手線で、日暮里まで行く …。
column2: Ok, ok. Yamanote line, go to Nippori.

column1: それから、日暮里で山手線を降りて、京成線に乗り換えてください。
column2: Then at Nippori, get off the Yamanote line, and transfer to the Keisei line.

column1: 日暮里で京成線に乗り換える…。ありがとうございました。
column2: Transfer to the Keisei line at Nippori. Thank you very much.

column1: by far, all along, the whole time
あのぉ、すみません。これは 京成線ですか。
はい、京成スカイライナーです。
column2: Um, excuse me. Is this the Keisei line?

column1: 京成スカイライナー？これは成田へ行きますか。
column2: Yes, this is the Keisei Skyliner.
Keisei Skyliner? Does it go to Narita?

column1: 普通の京成線と 京成スカイライナーと どちらのほうが 安いですか。
京成線のほうが ずっと 安いですよ。京成線は ７５０円、京成スカイライナーは １６７０円です。
column2: Which is cheaper, the regular Keisei line or the Keisei Skyliner?

column1: どちらのほうが速いですか。
column2: The regular Keisei line is much cheaper. The Keisei line costs 750 yen. The Skyliner costs 1670 yen.

column1: もちろん、京成線より京成スカイライナーのほうが速いですよ。
乗りますか。乗りませんか。
column2: Of course, the Skyliner is faster than the regular line.
Are you getting on or not?

column1: こんにちは、天道さん。今日は、昨日より　元気そうですね。気分はどうですか。
column2: Hello Mrs. Tendo. You look better than you did yesterday. How do you feel?

column1: あ、山川先生、お陰様で。昨日より、いいです。
column2: Ah, Dr. Yamakawa, thanks to you, I feel better than I did yesterday. But I’m worried about my piranhas and my dog.

column1: でも、ピラニアと犬が心配です。
column2: Hahaha. You worry more about your pets than your husband?

column1: ははは。旦那さんよりペットのほうが心配ですか。
column2: Haha. Well, the pets are cuter than Raizou-san.

column1: ふふふ。ペットは雷三さんよりかわいいですから。
column2: Well, you have a point (laughs). Mrs. Tendo, you’ll be released next week.

column1: ま、そうですね。（ははは）天道さん、来週、退院してもいいですよ。
column2: Really? Thank you. Oh, how’s your son?

column1: 本当ですか。ありがとうございます。あ、息子さんはどうですか。
column2: Thanks to you, he’s doing better than before. He’s pathetic.

column1: to rise, to go up; (class1 verb)
あのぉ、すみません。天道きりの病室はどこですか。
column2: Excuse me, what room is Tendo Kiri in?

column1: 天道...きりさん？ああ、天道さんの病室は２０５号室です。
column2: Mrs. Tendo Kiri? Her room is #205.

column1: そのエレベーターで二階に上がってください。２０５号室は一番奥です。
column2: Take the elevator to the second floor. 205 is the last room.
The last room on the second floor…Here.

column1: （コンコン）きり？どうだ？体調は？
おお。美雨。いいボーイフレンドを持っているね。強い男はいい。わしはスポーツの中でボクシングが一番好きだ。はっはっは。
column2: Oh, Miu. You have a good boyfriend, eh? A strong man is good. Boxing is my favorite sport…ha..ha..ha.

column1: 愛が一番大事だよ、美雨。パパは関係ない。お金も関係ない。美雨の幸せが一番大切だ。ははは。
column2: Love is the most important thing Miu. Your dad doesn’t matter. Money doesn’t matter. Your happiness matters most. Hahaha.

column1: to be bothered, to have a problem;V1
to take out, to produce; (class 1 verb)
山川さん！ここは、病院ですよ。タバコをすわないでください。
column2: Mr. Yamakawa! This is a hospital. Please don’t smoke.

column1: うるさいなぁ。あ、クローゼットを開けないでくださいよ。
column2: What a nag. Oh, don’t open the closet!

column1: …山川さん…。これは何ですか。お酒ですね？お酒を飲まないでください。
column2: Mr. Yamakawa. What’s this? Is this alcohol? Don’t drink alcohol!

column1: 大きい声を出さないでくださいよ。耳が痛いです。お～、イタイイタイ。
column2: Keep it down, will you? My ears hurt. Ouch! Ow, ow, ow!

column1: ふざけないでください。
山川先生の息子さん、本当に困ります。
column2: Dr. Yamakawa’s son is a real problem.

column1: ああ...言わないでくださいね。
column2: Don’t tell anybody, but Dr. Yamakawa’s son passed out and knocked his head when he saw blood, so he was brought in the same ambulance as Mrs. Tendo Kiri.

column1: 山川先生の息子さんは血を見て、倒れて、頭を打って、天道きりさんと一緒に救急車でここに来ました。
to enter, to come up; V1
あ、お父さん。わざわざありがとうございます。
column2: Oh, dad. Thanks for going out of your way to come here. Come in, come in. Huh, where’s Miu?

column1: さぁ、どうぞ。上がってください。あれ、美雨は。

column2: Oh…I see. Dad, did you eat dinner?
I ate with Miu at Narita station.

column1: あ・・・ お父さん、夕飯は？
column2: Oh…I see. Oh, yeah, I have a good whiskey. Do you want some?

column1: 美雨と成田駅前で食べた。

column2: Do you want ice in it?

column1: あ・・・そうだ。お父さん、うまいウイスキーがありますが、飲みますか。
column2: No ice. So, you’re against Miu getting married?
Huh? Well, I guess I am. I really appreciate what he’s done. To tell you the truth, I don’t hate him. But marriage is a different story.

column1: to put in, to turn on;V2

column2: Here you go, coffee. Do you take milk and sugar with your coffee?

column1: 晴夜さんはいつもコーヒーにお砂糖とミルクを入れて飲みますか。
column2: No, I take my coffee black. Thank you. Ouch, it’s hot!…Um, er, is Mr. Tendo…?

column1: いえ。入れないで飲みます。いただきます。アチッ。
column2: He’s upstairs. He’s been up there looking at Miu’s photo album this whole time without saying a single word. Oh, Haruya-san, did you eat before you came?

column1: 二階にいます。さっきから、何も言わないで、美雨のアルバムを見ているわ。
あ、晴夜さんは、ご飯を食べてきましたか。
column2: Oh, Mr. Tendo. Please allow me to marry…

column1: あ、いえ。食べないで来ました。（グウー）
column2: Enough! Quit dilly-dallying and put on your coat. Where’s Miu? We’re going to eat sushi. We’re celebrating mom getting out of the hospital.

column1: to arrive at, to reach; V1
first of all, to start with
皆様、おはよう ございます。
column2: Good morning, everyone. My name is Shin Shimoyama, and I'll be your tour guide. I look forward to our trip together. Now I will tell you today's itinerary, first, this bus will take us to North Kamakura. We will tour Engakuji and Meigetsuin at North Kamakura. Then, we will go to Kamakura station by train.

column1: 私は 観光ガイドの 下山新（しもやま・しん）と申します。どうぞ よろしく おねがい いたします。
column2: Hey, Mr. Guide, what time will we arrive at Kita Kamakura?

column1: では、今日の予定を 言いますね。
まず、このバスで 北鎌倉に 行きます。
北鎌倉で 円覚寺（えんがくじ）と 明月院（めいげついん）を 観光します。
それから、電車で 鎌倉駅に 行きます。
column2: Is that right? Harrumph. Where will we eat lunch?

column1: ねぇ、ガイドさん、何時に 北鎌倉に 着く？
column2: We'll eat close to Kita Kamakura station.

column1: ガイドさん、今日、大仏さんは 見ない?
column2: Mr. Guide, are we going to see the Great Buddha today?

column1: はい。残念ですが、鎌倉大仏へは 行きません。でも...
column2: Right, unfortunately we will not go to the Kamakura Great Buddha. But...

column1: ええ？大仏さんに行かない。
column2: Wha--t?? We're not going to the Great Buddha.

column1: はい。でも、明日、皆さんは 自由時間が たくさん ありますので…
column2: Right, but tomorrow, you will have a lot of free time, so...
(dryly) Oh, really. We have free time?

column1: はい。朝九時から 午後三時十五分まで 自由時間です。
column2: Yes. You'll have free time from nine in the morning to three fifteen p.m. So...you have around six hours. It's about a fifteen minute walk from your hotel to the Great Buddha, so...

column1: ですから...六時間位あります。
column2: How about Hasedera? Are we going to Hasedera today?

column1: 皆さんのホテルから 大仏まで 歩きで大体１５分ですので…
column2: No, but like I said, tomorrow you will have a lot of free time...

column1: じゃあ、長谷寺は？今日、長谷寺に行く？
column2: What? We're not going to Hasedera?

column1: See you then!, Have a nice day!, Have fun!, Go and come back! (literal)
皆さん、おはようございます。今から、自由時間です。
column2: Good morning everyone. You’ll have free time starting now. We’ll leave the hotel at three thirty, so please be at the hotel lobby at three fifteen. Well then, be careful. I'll see you all later.

column1: 三時半に ホテルを 出発しますから、3時15分に ロビーに 集まってください。
column2: Umm, Mr. Guide. Please show me how to read a map.

column1: では、気をつけて。いってらっしゃい！
column2: Right, right. This is the hotel. So, then we have...

column1: あのぉ、ガイドさん。地図の見方を 教えてください。
あ、はいはい。ホテルは これですね。それで...
column2: Ah, there are taxis in front of the station. It's a two minute walk to the station.

column1: ちょっと、タクシー、呼んで。
column2: Mr. Guide, please show me how to use a digital camera.

column1: あ、タクシーは 駅の前に います。
column2: Ah, please wait a moment. I'll be with you presently.

column1: to ride, to take, to get on; V1
おばあちゃん、どう？のる？10分、二千円!
column2: What do you say, Grandma? 2,000 yen for ten minutes!

column1: 何ですか。リヤカーですか。
知らないの？リヤカーじゃないよ。人力車だよ。速くて気持ちいいよ。
column2: Don't you know? It's not a cart, it's a rickshaw. It's fast and comfortable.

column1: 面白そう...。おじいさん、乗りませんか。
column2: Sounds interesting...why don't we ride, dear?

column1: 全然、危なくない。安全だよ。
column2: It's not dangerous at all. It's safe. Plus, 2,000 yen for ten minutes is not expensive.

column1: それに、10分 二千円は 高くない。
column2: That's right. It's not expensive. You don't want to Dear?

column1: そうですよ。高くありませんよ。ねぇ、おじいさん、だめですか。
column2: It's not that I don't want to...well, okay. Young man, take us to the Kamakura Great Buddha, slowly please.

column1: to be raised, to grow up ; V1
to wake up, to get up; V2
to arrive at, to reach; V1
おじいさん、おじいさん。ホテルに 着きましたよ。起きてください。
column2: Dear, dear, we’ve arrived at the hotel. Wake up.

column1: ん？もう着いた？そうか...。よく 寝た。
column2: Hm? We're here already? I see...that was a good nap.

column1: ああ、疲れた、疲れた。ああ、ガイドさん。
column2: Ah, I'm beat, I'm beat. Oh, hello Mr. Guide.

column1: あ、中川様。お帰りなさい。
ふう…。今日は よく 歩きましたよ。
column2: Pheew. I walked a lot today.

column1: そうですか。鎌倉は 初めてですか。
column2: Really? Is this your first time in Kamakura?

column1: はい。私達は、日系ブラジル人です。
column2: Yes, we're Japanese-Brazilians. We were born and raised in Brazil. Actually, this is our first time in Japan. Our granddaughter lives in Japan, so we‘re here to visit her.

column1: to ride, to take, to get on; V1
皆さん、出発時間です。バスに乗ってください。
column2: Everyone, it's time to leave. Please get on the bus. Please don't forget your personal belongings.

column1: 忘れ物をしないでくださいね。
column2: Oomph! Oomph! (sound of carrying heavy things)
Ah, welcome back Mrs. Ueda. You bought a lot of souvenirs, I see.

column1: あ、上田さん、お帰りなさい。
column2: Yeah, I was shopping the whole time. I asked you many questions yesterday, but I didn't do any sightseeing. I didn't have time.

column1: たくさん お土産を 買いましたね。
column2: Oh, you didn't have time? That's a shame. How about the Great Kamakura Buddha?

column1: 昨日、たくさん 質問したけど、観光しなかった。時間がなかった。
ええ？時間が ありませんでしたか？申し訳ありません。鎌倉大仏は？

column2: Ah...so what did you eat for lunch?

column1: おじいちゃん、おばあちゃん、お帰り。
ただいま、マルシアちゃん。
column2: How was your trip to Kamakura?

column1: 鎌倉旅行は どうだった？
column2: We had quite a good time, right dear?

column1: なかなか 楽しかったですよ。ねぇ、おじいさん。
column2: Yes, the rickshaw was fun. I want to ride again.

column1: ああ。人力車は 楽しかったね。また 乗りたいね。
column2: Was everything all right? It wasn't too cold?

column1: 大丈夫だった？寒くなかった？
column2: It was cold, but it was quite comfortable.

column1: 寒かったけど、なかなか 気持ちよかった。
column2: But, most of the tourists were senior citizens.

column1: でも、ツアーのお客さんは 年寄りが 多かったですね。
column2: Right right, I wanted to talk to younger people.

column1: そうそう。もっと若い人と 話したかった。
column2: Oh, right. Marcia, tomorrow, take us to a club in Roppongi, will you?

column1: あ、下山先輩！お帰りなさーい。
column2: Ah, Shimoyama, welcome back! Since you haven't been here, I was lonely every day. Was the Kamakura tour tough?

column1: 先輩がいなかったから、絵理花、毎日　寂しかったですぅ。
column2: It wasn't tough. It was all right, I guess.

column1: 鎌倉ツアーは大変でしたか。
column2: That's good. Hey, do you know when my birthday is? It's to-mo-rrow! So let's go on a date tomorrow.

column1: 大変じゃなかったよ。まぁ、普通だった。
column2: Tomorrow, birthday? All right, let's have a party with everyone!

column1: ねぇ、先輩、私の誕生日を知っています？あ・し・た・ですよ。
column2: Everyone, tomorrow is Miss Hidari's birthday. Let's throw her a birthday party!

column1: だから...明日デートしましょう。
formal form of the verb which means 'to have' or 'to be'
結婚式用のドレスはあります？
column2: Do you have dresses for a wedding ceremony?

column1: 結婚式用のドレスですかぁ？
column2: Dresses for a wedding ceremony? Of course we do. Please follow me. What do you think about this dress? It just came in yesterday from Paris.

column1: はい、もちろん ございます。こちらへどうぞ。
column2: Wow, it's beautiful! May I try it on? (changes into it) Oh no, this dress is too small for me. Do you have anything bigger?

column1: ...このドレスはいかがですか。
column2: Oh no, is it too small? Sorry about that. Please wait a moment. OK, how about this one?

column1: 昨日、ちょうどパリから入ってきました。
column2: Thank you. (changes into it) This dress is perfect.
Wow! You look fabulous! Mucho Fabuloso! It looks great on you. It's very elegant and luxurious! (to Raizō) Right? Sir?

column1: 試着してもいいですか。
column2: You look too young. A kimono would be better than a dress.

column1: to appear, to leave, to exit; V2
ねぇ、あなた。あなたのくつも 買いましょうか。
column2: Why don’t we get a new pair of shoes for you too, honey? A new pair of shoes for the wedding.
How about these shoes? They’re light and easy to put on. They’re the most popular ones we have.

column1: では、このくつは いかがですか。
column2: Hmph…I’m not going to the ceremony.

column1: このくつは 軽くて、はきやすいですよ。
column2: Oh, no. And why not? That’s sad…sooo sad (starts crying)
You’re getting on my nerves. Fine, fine…I’ll get them. Those, the ones that are easy to put on. Here’s my credit card.

column1: ふん。...結婚式には 出ない。
column2: Thank you very much! Please sign here.

column1: あららららら。どうしてですか。それは 悲しい。悲しすぎます。
column2: Huh? This pen is hard to write with.
Sorry about that, sir. Use my pen. It’s a breeze to write with. Here.

column1: to clear up, to be sunny; V2
to precipitate, to fall (rain, snow, etc.); V1
とうとう、明日は 結婚式ね。
column2: Finally, tomorrow is your wedding day.

column1: うん。ねぇ、ママ。明日 雨が降ると思う？
column2: Yeah. Mom, do you think it will rain tomorrow?

column1: う～ん。ママは晴れると思う。
column2: Hmmm, I think it will be sunny tomorrow. It’s going to be fine sweetie. Remember, I’m Mrs. Sunshine and your father is Mr. Sunshine.

column1: 大丈夫。大丈夫。ママは晴れ女。
column2: But I’m Miss Rain and Haruya is Mr. Rain. …Mom, do you think dad will come to the wedding tomorrow?
I think so. I just saw him polishing his new wedding shoes.
Oh yeah? Good. Mom, what do you think of Haruya?
At first I thought he was weak and unreliable, but now I think he’s strong. I think he’s a good man. It’s alright. There’s nothing to worry about.

column1: 絵理花さんは、どうして、下山さんが好きですか。
column2: Erika, why do you like Shimoyama?
Why? Hmm, well he's handsome, he's kind, he's smart, he's tall, and because he's perfect.

column1: うーん。ハンサムだし、やさしいし、頭がいいし、背が高いし、かんぺきだから。
column2: I, I'm also a handsome and perfect guy. Not to mention my family is rich. Umm, Erika, am I not good enough for you?

column1: ぼ、僕も、ハンサムでかんぺきな男ですよ。
それに、家は金持ちです。
あ、あのぉ...。絵理花さん。ぼ、僕はだめですか？
column2: You're not my type. And you're not reliable, and you have a bad personality.

column1: ひどい・・・ひどすぎる。ひどすぎます。絵理花さん。
あ、ごめんなさい。あ、泣かないで。
column2: Ah, sorry. Um, don't cry...but I think that Shimoyama-senpai is really great. I looooove Shimoyama-senpai. He's easy to talk to, and he has a good personality. Hey, do you think Shimoyama-senpai has a girlfriend?

column1: ...でも、下山先輩は本当に素敵だと思う。
column2: I don't know (sob). Don't ask me about that (sob).

column1: 絵理花、下山先輩、だーい好き。話しやすいし、性格いいし。
column2: It's Shimoyama-senpai. See you, Mitsuru-chan. Shimoyama-senpai! Shimoyama-senpai! Let's have lunch together!

column1: ねぇ、下山先輩は彼女がいると思う？
column2: E..Erika...You're so obvious. (ruefully) That blasted Shimoyama---.

column1: mistaking one person for another, mistaken identity
to differ, to not match; V1
あのぉ、どうぞ、座ってください。
え？ああ、どうもありがとうございます。よいしょ。
column2: Huh? Oh, thank you very much. (sits) Hmm? Are you the tour guide, Mr. Shimoyama?

column1: あれ？観光ガイドの下山さん？

column2: Oh, I'm mistaken. I'm sorry. But you're the spitting image of him. Hahaha, sorry about that.
Not a problem. Are you going on a tour of Asakusa, ma'am?

column1: でも、本当にそっくり。あはは、ごめんなさい。

column2: I haven't looked it up yet.

column2: How about a ticket? Did you buy a ticket?

column2: Hi, can I make a reservation for Thursday of next week? It's for two at 7:00.
Okay, then I'd like to make a reservation. Also, can I use a coupon?

あとクーポンを使うことができますか。
column2: Okay. Also, can I request some birthday magic and also have a commemorative picture taken?
I'm sorry, but we can't take pictures. You also won't be able to cancel or change your reservation time. Is this alright?

column1: それから、誕生日マジックを頼むことと記念撮影をすることはできますか。

辛いものは食べられる？

column2: Yes. I was born in Tokyo's Adachi ward, but I've lived in a lot of countries because of my father's job. Singapore, South Africa, Russia, Portugal, Chile...

でも、今は全然話せません。（笑）
column2: I did have a twin brother, but he got sick and died when I was five.

column1: which reminds me, on that subject

column2: His face… But you were twins right?

column2: Oh yes, but my mother said that we looked nothing alike.

column2: Huh… Oh hey, that reminds me - Mikado told me, “Shimoyama is doing a part time job in Roppongi at nights. You should fire him.”
Ah yes, Mikado… By the way, Mikado and Ms. Hidari are dating, aren’t they?

column1: そういえば、三門と左さんは付き合ってますよね。
column2: Well, Ms. Hidari said that Mr. Mikado was just a friend, not her boyfriend.

やっと大人になりました。

４０２ごうしつの林です。こんばんは。
column2: It's Hayashi from Apartment 402. Good evening.

column1: こんばんは。おひさしぶりです。
column2: Good evening. Long time no see.

column1: たのしそうですね。パーティーですか。
column2: This looks like fun. Is it a party?

column1: すみませんが、しずかにおねがいします。もう、１２じですから。
column2: I'm sorry, but please keep it down. It's already twelve o'clock, you know.

column1: もしもし、４０１ごうしつのエミリー・マーティンですが、 トイレがこわれました。
column2: Hello, this is Emily Martin from Apartment 401. The toilet's broken.

column1: いいえ、水が止まりません。
水が止まりました。でも、しゅうりがひつようですね。
column2: The water's stopped. But it needs repairing.

column1: あした、しゅうりやにでんわしますね。
column2: Tomorrow I'll call the repair shop.

column1: Thank you very much., Thanks. (a greeting on closing business calls and e-mails)
column2: よろしくおねがいします

column1: You've reached Ken Wood. I'm not available to take your call, so please leave a message and I will get back to you.
column2: You've reached Ken Wood. I'm not available to take your call, so please leave a message and I will get back to you.

column1: もしもし、イノベーティブリペアの木山です。
column2: Hello, this is Kiyama from Innovative Repair.

column1: トイレのしゅうりのことで、でんわしました。
column2: I'm calling about the toilet repair.

column1: すみませんが、あとで、でんわをおねがいします。
column2: I'm sorry, but please could you call me back?

column1: でんわばんごうは、89-1234-567です。
at, in, on (a particle indicating time)
No problem, all right, don't worry, it's fine
イノベーティブリペア、木山です。
column2: This is Kiyama at Innovative Repair.

column1: Ken Woodですが、トイレのしゅうりのことで、でんわしました。
column2: This is Ken Wood. I'm calling about the toilet repair.

column1: きょう、トイレのしゅうりに行きますが、だいじょうぶですか。
column2: I was planning on coming to repair the toilet today. Is that all right?

column1: うーん。あしたがいいです。
じゃ、あした、三時に行きます。
column2: All right, I'll come tomorrow at three o'clock.

column1: ねえちゃん、日本の中で一番怖い化け物は何？
column2: Hey sis, what's the scariest monster in Japan?

column1: 垢舐めってどういう化け物？
column2: What kind of monster is an Akaname?

column1: 恐ろしい化け物だよ。お風呂が汚くなると垢舐めが出てくる。あいつは汚いものを食べるんだ。
column2: It's a scary monster. If the bath gets dirty, Akaname appears. It eats the dirty grime.

column1: いいんじゃない？掃除しなくていいから！
column2: That's good, isn't it? Because you don't have to clean then!

column1: そう思うでしょう。でも違うよ。あいつの唾には毒が入っていて、
column2: You'd think so, but it's not. There is poison in it's saliva,
and if someone takes a bath in the bath it cleaned, that person gets seriously ill.

column1: そして、私たちのお風呂は汚いね。超汚い！
column2: And our bath is dirty, isn't it? Really dirty!

column1: （お姉さんに対して）ちゃんとお風呂きれいにした？
column2: (To the sister) Did you clean the bath yet?
Yoshi is cleaning it right now.

column1: よしが？おまえがやれっていっただろう。なんでよしがやってるんだ？
column2: Yoshi is? I told you to clean it. Why is Yoshi doing it?
He said that he wanted to.

column1: よし、本当にやりたいのか？
column2: Yoshi, did you really want to clean?

column1: 怖いよ！早く掃除しないと。
column2: I'm scared! I have to hurry and clean.

column1: わかった。やりなさい。彼はいい子だな。
column2: Okay. You go ahead then. Such a good kid.

column1: 来月は冬のボーナスを貰う。
column2: I can get winter bonus next month.

column1: こっちも！来月をとても楽しみにしてる。ところで、まだ四国旅行へ行くつもり？
column2: Same here! I'm looking forward to the next month. By the way, are you still planning the trip to Shikoku?

column1: うん、そう、そう！去年会社の冬のボーナスは平均６７万５千円だった。
column2: Yes, that's right! The average of the winter bonus last year was 675,000 yen, and it will increase this year, so I have enough money.

column1: 今年はまた増えるから、お金は余裕がある。
column2: 675,000 yen!! I envy you. Our average was 65,000 yen. It will decrease this year, too, so I'm really sad.

column1: 僕があげた薔薇の木はどこ？
column2: Where's the rose bush I gave you?

column1: ひどい！！死にそう！これは僕らの愛の象徴だよ。
column2: That's terrible!! It looks like it's going to die! This is a symbol of our love. Is our love going to die, too?
In winter, flowers and love wither.

column1: 冬だから花も愛も枯れるのよ。
column2: But, in the spring they come back.

column1: じゃ、春には復活するんだね。
column2: Yeah, but maybe with someone else.

column1: 104,105,106, はい、ここです。(ベルがなる音)
おかしいな。何で出ないのかなあ？
column2: That's weird. I wonder why he isn't answering?
What time are your plans for?

column1: ちょうど８時。おかしいなあ。
column2: It's 8 on the dot. That's strange.

column1: 電気もついていないし、彼はいなさそうだ。
column2: The lights are even off, and it seems like he's not here.

column1: 彼の車もなさそう。彼はどうしたんだろう。
column2: It seems like his car's not here either. I wonder what happened to him.

column1: せっかく君の誕生日なのにね。
column2: Man, I can't believe he'd do something like that on your birthday.

column1: 来月私の結婚５０年記念日で。妻と一緒に新婚旅行と同じところへもう一度行きたいんです。
column2: Next week is my 50th anniversary. My wife and I would like to go once again to the place that we went to for our honeymoon.

column1: おめでとうございます。どちらのほうへ？出発日はいつでしょうか。
column2: Congratulations! Where is the destination? When is the departure date?

column1: グアムへ。出発日は来週の月曜日でお願いします。
column2: To Guam. The departure date is next Monday please.

column1: 少々お待ちください。申し訳ございません。その日は切符が一枚しかございません。
column2: Wait one moment, please. I'm sorry, only one ticket is available.

column1: 申し訳ございません。その日は切符が一枚もございません。
column2: I'm sorry, not even one ticket is available that day.

column1: 信じられません。また、切符が一枚しかございません。
column2: This is unbelievable. Again, only one ticket is available.

column1: 行ける日はいつですか。
column2: When would it be possible to depart?

column1: 少々お待ちください。再来週の月曜日はあいています。
column2: Wait one moment, please. The Monday after next is available.

column1: 先週末神戸へ行ってきました。
column2: I went to Kobe last weekend.

column1: そうですよ。神戸ルミナリエって聞いたことありますか。
column2: That's right. Have you heard of the Kobe Luminarie?

column1: いいな～。ええ、どうでしたか。
column2: You're so lucky. How was it?

column1: 最高でした。何よりも、夜の街の雰囲気は一番よかったです。道のライトがきらきら光っていて、おしゃれな人が多くて、
column2: It was superb. Above all, the night atmosphere in Kobe was the best. The street lights were glittering, and there were many stylishly dressed people.
It was just like a movie. It was cold at night, but there was someone to keep me warm...

column1: あの、先週末彼女と銀座へ行ってきましたが、雰囲気はちょっとちがいますね。
column2: Well, last weekend I went to Ginza with my girlfriend, but the atmosphere was somewhat different.
She was not happy. I should also take her to Kōbe, shouldn't I?

column1: あれ！誰もいなさそうだけど、ドアが開いている。
column2: That's strange! It looks like no one is home, but the door is open.

column1: わからない。調べてみよう。
column2: I don't know. Let's check it out.

column1: そうだね。じゃ、お先にどうぞ。レディファースト。
column2: You're right. Okay, after you then. Ladies first.

column1: ただ今！誰かいるの？警察を呼ぶわよ。
column2: I'm back! Is somebody there? I'm going to call the police!

column1: 誕生日おめでとうございます！！！
お誕生日おめでとうございます！
信じられない！びっくりパーティー、私のために？
column2: I can't believe it! A surprise party for me?

column1: 一生懸命秘密にしていたんだよ。
column2: I was trying as hard as I could to keep the secret.

column1: 大成功。泣きそうになった。本当にありがとう。皆さんありがとう。
column2: It was a huge success! I was about to cry. Thank you so much. Thank you everyone.
How old are you this year?

column1: わ～素敵な家。この家はピカピカね。この床は鏡みたい！どうやって掃除するの？
column2: Wow, what a nice looking place you have. This place is spotless! This floor is like a mirror. How do you clean it?

column1: えっ、そう？気づかなかったわ。
column2: Oh, is that right? I didn't notice.

column1: 気づかなかったってどういうこと？
column2: Didn't notice? What do you mean?

column1: 掃除しない？じゃあ誰が掃除するの？
column2: Don't clean? Then, who does the cleaning?

column1: 只今。金田さん、こちらは私の主人です。
column2: I'm home. Mrs. Kaneda, this is my husband.

column1: 初めまして。金田です。宜しくお願いします。
column2: How do you do? I'm Kaneda. It's nice to meet you.

column1: こちらこそ。宜しくお願いします。
column2: Same here. Nice to meet you.

column1: はい、はい、わかりました。いまケーキを焼いているところだから後でその手作りケーキも持っていきます。でもとりあえず、コーヒを持っていきますね。
column2: Yep, understood. I'm baking a cake right now, so I'll bring you some homemade cake later. But, first things first - I'll get the coffee.

column1: どうして？いいの？今のは？
column2: What was that all about? Is that alright? What happened just now?

column1: いいのよ。旦那は専業主夫で、なんでも真剣にやるタイプだから。
column2: It's fine. My husband is a full-time house-husband, and he's the type that takes everything seriously.
That's so nice. I'm so jealous!
Did you hear? Did you hear?

column1: 山田さんが年末宝くじ当たったらしい！
column2: It seems Yamada won the year-end lottery!

column1: 君たち二人は幸せだよね。ええ。。。どうしたの？すごい顔してるけど。
column2: You two must be happy, right. Umm... what's up? That's some face...

column1: 彼女は運が悪くて、貧乏で将来性がないと思って、もうお婆さんだし。服の趣味も悪いし。
column2: I was thinking... she's unlucky, she's poor and has no future. She's already old, has no fashion sense, and...

column1: まあ、とにかく、昨日彼女と別れたんだ。しまったな。
column2: Well, anyways, we separated yesterday. I messed up.

column1: 彼女は自分の誕生日と君の誕生日を使ったらしい。もしかしたら。。。やり直せる可能性があるかもしれない。電話してみたら。。。
column2: I heard she played her birthday and your birthday. Maybe... just maybe there's a chance you can fix things up. What if you gave her a call...

column1: ああ、それはいいアイディアだ。さっそく電話してみよう。
column2: Ah, now that's a good idea! I'll call her right away! Oh, hey! It's Take!

column1: はい、西川たけですが。のりこさんはいますか。
column2: Yes, this is Take Nishikawa. Is Noriko there?

column1: またか。のりこさんはいません。
この電話番号は０６０−３３２１−３４１２ですよね。
column2: This phone number is 060-3321-3412, isn't it?

column1: や、僕、のりこさんの前の彼氏なんですが。
でも、私はのりこさんを知りません。昨日この電話を買ったばっかりです。
column2: But I don't know Noriko. I just bought this phone yesterday.

column1: とても後悔しています。今日ずっと鳴っています。本当に鳴りっぱなし！のりこさんってどういう人ですか。芸能人ですか。有名な人でしょうか。
column2: I'm really regretting it. It's been ringing all day. Ringing non-stop. Who is Noriko? Is she some famous TV talent? Maybe a celebrity?

column1: やあ、ちょっとわからないです。いや、では、どうもありがとうございます。
column2: Hmm, I'm not quite sure. Hmm, okay then. Thank you.

column1: いいえ、どういたしまして。
as ever, as usual, the same
ああ、佐々木さんから葉書が来た。
column2: Oh, I got a postcard from Ms. Sasaki.

column1: いよいよ本格的な寒さになってまいりました。お元気でお過ごしでしょうか。

column2: At long last, the formidable grasp of winter's coldness has fully taken hold of us. I do hope that you are spending your days well. It will have been two months since you departed Japan on business, Mr. Ishihara - how has work been since then? Here in Saitama, I am passing the days as I always have. I am certain you must be busy, but if time allows, please do write back.

column1: as a matter of fact, actually
佐々木さん、ご無沙汰していました。お手紙ありがとうございました。
column2: Ms. Sasaki, I must apologize for my long silence. Thank you very much for your letter. When I read your letter, I recalled nostalgically the time that we spent together. Actually, I am often reminded of you recently. That is because I will be getting married next month. When you reach this age, well...I don't  want to be alone.
I was thinking that I would contact you - apologies for my tardiness.
I will send more details later.

column1: 春とは名ばかりでまだ厳しい寒さが続いています。しかし、石原さんの良いお知らせを読んだら、心があたたかくなりました。

column2: It seems that spring is just a word as the harsh winter continues on. However, I was warmed upon reading your good news. Congratulations on your engagement. Mr. Ishihara, you are a kind and splendid person, and I know you will have a wonderful married life. I am envious of your wife-to-be.
Well, if the truth must be told, it seems as if I will become busy, so I think that I will not be able to send you another letter. This postcard will probably be the last.
She said she's getting married! Just like that! I didn't think it would happen like this. I have to stop her.

column1: はい、HISの中谷でございます。
もしもし、すぐハワイへいきたいんですが。
はい、かしこまりました。いつがよろしいでしょうか。
column2: Hello, I'd like to go to Hawaii at once.
Yes, certainly.  When would you like to leave?

column1: はい、かしこまりました。お調べいたしますので、少々お待ちください。。。

column2: Alright, please wait just a moment while I check on that. Hello, I'm very sorry, but there are no seats available for today.

column1: 明日はございませんが、明後日一番早い便に席が空いています。
column2: There are none tomorrow either, but there is one on the earliest flight the day after tomorrow.

column1: ありがとうございました。帰りの日はいつでしょうか。
column2: Thank you. When will you be returning?

column1: 来週の火曜日に席がございます。
column2: There is a seat available next Tuesday.

column1: では、明後日全日空、7時半発、ホノルル行きをおとりしておきます、
column2: Alright. You have reserved a ticket with ANA departing for Honolulu at 7:30 the day after tomorrow.  Your return date is Tuesday next week. The total is 82,500 yen.

column1: 佐々木さんの結婚式はどこですか。
チャペルのほうですが、今佐々木さんは控え室のほうにいます。
column2: It's at the chapel, but Ms. Sasaki is in the waiting room at the moment.

column1: どうぞ。お入りください。
佐々木さん、あなたは結婚してはいけません！

column2: Ms. Sasaki, you must not get married.

column1: 僕は思い当たるすべてのチャペルを探し続けて、今やっとあなたを見つけたんです。大変でした。
だから、ちゃんと理由を言ってください。
column2: I went through all the chapels in the neighborhood, and I finally found you. It wasn't easy, you know.

column1: 理由は、わたくしがあなたのことを愛しています。ずっと愛してきました。
column2: So please tell me clearly why you're here.

The reason is ... I've loved you for a long time. Really, I'm sorry for not saying anything. Like an idiot, I was always testing you. Please forgive me. I'm declaring my love for you now. Could you forgive this stupid old man?
Please tell me again you love me.

column1: もう一度愛していますと言ってください。
大きな声で愛しています！

column2: Please tell me again that you are foolish.

column1: もう一度、私は馬鹿だって言ってください。

column2: Yes, Mr. Ishihara, I accept your proposal.

column1: はい、石原さんのプロポーズを受けます。

column2: But there's only two of us.

column1: はい、私の婚約者はあなたです。

column2: It means I was also testing you.

column1: 私もあなたを試しました。

column2: Excuse me, please bring in Mr. Ishihara's tuxedo.

column1: すみません、石原さんのタキシードを持ってきてください。
column2: Mr. Ishihara, please change into this tuxedo immediately.

column1: untraceable, long lost, one's whereabouts being unknown,
study how to cope with the situation
（オフィスにて）社長、例の仕事ですが、提出日が来月とせまってきているので、そろそろ対策を練りましょう。
column2: (In the office)Boss, about the aforementioned work, next month's submission date is rapidly approaching, so we should really get started on the measures pretty soon.

column1: うーむ。どうしたものか…。
大事な取引先かと思いますので、エースの木ノ下にやらせましょう。
column2: This is an important customer, so let's ask Kinoshita.

column1: うーむ。木ノ下か。よし！木ノ下を呼んでくれ。

column2: Kinoshita won't be in until next month. It seems as if he's succumbed to maternity neurosis. I made him go to China, but he's missing now.

column1: なにー！中国だあ！？この忙しい時期に奴は何をやってるんだ。上海支局の李につないでくれ。木ノ下を探すんだ。
column2: What! China! What the heck is he doing at a such a busy time! Get me Mr. Lee at the branch office in Shanghai. Start looking for Kinoshita.

column1: even, if only, if just, as long as
whim, wanderlust, fickle, moody, uneven temper
社長、木ノ下がまだ中国にいるかどうかはわかりません。
column2: Boss, I'm not sure if Kinoshita is still in China.

column1: さっき中国にいると言ったじゃないか。
column2: Just a second ago you said he was in China, didn't you?

column1: 実は、木ノ下には放浪癖があるんです。アジアの国にいるかどうかすら、我々にははっきりとわからないのです。彼が行くと言った場所に本当に行くかどうかは誰にもわかりません。気まぐれな男なんです。
column2: To tell the truth, Kinoshita has habit of wandering about.  We don't know for sure if he's even in an Asia country.  Nobody knows if he is actually where he said he'd go. He's an unpredictable guy.

column1: 確か・・・木ノ下は大のチベット仏教好きだったな。よし！チベット支局のテンバにつないでくれ。木ノ下の行方を追うんだ。
column2: This work can't be done by anyone else but him. We have to find him, no matter what it takes.  If I remember right, he's a lover of Tibetan Buddhism.  I've got it!  Call Temba at the Tibetan branch.  Let's track down Kinoshita's whereabouts.

column1: 石原さんは、佐々木さんを妻として、健やかなる時も病める時も、いたわり、尽くし、生涯を共にすることを誓いますか？
column2: Do you, Mr. Ishihara, promise to care for, devote yourself to and live together with Ms. Sasaki as your wife in sickness and in health?

column1: 佐々木さんは、石原さんを夫とし、健やかなる時も病める時も、いたわり、尽くし、生涯を共にすることを誓いますか？
column2: Do you, Ms. Sasaki, swear that you will care for, devote yourself to and live together with Mr. Ishihara as your husband in sickness & in health?
Good. The bride and groom have made their marriage vows in the presence of God and the congregation.  I pronounce this man and this woman to be husband and wife.  So please exchange your rings.

column1: koban (former Japanese oval gold coin), oval
お母さん、今日、学校で、ことわざを習ったよ。
column2: Mom, we learned a proverb today at school

column1: え～と、「ネコに小判」と「ブタに真珠」だよ。
column2: Hmm, give money to the cat and cast pearls before swine.

column1: どっちもほとんど同じ意味なんだって。ネコに小判をあげても、ブタに真珠をあげても、ありがたいと思わないでしょ。だから、どんなに価値があるものでも、その価値がわからない人には何の価値もないっていう意味なんだって。
column2: The both mean almost the same thing. Whether you give money to a cat or cast pearls before swine, they probably won't appreciate it, right? Therefore, no matter the value of something, it is worthless if the person receiving it doesn’t know its value.

column1: そうね。今のタクミに、2万円もする高価なバットを買ってあげても、ブタに真珠っていうことね。
column2: I see. So buying you an expensive, 20,000 yen baseball bat now is like casting pearls before my little piggy. (oink)

column1: えっ！そんなことないよ！
column2: Huh! No, that's not so! No way!

column1: to rouse, to swell, to rise
brush tip, first on a list
昨日の同窓会は、結構盛り上がったな。ちょっと、はりきりすぎたよ。
column2: Yesterday's class reunion was pretty fun, wasn't it? I think I got a little worked up.

column1: いやあ〜、昨日は飲みすぎて、まだ気分が悪いよ。二日酔いってやつ。
column2: Yeah. I drank too much last night. I still feel sick with a hang over.

column1: 本当に久しぶりだったよな。
column2: It really had been a long time since we all last met.

column1: 15年振りくらいじゃないかしら。
みんな変わったよなあ。クラスのマドンナだったナオミちゃんなんて、最初見た時、ナオミちゃんかどうか、わからなかったもん。昔はスリムだったのに、太りすぎ。女って変わるよなあ…。
column2: Everyone had changed so much. At first glance, I didn't even recognize Naomi, who was the Madonna of the class. She was so skinny before and now she's too fat. Women can change so much...

column1: でも、一番の驚きは木ノ下だったでしょ。最初入って来た時、この美男子は一体誰だ？って・・・まさか木ノ下とは思いもしなかった。
column2: But the biggest change was Kinoshita. When he first came into the room, I thought, Who is this handsome guy? It never occurred to me that it could be Kinoshita.

column1: 高校の時は、いつも髪ボサボサで、服はよれよれで、（分厚い本しか読んでなくて）オタク系の筆頭だったのにな。いったい、奴には何があったんだろう。
column2: In high school, he always had messy hair, worn out clothes and was the leader of the geeks. What on Earth happened to him?

column1: 木ノ下に電話してみようぜ。

column2: Sure. We couldn't talk to him much yesterday.

column1: もしもし、木ノ下ですが。やあイワオくん。どうしたの？
おう木ノ下。いやあ、昨日は懐かしかったな。それにしても、木ノ下の変わりようには度肝を抜かれたよ（面食らったよ）。一体どうしてたんだよ。その辺、話してくれよ。
column2: Hello, this is Kinoshita. Hey, Iwao. How are you?

column1: ははは。確かに、高校の時の自分とは全然違ってうつるみたいだね。実はあれからすぐ、世界一周の旅に出たんだ。途中、南米のペルーにある、世界遺産のマチュピチュ遺跡で、不思議な女性に出会ったんだ。なんと、あのロックフェラー財団の幹部だった人で、その人から、ありとあらゆることを徹底的に教え込まれたわけなんだ。
column2: Hey, Kinoshita. Wow, it was really a blast from the past, yesterday, wasn't it? We were also really surprised at how much you'd changed over the years. What on earth happened to you? Tell us about that.

column1: えっ、何があったんだよ！
column2: Yeah. I guess I have changed a lot since high school. Actually right after graduation, I took a trip around the world. I stopped by Machu Pichu, the World Heritage Site in Peru, and met a mysterious woman. She was a senior official at the Rockefeller Foundation and she taught me a lot of things.

column1: 電話では長くなりそうだから、続きはまた今度会った時に話すよ。
おいおい。気になって眠れないよ。じゃあ、時間がある時に連絡しろよ！
column2: It's kind of a long story. So I'll tell you the rest when we meet.
Hey, now you've got me so curious I can't sleep! Well, call me when you have time!

column1: to extract, to omit, to unplug, to draw out; V1
to tie something to something else
ここにあったはずの天ぷら、誰が食べたの〜？夕飯のうどんに載せるはずだったのに〜。
column2: The tempura should have been here. Who ate it? It's supposed to be put in the udon for dinner.

column1: 僕じゃないよ。今帰ってきたばっかりだもん。
column2: I didn't do it!  I just got back home now.

column1: 僕でもないよ。ずっとあっちでプレステやってたもん。
column2: I didn't do it! I've been on the Playstation over there all day.

column1: かぼちゃのてんぷらでしょう。僕、かぼちゃ嫌いだもん。食べるはずないよ〜。
column2: It's pumpkin tempura, right?  I hate pumpkin.  I wouldn't have eaten it!

column1: 正直に言わないと、あんた達、夕飯抜きよ！
column2: There were both pumpkin and squid tempura.  Be honest and tell the truth!  If you don't tell the truth, you guys will go without dinner.

column1: （一斉に）僕たちじゃないよー！

column2: Isn't it dad?  Because pumpkin and squid are supposed to be his favorite!

column1: あの野郎〜！！お父さんはどこなの？隠れても無駄よ。家のどこかにいるはずよ。連れてきなさい！みんなで、縛りつけて尋問するわよ！
今日って少し寒くない？
もう5月なのに寒いよね。今年って異常気象って話だよ。
column2: Yeah. It's already May but it's still cold. I hear we've got abnormal weather patterns this year.

column1: さっきまで、雨空だったのに、雨が止んで、陽が出て来て、むしむしするよー。
column2: Huh, cold? It was cold until just a little bit ago, but it's kind of muggy now. It was rainy and it stopped raining and now the sun came out, and it's humid.

column1: 確かに、蒸し暑くなってきたね。もう梅雨入りかなあ。今年は桜も早かったしね。
