column2: You're right. It's getting muggy. Is it already rainy season? The cherry blossoms bloomed early this year too.

column1: あっ、また陽が陰ってきた。なんだか今日は、イギリスの天気みたいだなあ。
column2: Look. It's getting cloudy again! This is a little bit like English weather.

column1: 晴れても、曇りになったり、雨が降ったり。寒くなったり、暑くなったり。
column2: In England, they say they have four seasons in 1 day.  Even if it's clear right now, it'll get overcast, it’ll rain, it’ll get cold, and it will get hot.

column1: それだけ、変わりやすいってことなんだね。
column2: That means the weather is very changeable, right.

column1: スーパーに買い物に行ってきてくれる？このマイバッグを持って行ってよね。レジ袋はもらわないで、このカードにスタンプを押してもらってきてよ。
column2: Can you go to the supermarket for me? Bring this bag, too. We can get a stamp on this card if we bring our own bags instead of using the store's plastic bags.

column1: はいはい。ところで、このスタンプを集めると何かいいことあるの？
column2: Sure. By the way, what happens if we collect these stamps?

column1: 20個たまったら、100円割引してくれるのよ。
column2: When we get 20 stamps, we get a 100 yen discount.

column1: ということは、1枚5円っていうことか。でも、レジ袋を削減したところで、それほど環境にいい影響があるとは思えないなぁ～。
column2: So in that case, each stamp is worth 5 yen. But I don't think we're going to have much positive impact on the environment just by reducing those plastic grocery bags.

column1: そんなことないわよ。そういう小さいことをしたところで無駄だと思うことが良くないのよ！
column2: It's not good to think that a little effort is useless!

column1: address (of a house, office, building, etc.)
ねえ。お腹すいたから、ピザでも食べない。
column2: Hey, I'm hungry. Why don't we eat a pizza?

column1: うん、いいねえ。デリバリーで、ピザ頼もうか。
column2: Yeah, that sounds good. Let's get it delivered?

column1: お電話ありがとうございます。ダイナマイト・ピザです。お電話番号からお願いします。
column2: Thank you for calling Dynamite Pizza. May I have your phone number please?

column1: あのー、初めてなんですが。
column2: Umm.. This is my first time.

column1: それでは、最初に電話番号と住所とお名前を登録させてください。
column2: In that case, let's start by registering your name, number and address.

column1: はい。電話番号は03-3456-7890で、住所は港区赤坂3-4-1です。名前はユウです。
column2: Sure. My phone number is 03-3456-7890. And my address is 3-4-1 Akasaka, Minato-ku, Tokyo. My name is Yu.

column1: ありがとうございます。登録させていただきました。
column2: Thank you very much. You're registered now.

column1: では、ご注文をお伺いします。ピザ生地とサイズをお選び下さい。
column2: Okay. I'll take your order now. Please choose the pizza crust and size.

column1: ピザ生地とサイズは、どんな種類があるんですか。
column2: What sizes and crusts do you have?

column1: 生地は、パン生地とクリスピー生地がございます。クリスピー生地は、うすい生地です。サイズは、MとLの2種類です。Mは約25cmで、Lは約31cmです。
column2: We have soft crusts and crispy crust. The crispy crust is very thin. The sizes are either medium or large. A medium is about 25cm and a large is about 31cm.

column1: 生地はパン生地で、サイズはLでお願いします。
column2: I'll have a large pizza with a bread crust.

column1: かしこまりました。それでは、ピザの種類をお選びください。
column2: OK. Please choose the type of pizza.

column1: えーっと、マリゲリータと、ペスカトーレの、ハーフ＆ハーフでお願いします。
column2: Ummm. I'd like a half-and-half, margherita and pescatore.

column1: かしこまりました。ご一緒にサイドメニューはいかがですか。
column2: OK. Would you like a side dish with your order?

column1: コーラを三つお願いします。
ありがとうございます。合計で4,000円です。45分ほどでお届けに上がります。スピードが売り物なので、45分を過ぎましたら半額にサービスさせていただきます。
column2: Thank you very much. Your total is 4000 yen. We'll deliver them to you in about 45 minutes. Speed is our sales point, so we'll give you half off if the delivery takes more than 45 minutes.

column1: ご注文ありがとうございました。
ご飯を食べながらテレビを見るのはやめなさい。
column2: Stop watching TV while you eat.

column1: えぇっ、サザエさんを見逃すなんていやだよぉ。
column2: What? I don't want to miss (the TV show) Sazae-san.

column1: じゃあ、サザエさんを見た後で、ご飯にしなさい。
column2: Then eat your dinner after you watched Sazae-san.

column1: えぇっ、お腹もペコペコだよ。昼から何も食べてないから、後30分も我慢できないよ。
column2: What? I'm starving. I can't wait another 30 minutes!

column1: ダメよ。ダメ。どっちかにしなさい！
column2: No, no. You have to choose one.

column1: えぇっ、お父さんはいつも新聞読みながら、ご飯たべてるよ。お母さんだって、いつも編み物しながら、テレビみてるじゃないかあ。
column2: What? Daddy always reads a newspaper while eating. And Mom, you watch TV while you knit.

column1: お母さんの言うことをきけないなら、今夜のカレーライスはぬきよ！
column2: If you can't obey me, you're going to miss out curry and rice.

column1: 今回もいつも通りでよろしいですか。
この写真みたいにしてください。
あのー。いつも毛先を少し切るだけじゃないですか。
column2: Ummm...You always just trim your bangs a bit, right?

column1: 僕は自分自身を変えたいんです。
失礼ですけど、何かあったんですか。
column2: Excuse me for asking, but did something happen?

column1: （小声で）恋人にフラレたとか・・・。
column2: Were you dumped by your girlfriend, or something like that?

column1: 彼女は僕のことを軟弱だ、なんて言ったんです。「あなたの女々しいところがもう耐えられない」なんて捨てゼリフを残して、僕を捨てたんだ。だから、だから僕は・・・（涙がこみ上げてくる）。
column2: She said that I'm weak. Then she dumped me, and before leaving me she said this, I can't stand your effemimate features any longer!

column1: わかりました。きっちり、男らしいモヒカン・ヘアーにさせていただきます。キーワードは「パンク」でいきます！彼女を見返してやりましょう。
column2: I see. Let me fix you up with really manly Mohawk. We're going punk style, baby!

column1: すみません。このユースホステルへの行き方を教えてもらいたいのですが。
column2: Excuse me. Can you please tell me how to get to this Youth Hostel.

column1: う〜ん、どれどれ。う〜ん・・・う〜ん。
column2: Okay...go straight here, then turn right at the 4th traffic light. The 4th traffic light.

column1: えーっと、ここを真っすぐ行ってですねー、四番目の信号を右に曲がってください。四番目ですよ。
column2: Then, you can see it on the left hand side..
What!! I've been looking around for an hour!! Can I really get there that easy??

column1: そうすると、左手に見えますので。
column2: On the left hand side, you can see another police station. Go ask there.

column1: なんだ。一時間ず〜っと迷ってたのに、そんな簡単に行けるんですか。
column2: Hey come on! What was that!.

column1: to try one's best, to hang in there;V1
明日は運動会だ。みんな頑張るように。
column2: Tomorrow is Sports Day. Everyone be sure you try hard!

column1: 先生、うちのクラスは何組ですか。
column2: Teacher, what color team are we going to be?

column1: うちのクラスは赤組だ。みんな、白のハチマキを巻いたらダメだぞー。
column2: Our class is on the red team. Everyone, make sure you don't wear a white headband!

column1: アリサ、運動会はどうだった。
赤組は優勝したけど、私は徒競走で2位だったの。
column2: Red won it all, but I came in second place in the running race.

column1: 優勝かあ。すごいじゃん。
column2: You guys won it all! That's great!

column1: でも、一生懸命走ったのに徒競走で負けちゃったから、喜び半分って感じだわ。
column2: Yeah but I lost the race, even though I ran as hard as I could. So for me this victory is only half as sweet.

column1: ねえねえ、マミの彼氏どうだった。会ったんでしょう。
column2: Hey, hey, how about Mami's boyfriend? You met him, right?

column1: そうねえ。優しそうな感じだったかな。
column2: Yeah. I guess he seemed kind of nice.

column1: 優しそうな感じって、どういうこと。
column2: He seemed kind of nice? What do you mean by that?

column1: 包容力がありそうな感じ。
包容力があるって・・・どんな感じなの。
すぐ怒ったりしなそうな感じ。
column2: It seems like he doesn't get angry very easily.

column1: へー。柔和で、笑顔が素敵そうなイメージだわ。
column2: Wow...I can picture a handsome smiling face and mild mannered temperament.

column1: special move, usually one unique to a certain fighter or fighting style
boss character in a video game
ねえ。コントローラーの使い方を教えてよ。
column2: Hey, show me how to use the controller.

column1: OK。簡単だよ。まず、Aボタンを押してみて。
column2: OK. It's really easy. First, press the A button.

column1: 最後に、A＋Bを一緒に押してみて。
column2: And lastly, push the A and B button together.

column1: おっ、なんかすごい技がでたっ！
column2: Wow. I just did something really cool!

column1: 必殺技だからね。この必殺技は１ステージで2回しか使えないから、強いボスキャラの時に使った方がいいよ。
column2: That's a special trick. You can only use the special one twice in a level, so you'd better leave it for the strong boss character.

column1: to be in a book shelf

column2: I'd like to check out this book. (presents his/her ID card.)

column1: 現在、7冊お借りになってますね。学部生の方は、7冊までしか貸し出しできないんです。
column2: You currently have seven books on loan from this library. You can only check out up to seven at a time.

column1: スタッフ:湘南の図書館にあるようですが、お取り寄せしますか。
column2: Wait. We may have the same book in Nakano Ward. Let me look it up. Can you wait a while?

column1: 問題なければ、明日の夕方くらいには届くと思います。
column2: We have that book at our Shōnan branch. Do you want me to bring it here?

column1: わかりました。ありがとうございます。
昨日、久しぶりに実家に電話したんだけど、母さん、俺のこと最初誰だかわからなくてさあ。
column2: I called home last night for the first time in a while, and my mother didn't recognize my voice at first.

column1: あんた、声変わりでもしたんじゃないの。
column2: Maybe your voice changed or something?

column1: ユウジ今、風邪ひいてるから、風邪声だっただけよ。
column2: You have a cold right now, so you sounded stuffy.

column1: そうかなあ。年をとると、忘れっぽくなるって言うから、俺の声も忘れちゃったのかと思った。
column2: You think? They say that people get forgetful as they age. So I thought maybe my mother forgot my voice.

column1: 何言ってんの。あんたの声は普段から子供っぽいっていうか、子供みたいに高いじゃない。でも今はガラガラ声だから誰でも間違うわよ。
column2: What are you talking about? Your voice is always high-pitched and child-like. But now you sound coarse. So obviously people are not going to recognize you.

column1: （情けない声で）お母ちゃん、俺のこと忘れたりしないよね。
column2: (in a pitiful voice) Mom, you wouldn't forget me, would you?

column1: あたり前じゃない。あんたはいつも女々しいわね。このマザコンが！！
column2: Of course not! You're always such a sissy! You momma's boy!

column1: human emotions (joy, anger, pathos, and humor)
(a round of) calls at the homes of one's pupils
こういう言い方はよくないですが、あの子は子供のくせに妙にさめている感じがするんです。
column2: I don't mean to sound rude, but I feel like that student is a bit jaded despite being a child.

column1: 休憩時間でも、お友達の輪に入らないですし感情表現というか、喜怒哀楽を全然おもてに出さないんです。
column2: Even during breaks, he won't join his friends and he doesn't express any emotion. Rather, he doesn't show his joys, anger, sorrows or happniness.

column1: でも、いろいろな子供がいるでしょう。あなたも新人の先生じゃあるまいし、いままでの経験があるでしょう。
column2: But there are different kinds of children. You're not a new teacher. You have plenty of experience to learn from, don't you?

column1: 授業中も答えがわかっているくせに、当てても何も言いません。そのくせに、テストの点数はいつもクラスで一番です。心を開かせようと、色々努力しているんですが・・・一向に。
column2: During class, he won't say anything even though he knows the answer. And yet he gets the highest test scores in his class. I am really trying hard to make him open up his heart...But there is no change.

column1: そうですか。来月から家庭訪問が始まるので、その辺りを親御さんに婉曲に聞いてみてください。それからまた話しましょう。
column2: Is that so. Well, next month, the teachers will start visiting students' homes to talk to parents. So try and ask the student's parents about this. Let's talk again after that.

column1: 昨日の深夜、あなたが寝た後で、突然帰ってきてまだずーっと上で寝てるのよ。
column2: Late last night, after you went to bed, he came home suddenly and he's still upstairs sleeping.

column1: よっぽど疲れているんでしょう。飛行機ではあまり眠れないって言っていたからな。
column2: He must be really tired. He said he couldn't sleep well on the plane.

column1: それにしても、もう夜の８時よ。
column2: Even then, it's already 8 o'clock at night.

column1: 腹が減れば、下に降りてくるだろう。そんなに心配しなくても大丈夫だって。
column2: He'll come downstairs if he's hungry. You don't have to worry that much.

column1: あの子がロンドンで就職してからもう２年になるわ。その間に連絡してきたのは数回だけ。
column2: It's only been two years since he started working in London. And he's only contacted us a few times since then.

column1: よっぽど忙しいんだろう。便りのないのは元気な印っていうし。後で、下に降りてきたら、仕事の事とか聞いてみたらいいだろう。それより、アイツ結婚はどうなんだ。
column2: He must be really busy. You know what they say no news is good news. Later when he comes downstairs, ask him about his work. But more importantly, is he going to get married anytime soon?

column1: おはようございます。これから販売促進第１課の朝会を始めます。では、まず、課長から連絡事項をお願いします。
column2: Good morning. Let's get started on the first sales promotion morning meeting. Alright, first, we'll hear from the section chief.

column1: おはようございます。実は人事異動で、明日、業務課からうちの課に異動してくる人がいます。明日の朝、改めて紹介しますが、今日のうちに、新しい人の机とパソコンを用意しておいてください。
column2: Good morning. The thing is, because of a staff reshuffle there are people coming from the general affairs section into our section tomorrow. Tomorrow morning I'll introduce them formally, but by the end of today, please prepare a desk and computer for the new people.

column1: どんな人が来るんですか？
column2: What kind of people are coming?

column1: それは、明日のお楽しみということで。それから、歓迎会の手配もお願いしますよ。
column2: That, we can look forward to tomorrow. Also, please make arrangements for a welcome party.

column1: それでは、机やパソコンを用意する人と、歓迎会の幹事を決めたいと思います。どなたか立候補してくれる人はいますか？
column2: Well then, we should decide who will prepare the desks and computers, and who will be the welcome party coordinator. Are there any volunteers?

column1: （立候補してもいいけど、正直言うと、どんな人が来るかに寄るんだけどな。。。）>課長、やはり、どんな人が来るか教えて頂けないでしょうか。その方が、歓迎会の店を選ぶのに都合がよいかと思います。
column2: (I could volunteer, but to tell the truth it depends on what kind of people are coming.) Section chief, you couldn’t tell us what kind of people are coming? I think that would make it easier for choosing the place (restaurant) for the welcome party.

column1: どうせ、君たちは、若い女の子がいいと思っているんだろう。やっぱり、明日のお楽しみにしよう。
column2: Well basically, you guys would like it to be a bunch of young girls, right?  So let this be something to look forward to tomorrow!

column1: そろそろ結婚式のシーズンね。
column2: It's almost wedding season, isn't it?

column1: そうだな。もう久しく結婚式なんて行ってないな。
column2: I guess so. We haven't been to a wedding in a while, have we?

column1: あなたのお友達に独身はいっぱいいるのにねぇ。全然その兆候すらないわね。
column2: Yes, despite the fact that you have many single friends. They show no signs of getting married.

column1: 独身時代が長すぎて、今さら、結婚に踏み切れないんじゃないかな。
column2: They've been bachelors for so long, that they probably can't make the jump into marriage anymore.

column1: 結婚に踏み切るって、そんなに勇気がいることなの？
column2: Do you need that much courage to make the jump into marriage?

column1: うーん、周りの既婚者たちの悲哀を見過ぎたんじゃないか。何事も知りすぎるとよくない面が目に付くからね。
column2: Well, they've probably seen too much grieving by the married people around them. Whenever you learn too much about something, you start to focus on the negatives.

column1: それって、どういうこと？周りの既婚者って、あなたのことじゃない！！
column2: What's that supposed to mean? The term married people around your friends refers to you!

column1: to keep company with, to go out with; V1
もう、聞いて聞いてよ。２週間も前にコウジに手紙を書いたのに、なかなか返事が来ないのよ。
column2: Listen, listen. I wrote to Koji two weeks ago and he hasn't written back as much as I expected.

column1: 今時、手紙を書くなんて古典的ね。今はメールよ。メール。
column2: Wow. How conservative of you to write letters in this day and age. E-mail is the way to go now.  E-mail!

column1: メールは確かに早いし便利だけど・・・なんて言うか、気持ちとかがなかなか伝わらないじゃない。
column2: I admit, e-mail is fast and convenient... But you know, you can't really express how you're feeling.

column1: あんた達、もうつきあってかなり長いじゃないの。いまさら、相手の気持ちがどうのこうのなんて・・・あんた、見かけによらずロマンチストねえ。
column2: Haven't you and Koji been dating for a long time? What do you mean; you can't express your feelings? You're a romantic, aren't you, despite appearances.

column1: 直筆を読むと、メールより気持ちが伝わってくるから嬉しいじゃない。
column2: I like it because when I read handwritten letters, I feel that more emotion comes through compared with e-mail.

column1: 確かにそうだけど。やっぱり面倒くさいわ。メールでいいわよ。
column2: You're right. But it's still a pain in the neck. I'll keep using e-mail.

column1: うるさいわねー。私はコウジの直筆じゃないと嫌なの！
column2: Oh shut up. I won't accept anything but Koji's hand-written letters!

column1: （弱々しく）おはよう。昨日、飲み過ぎたせいか、頭がガンガンする。
column2: (sounding weak) Good morning. My head is killing me, perhaps because I drank too much yesterday.

column1: あんたが二日酔いなんて、珍しいわね。
column2: It's unusual of you to be hung over.

column1: 腹が減ってる時に、食べずにガンガン飲んじゃったせいかな。
column2: Maybe it's because I drank a lot on an empty stomach.
What do you want for breakfast?

column1: 飲み過ぎたせいか、胃がむかむかする。コーヒー入れてくれない。
column2: My stomach feels nauseous, perhaps from drinking too much. Will you pour me some coffee?

column1: to be late, to be delayed
遅い。遅い。もーう。今何時だと思ってるのよ。
column2: You're late. You're late. For goodness sake...What time do you think it is?

column1: 何でトモはいつも約束の時間に遅れるのよ。時間にルーズなのは社会人として失格よ。
column2: Why are you always late to our gettogethers? Being unpunctual makes you irresponsible as an adult.

column1: だから、ごめんて。最近は心を入れ替えて、ちゃんと時間通りに来てるじゃん。今日は本当にたまたまだよ。
column2: That's why I apologized. I've been coming on time recently, because I decided to change. It was just a coincidence that I was late today.

column1: 原宿駅出たところで、コージとばったり会ったもんだからさ・・・すげー久しぶりだったから、ちょっと話こんじゃって。
column2: I bumped into Koji unexpectedly when I left Harajuku Station...It's been such a long time since I last saw him so we got caught up in our conversation.

column1: えーっ、コージって大学の時のあのコージ君！？

column2: I wanted to see him, too. So, what is he doing now?
He said he works at an advertising agency.

column1: やっぱなー。コージ君は誰かさんと違って、すごいオシャレだったもんね。
column2: That makes sense. Unlike someone, Koji is really stylish.

column1: それって、俺はどんくさかったってことかよー。
column2: Are you trying to say I was uncool?

column1: examination at the end of term
先生、古文の問題でどうしてもわからないところがあるので、夏休みに補習授業をやってもらえませんか。
column2: Teacher, there is something I just don't understand about our Classical Japanese text. Can you give us make-up lessons during summer vacation?

column1: 先生、夏休みは忙しいんだけどなあ。
古文を苦手にしている人、周りでも結構多いんです。先生の時間があるときでよいのでお願いします。
column2: There are many people around me who aren't very good at Classical Japanese. We would appreciate it if you can give us some lessons in your spare time.

column1: 古文だけでいいの。期末テストの結果、現代文もあまりよくなかったんじゃないの。
column2: Are you sure that all you need are classes in Old Japanese? You didn't get very good results in Modern Japanese finals either, did you?

column1: はい。できれば現代文もお願いしたいです。
column2: Yes. I would like Modern Japanese classes as well.

column1: 君は確か、この間まで部活動をやっていたよね。ひょっとして現役で合格するつもり。
column2: You were a member of a club until recently, weren't you? Do you plan to pass a university exam this year?

column1: はい！家の都合上、どうしても現役で合格しなきゃいけないんです。
column2: Yes! I have to pass this year, due to family circumstances.

column1: じゃあ、頑張らないとね。
column2: Then you'd better study hard, shouldn't you?

column1: あら、学くんのお母さん、お久しぶりです。
column2: Oh my, Manabu's mother. It's been a long time.

column1: あっ、徹くんのお母さん、お久しぶりです。教室の後ろに貼ってあった作文、読みました？
column2: Oh, Toru's mother. It sure has been a long time. Have you read the compositions posted on the back of the classroom?

column1: 読んだわよ。もう、うちの子、作文が下手でいやになっちゃうわ。
column2: Yes, I have. My child is so bad at writing compositions, it embarrasses me.

column1: あら、そんなことないわよ、うちの子に比べたら、全然上手よ！まったく、うちの学ときたら、4年にもなって、1年生みたいな作文しか書けないんだから！！
column2: Oh that's not true. Your son is great compared with my child. My Manabu is in fourth grade and can only write compositions like a first grader.

column1: でも、学くんの作文、面白いこと書いてあるわよ。
column2: But Manabu writes something interesting in his composition.

column1: 面白くてもだめよ。きちんとした文章を書かないと。
column2: Interesting isn't good enough. You have to be able to write good sentences.

column1: そうかしら、きちんとしてても、内容が面白くないとつまらないじゃない。
column2: Do you think so? Even if you write properly, it would be boring if the content isn't interesting.

column1: だめだめ、作文なんだから、きちんとした文章じゃないと。。
column2: No, no. Compositions must be written properly...

column1: 早紀ちゃん、岩盤浴って行ったことある？
column2: Saki, have you ever been to a bedrock bath?

column1: あるよ。すっごい汗をかいて、気持ちいいよね。
column2: I have. It feels great, doesn't it? All that sweat...

column1: 岩盤浴って、ダイエット効果があるだけじゃなくて、新陳代謝も良くなるから、健康にいいらしいよ。
column2: Bedrock baths are effective in losing weight as well as boosting your metabolism, so it's apparently good for your health.

column1: 確かに、岩盤浴に行った後はちょっと動いただけでも汗が出るよね。
column2: Now that you mention it, after I go to a bedrock bath, I sweat a lot just from moving a little bit.

column1: そういえば、岩盤浴より効果が高い溶岩浴っていうのもあるよね。
column2: There are those molten rock baths that are more effective than bedrock baths, right?

column1: あるある。でも溶岩浴って言葉、ちょっと恐い感じがあるね。溶岩って、真っ赤でどろどろしたイメージがあるから、火傷しちゃいそうな気がするわ。
column2: Yeah, but the word molten rock sounds a bit scary. Molten rock has the image of being bright red and thick, so I feel like we're going to get burnt.

column1: 早紀ちゃん、どろどろの溶けた溶岩を想像する人は、かなりめずらしいよ。
column2: Saki. it's really rare for someone to imagine a red hot lava.

column1: マチコの彼ってすごく料理が上手いんだって。スペイン料理とかフランス料理とか作ってくれるんだって。いいなー。
column2: Machiko's boyfriend is apparently really good at cooking. He makes her Spanish foods and French dishes. I envy her.

column1: スペイン料理くらい俺でも作れるよ。
column2: I could make Spanish food. That's easy.

column1: えっ、ほんとに。じゃあ作ってよ。
column2: What? Really? Then make something for me.

column1: ーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーー
出来た。これが本場のパエリア。バレンシア地方の代表料理だよ。

column2: Here we are. This is the real paella. It's one of the main dishes of Valencia.

column1: 日本で食べるパエリアはどちらかというとチャーハンみたいなんだけど、本場スペインのは、リゾットに近くて米がパラパラじゃなくて半煮えなんだよ。
じゃあ、今度食べ比べてみようよ。
column2: The paella you get here in Japan is more like fried rice. But the paella in Spain -- the original home of paella --  is closer to risotto. The rice is half-boiled and not separated.

column1: えーっ。お金出してパエリア食べるくらいなら、その金で別の料理を食べた方がいいって。こんな最高のパエリア作れるのは、東京では俺くらいしかいないもんね。
column2: Then let's compare the two types sometime soon.

column1: 皆さんこんにちは。本日のメインイベント、ピーターアーツ選手対アーネストホースト選手の一戦です。谷川さん、今日の戦いどう思いますか？
column2: Hello, everyone. This is the main even of the day: Peter Aerts vs. Ernesto Hoost. Mr. Tanigawa, what do you think of today's fight?

column1: そうですねぇ、アーネストホースト選手の廻し蹴りは正確、そして速いですからね。また、ピーターアーツ選手の突きは世界一！ですから、アーネストホースト選手はピーターアーツ選手の突きを打たれると、難しくなります。
column2: Well, Ernesto Hoost's kick is pretty accurate and fast. And Peter Aerts' punch is the world's best. So if Ernesto Hoost gets punched by Peter Aerts, it could be a difficult match.

column1: ですが、ピーターアーツ選手は今年のＭＶＰに選ばれた選手です。油断できませんねぇ。
column2: But Peter Aerts won the MVP Award this year. Ernesto should be careful.

column1: お、そろそろ試合が始まるようですよ！
column2: Oh, the match is about to begin.

column1: 会場も盛り上がってまいりました！さて、一体どっちが勝つのでしょうか！！！！！
column2: The arena is getting really excited. Which of these players are going to win?

column1: さぁ、ゴングが鳴らされました。おおぉっといきなり、ピーターアーツ選手後ろに回られて蹴りをもらった！！！
column2: The match has just begun with the sound of the gong. Wow. Peter Aerts is suddenly spun around and kicked!!

column1: アーネストホースト選手すばらしい動きですねぇ！！あのフットーワークには感心させられます。
column2: That was a fantastic move by Ernesto Hoost!! His foot work is impressive.

column1: だが、ピーターアーツ選手負けていない！！あんなすばらしい蹴りをやられましたが、今度は突きの連打だぁ！！だが、アーネストホースト選手、全ての突きを受け流す！！どうやら、ピーターアーツ選手の技は研究されたようだぁ！！
column2: But Peter Aerts isn't losing the battle yet!! He's got a painful kick but now he's punching Ernesto repeatedly!! But Ernesto Hoost barely avoids the punches!! Looks like Ernesto did his homework and studied Peter Aerts' moves!!

column1: いらっしゃいませー。今日はどんな髪型になさいますか？
column2: May I help you? What kind of hair style would you like?

column1: いやー、もう冬だからね。そんなに短くしなくても良いんだけど。だけど、もみ上げは切らないでよ！！
column2: Well, winter season is around the corner. Just I don't want get it short. And don't get my sideburns either.

column1: 分かりました。それではいつもより少し長めにしておきましょう。カラーリングはどうしますか？
column2: Definitely sir. So I'll cut it longer than usual. How about hair coloring?

column1: んー、どうしようかなぁ。
この写真の感じの明るさなんてどうでしょう？
column2: How about this brightness on this pictures?

column1: あー良いね、んじゃこれで。
シャンプーの方はどうしますか？
お客様、こんな感じでいかがですか？
ん～。。。もうちょっと後ろの方を短くしてもらえないかな。
column2: Can I get it shorter behind the ear?

column1: はい、分かりました。。。。こんな感じですかね？
うんうん、そんな感じで。
はい、それではお疲れ様でした。料金は8,000円になります。
column2: Sir, sorry you had to wait so long. The price is 8,000 yen.

column1: to turn one's head, to look over one's shoulder
to leave it to, to give over
to take someone at advantage, to catch someone unprepared
いらっしゃいませー、こんにちは。今日はどんな髪型になさいますか？
column2: Hello, may I help you? What kind of hair style would you like?

column1: んん、そうね。もうすぐ夏だし、今日は奇抜な髪型に挑戦しちゃおうかなっ！！
column2: Well, summer season is around corner, so I wanna get extraordinary style.

column1: なんていうかな。歩いてると、人が振り返ってしまいそうなやつ！んん。。そうだな。。もう、店員さんにお任せしちゃうよ！
column2: Well, I wanna get it like people turn around and look at my hairstyle on the street. OK, then it's all up to you!

column1: ほほー、人が振り返ってしまいそうなやつ。。。わたしに任せちゃっていいんですか？
column2: I see... people turn around and look at you.... and all up to me eh?

column1: 本当に良いんですね？分かりました。それでは。。。。ウりゃ！！！（後ろから不意を付いて攻撃）
column2: Are you sure? Got it. Then.....ha!!!(attacking from behind)

column1: お客さん？。。。お客さま？？。。。おきゃくさまーーー！！！起きてください、もう終わりましたよ。
column2: Sir!... hello?.... SIR!!!!!!  Wake up, everything is done.

column1: お客様、出来ましたよ！奇抜な髪型！
はっ・・・・えっ・・・・あぁ・・・・・・・・なんじゃこりゃ～！！
column2: What...?  ah.... What the heck is this?!

column1: to black out, to die away
to press down, to hold down
to fall down, to fall over, V1
to seize, to capture, to arrest
こちら、現場の山中です。昨日、こちらのコンビニに強盗が入りました。ですが、強盗は一人の青年によって見事取り押えられました。
column2: This is Yamanaka, reporting on site. Yesterday, this convenience store was robbed. But one of the robbers was caught by a young man. Oh, maybe that's the young man himself...Let's go talk to him!
Excuse me. May I ask you some questions?

column1: すいません、ちょっとよろしいですか？

column2: Are you the one that caught the robber here yesterday? Please tell us about it in detail.

column1: アナタが、昨日ここで強盗を捕まえたという方ですか？！昨日の事を詳しく教えてください！
column2: Well, I was on my way home from school. I bought a snack at the convenience store, and was about to leave when the robber came in. The robber tried to run away with the money, but he tripped. That's when I pinned him down.

column1: いやー、あれは学校から帰っているところでした。このコンビニでお菓子を買って、出るところに強盗が入ってきて。
column2: I see. That's brilliant! That's so cool! And the robber tried to get away?
Uh, not at all. He lost consciousness when he tripped.

column1: なるほど！素晴らしいですねぇ！かっこいいですねぇ！！！で、強盗は逃げようとしたんですか？
column2: Oh, ah, I see. That's it? I see. That's not so cool... Uh, sorry to take up your time  (I didn't mean to be rude). So it was a clumsy robber. That's it from the crime scene!

column1: またタバコ吸ってんの？タバコばかり吸い過ぎると病気になるよ！
column2: Are you smoking again? You can get sick from smoking too much!

column1: いやー、これだけは止められないよ。
column2: This is one habit I can't quit.

column1: タバコばっかり吸って、運動もしていないんだから、体力も落ちてくるでしょ？
column2: You smoke all the time and you don't exercise, so you're losing stamina, aren't you?

column1: んん、でも、タバコ無いと仕事に身が入らないんだよね。あれ、お前この前までタバコ吸ってたよな。
column2: But I can't concentrate on my work unless I smoke. Hey, you were smoking up until recently, weren't you?

column1: うん、だけど、この前止めたばかりなんだ。体の調子も良いし、ご飯もおいしいんだよねー。それに、タバコ代も浮くしさ。
column2: Yeah, but I just quit. I'm feeling healthier and food tastes better. And I can cut down on cigarette costs.

column1: そうか、じゃあ、俺も頑張って禁煙してみるかなぁ。
column2: Oh, then maybe I'll try hard to quit smoking, too.

column1: だけどな、タバコ代が浮いたお金でギャンブルを始めてしまったんだ。。
column2: But you know what? I started gambling with the money I saved by not buying cigarettes.

column1: えー！ギャンブルは止めた方がいいよ。実は俺、この前ギャンブルを止めたばかりなんだ。
column2: What? You better stop gambling. Actually, I just stopped gambling myself.

column1: いやーでも、面白くてさぁ！止められないよ。
column2: But it's so much fun! I can't stop!

column1: なぁ、、、俺らって似た者同士だな。
column2: Hey (did you realize?) we are really alike.

column1: (food) to deep fry in hot oil
special mixed flour for fried chicken
to brush off, to sweep away
to leave something for a while
counter for spoons, cups or glasses

column2: Today, let's make Chef Gonzaemon's famous Japanese-style fried chicken!  It is very delicious!
1) Cut the chicken legs into bite-size pieces.
3) Put the grated ginger and garlic in a bowl, and add 1 tablespoon of soy sauce and sake.  Mix them together.
4) Drench the chicken with the sauce made in step #3.  Rub it so the flavor will soak in.  Leave it for about 30 minutes.
5) Put potato starch into a plastic bag, then put the chicken in.  Coat the chicken evenly with potato starch.
6) Pour the oil into a frying pan.  Add the oil until it covers the meat.
7) When the temperature of the oil reaches 180 degrees, put it on medium heat, and fry it for about 4-5 minutes.
*You can use wheat flour if you can't find potato starch.
*If you use the frying powder, instead of potato starch, which you can purchase in supermarket, you can omit step 2 and 3 and coat the chicken with frying powder directly.
*After coating meat with potato starch, it is better to get rid of unnecessary powder by dusting it.
* Because the time required for frying depends on the size of the meat, if you are not too sure, you can cut the meat in order to check if it has been well cooked or not.

column1: Japanese sweet rice wine for cooking
to be fond of, to get close
ジェーポッド・ワンオーワンのクッキング・ワンオーワンへようこそ！
column2: Welcome to Cooking 101 brought to you by Japanesepod101.
Today, we're going to make Chef Gozaemon's popular dish called Niku Jaga (Niku means meat, and jaga is short for jagaimo which means potato)

column1: 1. まず、だしをとります。水2カップをなべに入れて沸騰させます。そこに、かつお節を一握り程度入れて、1分程度煮立たせてから、かつお節をすくい取ります。
column2: 1. First, you make the dashi. You can do this by boiling two cups of water in a pot. Add one handful of bonito flakes and boil it for about a minute, then take out the bonito flakes. (The remaining flavored water is considered dashi which is used for many Japanese dishes.)

2. Then you prepare the ingredients. Cut beef into lengths of 3 to 4 cm. Peel the potatoes, cut them into fours and let them sit in water. Cut onions into eight pieces in comb shapes. Carrots should be cut into bite-size chunks.
3. When the frying pan is heated, add cooking oil and sautee the beef. When the meat changes colors, add potatoes (make sure they're not dripping wet), then add onions and carrots.

4. Add the dashi made in step 1 into the pot and let the contents boil. Skim the scum created from boiling potatoes and other ingredients. Then add soy sauce, sake, sweet cooking rice wine, and sugar. Place a light lid direclty on the contents and boil for about 15 to 20 minutes in medium heat.
5. When the ingredients become soft, taste it and add condiments as needed. And it's done.

column1: ・だし汁は、顆粒のだしの素を使ってもいいです。ステップ4で、だし汁の代わりに水を入れて、だしの素を加えればOKです。
column2: - Dashi can be made from powdered dashi mix. In that case, you can add water instead of dashi in step 3 and add the powdered dashi mix.
- Potatoes can easily lose shape or dissolve under heat, so it would be good to cut off the edges.
- The light lid in step 4 should be a bit smaller than the diameter of the pot, and placed directly on top of the boiled ingredients. This makes it easier for the taste to soak into the ingredients.

column1: 肉じゃがは、お袋の味として多くの日本人に親しまれています！是非、挑戦してみてください。
column2: Niku jaga is loved by most Japanese as a popular Mom's dish. Please try it out.

column1: 子どもたちに本を読ませるためには、まず、親御さんが読書することが大切です。
column2: To get children to read, it's important for parents to read first.

column1: （子どものお手本になれってことね。）
column2: You mean be a good role-model, eh?

column1: 普段、好きなだけゲームで遊ばせておいて、急に「本を読みなさい」と言っても無理です。
column2: It's not going to work if you let them play games all they want everyday and suddenly tell them to read a book.

column1: （うちは、親が二人ともゲーム好きなんて、最悪だわ。）
column2: In our family, both parents like games, so this is the worst-case scenario.

column1: それから、親が読んだ本の感想を子どもに聞かせることも大切です。そういう家庭環境が、子どもに読書する気を起こさせることになるんです。
column2: And it's also important to tell your children what you thought about the book you read. That kind of family environment will motivate children to read.

column1: それでは、各ご家庭で子どもに読書習慣をつけさせるために、どのようなことをしているか、紹介していただけませんか？
column2: Now, can we have you tell us what you are doing at home to motivate your children to read?

column1: 子どもが、無理やり読書させられたと感じないように、子どもと一緒に本を選ぶようにしています。
column2: I try to select books with the children so that they don't feel that they are being forced to read.

column1: なるほど。自主的に読書することが大切ですね。
column2: I see. It's important for them to spontaneously read books.

column1: でも、子どもが選ぶ本にがっかりさせられることもあります。
column2: But sometimes I am disappointed by the books my children select.

column1: 子どもが選んだ本をそのまま読ませる方がいいですよ。
column2: It's better to let the children read what they chose.

column1: そうなんです。嬉しそうに読む姿に、やっぱり読みたい本を読むのが大切だと実感させられました。
column2: Yes. Watching how happy my children were reading, I felt that it was important for them to read whatever they want.

column1: （１．寿司屋でバイト ）おはようございます、大将！
column2: (1) Part-time job at a sushi restaurant) Good-morning boss!

column1: おう、わさびちゃん。今日もよろしく頼むよ！
column2: Hey Wasabi-chan.  It's good to have you here today as well.  Oh yeah, I made tako-wasabi the other day.  Why don't you have a try before you start your work?

column1: 私、わさび大嫌いなんですよ。。
column2: Oh, I see.  You hate wasabi.  Sorry about that.

column1: わさびが全部無くなってる。。。代わりに全部、真っ黄色いからしになってるぞ。。。
column2: All the wasabi is gone...  Instead, it's been replaced by bright yellow mustard.  How can you have mustard on sushi...
What am I supposed to do?  Drat!

column1: to throw away, to cast aside
to vanish, to disappear, to go out;V2
どうでした、大将？！お店にわさびは売っていましたか？！
column2: What happened, boss!?  Were they selling wasabi in the shops!?

column1: どうやら伊豆中のわさびが消えち（てし）まったらしい。隣のソバ屋のわさびも全部からしに変わったそうだ。。
column2: It seems like all the wasabi has disappeared from Izu.  Apparently, all the wasabi in the soba (buckwheat noodle) restaurant next door has been replaced with mustard as well.  Who did this?  I can't open the shop like this!
Boss, I'll be out for a little bit.

column1: 大将、ちょっと出かけてきます。。
column2: What?  Wasabi-chan, where are you going?
She goes to the wasabi farm.

column1: きっと、ここにもわさび泥棒が来ているはず。。。
column2: Surely, the wasabi thief should be coming here as well.

column1: まったく、なんでこんなにワサビばっかり。。。全部捨ててやる！！
column2: Really, why is there so much wasabi?  I'm going to throw them all away!!

column1: to continue, to keep on; V2
to burn one's nose especially when one eats wasabi
to take, to pick up, to get, to pass;V1
え、わさび君？！こんな所で何しているんだね？！
column2: Oh Wasabi-kun!?  What're you doing in a place like this!?

column1: いえー、ちょっと。。。校長こそ何しているんですか？
column2: Oh, um...  I just needed to do a little something... What about you?  What are you doing here?

column1: いやね、ちょっとここら辺の雑草でも取ろうと思って。。
column2: Oh, I just thought I'd remove some weeds around here.

column1: 校長、、それワサビですけど。。
え！？あ、、、、わさび君、僕はね、わさびが大嫌いなんだよ！！緑だし、ツンと来るし！からしの方が断然おいしいじゃないか！
column2: What!?  Oh.... Wasabi-kun, you see, I HATE wasabi!!  It's green, and it stings your nose!  Isn't mustard so much better!?  Needless to say, on oden and shumai and dumpling...  Think of mustard on sushi, and mustard on soba!!  Do you see my point!?

column1: 校長、それは無理があります。。
column2: Whaaaaat!?   You just don't get it, do you...?  It's pointless to keep talking to you.  But I can't let you go back alive after you seeing me now.  You know what's going to happen, don't you?

column1: ええええーーー！？まったく、分からん子だ。。。君にこんな話を続けていくのは無駄だ。
わさび君、君には死んでもらうよ！でやぁー！！！
column2: Wasabi-kun,  you will have to die!
I have no choice..   It seems that I have to....

column1: いたたた。。。。なんでそんなに君は強いんだ・・・空手か何かでもやっているのかね？
column2: Wasabi pull outs a wasabi root and bites into it.

column1: いいえ、校長。ワサビです。わさびを食べると、特別なパワーがわいてくるのです。
な、なんだって！！君が噂の「わさびくノ一」。。。。相手が悪かった。。。グフっ。。。
column2: Ooouchhhh....  Why are you so strong...?  Do you practice karate or something?

column1: to hit on, to pick up
（アメリカのカフェで。）すみません、あの、失礼ですけど、日本の方ですか。
column2: (At a cafe in the U.S) Excuse me, sorry to interrupt you, but are you from Japan?

column1: 私、今大学で日本語を専攻しているんですけど。
column2: Currently, I'm majoring in Japanese at a university.
I'd like to be able to speak Japanese.  Will you be my friend?

column1: え！？あの、私、最近忙しいので・・・。
column2: What?  Erm, kind of busy these days...

column1: お願いします。日本語ができるようになりたいんです！
column2: Please, I want to be able to speak Japanese!

column1: 日本の漫画が読めるようになりたいし、
column2: I want to be able to read Japanese manga,

column1: 日本の歌が聞き取れるようになりたいし、
column2: listen to and understand Japanese music,

column1: 日本の映画を字幕なしで見られるようになりたいし、
そうですか・・・。でも日本語もう十分お上手ですよね。
column2: I see.... But your Japanese is already adequate enough.

column1: ところでトムさんはどうしてそんなに日本語が上手なんですか。
column2: By the way, Tom. Why are you so good at Japanese?

column1: 毎日、一日一個は新しい単語を覚えるようにしています。
column2: I try to memorize a new Japanese word everyday. And I watch Japanese animations or movies when I have free time. When I watch animations and movies, I try to jot down my favorite quotes in a notebook.

column1: それから、暇なときは日本のアニメや映画を見るようにしています。
column2: Wow. You're actually very studious. (I didn't see that part of you before.)
And when I see a cute Japanese girl on the streets, I try to talk to her.

column1: へー、意外に勉強熱心なんですね。
ところで、今後連絡できるように、携帯の番号教えてもらえませんか。
column2: By the way, can I have your cell phone number so that I can call you in the future?

column1: あ、はいどうも。登録しました。じゃあ早速今かけてみますね。
column2: Oh, thank you. I've got your number registered (in my phone.) I'll try calling you right now, okay?

column1: あれ、おかしいなぁ。つながりませんけど。
column2: Hmmm. That's strange. It's not connecting. You gave me the wrong number on purpose so I can't call you, didn't you?
No, that's not it. I think my phone's acting up. Here, let me give you my email address so we can keep in touch via e-mail.

column1: じゃあ誰かお友達紹介してもらえませんか。
column2: Can you introduce me to a friend of yours?

column1: あ、いいですよ。みさっていう暇な子がいるんで、ちょうどいいと思います。
column2: Um, sure. There's a girl named Misa, who has some free time. So I think she would be perfect for you. Do you want me to call her now and invite her over?
Yeah, thanks! I'd appreciate that! What kind of girl is she? Is she cute?

column1: はい、是非お願いします！どんな子ですか。かわいいですか。
column2: (beep, beep) Oh, she's not picking up the phone. I'll tell her to call you directly later.

column1: （プープー）あれ、電話に出ませんね。じゃあ後でトムさんに直接電話をかけるように言っておきます。
pinky promise (Cross my heart and hope to die, stick a needle in my eye.)
in fact, to tell you the truth
to leak out (a secret), to be exposed
ところでじゅんこさんはどうしてアメリカに来たんですか。
column2: By the way, why did you come to America?

column1: トムクルーズに会うためです。なんちゃって。英語を勉強するためです。
column2: To meet Tom Cruise. Just kidding. I came here to study English. So why are you wearing a mask that big?
Actually, I'm a famous actor. I'm always doing this to hide my identity.

column1: ぼく、実は有名な俳優なんです。ばれないようにいつもこうしてるんです。
column2: What? Take off the mask for once, Please. Wow, you're Tom Cruise!?  Really!

column1: え？一回マスク取ってみてください！
column2: Shh. Keep it quiet. Don't tell anyone about this. Let's pinky swear to keep that secret!
Cross your heart, hope to die, stick a needle in my eye.

column1: to get on (a train), to take (a train); class 1 verb
to transfer, to change trains; class 2
この前、川越に引っ越したんだ。
column2: I moved to Kawagoe the other day.

column1: うん、川越まで行くと家賃安いし広いところを借りられるからね。
column2: Yeah, If you go to Kawagoe, you can rent a  big, cheap apartment. I'm having a house-warming party. Why don't you come?
Can I come? I've never been to Kawagoe. How do I get there? Wwhich line should I take?

column1: いいの？川越なんて行った事ないんだけど、どうやって行くの？何線だっけ？
column2: It's fast if you take the Tobu Line. At Shinjuku, take a train bound for Ikebukuro. At Ikebukuro, transfer to the train bound for Ogawa-machi. It'll take you to Kawagoe. It's confusing from the station to my house so I'm gonna send you an e-mail.

column1: 東武線を使うと早いよ。新宿で池袋行きの山手線に乗る。
column2: OK! I'll leave it to you. I'm looking forward to it!

column1: local (train that stops at every station)
すみません、この電車は小川町に行きますか？
column2: Excuse me. Does this train go to Ogawa-machi?

column1: はい、ですが各駅停車ですよ。小川町に行くなら、急行電車の方が速いですよ。
column2: Yes it does, but this is a local train. If you want to go to Ogawa-machi, an express train will be faster.

column1: 急行は川越に止まりますか？
column2: Does the express train stop at Kawagoe?

column1: そう思いますけど。あ、急行はあれですよ！
column2: I guess so. Oh, that's the express train!

column1: どうもありがとうございます！

column2: Hey, Yasumi. Where are you now?

column1: いま、池袋駅。東武東上線に乗るところ。
column2: I'm at Ikebukuro Station. I'm about to get on Tobu Tojo Line.

column1: 早く来なよ！彼女がピザを焼いたところなんだ。超うまそうだよ。
column2: Hurry up! My girlfriend just made pizza. It looks so good, dude.

column1: 「駅を出たら右に曲がって、そば屋が見えるまでまっすぐ進む。」ああ、ここか！
column2: Take a right after going out of the station, and go straight until you see a soba shop.

Take a right, and go straight. When you get to the laundromat, take a right and go down the shopping street.  Ah, I found it. This shopping street looks interesting. Ah, whatever, Hajime's house is far...what a pain in the neck.
Take a left at the shrine.
What? There are two streets...what should I do?
After taking a left at the shrine, go straight until you see the big statue of a cell phone. hmmm.

column1: 「大きな携帯のオブジェ」を探しているんですが、どっちの道に行ったらいいですかね？
「大きな携帯のオブジェ」？この道を行ってください。あっちの道は駅の方に行ってしまいますよ。
あ、そうですか、ありがとうございます。
column2: I'm looking for a big statue of a cell phone. Which way should I go?
The big statue of a cell phone? Take this way, that way leads to the station.

column1: あの道をまっすぐ行くと駅に着くんだよね。。。じゃあなんで一はこんなめんどくさい道を俺に教えたんだ？
はぁ、、はぁ、、やっとついた。。。ここに着くのに、軽く冒険をしてしまった。
column2: I finally found my way, but what an adventure that was.

column1: おお、ヤスミ！やっと来たか。なんでそんなに時間がかかったんだよ？
column2: Yo, Yasumi! You finally made it. What took you so long?

column1: お前の教えてくれた道、、かなりややこしかったぞ。。まぁ着けたけどさ。
column2: The directions you gave me... were very confusing, but I made it. Come to think of it, you said something about pizza, didn't you?

column1: そうそう俺の彼女が作ったピザだぞ。
column2: Really! I love pizza, you know.

column1: マジ！俺ピザ大好きなんだよね。
column2: If you had arrived earlier, you could have eaten it. Sorry, we ate it all.

column1: もう少し早く着いてれば、食べられたのにな。みんな食べちゃったよ。わりぃね
column2: What!?  I went all the trouble to come here... oh, never mind. At least, I know the shortcut home.

column1: to affect, to put on airs
she, baby(use this expression when hitting on girls)
すすすすすすすすいません！！！あ、あの、お一人ですか？！あ、ああ、あなたをナナナナナナナナンパしてもイイですか？
column2: Uhhhh, Excuse me. Umm...a-a-a-are you alone? Uhhh... Can I hit on you?

column1: はぁ。。。。あんなナンパじゃ、ダメよ。。。よし次はあの人に！！
column2: Ohhhh... that attempt was no good. OK! On to the next one!!

column1: おい、そこのイケメン、一人かい？もしよかったら、私と映画でも観に行かないかい？
column2: Hey you! Good looking guy over there. Are you alone?  Yo, if it's OK, why don't you go and see a movie with me.

column1: はぁ？おめ、何気取ってんだよ？そんなナンパするやつ見たことねぇよ。
column2: Who the heck you think you are?  I've never seen anyone trying to hit on me like that before!

column1: ダメだなぁ。。。あれ？もしかして、それって村上春樹の新作ですよね？
column2: Ohh, It's no use... By chance is that a new work by Murakami Haruki? How is it? Is it interesting?
Ah, yeah. This time he did a good job!

column1: あ、はい。今回の作品はとても面白いですよ！
column2: I see. I have to buy it too.

column1: へぇ、私も買わなくちゃ！
column2: Do you read books by Murakami Haruki?

column1: 村上春樹の作品、読むんですか？

column2: If you are interested, why don't we go to a cafe and talk about books by Murakami Haruki over a cup of coffee.

column1: もしよかったら、喫茶店でコーヒーを飲みながら村上春樹の作品の話でもしませんか？
Haruki Murakami, a Japanese writer and translator
When the Last Sword Is Drawn (a Japanese samurai movie)
へぇ！！そんなに村上春樹が好きなんだ。すごいねぇ。
column2: Wow! You like Murakami Haruki that much. I'm impressed.

column1: ゆうこちゃんは他に趣味はあるの？
column2: Yuuko-chan, do you have any other hobbies?

column1: そうねぇ、ダーツをしたり、お酒を飲んだり、あ、あと映画を見るのも好きかな。
column2: Well... I like playing darts, having drinks, and watching movies.

column1: ダーツはしたこと無いけど、俺も酒を飲んだり、映画を見るのが好きだよ。
column2: I've never played darts but I like drinking and movies too. Are you free on this weekend? Why don't we go and see a movie? If you'd like...
How was that movie?  When the Last Sword is Drawn.  Was it interesting for you?

column1: どうだった、この映画？『壬生義士伝』（みぶぎしでん）。面白かった？
column2: Uhhh... yeah. But historical movies are difficult, don't you think?

column1: う、、、うん、、、まぁね。でも、歴史って難しいよね。

column2: No it wasn't! It was good!! Putting that aside, what are we gonna do after this? I know a restaurant that serves good sake in Roppongi. You wanna go?

column1: いや、そんなこと無いよ！面白かった！！
great!, amazing!; highest, the best, the most
まぁ、映画はつまらなかったけど、いいデートだったのよぉ
column2: Well, the movie was boring but it was a good date.

column1: へぇ、、、、良いわね、、、、幸せそうね。。。
column2: (uninterested because her own date was bad) I see... well, that's nice, you look happy.

column1: その後に行った、たかおさんお勧めのお店も雰囲気が良くてさ、
column2: Also, the atmosphere at the restaurant that we went to after the movie was good. The food  and drinks were also good, so it was the perfect date.

column1: はいはい。。。それは良かったわね。。。
column2: So, tell me about your date? You had a date too, right?

column1: で、あなたの方はどうだったのよ？あなたもデートだったんでしょ？
column2: Yeah.... ha ha, (lying) I had a great time! We had dinner at a restaurant on the top floor of Roppongi Hills. The view was great and he was cool. It was the best date ever.

column1: うん、、、はは、すごく楽しかったよ！六本木ヒルズの最上階のレストランで二人で食事してさ。
column2: Really! I'm glad that we both had good dates!

column1: ねぇ、君。かわいいね。銀行の仕事は楽しいかい？僕、この銀行に口座を開きたいんだけど。
column2: Hey baby, are you enjoying working at the bank? I'd like to open an account at this bank.

column1: 本日、外国人登録証とご印鑑をお持ちですか。
column2: Do you have your Alien Registration Card and inkan (personal stamp) with you today?

column1: お嬢さん、確かに、僕は、ブロンドでハンサムだけど、外国人じゃないんだよ。
column2: Look here toots, I have blond hair and I AM handsome as you can see, but I'm not a foreigner.

column1: そうですか。では、こちらのカードをどうぞ。番号が呼ばれるまでお待ちください。
column2: All right then, please take this number ticket. Please be seated until your name is called.
Ticket 89, please come to the counter.
Ticket 90, please come to the counter.
Ticket 91, please come to the counter.
91? Here, here, 91! That's me. Hello. I'd like to open a bank account, please.
Would you like to open an Ordinary Savings Account?

column1: 普通預金の口座でよろしいですか。

column2: An Ordinary Savings Account is an account you can deposit or withdraw money whenever you want to.

column1: 普通預金は、いつでも、預け入れや引き出しができる口座です。
column2: Ummmmm, yes, yes, that’s the one. An Ordinary Savings Account, please.

column1: あ、そうそう、それ。普通預金の口座をお願いします。
column2: Do you have your public utility bill-payment receipt, your inkan (stamp) and your identification such as driver's license or national health insurance card with you today?

column1: 本日、運転免許証や健康保険証などの身分証明書と公共料金の領収証、それからご印鑑をお持ちですか。
column2: Of course I have them.  Here ya go.

column1: それでは、こちらの申し込み用紙にご記入ください。
column2: All right, then. Please fill out this form.

column1: はい。（カリカリカリカリ）これで大丈夫ですか。
column2: OK. (filling out the paper) Is this correct?

column1: ありがとうございます。本日、おいくらご入金なさいますか。
column2: Thank you, sir. How much would you like to deposit today?

column1: いくらでも結構です。1円でも結構です。
column2: It doesn't have to be much. Even one-yen is fine.

column1: ふーん。じゃ、2円入金します。
column2: Well... In that case, I'll put in 2 yen.

column1: かしこまりました。用意が出来ましたら、お名前をお呼びいたしますので、少々お待ちください。
column2: Thank you sir. I'll call your name when everything is ready. So please be seated.

column1: はーい。大河と呼んでください。
（コホン）こちらが、虎畑大河様の通帳でございます。キャッシュカードは1週間から10日後に、ご自宅にお送りいたします。
column2: (Hem) Here is your passbook, sir. Your cash card will be sent to your home address in a week or 10 days. And here is a small present for you.
Thanks. Oh! Here is my business card. Please give me a call or e-mail. See ya! (Blows a kiss)

column1: どうも。あ、そうだ。これ、僕の名刺です。よかったら、メールか電話ください。じゃまた。（チュッ）バァ～イ。
column2: What is that? Is he crazy?

column1: ねぇねぇ。君達。今、暇？今からうちの店に来ない？
column2: Hey girls, do you have time now? Do you want to come to our club now?

column1: (ちっ。:舌打ち)だめだなぁ。今月、金ないから、お客連れて行きたいんだけどなぁ。
column2: Dang, no luck. Since I don't have any money, I want to bring a customer in to the club.

column1: 最近金使いすぎているから、積立用の口座をもう一つ作ったんだ。
column2: Recently, I've just been spending too much, so I set up a second savings account. I put aside 20,000 yen every month.
Wow. I'm impressed. I'm always broke at the end of the month. Hey, can I stop by an ATM cuz I need to withdraw some money.

column1: 俺なんか月末にはいつもスッカラカンだよ。
column2: Your balance is only 20,000 yen? We still have 2 more weeks until payday.
Eh, you're withdrawing everything? Are you serious?

column1: え？全額おろすの？マジで？
column2: I'm having dinner with Hatsuko tonight.

column1: 今夜、ハツコさんと食事に行くんだ。
column2: Hatsuko? You mean Hatsuko the lawyer?

column1: ハツコさんって、あの、弁護士の？
column2: When we have dinner, she'll deposit quite a bit of money for me.

column1: 一緒に食事をすると、大金を振り込んでくれるし。
service charge, charge for service, commission

column2: (ding-dong) Ticket 103, please come to the counter.

column1: いらっしゃいま…あ。（ゲッ　また来た！　ちんちくりんホストが！）
column2: Hello... Oh (uh...here he comes again! He's such an idiot!)

column1: あ、偶然ですね。また君かぁ。僕は運命を感じるなぁ。
column2: What a coincidence. It's you again. I feel like this is destiny.

column1: （コホン）それで、今日は、どのようなご用件ですか。
column2: Ahem, so how may I help you today?

column1: 小銭をお札に両替したいんですけど、手数料はかかりますか。
column2: I'd like to change coins to bills. Is there service charge for that?

column1: 硬貨50枚までは無料でございますが、51枚からは手数料が315円かかります。
column2: Up to 50 coins, there's no service fee required.  However if it's more than  51 coins, it costs 315 yen. Over 501 coins, it costs 630 yen. Do you have a lot?

column1: たくさんございますよぉ。（カウンターに硬貨を置く）
column2: I see. Please fill out this form while you are waiting. (picks up the heavy bag of coins) Ugggggggh...this is heavy!

column1: では、お待ちの間に、この用紙にご記入をお願いいたします。(硬貨の入った重い袋を持ち上げる)

column2: As I told you before, call me Taiga.
I'm sorry that I have kept you waiting. Your total is 65,332 yen.

column1: だから。大河って呼んでくださいよ。
column2: I'd like to deposit half of that amount.

column1: お待たせいたしました。全部で6万5332円でございました。
column2: I see. You would like to deposit 32,666 yen in your ordinary savings account, right? Certainly, sir. Well then, please fill out this form.

column1: 半額を普通預金の口座に入れたいんですけど。
a savings account for daily use
よう、大河！銀行で何してたの？早速、金をおろしていたのか？
column2: Yo, Taiga. What were you doing at the bank? Were you withdrawing money?

column1: ああ、聖夜か。いや、金を引き出していたんじゃないよ。
column2: Hey, Seiya. Nope. I wasn't withdrawing the money.

column1: え？リッチな弁護士、ハツコ先生から、振込みあったんでしょ？
column2: Oh... Hatsuko, the rich lawyer deposited money in your account?

column1: いや…。それが、急用ができたからって、キャンセルされちゃって。
column2: Uh... She canceled the date saying she has urgent business.
So, it means you have a balance of 0 yen? (you don't have any money left in your account?)

column1: 俺、貯金はないけど、いつも、一円玉と五円玉と十円玉は貯金箱に入れるんだ。
column2: I don't have any savings, but I always save one-yen, five-yen and ten-yen coins.

column1: で、たくさん貯まったから、今日銀行に持ってきたんだ。6万5332円あった。
column2: And I saved a ton of them and brought them to the bank. It came to 65,332 yen.

column1: へぇー（あいづち）すげー。で、貯蓄用の口座は作った？
column2: Dude, that's awesome! Did you set up a second account to save money?

Next time I will. This time I put half the amount of 65,332 yen to my ordinary savings account so I took only 32,666 yen in cash. I'm spending half of it on living expenses and the other half is going to be my pocket money.

column1: 今回は6万5332円の半額を普通預金の口座に入れて、半額の3万2666円だけおろしてきた。
column2: You really should put it in the time deposit account, not in the ordinary savings account. But, well, Taiga, you finally learned something. I'm so happy for you! (crying with joy)

column1: Name of limited express for Odakyū  Line
What!, exclamation to express disappointment or blame
ジョン、夏休みは、どうする？
column2: John, what do you want to do for summer vacation?

column1: 温泉、いいねぇ。どこの温泉に行こうか？
column2: An onsen...Sounds nice. Which onsen shall we go to then?

column1: うーん。温泉に詳しくないからな・・・。加奈子のお勧めはどこ？
column2: Well. I don't know about hot springs very well...so what is your recommendation?

column1: そうねぇ。なるべく近いところがいいね。箱根はどう？
column2: Yeah, well...it's probably better to go to a place close by. How about Hakone ?

column1: 箱根は、日帰りできるし、富士山も見られるし…
column2: Oh, we can make a day trip to Hakone, and we can see Mt. Fuji. It's a good idea. Let's go to an onsen in Hakone.
And what's better, because we can go on a Romance car, we can eat ekiben. Sounds like fun. I can't wait.

column1: それに、ロマンスカーで行けるから、駅弁も食べられるし、楽しいよ！
わぉ！駅弁？食べよう、食べよう！
column2: All right then, it's decided. We go to Hakone. You know Toru also wants to go to Hakone. So let's invite him too.

column1: じゃ、箱根に決まり！トオルも温泉に行きたがっていたから、誘おうよ。
column2: What? Toru? O...Ok. Let's do that. (Oh, it's not just the two of us.)

column1: to be worried, to be bothered
for, for the sake of, to one's advantage
あのさぁ、夏休みに、箱根の温泉に行こうと思っているんだけど、一緒に行かない？
column2: I'm thinking about going to a hot spring in Hakone for summer vacation.  Why don't we go together?

column1: 箱根かぁ！いいね。行く、行く！
column2: Oh, Hakone! That's great. I'd love to!

column1: よかったぁ。困ってたんだ。助かったわ。
column2: Oh, that's great. I was worried. You saved me.

column1: ジョンも一緒に行くんだけど、彼に温泉の入り方を教えて欲しいんだ。
column2: John is also coming with us. I want you to teach him what to do with a hot spring.

column1: ふーん、そのために、僕を誘ったんだ。
column2: I was asked for that purpose?

column1: そのためだけじゃないよ。勘違いしないでよ。
column2: It's not only for that. Don't get me wrong.

column1: おいしいものをたくさん食べて、温泉に入って、楽しもうね！
column2: Let's eat lots of delicious food and enjoy the hot springs. I'll get in touch with you later. See you. Bye.

column1: to splash hot water on yourself (before getting in a bathbub)
ジョン、この小さいタオル、持った？
column2: John, do you have this small towel?

column1: うん。でも、このタオルは、何のために使うの？
column2: Yeah, but what's this towel for?

column1: :（温泉の浴室への引き戸を開ける音）
column2: First, you wash yourself with this towel, then you get in the onsen. O.K. Let's go.(opening a sliding door to the bathroom)

column1: わぁ、広いなぁ！泳げるね。
column2: Wow, it's so big. We can swim in it.

column1: 皆、泳ぎたがるんだよ。でも、泳いじゃだめだぞ。
column2: Everybody tends to want to swim, but swimming is prohibited.

column1: 体、洗った？そしたら、浴槽に入る前に、かけ湯をするんだ。
column2: So, did you wash yourself? If that's the case, before getting in the bath, let's put hot water on ourselves.
In order to adjust your body to the temperature of the onsen, you should put the hot water on your body.
All right, let's get in the bath.

column1: どうした？ジョンも入れよ。
column2: What's the matter? Get in John.

column1: あ、だめだめ。ジョン。タオルは、浴槽の中に入れちゃだめだよ。
column2: Oh no, no! John, you can't take your towel into the bath.
Well, what do I do with it?

column1: 僕は、小さくたたんで、頭の上に載せるよ。
column2: Fold it up small and put it on your head.
Oh, I get it. I can do that.

column1: 君達、あんまり長湯するなよ。倒れるぞ。

column2: Don't stay in too long you two - you'll fall down! Get out and take a break from time to time, OK?

column1: そ、そろそろ、上がろうか。
column2: Ah, let's get out of the bath.

column1: そっ…そうだね。シャ、シャワー浴びよう。じゃ、お先に・・・。
column2: Oh, okay. I think it's time for a shower. See you later.

column1: シャワー？（舌打;チッチッチ）シャワーは浴びちゃダメダメ。
column2: A shower?! Tsk tsk, a shower is no good!  It'll undo the effects of the onsen.

column1: おじいさん。見てください。今日は星がきれいですよ。
column2: Look – the stars are beautiful tonight.
Oh, they really are. Look, a shooting star!

column1: スミマセン。ココハ ドコ デスカ。
あわわわわわわわ。と、とととととうきょう。ジャ、ジャパン。
オオ。ニホン デスカ。マチガエマシタ。

column2: Ahhh…. To, To, To, Tokyo… Ja, Japan.

column1: こここ、国連の事務局ぅ？？多分、ニューヨークだと思います。
column2: Oh, this is Japan? I made a mistake. Excuse me, could you tell me where the United Nations office is?
The U…U…U…United Nations office?! I think it’s in New York.

column1: どっちって…よくわからないですけど、もっと、西だと思います。
ソウデスカ。アリガトウ ゴザイマシタ。
column2: Direction?... I’m not sure, but I think farther West.

column1: ワタクシハ、ピーター ト モウシマス。トオイホシ カラ キマシタ。コンゴトモ　ヨロシク オネガイシマス。
column2: I see. Thank you very much. My name is Peter. I came from a distant star. My people wish to open trade relations with the earth.
On our planet, human finger nails are very expensive.

column1: ワタシタチノ ホシ デハ、ニンゲンノ ツメ ハ トテモ タカイデス。
a sign of women being around
a friend with whom one corresponds by e-mail,
俺、最近、メル友ができたんだ。
column2: I made a friend online recently.

column1: ほんと？でも、それって、ちょっと変じゃないか？
column2: Really? But isn't that kind of weird?

column1: 直接会って友達になるのが普通だろう？
column2: Usually you meet in person and then become friends, right?

column1: まぁ、そうだけど、俺、女の子の知り合いもいないし、俺の友達も女っけないし。だから、ミクシーに入ってみたんだ。
column2: Well, yeah, but I don't have any female friends, and my friends are not the type that hang around with girls. So I joined Mixi.

column1: で、誰かいい子見つかった？
column2: And... did you find a girl?

column1: ううん。だめ。それで、海外で流行っているフェイスブックを試してみたんだ。
column2: Not really. So then I joined Facebook, which is popular abroad.

column1: アプリのほとんどが英語だからさ。最初は、使いこなすのが大変だったよ。
column2: Most of it is in English, so the learning curve was pretty steep.

column1: ふーん。でもさ、ネットで彼女を見つけるのって、どうなの？大丈夫なの？
column2: Hmm. But is it all right looking for a girlfriend online?

column1: でも、確かに、一人よりはましか….
column2: But, I'm sure it's better than being alone.

column1: そうだよ。これ見てよ。毎日この子からメールが来るんだぜ。
column2: That's right! Look at this. I get a mail from this girl every day.

column1: 彼女からのメールを待つのも、返事をするのも、すっごく楽しいんだ。
column2: I love receiving mail from her, and I love replying to her.

column1: 今日も、彼女からメール来た？
column2: Did you get another email from your girlfriend today?
Of course. I get them every day.

column1: へぇ、すごいな。このごろ、お前、前より元気そうだな。
column2: Look at you. These days you seem to have a new spring in your step.
So when are you going to marry her?

column1: ええぇ？？まだ会ったことないのに結婚するなんて、考えたこともないよ。
column2: Whaaat?! I haven’t even met her face-to-face and you’re talking about marriage?! I hadn’t even thought about it.

column1: そうなのか？じゃ、いつ会うんだよ。
column2: Oh yeah? So when are you going to meet her?

column1: 会いたいような、会いたくないような。。。
column2: Well I want to meet her, but at the same time I don’t want to meet her… It’s just that I don’t want her to hate me as soon as she meets me.

column1: はぁ？毎日、メールやり取りしているのに、会ったこともないなんて、おかしいよ。
column2: No, well we’re still just friends, but! I have seen her picture. That’s good enough for me.

column1: 俺、昨日、愛ちゃんに会ったよ。
へぇ、彼女の名前、愛っていうんだ！
column2: So her name is Ai, huh.

column1: とうとう彼女に会ったか！で、いつ結婚？
column2: So you finally met her. So when's the wedding?

column1: やめてくれよ！だいたい、直接会ったのを今は後悔してるんだ。
column2: Cut it out. To tell you the truth, I regret meeting her face to face.

column1: 何で、後悔してるんだよ。
確かに顔は可愛かったよ。けど、最初に、
column2: Well, she is cute. But after she introduced herself with :Hello, my name is Ai, she started writing emails on her phone!

column1: 「こんにちは、愛です」って、自己紹介だけして、すぐに、携帯メールを打ち出したんだぜ。
友達にメールしてたのか？
column2: No, she was emailing me! Although we were right next to each other, our communication was email only.

column1: いや、俺にメールしてたんだよ。一緒にいるのに、メールのやり取りだけ。。。
column2: Even though we were eating together, she wouldn't even look at me.

column1: 一緒に食事をしているのに、俺の顔も見ないんだよ。
column2: I've never heard of that kind of date. So how did she order food?

column1: そんなデート、聞いたこともないよ。じゃ、食事の注文はどうしたんだよ。
食事のオーダーもメールで来た。
column2: Huh? What about after dinner? What did you do afterwards? You're going to meet her again, right?

column1: はぁ？食事の後は？食事の後はどうしたんだ？また、会うんだよな？
column2: After we left the restaurant, I got this email from her -

column1: レストランを出た後に、メールが来て
column2: Thank you for today. Perhaps we should start to look for new email friends.

column1: 最近、仕事おもしろくないし、これからはあんまり残業しないことにしたから時間もあるし、ペットでも飼いたいんだよね。
column2: Lately my work is boring. So I've decided to not work so much overtime. Now that I have a little more free time. I'm thinking about getting a pet.

column1: へぇ、ペットって、たとえば、犬とか、猫とか？
column2: A pet? Like a dog or a cat?

column1: いろいろ考えたんだけど、犬とか猫じゃ、すぐに物足りなくなるんじゃないかなって思ってるんだ。
column2: Well, I've been thinking. Having a cat or a dog, it just isn't enough. There's something missing.

column1: うーん、まだわからないんだけど。。。珍しいペットを売ってるショップにでも探しに行こうかな。
column2: Well, I'm not sure yet. But I'm thinking of looking at an exotic pet shop.

column1: そうしなよ。日本でも、変わったペットは珍しくなくなったからね。
column2: Oh, sounds good to me. Even in Japan, rare pets are not so rare any more.

column1: そうだね。フェレットとか、小さいサルをペットにしている人もいるし、ペンギンを飼ってる家の話も聞いたことあるよ。
column2: That's true. Some people have ferrets or monkeys, and I even heard peple who have penguins.

column1: あぁ、そういえば、プレーリードッグを飼ってる友達がいたわ。
column2: Speaking of which, I have a friend who has a prairie dog.

column1: 俺も、そういう特別なペットがいいな。
column2: I also want something special like that.

column1: すいませ～ん。変わったペットを探してるんですけど。
column2: Excuse me, I'm looking for an exotic pet.

column1: 変わったペット？お客さん、お目が高い！うちは、日本一個性的なペットショップです。
column2: An exotic pet? You, sir, have come to the right place! We are the number one exotic pet shop in Japan.

column1: ショーウィンドーの中の蛇は何ていう蛇ですか？
column2: Hey, what's the name of that snake in the window display?

column1: あれは、マムシです。毒を持っていますし、獰猛です。お薦めとは言えませんが、スリルは楽しめます。お子さんは、いらっしゃいますか？
column2: That, sir, is a Japanese pit viper. Not only is it poisonous, but it is quite fierce. I wouldn't really recommend it, but you can at least enjoy the thrill. Do you have children, sir?

column1: いませんが、マムシは結構です。じゃ、むこうにいるのは何ていう鳥？
column2: No, I don't, but I'll pass on the pit viper. So, what's the name of the bird over there?

column1: あれは、野生の七面鳥です。
へぇ～。野生の七面鳥か！あっ、あれはアザラシ？
column2: Wow, a wild turkey! Oh, is that a seal?

column1: いえ、あれはアシカです。お世辞にもかわいいとは言えませんが、子連れなんですよ。すごいでしょ。
column2: No, that's a sea lion.  I can’t say it's cute even out of pure flattery, but it does have babies. Amazing, isn't it?

column1: なるほど。。　あっ、イカだ！かわいいですね！
column2: I see... Oh, a squid! It's cute, isn't it?

column1: お客様、あれは、タコです。　まぁ、イカと似てないとは言えませんがね。。。
column2: Um, sir, that's an octopus. Well, you can't say that they don't look alike...

column1: any and all, all kinds of
ねぇ、変なペット、飼うことにしたの？この前、変わったペット専門店に行くって言ってたじゃない。
column2: So, did you decide on an unusual pet? The other day, you were talking about going to an exotic pet shop, right?

column1: おぅ！行ったよ。すっごい店だったよ。ありとあらゆる動物がいたぜ。
column2: That's right. I went, and it was incredible. They have every kind of animal you can imagine.

column1: えっ本当？たとえば、どんな動物がいたのよ。
野生の七面鳥、アシカ、サメ、それから、タコ、サル、トカゲ、熊、あと、河童もいたよ。
column2: They had wild turkeys, sea lions, sharks, and also octopuses, monkeys, lizards, bears, and they even had kappas. So I took a look at everything, and though it took a while I decided to get the octopus.

column1: 目移りして、なかなか決められなかったけど、結局、タコを飼うことにしたよ。
column2: An octopus?! Where are you keeping it?

column1: えっ、タコ？どこで飼ってるの？！
column2: Well, I was keeping it in the bathtub...

column1: バスタブで飼ってたんだけどね。。。
column2: Ah, well it's not impossible, but how do you take a bath?!

column1: あー、無理とは言わないけど。。。でも、お風呂は、どうしてるの？！
column2: Well, that's the thing. I decided to take a bath with it... but, I took too long. And before I knew it, Tako-kun... he stopped moving. So basically, I boiled him. The octopus. In the bathtub.

column1: いやぁ、一緒にお風呂に入ろう…と思ってさ、でも、長湯し過ぎちゃったんだ。
column2: What?! So what did you do?

column1: 気づいたときには、タコ君。。。動かなくなっていたんだ。
column2: Well, I'm from Osaka, so do you know the first thing that comes to mind when I hear the word “octopus?” Takoyaki. So, here you go (hands a plate to Mana), takoyaki courtesy of Tako-kun. Bon apetit!

column1: ねぇ、来週って江戸城公園の花火大会じゃない？
column2: Hey, the Edo Castle Park fireworks show is next week, isn't it? I love fireworks! Why don't we all go dressed up in yukatas?

column1: アヤ、花火大好きなの。みんなで、浴衣を着て行かない？
column2: Sounds good. What day is it?
Saturday. It starts at 7 p.m. Boys are in charge of saving a space. I'll make bento.

column1: 土曜日。7時から。場所は男子がとってね。
column2: Saturday...? Saturday's not good for me...

column1: アヤ、お弁当つくっていくから。
column2: Masa-san, by any chance, are you going on a date with one of those Shibuya girls?

column1: 土曜日かぁ・・・。土曜日はちょっとなぁ・・・。
column2: No. Actually, I'm going to do karaoke by myself.

column1: マサさん、もしかして、渋谷のギャルとデートですかぁ？
column2: I love doing karaoke by myself, too! You don't have to take turns with other people, and it's really fun, isn't it?

column1: 違うよ。ひとカラしに行くんだよ。
あたしもひとカラ大好きですよ！他の人と交代しないですむし、ほんと楽しいですよねぇ。
column2: Hitokara? Huh??? You sing karaoke all by yourself? I can't believe it.
It's pretty fun. It's cheap, too, if you don't order drinks. You sing what you want, and you don't have to listen to other people's horrible singing.

column1: to be wrong, to be mistaken
オレも、先週末、駅前のビックエコーで、5時間ヒトカラしてましたよ。
column2: I went to the Big Echo, in front of the station, by myself last weekend and did hitokara (karaoke by oneself) for five hours.

column1: まじで？俺も、昨日あそこで、5時間ヒトカラしてた。
column2: Are you serious? I went there yesterday and sang by myself for five hours.

column1: え、私もあそこの常連ですよ。
column2: Yeah? I'm a regular there. I went three times last week, and racked up three sheets of point cards.

column1: 週に3回くらい行ってたら、ポイントカードが3枚くらい貯まっちゃいましたよ。
column2: If you guys are all doing it, I want to try it once, too!

column1: みんなしてるんだったら、アヤも一回やってみたいなぁ！
column2: Why not? Give it a shot.

column1: いいじゃん、がんばって。
column2: Bu---t, I don't want to. I have a good idea...let's all go to karaoke by ourselves wearing yukatas!

column1: えー。一人じゃ、いやだよ。そうだ、いい考えがある。。。　みんなで、浴衣着てひとカラしよう！
column2: Let's all go? How can we sing by ourselves if we all go?

column1: みんなで？それはひとカラじゃないですよ。
column2: It is “by ourselves” if we all go into separate rooms at the karaoke place.

column1: カラオケ屋さんに入ってから、別々の部屋で歌ったら、ひとカラじゃないの？
column2: Well, yeah, I guess you can call that hitokara.

column1: まぁ、それも、ひとカラですね。
column2: Then it's decided! Next Saturday we're all going to do hitokara together!

column1: じゃ、決まり！来週の土曜日は、みんなでひとカラしよっ！
column2: We're all going to do Hitokara together. There's something wrong with that...

column1: as a matter of fact, the truth is
いらっしゃいませ。何名様ですか。
column2: Welcome! How many are in your party?

column1: 4名です。あ、でも、4部屋お願いします。
column2: Party of four. Um, but, we want four rooms, please.

column1: ねぇ。本当にカラオケするの？アヤ帰ってもいい？実は音痴なの。
column2: Hey, are we really doing karaoke? Can I go home? I'm actually tone deaf.

column1: 帰ってもかまわないけど、絶対、後悔するよ。
column2: You can go home, but you'll definitely regret it.

column1: 大丈夫、大丈夫。自分しかいないんだから、音痴でも恥ずかしくないですよ。
column2: It's ok, it's ok. You're by yourself, so even if you're tone deaf, you don't need to be embarrassed.

column1: アヤさん、ひとカラはどうですか。楽しいですか。
column2: Aya, how is it? Is it fun?

column1: うん、すごく楽しい！なんで今までヒトカラしなかったんだろう。
column2: Yeah, it's so much fun! Why didn't I do this sooner?

column1: もしもし？秀美ちゃん？匠とアヤに連絡できないんだ。なんか聞いてない?
column2: Hello? Hidemi? I can't reach Takumi or Aya. Have you heard anything?

column1: そうかぁ。オレ、そろそろ帰ってもかまわないかな？
column2: I see. Do you mind if I wrap it up soon?
Oh, OK, I'm ready to go, too.

column1: 隣のミケちゃんどうしたの。昨日から屋根の上にずっと座ったままよ。
column2: What's wrong with our neighbor Mike? He's been sitting up on the roof since yesterday.

column1: ミケちゃんの子供が一人、家を出たまま帰ってこないんだって。
column2: One of Mike's kids ran away from home and hasn't returned since.

column1: あらあら、いつまでも子供のままだと思っていたけど、ボーイフレンドとデート？
column2: Tsk, tsk, I was wondering when she'd grow up, but on a date with a boy already?

column1: ねずみをくわえたまま歩いているのをご主人さんが見て、すごく怒ったんだって。
column2: Her master got angry at her for walking around with a mouse in her mouth.
Oh, so that's why she ran away.

column1: 難しい年頃だからね。ご主人さんに腹を立てて、家を出て、そのままだって。
column2: She's at a tough age. She angered her master, ran away, and that's how it's been this whole time.

column1: 親は大変よね。私、独身のままで本当によかったわ。
column2: Parents have it rough, huh? Thank goodness I'm single.

column1: ま、姉さんの場合、相手がいないからね。
column2: Well, in your case, you don't have anybody. But you can't stay young forever. Why don't you think about your future, just a little?

column1: でも、いつまでも若いままじゃないんだからさ、すこし、考えたら、自分の人生。
to part, to divorce, to break up

column2: I haven't heard a word from you all night. Where were you?
There was a going away party at work. I went with my coworkers to karaoke, then to a club.
Do you know what time it is?

column1: 連絡もせずに、今までどこに行ってたの。
会社の送別会があったんだ。同僚とカラオケに行って、そのあと、クラブに行って。
column2: So you were just out there having a blast without checking your phone calls or emails?
My phone wasn't in my pocket; it was in my bag…Kumi, don't get mad, listen to me.

column1: さぁ…。４時くらい･･･ですか・・・ね？
column2: Your coworker, Mr. Yamada, said that he left you at 12.

column1: ほう。電話にもメールにも気づかずに、遊んでいたんだ？
column2: Yeah, he didn't come to the club…why are you making that face? You don't believe me?!

column1: by no means, you don't say
to pierce, to stab, to prick
to remove, to expel, to drive out
to be huffed, to become upset
よう、おはよう。けんちゃん。昨夜、彼女に怒られたか？
column2: Yo, good morning, Ken. So your girlfriend chewed you out last night?

column1: ああ、最悪だよ。悪かったなぁ、山田。クミ、昨日の夜遅く電話しただろう？ごめんな。
column2: Yeah, it was horrible. Sorry about that, Yamada. She called you late last night, right? Sorry.

column1: いいんだよ・・・。え、け、けんちゃん、どうした？その顔？まさか、彼女に殴られたのか？
column2: It's all right. What happened to your face, Ken? Jesus, did your girlfriend sock you?

column1: まさか。蚊に刺されたんだよ。
column2: No, I was bitten by mosquitoes.

column1: クミ、昨夜、カンカンでさ。俺、部屋から追い出されて、ベランダで寝たんだ。家、ワンルームだからさ。
column2: Well, Kumi was fuming last night, so she kicked me out of my room. I had to sleep on the veranda, since the apartment is only one room.

column1: で、朝起きたら、こんな顔になっていた。で、何時くらいに電話があった？
column2: So when I woke up, my face looked like this. So what time did she call?

column1: ああ。２時くらいだったかな。（あくび）
ええ？２時？あいつ、そんな時間に電話したのか？
column2: What? 2 o'clock? She called at that hour?!

column1: ああ、（あくび）5分おきに電話がきたよ。「連絡つかないんですぅ・・・。」って。
column2: Yeah (yawns), she called every five minutes, saying I can't get in touch with him. You need to treat her better (yawns).

column1: to go out with, to get along with
to dump someone, to shake something, to wave (hand) ; V1
ねぇ、梨花、今日、何かあるの？すごくかわいい格好してる。
column2: Hey, Rika. You have something going on today? You look really cute.

column1: ・・・実は、今日、ケンジ君とお出掛けなの。
column2: Actually...I'm going out with Kenji today.

column1: 梨花、とうとう、ケンジ君をデートに誘ったの？
column2: Rika, you finally asked Kenji out on a date?

column1: ううん。私が、ケンジ君に誘われたんだ。　「明日、ちょっと、買い物付き合って」って。
column2: No. Kenji asked me on a date. Hey said come shopping with me tomorrow.

column1: へぇ。。でも、どうするの？　この間、部長が梨花に取引先の人を紹介するって言ってたじゃない。
column2: Ooh. But, what are you going to do? The other day, the boss said he was going to introduce you to a client.

column1: う...ん。そうなんだよね。先週、部長に取引先の人を紹介されたんだ。それでその後、課長に別の取引先の人を紹介されたんだ。
column2: Ummm, that's right. Last week, the boss introduced me to one of our clients. Then after that, the section chief introduced me to another client. I've had dinner several times with each guy, but for now, I guess I'm just playing the field.

column1: どっちの人とも何度か食事に行ってるんだけど、今は様子を見ているかんじかな。
column2: Hmm, you're a big hit with the guys, huh?
Surprising, isn't it? After my ex dumped me last month, I've become pretty popular with the guys.

column1: easily,as if it was something simple
で、結局、ケンジ君と買い物行ったら、「彼女の指輪を一緒に選んで。」って言われたの。超ショックよぉ。
column2: So, I went shopping with Kenji, and he said Help me look for a ring for my girlfriend. It was a huge shock.

column1: へぇー。で、ケンジ君には告白したの？
column2: Whoa. So did you confess your feelings to him?

column1: 一応、したけど、あっさり振られたわ。「結婚したい子がいるから」って言われた。
column2: Well, sort of, but he interrupted. There's a girl I want to marry, he told me.

column1: ま、しょうがないわね。次よ。次。もっと、良い男を見つけるんだ。でも、社内恋愛はやめるわ。皆に、噂されるからね。
column2: Oh well, what can you do? Next time, next time. I'll find a good man. But I'll stop dating within the company. There's so much gossip, you know.

column1: （ため息）あかりちゃんは、いいわね。素敵な旦那様に愛されていて。
column2: (sighs) You're so lucky, Akari. You have a wonderful husband who loves you.

column1: 素敵かどうかは、分からないけど、まぁ、愛されてるかもね。でも、嫉妬深くて大変よ。
column2: I don't know about wonderful, but he probably loves me. But, his jealousy is a problem. Recently, he looked through the mail on my phone, and he deleted all the men in my address book.

column1: この前、旦那に携帯のメールを見られて、男の子のアドレスを全部消されたわ！
to take a living thing somewhere

column2: Good morning, Mr. Turkey. It's almost Thanksgiving, isn't it?

column1: あ、おはようございます、七面鳥さん。･･･もうすぐサンクスギビングですね。
column2: That's right! I'm so excited! I can't wait! This is my first Thanksgiving!

column1: そうなんですよ！僕、楽しみで楽しみで。サンクスギビングのイベントは初めてなんです。

column2: Master always tells me, You are the hero of Thanksgiving. Isn't that amazing? Everyone has their expectations up.

column1: 「感謝祭は、君がヒーローだ！」とご主人さんに言われているんですよ。すごくないですか。僕、みんなに期待されているんです。
column2: Is...that..so? It'll be sad. Where will you be taken?

column1: ･･･そう･･･ですか。さみしくなりますね。どこに連れて行かれるんですか。
column2: The White House, is what they told me. They'll introduce me to my brothers there, I am so looking forward to it. Oh, master's calling. It's almost time to go. Well, see you.

column1: ホワイトハウスと言われました。そこで、兄弟達を紹介されるので、とても楽しみなんです。
column2: ...Well, see you, he said. What a pity. He doesn't know, does he?

column1: あ、ご主人さんが、呼んでいる。そろそろ出発の時間です。じゃ、また。
column2: He'll be throttled, plucked, thrown in an oven, roasted...

column1: ･･･「じゃ、また。」って･･･。かわいそうね。知らないのかしら？
column2: Stop it! Stop it! That's enough.

column1: 絞められて、羽をとられて、オーブンに入れられて、焼かれて…。
やめて！やめて！もう十分。
column2: It's almost time to go. Hurry it up. Everyone is waiting for the roast turkey.

column1: to forget everything, to write it off
星野先輩！お久しぶりです！実は、相談があるんですが。
column2: Hoshino! Long time, no see! Actually, I have to talk to you.

column1: あっ、五味。お前には、もう、だまされないぞ。
column2: Oh, Gomi. I won't be fooled by you again.
Huh?! What are you talking about??

column1: 俺の部長は漫画が大嫌いなのに、漫画好きだって、俺をだましただろ。俺は、あれから部長ににらまれて大変だったんだぞ！
column2: You told me my boss loves manga when he actually hates it! You tricked me. Ever since then, he just glares at me.

column1: すいません。本気にすると思わなかったんです。本当にすいません。
column2: I'm sorry. I didn't think you'd actually do it. I'm really sorry.

column1: まぁ、いいだろ。水に流してやるよ。
column2: Ah, it's all right, I guess. I'll let it slide.

column1: ありがとうございます！ところで、先輩、そろそろお歳暮の季節ですね。やっぱり、上司にお歳暮を贈った方がいいでしょうか。
column2: Thank you! By the way, it's almost time for year-end presents, right? Do you think I should send one to my supervisor?

column1: 何が喜ばれると思いますか？
column2: What do you think he'd like?

column1: う～ん、それは、その人の性格とか好みによって違うよ。五味の部長は、坂口部長だよな。今度、会う機会があるから、ちょっと聞いてみようか。
column2: Hmm, that depends on his personality, on his preferences. Your supervisor is Mr. Sakaguchi right? I'm going to meet with him soon, shall I ask him?

column1: 助かります！よろしくお願いします！
column2: That would be great! Thank you!

column1: to try to gain someone's favor
to be of some help, to serve as a reference
あ、坂口部長、ちょっと、よろしいですか。
column2: Ah, Mr. Sakaguchi, may I have a minute with you, sir?

column1: 実は、お客さんへのお歳暮を何にしたらいいか、ご意見を聞きたいと思いまして。。.
column2: Actually, I'd like to ask your opinion on year-end presents for my clients...

column1: そうだなぁ。子供がいる家庭なら、子供に喜ばれるお菓子がいいんじゃないか。
column2: Yeah, well if it's a family with children, why don't you give them some sort of sweets the children will like? Fancy food that you can't find in a supermarket is also good.

column1: それから、スーパーで売られていない高級な食べ物もいいな。

column2: Well, presents are a must with the clients, but I find the whole year-end present giving and receiving thing to be loathsome. Recently, I've been getting presents from my employees, but to tell the truth, it's a bother.

column1: まぁ、取引先は仕方がないが、お歳暮は、贈るのも、贈られるのも、嫌いだね。
最近、部下からもお歳暮が贈られてくるが、はっきり言って、迷惑なんだ。
column2: First off, I can do without that fawning attitude. I think gift-giving within the company should be prohibited.
You've been really helpful! Thank you.

column1: That will teach you., Someone got what he/she deserved.
あなた～。五味さんからお歳暮が贈られてきましたよ。
column2: Honey… you got a present here from Mr. Gomi.

column1: え？お歳暮？あいつめ。（ガサガサ；包みを開ける）
column2: A year-end present (fuming)? That darned Gomi. (opens the package) He sent, this expensive.... That Gomi doesn't understand my personality one bit. Doesn't he understand what a bother this is to me? This is ridiculous.

column1: こんなに、高いものを・・・。。五味は、私の性格をわかっていないな。
column2: Hoshino! Thank you for the other day...I sent a luxury fruit basket like you recommended.

column1: 迷惑だと思われることがわからなかったのか。まったくけしからん。
星野先輩！この間はありがとうございました。。。
column2: But, recently, Mr. Sakaguchi has been ignoring me...and he hasn't even thanked me...I wonder why. Has the present not arrived yet?

column1: 先輩のアドバイスどおり、超高級フルーツ詰め合わせを贈りました。
column2: Don't worry about it. Mr. Sakaguchi probably just forgot to say thanks.
I wonder. He hasn’t even invited me out for a drink.

column1: でも、最近、部長に無視されるんですよね。。。それに、お礼も言われないんですよ。。。
to cancel at the last minute

column2: I made us a reservation for Christmas dinner.

column1: 茂？クリスマスディナーの予約とっておいたよ。
column2: Oh, thank you! Two guys spending Christmas Eve together is not cool, but what can you do?
It's better than being alone. So, let's meet at the Oedo line Roppongi station ticket barrier at 6:30.

column1: 男二人で、クリスマスイブを過ごすなんて、さえないけど、しょうがないな。
じゃ、大江戸線の六本木駅改札に6時半にしよう。

column2: Oh, Shigeru. What?!?! You're bailing out on me?! You're going on a date with a girl you met yesterday?! You can't do this to me, man! (hangs up) What's his problem!
What?! You don't just cancel on your friends like this, Sayuri! I cleared my schedule just for you, you know. Wa-wait a minute... Ah, she hung up.
(Huh, I wonder if someone bailed on her, too...) Umm, excuse me. My friend just cancelled on me, and now I'm here alone, but if you'd like, why don't we eat together?

column1: あっ、茂。　えっ！！！！ドタキャン？！
column2: Oh, um, sure. (Lucky!!! He believed my fake phone call!)

column1: to deliver, to take, to bring
さ、帰るか。今年も、誰もチョコレートをくれなかった...。
column2: Time to go home. I didn't get any chocolate this year, again... (sighs). For sixteen years in a row I haven't received Valentine chocolates.

column1: (はぁ・・・）俺は、16年連続バレンタインデーのチョコレートをもらう事ができなかったのか。
column2: (He opens the door to his shoe cubby, and out falls a letter.)

column1: あれっ、手紙だ！読んでみよう。
column2: Huh, a letter! Let's see what it says Dear Keisuke, meet me behind the school gym today at 5 p.m. From Natsuko. Whooooa!!! Natsuko-chan's going to give me chocolate!!! Yeeesss!!!!!!! (runs)

column1: 圭介君へ、今日の5時に体育館裏に来てください。夏子より。
おー！！！！俺に、夏子ちゃんがチョコレートをくれる！やったー！（走る！）
あのー、圭介君。これ・・・
column2: (To himself) Yeesss!! Finally, my first Valentine chocolates ever!

column1: （心の声で）やったぞ！ついに、人生初のチョコレートをもらうぞ！
column2: Please give this chocolate to Koji. I'm too shy to do it.

column1: このチョコレートを浩二君にあげて！
column2: ...oh, Ko, Koji. Ah...right. Um, got it. I'll get it to him today.

column1: 私…恥ずかしくてあげることが出来ないの。
to go out, to answer (the phone, the doorbell)
to go in, to come in
浩二、ちょっと出てくれるー？
column2: Koji, can you get that for me?
Okay--. Oh, hey! What's up? Come in, man.

column1: おっす！！どうした？ま、上がれよ。
うわっ！！チョコレートがたくさんある！！今年もたくさんもらったな。
column2: What?! Look at all this chocolate!! You got a bunch again this year.

column1: ああ、20個くらいもらったよ。全部食べられないから、ちょっと食べてくれる？
column2: Yeah, around 20 or so. I can't eat them all, so can you eat some for me? I'm trying not to eat that much chocolate; it gives you pimples, you know. So, what's up?

column1: あまりチョコを食べないことにしてるんだ。ニキビができちゃうから。で、用は何？
これ、夏子ちゃんからのバレンタインチョコ。
column2: Oh, I see...she made me chocolates last year, too...what should I do?

column1: 去年も夏子ちゃんからもらったのか。本当にうらやましいな。
column2: You got chocolates from Natsuko last year, too?! I'm so jealous, man.

column1: 実は、彼女、ちょっと性格が合わないんだよね。すごいおとなしいから、話が続かないんだ。
column2: Actually, she's not my type. She's too quiet, so our conversations don't last very long. Did you get any chocolates this year, Keisuke?

column1: 圭介は、今年誰かからチョコもらった？

column2: So, will you take Natsuko's chocolates for me?

column1: じゃあ、夏子ちゃんのチョコレートも、もらってくれるか。
column2: Huh? Is it all right? Thanks! (chewing) Mmm, these are good! These are the best chocolates I've ever had! .... But you're not going to have any? She made them for you, after all.

column1: え？いいの？いただきまーす。
column2: I'm fine with just Fuyuka's chocolates. She's the only one for me.

column1: （もぐもぐ）うまい！！こんなおいしいチョコは初めてだ。
column2: Are you going to give her anything on White Day?

column1: …あ、でも、食べてあげないの？わざわざ作ってくれたんだよ。
column2: I'm going to take Fuyuka to a movie.

column1: 俺は、本命の冬花ちゃんのチョコだけでいいんだ。
column2: I see...well, there's not much to argue about if you're only into Fuyuka.

column1: to pass over, to hand over, V1
to deliver, to take, to bring
おはよう！夏子ちゃん。そのバックかわいいね。
あ、ありがとう。お父さんに買ってもらったの。ホワイトデーのお返し。
column2: Thanks. My dad got it for me, as a White Day present.

column1: 夏子ちゃんどうしたの？元気ない？
column2: What's wrong Natsuko-chan? You don't look so good.

column1: ねぇ、圭介くん。浩二君にチョコレート渡してくれた？
column2: Keisuke-kun, did you give Koji-kun my chocolates?

column1: え？ああ。もちろん、届けてあげたよ。
column2: Huh? Yeah, of course I did.

column1: そうだよね。届けてくれたよね。
column2: Right, of course you did. I wonder if he ate them. Maybe he didn't like them...

column1: あ、浩二君、私のチョコレート食べてくれたかなぁ。
あ、もしかして、チョコレート美味しくなかったのかなぁ。
column2: Huh, what? You ate my chocolate??

column1: いや、あれは、すごくおいしかったよ。
column2: No, no, no. I didn't. But Koji couldn't eat them all, so he shared some with me.

column1: え？なに？！私のチョコ食べたの？
column2: That's horrible! So Koji-kun gave you my chocolate!

column1: いやいやいやいや。食べてないよ。
浩二が食べきれないから、ちょっとだけ分けてもらったんだよ。
column2: Really...well, I guess I'll give you some obligatory chocolate next year then.

column1: a flight attendant, a cabin attendant
すみません。僕の座席はどこですか。
column2: I'm sorry, can you tell me where my seat is?

column1: こちらの通路をまっすぐ行って、右側です。
column2: Just go straight down this aisle and it’s on the right.

column1: ありがとうございます。
よいしょ。緊張するなあ。日本に行くの初めてだから。
column2: Here we go. Man, I’m nervous – this is my first time going to Japan. But I’ll be fine – Kazuki is waiting for me over there.

column1: でも、大丈夫。あっちでは、和樹が待っているから。
この飛行機はジャパニーズポッド、１０１便です。私（わたくし）は、客室乗務員の田中です。
column2: Welcome to JapanesePod flight 101. I am flight attendant Tanaka. Our scheduled flight time to Japan is 10 hours. We will be taking off shortly, so we ask that you please fasten your seat belts and turn off all cellular phones. We hope that you have a pleasant flight.
Kazuki! It’s been such a long time!
