column1: 久しぶり、ジャック！フライトはどうだった？
column2: Yeah, it really has Jack! How was your flight?

column1: 良かったよ。全然揺れなかったし、機内食、カレーで美味しかった。
column2: It was good. No turbulence at all, and the in-flight curry was delicious. But, before anything else can I use the bathroom? I didn’t go at all the whole flight.

column1: それより、トイレ行っても良い？一度もトイレ行かなかったから。
何で行かなかったんだよ。
column2: Well, I had the window seat and the Japanese woman sitting next to me was just so beautiful. I got all nervous and couldn’t work up the nerve to say anything. Watch my bag will you?

column1: 窓側に座ってたんだけど、隣の日本人がすごい美人でさ。
だから、緊張して、頼めなかったんだよ。
じゃ、この荷物、見ててくれない？
column2: Shall we go? Oh, I got my driver’s license last month.

column1: 分かったよ。ここで待ってるね。

column2: Alright Jack, can you put your suitcase in the trunk?

column1: じゃあ、行こうか。あ、俺、先月免許取ったんだ。
column2: Okay! Hmmm… it’s really heavy! Kazuki, could you hold the other side for me?

column1: じゃあ、そのジャックのスーツケース、トランクに入れてくれない？
column2: Sure. Oof! Okay, let’s go to my place. My mother is waiting for us.

column1: to mistake something for something else
あら、いらっしゃい。チャック君ね。
column2: Oh, welcome! You are Chuck, right?

column1: お母さん。チャックじゃないよ。ジャック。間違えないでよ。
column2: Mom, it’s Jack not ‘Chuck!’ Get it right!

column1: ごめんなさいね。ジャック君。
column2: I’m sorry, Jack. I know you two just arrived, but can I ask you to run an errand for me?

column1: 着いたばかりで悪いんだけど、二人で、お使いに行ってもらえない？
ジャック、メモになんて書いてある？読んでくれない？
column2: Jack, what does it say on the memo? Can you read it for me?

column1: えっと、玉ねぎ、にんじん、じゃがいも、豚肉、チョコレート。
column2: Uh, onions, carrots, potatoes, pork and chocolate.

column1: あっ、今夜はカレーだね！
column2: Ah, sounds like we’re having curry tonight.
What? Curry again?! But why would you put chocolate in a curry?

column1: でも、なんで、カレーにチョコレートなんて入れるの？
column2: Oh yeah, that’s the ‘kakushi aji.’ (secret ingredient)

column1: （・・・でも、かくしあじ？かくしあじってなんだ？）
column2: Well, I’m going to look for the chocolate. Jack, would you look for some pork?

column1: じゃあ、おれはチョコレートを探すから、ジャックは豚肉探してもらえない？
to step back, to move down (intransitive)
to be into sth, to be immersed in
ジャック、今日はどこ行きたい？
column2: Jack, where do you want to go today?

column1: うーん、自然が多いところに連れて行ってくれない？
column2: Hmm, will you take me someplace with lots of nature?

column1: 分かった。じゃあ、高尾山に行こう！
column2: Alright. Let’s go to Mt. Takao!

column1: いやー、高尾山は、空気がきれいだね。
column2: Well well, the air on Mt. Takao is so nice. Oh look, it’s a squirrel! Let’s catch it Kazuki!

column1: あっ、あれリスだ！！和樹、捕まえようぜ！
やったー！捕まえた！（リスの鳴き声）
column2: Hey, let’s take a commemorative picture with the squirrel.

column1: じゃあ、リスと一緒に記念写真を撮ろう。
column2: Excuse me, would you take a picture for us?

column1: すみませーん。写真を撮っていただけませんか。
column2: I’m not quite getting you. Would you take a step back? Uh… A little to the right. Ok, could you take one more step to the right? And can you hold the squirrel a little bit lower? Yes, yes that’s it! Okay, say cheese!

column1: 写らないので、もうちょっと、下がっていただけませんか。
あ・・・もうちょっと右ですね。
column2: Wow, that guy was really particular about his camerawork.

column1: ごめんくださーい。 探偵事務所Ｘはこちらですか。
column2: Excuse me, is this the office of Detective X?

column1: そうです。さぁ、どうぞ、こちらへおかけください。
column2: Yes it is. Please come in and have a seat. I am Detective X, and I’ll solve any case. Now, what seems to be the matter?

column1: 私（わたくし）、探偵Xと申します。どんな事件でも解決します。
column2: I’m Kimi Tokugawa. You see, the colored carp in my pond have disappeared. Can you help me find them?

column1: 今日は、どんなご用件ですか。
column2: That should be easy. When did they disappear?
Yesterday, when I came back from a week-long trip abroad. They may have disappeared while I was away.

column1: 実は、家（うち）の池にいた錦鯉がいなくなってしまったんです。見つけてもらえますか。
column2: Your fish may have been stolen by someone.

column1: そんなの朝飯前ですよ。いついなくなったんですか。
column2: Please catch the culprit. When I bought them some time ago, each colored carp cost me 1,000,000 yen. I paid 3,000,000 yen all together for those three fish!

column1: 昨日、1週間の海外旅行から帰ってきたんです。。
column2: Huh, colored carp are that expensive?!

column1: ここが、キミさんの家の庭ですね。
column2: So, Kimi this is your garden - and you say that a week ago three colored carp were here in this very pond.

column1: そして、一週間前までは、この池に錦鯉が3匹いた。
はい、そうだったと思います。
column2: Alright, let’s start questioning your neighbors.

column1: では、近所の人に聞き込みを開始しましょう。

column2: Have you seen any suspicious people here in the past week?

column1: この1週間で、誰か、不審な人は見ませんでしたか。
column2: No, I don’t think there have been any suspicious people around here.

column1: 変な人はいなかったと思います。
column2: No suspicious people… Well then, have you heard any sounds? Like the splish-splashing of water perhaps?

column1: 不審者はいない・・・。
column2: Nope, I don’t think I’ve heard any large sounds in particular.

column1: では、何か、音は聞こえませんでしたか。バシャバシャという水の音とか。
column2: Didn’t hear any sounds… Hmmm, puzzling. Can you remember anything else? Even the most trivial detail may help.

column1: いえ、別に大きい音は聞かなかったと思いますよ。
column2: I’m sorry. This area is normally pretty quiet, and I don’t think anything changed while Kimi was away.

column1: to grab, to hold, to clutch; V1
うーん。不審な人はいなかった。物音もしなかった。
column2: Hmm. There were no suspicious people. No noises. I just don’t know… Who could the culprit be?

column1: わからない・・・。犯人は誰だろう。
column2: Wait!! I’ve had an epiphany! I know who did it.

column1: ん・・！！ひらめきました！
私、犯人が分かりました。
犯人は、人間ではありません。
column2: No. Think about cat behavior. They hate getting wet more than anything else. A cat probably wouldn’t go anywhere near the water.

column1: 動物か！もしかして猫ですか。
column2: I see. Then a dog must be the culprit!

column1: いいえ、猫の習性を考えてください。
column2: No, a dog couldn’t catch a colored carp with its paws. And on top of that, a dog would make so much noise that surely the neighbors would have noticed. It couldn’t have been a dog. The culprit is… (whispers)

column1: 猫は、水にぬれるのを極端に嫌うんです。おそらく、水には近づかないでしょう。
column2: Wow, what amazing deductive reasoning! Please, take me on as your pupil!

column1: なるほど。ということは、犬が真犯人ですね！
column2: Who is the shocking culprit? Find out on next week’s broadcast!

column1: to leak out (a secret), to be exposed
この推理ドラマ微妙な話だなぁ。
column2: The story on this detective drama is kind of lame. And they’re putting off the ending until next week? I think a bird did it.
Really? But a bird couldn’t hold a whole colored carp. I think a human must have done it after all.

column1: 私は、鳥が犯人だと思うな。
column2: Well, it is true that colored carp are really expensive. The culprit might want to sell the stolen carp on an Internet auction.

column1: そうかな。鳥が錦鯉をくわえられるはずがないよ。
column2: Yeah, they probably just want to sell the carp somewhere. I think they just need to find out where this criminal is planning to sell them and arrest him.

column1: やっぱり、人間が犯人のはずだよ。
column2: But the culprit couldn’t sell them that easily. If he tries to do it too soon, he might get caught.

column1: 確かに、錦鯉って本当に高いし、犯人は、盗んだ錦鯉をネットオークションで売るかもしれないよね。
column2: Haha, you’re right. No criminal is that stupid. But it does seem like Kimi Tokugawa didn’t really need to go out of her way to hire a detective.

column1: そうそう。犯人は、錦鯉をどこかで売るはずだよ。
column2: Looks like the old lady could have solved the case all by herself.

column1: to start over, to do over
宮島物産では社員が毎日トイレ掃除をしているんですか。それは、どうしてでしょうか。
column2: Do the employees at Miyajima Trading clean the toilets every day? Why is that?

column1: 社員を教育するためです。
column2: For the purpose of employee training.

column1: 私は、社員に、他の人の気持ちを考えるように言っています。
column2: I tell my employees to think about how other people feel.

column1: なるほど。ユニークなアイディアですね。
column2: I see. That is a unique idea.

column1: さて、今日もトイレをチェックするか。
column2: Okay, well let’s check the toilets today.

column1: ん！なんだ、この汚いトイレは！
column2: Hmm?! What is this dirty toilet?!

column1: ここの清掃の担当は・・・・（メモをチェックする音）田中の部署か。
column2: Who is in charge of the cleaning here? (sound of checking a notepad) Ah, this is Tanaka’s department.

column1: 田中君、２階のトイレ、汚かったぞ。
column2: Ms. Tanaka, the second floor toilet is awfully dirty.

column1: 申し訳ありません。部下に、やり直すように伝えます。
column2: I apologize. I’ll tell my subordinates to do it again.

column1: 吉川君、また、トイレ掃除をサボったでしょ。
column2: Yoshikawa, you skipped out on your toilet cleaning duties again didn’t you?

column1: この前も、サボらないように言ったでしょう。
column2: Didn’t I tell you before not to shirk your responsibilities?

column1: 給料カットするわよ（笑）。
column2: I’m going to cut your pay! (laughs)

column1: 申し訳ありませんでした。これからは、気をつけます。
column2: I’m very sorry. I’ll make sure it doesn’t happen again.

column1: （心の声で）「新人の上田に、掃除するように頼んだんだけど、あいつ、サボったな。」
column2: (internal voice) I told that new guy, Ueda, to do the cleaning, but it looks like he skipped out.

column1: to get done with, to tidy up; V2
ペーターさんの引越しパーティー行く？
column2: Are you going to Payter’s moving party?

column1: はい。ペーターさんの新しい新居見てみたいですね。
column2: Yes, I want to get a look at Payter’s new place.

column1: 私も参加します。誰が来るんですか。
column2: I’m going too. Who else is coming?

column1: 誰が来るか分からないんだよね。
column2: You know, I’m not sure. It sounds like the start time isn’t even decided yet.

column1: いつ開くかもまだ決めてないみたい。
じゃ、僕、ペーターさんにちょっと聞いてみます。
column2: Payter, have you decided when you’re going to have your moving party?

column1: ペーターさん、いつ引越しパーティーをするか決めましたか。
column2: I’m planning to have it in the evening next Friday. Can everyone come?

column1: 来週の金曜の夕方にするつもり。みんな、来れる？

column2: I’ll be there after I take care of things at work.

column1: 私は、仕事を片付けてから、行きます。
column2: I’m also not sure what time I can get off work that day, but I should be going too.

column1: 私も仕事が何時に終わるかわからないけど、たぶん行きます。
直子さん、明日のパーティーに何を持っていくか決めました？
column2: Naoko, did you decide what you’re taking to the party?

column1: あ・・・まだ。そうだ、みんなで引越しのプレゼント一緒に買わない？
column2: Oh, not yet. Oh yeah, why don’t we all chip in for a moving present?

column1: いいですね。プレゼント何にするか考えましょう。
column2: Great. Let’s think about what kind of present to get.

column1: to dine out, to go out to eat
to go somewhere frequently, to commute
to be pleased with, to like
引越し祝いに、食器はどうですか。
column2: What about tableware as a moving gift?

column1: うーん。ペーターさん、毎日外食していますよね。
column2: Hmm…but Payter eats out every day, right?

column1: だから食器を使うかどうか、わかりませんよね。
column2: We can’t even be sure if he’d use tableware can we?

column1: え？表札（笑）？表札って...家の入り口にある、表札ですか？
column2: Huh? A nameplate? Haha. Like the ones at the entrance of a house?

column1: ペーターさんが気に入るかどうか微妙ですね。
column2: I think it's doubtful Payter would like that.

column1: あと、英語で書くか、日本語で書くかわからないですね。
column2: And, we can’t even be sure if we should write it in English or in Japanese.

column1: そっか・・・。表札はだめか。
column2: Oh yeah…I guess a nameplate is out then.

column1: ねぇ、ぺーターが何が好きか分かる？
column2: Hey, does either of you know what Payter likes?

column1: プレゼントできないじゃない！
column2: But we can’t give him any of those things, can we!

column1: あ、ペーターさん、今一カレーのカレーライス大好きですよ。
column2: Oh, he does really love the curry rice at Imaichi curry restaurant.

column1: 週一で通っているみたいですよ。
column2: It sounds like he goes there once a week.

column1: 今一カレーには、ギフトセットがあるか分かる？
column2: Do you know if they have a curry gift set?

column1: はい、ギフト用レトルトカレーがあります。
column2: Yes, they have a boil-in-the-bag gift curry.

column1: これで、ぺーターさんはオフィスで大好きなカレーが食べられますね。
column2: Payter would be able to eat the curry he loves right at the office.

column1: to make it in time for
to leave it to, to give over
chūhai, a mix of shōchū, carbonated water, and lemon
気に入るかどうか分かりませんが、引越し祝いです。どうぞ。
column2: We don’t know if you’ll like it or not, but we bought you a moving gift. Here you go.

column1: 大勢の人がいますね。そして、大豪邸ですね。
column2: There are lots of people here. And this place is huge!

column1: いやいや。家具がほとんどまだないからね。
column2: Oh no. It just looks big since most of the furniture hasn’t arrived yet.

column1: いくらか知らない。妻に任せているから。
column2: I don’t know how much it is. I leave that up to my wife.

column1: そんなに高くないと思うよ。
column2: I don’t think it's that expensive though.

column1: このテレビすごいでかいですね！
まだ、どこに置くか決めていないんだよね。
column2: We haven’t decided where to put it yet.

column1: 直子さんは間に合うかどうか分からないって言っていましたよ。
column2: Naoko said she wasn’t sure if she’d make it here on time or not.

column1: そうか、じゃあ先に乾杯しようか。
column2: Okay, well shall we start drinking without her then?

column1: あ、みんなが何を飲むか分からなかったから、ビール、チューハイ、ワインを用意したんだ。
column2: I wasn’t sure what everybody drinks, so I got beer, chu-hai (shochu with tonic water) and wine.

column1: じゃあ、みなさん、グラスを持ってください。
今日は来てくれてありがとうございます。では、乾杯！
column2: Thank you all for coming today. Cheers!

column1: じゃあ、授業を、始めましょう。
教科書の138ページを開いて下さい。
column2: Please open your textbooks to page 138.

column1: アレキサンドラさん、まず例文を読んでもらえますか。
column2: Alexandra-san, could you read the sample sentence please?

column1: 天気予報によると、明日は雨だそうです。だから、･･･
column2: According to the weather report, apparently it will rain tomorrow. So please take your...

column1: だから、傘を持って、出かけて下さい。
column2: So please take your umbrella with you when you go out.

column1: はい、ありがとうございます。漢字が少し難しいですね。
アレキサンドラさんは、どうやって漢字を勉強していますか。
column2: The kanji was a bit tough, wasn't it?

column1: えっと、私は…漢字を見ます。何回も見ます。
column2: Alexandra, how do you study kanji?

column1: なるほど。アレキサンドラさんは、何度も見て、覚えるそうです。
column2: Well, I... look at them. I look at them over and over.
I see. So apparently, Alexandra remembers kanji by looking at them over and over.

column1: 僕は、10回ずつ漢字をノートに写して、覚えます。
あと、中国人の友達は、何度も声に出して読むそうです。
column2: I remember them by copying each kanji ten times in my notebook. :And a Chinese friend of mine says he reads them out loud over and over.

column1: 色々な勉強の仕方がありますね。
column2: Well, it looks like there are lots of ways to study kanji, aren't there.

column1: 先生は、韓国語と日本語の通訳をしている友達がいます。
column2: I have a friend who does Japanese and Korean interpretation.

column1: その人は日本語の本をたくさん読んで、漢字を覚えたそうですよ。
column2: They say they studied kanji by reading a lot of books in Japanese.

column1: fermented soybeans with a very strong smell
to be built, to be constructed
to be into, to be hooked on
高橋先生！お疲れ様です。
ああ、金城先生。お疲れ様です。
先生は、お昼休み、外に食べに行きますか？
column2: Are you going out to eat for your lunch break?

column1: あ、決めてなかったけど。。。
そういえば、生徒が、近くにすし屋ができたって言ってたんですけど、試してみませんか。
column2: but say, that reminds me, a student said that a new sushi shop is opening up nearby. Would you like to go try it out?

column1: いいですね！行きましょう。
うーん。やっぱり、寿司はうまい。しかも、この値段は安い。
column2: Mmm. This sushi is great! Plus, it's cheap!

column1: 味も値段も良いので、はまりますね。
column2: The flavor and the price are both great so it's hard to resist!

column1: ところで、最近の生徒は、日本食が好きだと思いませんか。
column2: By the way, have you noticed that your students are really into Japanese food recently?

column1: そうですね。生徒のアレキサンドラさんは、ラーメン屋の常連だって言っていましたよ。
column2: Yeah, you're right. Alexandra-san was saying that she's a regular at the ramen shop.

column1: あと、焼き鳥も生徒達に人気があるそうです。
column2: Also, yakitori seems to be quite popular among the students.

column1: そういえば、この前、生徒に嫌いな日本食があるか聞いたんですよ。
column2: Speaking of which, the other day I asked my students if there were any Japanese foods that they didn't like.

column1: みんな納豆が嫌いだそうです。
シェリフさんが「納豆は足のにおいです」って言っていましたよ。（笑）
column2: Sheriff said that natto smells like feet (laughs).

column1: 実は、私も納豆が食べられないんですよ。
column2: Actually, I don't like natto myself.

column1: to work for, to serve, to fill a post;V2
to be popular, to be attractive to the opposite sex;V2
会社に勤めている方は、お昼に何を食べていますか。
column2: To those of you who work at an office, what do you eat for lunch?

column1: 最近、巷ではお弁当を持ってくる「弁当男子」が流行っているようです。
column2: In recent society, it appears that the trend of bento boys, or men who bring a bento lunch to work, is catching on.

column1: 三浦アナウンサーが、レポートにいっています。三浦サーン。
column2: Mrs. Miura is reporting on location. Mrs. Miura!

column1: はいはーい。今、私は赤坂のイノベイティブランゲージのオフィスに来ています。
column2: Yes, I'm here on location at the Innovative Language office in Akasaka.

column1: あ、早速、美味しそうなお弁当を食べている男性達を発見しました。
column2: Oh, and right away I see a group of men eating bento.

column1: すみませーん。お弁当、美味しそうですね。そのお弁当は、自分で作ったんですか？
column2: Excuse me for interrupting! Those bento look delicious! Did you make them yourselves?

column1: はい。・・・子供が生まれて、来月から、・・・お小遣いが下がりそうなので・・・。
column2: Yes...My child was born and so starting next month... it looks like my allowance will be taking a dive...

column1: 確かに、節約できそうですね。お隣の方は？
column2: Well it definitely seems like you could save money this way. And how about the person next to you?

column1: 環境を考えて、お弁当を作っています。
column2: I make my own lunch out of consideration for the environment.

column1: なるほどー。あと、料理ができる男性は、もてそうですよね。
column2: I see! And, I hear that men who can cook are quite popular with the ladies, is that right?

column1: はい、実はそれが１番大きな理由なんです・・・。
column2: Yes, that's actually my biggest reason...

column1: 弁当男子には、さまざまなメリットがありそうですね。
column2: Well, it looks like there are a lot of benefits to being a bento boy,

column1: この流行はこれからも続きそうです。
column2: and it looks like this trend will continue on into the future.

column1: Kill two birds with one stone
以前、この番組で「弁当男子」について特集しました。
column2: We previously ran a feature segment on Bento Men.

column1: 最近は、「水筒男子」が流行っているそうです。
column2: Recently, it looks like the trend of Thermos Bottle Men is catching on.

column1: ゲストのお二人は知っていますか。
column2: To our two guests - do you know of this trend?

column1: 会社に自分の飲み物を水筒に入れて、持ってくる人ですよね。
column2: It refers to men who bring their own Thermos bottle to the office, right?

column1: 聞いた事ないですな。日本の男性も変わりましたな。
column2: I've never heard of that. Japanese men sure have changed.

column1: アンケートの調査結果を見てみましょう。
column2: Let's take a look at the results of this questionnaire.

column1: なんと、２０代男性の会社員の約半数が、マイドリンクを持って来ているそうです。
column2: Apparently, around half of all male office workers in their twenties take their own drink with them.

column1: 理由は、「節約のため」が一番多かったそうです。
column2: Saving money was the most common reason cited.

column1: 毎日ペットボトルの飲み物を買わないでいいですから、一ヶ月3000円くらい節約できそうですね。
column2: You don't have to buy a drink in a plastic bottle every day, so apparently you can save three thousand a month this way.
After all, we ARE in a recession, so.

column1: 私は、水筒を持っていくのはできないな。恥ずかしい。
column2: I wouldn't be able to carry a Thermos bottle with me.

column1: また、環境のために持ってきている人もいるそうです。
節約とエコで、一石二鳥ですね。
column2: It seems that some people also carry them as a way to help the environment.

column1: そういえば、「弁当女子」「水筒女子」とは言わないのは、何でなんでしょうね。
column2: You can save money and it's eco-friendly so it's like killing two birds with one stone.

column1: こら、ポチ！吠えちゃだめ。すみません。
column2: No, Pochi! No barking! I'm sorry.

column1: （あ、この人、めちゃくちゃ綺麗な人だな。）
column2: (Oh wow, this person is really pretty.)

column1: あ、大丈夫ですよ。かわいい洋服を着ていますね。トイプードルですか。
column2: Oh, don't worry, it's fine! Your dog is wearing such cute clothes! Is it a toy poodle?

column1: そうです。そちらこそ、スカートを履かせて、可愛いですね。名前は何と言うんですか。
column2: That's right! Your dog is also cute wearing a skirt. What's her name?
Her name's Maria. My Mom says that Chihuahuas are sensitive to the cold, so she always makes her wear clothes.

column1: 母が「チワワは寒がりだから」って言って、洋服を身につけさせているんです。
column2: It's also good for preventing shedding, apparently.

column1: ああ、抜け毛の防止にもなるそうですね。
column2: Oh really? My Mom is something else; she makes Maria listen to classical music and makes her sing along to it.
Wow, that's quite something! Right now, I'm making Pochi learn some tricks. I want to make him learn how to ride a unicycle and spin plates.

column1: すごいんですよ。母は、マリアにクラシックを聞かせたり、音楽にあわせて、歌わせたりしているんですよ。
column2: Wow, you're making him learn how to do that?!

column1: へー。すごいですね。僕は今、ポチに芸を覚えさせているんですよ。
column2: Hey, I'm thinking of going to that dog café over there and getting Pochi a bite to eat. Would you like to come along?

column1: 一輪車に乗らせて、皿を回させたいんです。
to be conscious of, to be aware;V3
to be worried, to be troubled
to force a smile, to give an embarrased smile, to laugh nervously
みなさん、こんばんは。ＤＪマキコです。
column2: Good evening, everyone! DJ Makiko here.

column1: 今晩も、エイサクさんと一緒に、お送りします「ニッポン101」の時間です。
column2: It's now time for Nippon 101, brought to you by Eisaku and me.

column1: では、早速ですが、今日の質問を紹介します。
column2: Without further ado, I'd like to share today's question.

column1: 高校２年生、ペンネーム「おっちょこちょい」さんから来ています。
column2: It's from a second year high school student who calls himself Scatterbrain.

column1: こんばんは、おっちょこちょいくん。
実は、今クラスに好きな子がいます。
column2: He writes, You see, there's a girl I like in my class.

column1: どうしたら、彼女に僕の気持ちを気付かせることができるか、それから、どうしたら、彼女を笑わせることができるのか悩んでいます。アドバイスお願いします！
column2: I want to know what I can do to make her laugh, and I'm also wondering about how to let her know how I feel. Please give me some advice.

column1: 最初の答えは、簡単だ。「すきだ」って言えばいい。笑わせるのは難しい。。。
column2: Well the first answer is easy. Just say you like her. Making her laugh might be tough…

column1: そうだ！駄洒落はどう？例えば「ニューヨークで入浴する」。
column2: Oh, I know! How about saying some puns? Like, Taking a bath, nyūyoku, in New York, Nyūyōku!

column1: ・・・きっと、彼女を苦笑いさせてしまいますね。
column2: That'll only make her laugh in embarrassment.

column1: やっぱり、無理やり笑わせようとするのは、よくないか。
column2: I guess it's not a good idea to try too hard to make her laugh.

column1: あまり意識しすぎないで、色々な機会に話しかけてみることはどうですか。
column2: Don't think too hard about it. Why don't you just try to find lots of different opportunities to talk to her?

column1: 彼女のことを知らないと、喜ばせることはできませんからね。
column2: If you don't know anything about her, you can't really make her happy.

column1: to satisfy oneself, to accept a situation
小学校の一部が「子どもが作る弁当の日」を実践しています。
column2: A group of elementary schools are holding a Kids Make Their Own Lunch Day.

column1: 今日は、この弁当の日の新聞記事を読んで、３人のグループで話し合ってください。
column2: Today, please read this newspaper article about Lunch Day, and discuss it in groups of three.

column1: 「弁当の日」についてどう思う？
column2: What do you think about Lunch Day?

column1: 私は、賛成。子どもに自分でお弁当を年に5回作らせるんでしょ。
column2: I agree with it. They make kids put together their own lunch five times a year, right? By doing so, I think it makes the kids really think about the importance of nutritional balance.

column1: そうしたら、子どもに栄養バランスの大事さを考えさせることができると思う。
column2: That's true. But according to this article, it looks like there are some complaints and opposing opinions from the parents. Making kids put together their own lunch can be dangerous, and every family's home situation is different, so wouldn't it be a bit tough?

column1: そうだね。でも、この記事によると、保護者から、苦情や不満が出ていて、反対意見もあるみたいだね。
column2: Yeah, but I think they should just explain the advantages of Lunch Day to make the parents feel at ease. If they show them examples of other schools that have had success with this, they should be able to convince the parents. Anyway, I think it's really important to create an opportunity for kids to think about what they eat.

column1: to be taken care of; V1
「なるべく、留学生には、日本語を話させてあげてください。留学生には日本の普通の生活を体験させてあげてください。」って先生は言ってたけど、
column2: The teacher was saying, Please let your exchange student speak in Japanese as much as possible, and please let them experience typical Japanese life,

column1: 本当に特別なことをしなくても大丈夫かしら。
column2: but do we really not have to do anything special?

column1: 去年、太一はジョー君の家に泊まらせてもらったり、おいしいタイの家庭料理を食べさせてもらって、本当にお世話になったみたいだから、俺達もジョー君を楽しませてあげたいよな。
column2: Last year, Taichi got to stay at Joe's house, and they let him try some homemade Thai food and did a lot for him, so I also want to let Joe have a nice time.

column1: あ、明日は、ジョー君に銭湯を体験させてあげようかな。
column2: Oh, maybe tomorrow, I'll let Joe experience what a public bath is like.

column1: でも、タイには銭湯がないから、嫌がるかもよ。
column2: But they don't have public baths in Thailand so he might not like the idea.

column1: そうかー。とにかく、リラックスさせてあげないとね。
column2: Oh, right…well, anyway, we have to make sure he feels relaxed.

column1: 遅いわね。何かあったのかなぁ・・・。
column2: It's getting late. I wonder if something happened.

column1: あ、来た来た。いらっしゃーい。ジョー君！
あ、はじめまして。ジョーと申します。遅くなってすみません・・・
column2: Oh, nice to meet you! My name's Joe. I'm sorry I'm late.

column1: あ、あのー。すみませんが、電話使わせてくれますか？
column2: Um, excuse me, but would you let me use the phone?

column1: タクシーの中に、荷物全部忘れてきたんです！！
column2: I left all of my luggage in the taxi!

column1: to have a hard time, to be in trouble
to look up, to search for
愛、どうしたの？相談があるって。
column2: What's up, Ai? You said you had something to talk about.

column1: 実は、サークルに好きな人ができて。
column2: Well, actually, there's someone I like in the club I'm in.

column1: え？本当？どんな感じの人？
column2: Oh? Really? What are they like?

column1: それが、B型の人なの・・・。
column2: That's the thing; he's a blood type B person. Like, there are a lot of blood type B people who are kind of odd, right? And plus, he has a lot of female friends. What can I do to get him to like me?

column1: ほら、B型の人って変わった人が多いでしょ。それに、彼、女友達が多いみたいだし・・・
column2: Hmm…so he's a blood type B person. By the way, my blood type is B, too. Did you know that?

column1: どうしたら、私のこと好きになってもらえるかな・・・。
column2: Huh? So, if you're the same blood type, then you must understand how blood type B people feel, right?

Don't ask such stupid things! If you could understand everything based on blood type, you wouldn't be having this much trouble. (laughs) But, it'd be interesting if you looked it up on the Internet. It'd give you something to talk about. If you looked at message boards, you'd probably be able to get a lot of different opinions.

column1: ちなみに、わたしもB型なんだよ。知ってた？
column2: Blood type B men like unique, artistic women. B-type men like to be free, so if you try and put restraints on them, you will get on their bad side.

column1: ええ？じゃあ、さくら、同じ血液型だったら、Ｂ型の人の気持ちも分かるでしょ？
column2: Hmm…that's true. If someone were to try to control me, I don't think I'd like it.

column1: バカなこと聞かないでよ。血液型で全部わかったら、苦労しないよ。（笑）
column2: I've got it! I'll just become a unique woman!

column1: でも、ネットで検索したら面白いんじゃない。
to mistake something for something else
ねえねえ、愛。最近彼とどうなった？
column2: Hey, Ai. Whatever happened with that guy recently?

column1: 彼の気持ちがわからない。彼、気分屋だし・・・。
column2: I don't know how he feels. He's pretty moody.

column1: 何？この本。『Ｂ型自分の説明書』。おおー。
column2: What? What's this book? An Instruction Manual for Your Type-B Self. Whoa!

column1: これ読むと、彼の気持ちがわかるかもよ。
column2: If you read this, you might be able to understand how he feels.

column1: あ、つ、つ、翼君！ひさしぶり。ははは。
column2: Ah, Ts-Ts-Tsubasa! Long time, no see, ha ha!

column1: どうしたの？い、今から授業？
column2: What's up? Y-You have class now?

column1: そうそう。たまには、授業に出ないと、卒業できないからね。
column2: Yeah. 'Cause If you don't show up to class every once in awhile, you can't graduate, sooo...

column1: あ、その本、今すごい人気だよねー。あれ？愛ちゃんはＢ型？
column2: Oh, those books are really popular right now, huh! Wait, Ai, are you a Type-B person?

column1: （小さい声で）ねぇねぇ、愛、この人？
column2: Hey, Ai, is this the guy?

column1: へー。B型は変わっているって言われるとうれしい。・・・へー。
column2: Wow, it says that Type-B people like to be called strange or unusual. Hmm...

column1: や、やっぱりさ、翼君も、個性的だね・・・って言われるとうれしいの？
column2: S-So, I guess you like to be called unique, too, Tsubasa?

column1: え？俺？別に。ていうか、俺、O型だし。
column2: Huh? Me? Not really. I mean, I'm Type-O anyway.

column1: ああ、よく間違えられるけど、O型。
column2: Yeah, I always get mistaken for it, but I'm Type-O.

column1: しかも、俺、占い絶対信じないし。
column2: Besides, I don't even believe in that kind of stuff.

column1: to look up, to search (in a dictionary)
to shine, to glitter, to light up; V1
to be surprised, to be astonished; class 1 verb
はい、今日ご紹介するのは、こちら！シャポーから発売されている電子辞書です！
column2: Hello, and today I'll be introducing this! An electronic dictionary from Sharpo!

column1: 電子辞書は「学習」「旅行」「日常生活」「ビジネス」の場面でとても役に立ちます。
column2: An electronic dictionary is extremely useful for study, for travel, for your daily life, and for business.

column1: ご家族、お友達、近所の人、まだ持っていない人が周りにいたら、是非プレゼントしてあげてください。
column2: If there's anyone close to you - a family member, a friend, a neighbor - who still doesn't have one, please give them one as a present!

column1: では、機能の説明をします。まず、大きな画面。
column2: And now I'll explain about the functions. First of all, we have the large screen.

column1: そして、このボタンを押すと、バックライトが光ります。
column2: And now if we press this button, the backlight comes on.

column1: 漢字の読み方がわからなかったら、ペンで、ここに、漢字を書きます。
column2: If you don't know the reading of a kanji, you write it here with the pen.

column1: 漢字を書くと、辞書が引けます。
column2: When you input the kanji, the dictionary searches for it.

column1: はい、この素晴らしい内容で、お値段はなんと、消費税込み24800円。
column2: And yet with all this incredible technology, the price is an amazing 24,800 yen, tax inclusive!

column1: まだ驚いたら、だめですよ。送料無料。
column2: But wait! That's not all! Shipping is free!

column1: そして、今日中に電話で注文すると、5000円引き。
column2: And what's more, if you order today, you'll receive a 5,000 yen discount!

column1: ということで、お値段は、19800円。19800円です。
column2: So taking the discount into account, the price is 19,800 yen. That's 19,800 yen.

column1: さらにさらに、2つ買うと、電子辞書がもう一つもらえます。どうですか！
column2: AND FURTHERMORE! If you buy two electronic dictionaries, you'll receive a third one free! How about it?!

column1: to be concerned about, to be interested in
お嬢さん、悩みがあるんじゃないですか。
column2: Young lady, you're worried about something, aren't you?

column1: 手相占いをしませんか。
column2: Won't you have your palm read?

column1: ええ？悩みがあるって、どうしてわかったの？
column2: Huh? How did you know I'm worried about something?

column1: 顔を見ればわかりますよ。そこに、すわりなさい。
column2: I can tell by looking at your face. Please sit there.

column1: 悩みは結婚とお仕事ですか？
column2: Are your worries about marriage and work?

column1: ええ？なんで、結婚と仕事で悩んでいるって、わかったんですか？
column2: Huh? How did you know I'm worried about marriage and work?

column1: 女性だと、一番気になることですよね。じゃあ、手を見せてください。
column2: They're the number one things that women worry about. All right, show me your hand.

column1: （ふむふむ）あなた、仕事で成功できたら、結婚はしないで良いと思っていますよね。
column2: (Hmm, hmm...) You think that if you're successful at work, then you don't need to get married, don't you?

column1: 自分より、年収が高くて、頭がよくて、仕事ができる男性がいれば、結婚したいですよ。
column2: If I find a man who earns a higher salary than me and is more clever and better at his job than I am, then I'd want to get married.

column1: そんなことを言っていると、一生独身ですよ。
column2: If you say that sort of thing, you'll be single your whole life.

column1: あ、いや・・・待ってください・・・あなた、結婚できますよ。
column2: Ah, wait a moment... You will get married.

column1: 間違いなく理想の相手と出会います。
column2: No doubt about it. You will meet your ideal man.

column1: よかったー。いつですか。
column2: Thank goodness! When will that be?
For the time being, I'll have a beer.

column1: あれ、康平。お前、今日車で来たんじゃなかったっけ？
column2: Hey, Kōhei, didn't you come by car today?

column1: ちょっと飲むだけなら、大丈夫だよ。
column2: If it's just a little alcohol, there's no problem.

column1: 最近、取り締まり厳しいし、罰金高いんだから。
column2: Recently there's been a crackdown as well as an expensive fine.

column1: おれが通る道なら、警察いないはずだから、捕まらないよ。
column2: On the roads I take, there shouldn't be any police, so I won't get caught.

column1: 捕まらないなら、良いってことじゃないんだよ。
column2: It's not a case of it's fine as long as you don't get caught.

column1: お酒が入っていると、判断も鈍くなるんだぞ。
column2: When you drink, your sense of judgment gets slower.

column1: もし、交通事故を起こしたら、どうするんだよ。一生を棒に振るぞ。
column2: What would you do if you had an accident? You'd be throwing away your life.

column1: すみませーん、ウーロン茶お願いします。
column2: Excuse me, I'll have an oolong tea, please.

column1: じゃあ、お疲れー。またねー。
column2: It was fun, guys. See ya.

column1: はい、止まってください。
『飲んだら乗るな。乗るなら飲むな。』。飲酒運転の取締りを強化しています。
column2: If you drink, don't drive. If you're driving, don't drink. We are cracking down on drunken driving.

column1: はい、息をはいてください。
はい、大丈夫ですねー。どうぞ。
『飲んだら乗るな。乗るなら飲むな。』ね。
column2: If you drink, don't drive. If you're driving, don't drink!

column1: to sign up for, to apply for
すみません、イタリアローマ旅行のプランを探しているんですけど・・・
column2: Yes, excuse me, I'm looking for a package trip to Rome, Italy.

column1: こちらは、どうでしょう。
期間限定の激安プランです。
column2: This is an extremely cheap limited-time plan.

column1: 4月と5月限定かー。それに、航空券とホテルだけのセットなんですね。
column2: Limited to April and May, huh...Plus it only includes airfare and hotel.

column1: 本当にお手ごろな値段ですね。
column2: It really is quite a deal, isn't it.

column1: 世界遺産を巡るオプショナルツアーをつけても、いいと思いますよ。
column2: I think it'd be a good idea to add the optional World Heritage Site tour to it.

column1: あー、オプションはいらないです。
column2: Ah, I don't need any optional stuff.

column1: そうですか。ま、オプショナルツアーに参加しなくても、十分楽しめますからね。
column2: I see. Well, even if you don't participate in an optional tour, you can still have a lot of fun.

column1: 出発日は決まってますか？
ええっと、５月２日がいいんですが。
column2: Umm, I'd like to leave on May second...

column1: 申し訳ありません、その日は既に予約がいっぱいでして・・・
column2: I'm very sorry, that day is already booked solid...

column1: じゃあ、4月30日の出発は空いていますか。
column2: Well, are there any openings for flights leaving on April thirtieth?
Does the fare stay the same?

column1: はい、いつ出発しても、同じ値段です。
column2: Yes, the fare stays the same no matter when you leave.

column1: その金額に燃油サーチャージは含まれていますか？
column2: Is the fuel surcharge included in this fare?

column1: はい。燃油サーチャージと空港施設使用料を含めて、この価格です。
column2: Yes. This is the price with the fuel surcharge and airport landing fee included.

column1: 本当にお得なんですね。
column2: It really is a good deal.

column1: じゃ、このプランで申し込みます。
column2: Okay, I'll go with this plan.

column1: ありがとうございます。
to cool down, to get cold
to be placed on, to be piled on
「安いのにおいしい、B級グルメ」を今日も、皆さんに紹介していきたいと思います。
column2: Today I'd like to introduce you all to cheap but good B-level gourmet food!

column1: 今日紹介する、B級グルメは「焼きそば」。そう！秋田県、横手の　ご当地グルメです。
column2: The B-level gourmet food we're going to introduce today is yakisoba—fried noodles! That's right! This is the local specialty of Yokote, in the Akita prefecture.

column1: では、レポートを見てみましょう。
column2: Now then, let's take a look at the report.

column1: わたしは今、「じゅうじゅう、ごくり、焼きそばの街」横手　にきていまーす。
column2: I am now in the city of Yokote, known as the city of sizzling good yakisoba.

column1: では、早速お店に入ってみます。
column2: Without further ado, let's head into the restaurant!

column1: うわー。平日なのに、満席ですね。
column2: Wow! Even though it's a weekday, it's packed!!

column1: あのぉ、焼きそばください。
column2: Excuse me, I'll take some yakisoba, please.

column1: はい、これが、本場の横手やきそば。うまいよ。
column2: Here you go, the real Yokote yakisoba. It's great!

column1: うーん。ソースがいいにおい！焼きそばの上に、目玉焼きが載っているんですね。
column2: Mmm... the sauce smells wonderful! And there's a fried egg on top of the yakisoba.

column1: そう。それが、横手焼きそばの特徴。
column2: That's right. That's the signature characteristic of Yokote yakisoba.
Eat up before it gets cold!

column1: はい。いただきまーす。うーん。辛いのに、優しい味。
column2: Okay! Let's eat! Mmm! Even though it's spicy, it's got a nice, gentle flavor.

column1: あ、これは、半熟卵のおかげですね。
column2: Ah, this is because of the half-done egg, I see.

column1: そう。それだけの量があるのに、たった500円だよ。
column2: Right. Even though you get this much, it's a mere five hundred yen!

column1: こんなにおいしくて、すごいボリュームがあるのに、この値段！
column2: Even though it's so delicious and you get so much of it...what a price!

column1: まさに、B級グルメの王様ですね！
column2: This is definitely the king of B-level gourmet food!

column1: to be in a haste, to rush
おっす！ん、目の下にくまがあるじゃん？どうしたんだよ？
column2: Hey, what's up? Hmm, you've got dark circles under your eyes! What happened to you?

column1: え？ほんと？フアー。（あくび）
実は、最近眠れないんだ。
ああ、不眠症ってやつかな。フアー。
ゴールデンウィークが終わってから、全然やる気も出ないんだよね。
column2: Ever since Golden Week ended, I haven't had any motivation whatsoever.

column1: あ、おれも！朝全然起きられないし、一日中だるいんだよな。
column2: Oh, me too! I can't get up in the morning at all, and I feel so sluggish all day.

column1: こんにちは。どうした？二人とも、眠そうな顔して。
column2: Hello there! What's wrong? You both look so sleepy. (laughs)

column1: 今、「最近なんだかだるくて・・・」という話をしていたところだったんですよ。
column2: We were just talking about how we've been feeling so sluggish lately.

column1: あー、それは五月病じゃないですか。
column2: Ahh, isn't it that May Sickness?

column1: そう。大学一年の四月は、新しいことばかりで、毎日緊張するでしょう。
column2: Yeah. For freshman, April is full of new things, so you feel a bit nervous every day, right?

column1: で、その疲れが、５月の連休の後に、一気に出てきたんだよ。
column2: Then, after the long vacation in May, all of that fatigue just came out at once.

column1: どうしたら・・・いいんですか。
新しい環境に慣れるのは、難しいんだから、あせる必要はないよ。
column2: Well, it's tough getting used to a new environment, so there's no need to get impatient.

column1: はい！ありがとうございます！
あ、そうそう。僕、五月病についての本を書いているから、本屋で買ってね。
column2: Oh, I almost forgot. I've written a book about May Sickness. Pick it up at the bookstore, okay?

column1: to be the talk of the town
私は、今、ILL料理教室にきています。
column2: I am currently at the ILL Cooking School.

column1: 今日は、最近話題になっている、「料理合コン」についてレポートします。
column2: Today, I'd like to report on cooking matchmaking parties, which have become a hot topic lately.

column1: では、ILL料理教室の講師森光先生にお話しを聞いてみましょう。
column2: Now, let's ask ILL Cooking School instructor Ms. Hikari Mori more about them.

column1: 先生よろしくお願いします。
column2: Ms. Mori, thank you for your time!

column1: よろしくお願いします。
先生、「料理合コン」というのは・・・
column2: Ms. Mori, what exactly is a cooking match-making party?

column1: 料理教室での合コン・・・
column2: A matchmaking party that takes place at a cooking school.

column1: つまり、初対面の男女のグループが料理を一緒にして、知り合うことができるパーティーです。
column2: In other words, a party where men and women who are meeting for the first time cook something together and get to know one another.

column1: 料理合コンの魅力は、何でしょうか。
column2: What's the appeal of these cooking matchmaking parties?

column1: まず、料理の勉強になります。
column2: First of all, you can learn how to cook.

column1: そして、料理合コンで知り合ったカップルは長く続くと言われています。
column2: Also, they say that couples that meet at these cooking parties stay together for a long time.

column1: そうなんですかー。どうして関係が続きやすいんですか。
column2: Really, is that so? Why is it so easy for them to continue the relationship?

column1: 一緒に料理を作るので、相手の性格がわかりやすいんです。
column2: It's really easy to understand your partner's personality because you are cooking together.

column1: 共通の話題があって、話も弾みますし。
column2: You have something to talk about, and so the conversation is really lively.

column1: 参加者の中には、「結婚後の生活が想像しやすい」って言う人もいるんですよ。
column2: Among those who've participated, there are some who say that they can easily envision what their life would be like after marriage.

column1: 料理が習えて、最高のパートナーも見つけられるんですね。
column2: So you learn how to cook, and you can also find a great partner!

column1: まさに、良いことだらけ！いいなー。私も参加したーい。
column2: It's a win-win situation! How nice…I want to try it out too!

column1: to hold something between two things
to move something out of the way
すみませーん、わたくし、赤坂新聞の者なんですが・・・
column2: Excuse me, I'm from The Akasaka Newspaper...

column1: え・・（心の声-宅配便じゃないじゃん！どうしよう。うち新聞いらないし。）
column2: Uh... (He's not a deliveryman! What do I do...? I don't need the newspaper.)

column1: 新聞を購読しませんか。
column2: Would you like to subscribe to the newspaper?

column1: あー、申し訳ないんですけど、もう間に合っていますので、大丈夫です。
column2: Oh, I'm really sorry, but I'm already getting the newspaper, so it's okay...

column1: （心の声-あー！あー！この人、ドアに足を挟んでる！）
column2: (Ah! His foot is holding the door!)

column1: いま、契約すると、景品が付きますよ。
column2: If you sign up now, we'll throw in some free gifts.

column1: 洗剤5箱、商品券3000円分、そして、ディズニーランドのパスポートを差し上げます。
column2: Five boxes of detergent, a three thousand yen gift certificate, and a Disneyland passport.

column1: 私、来年の4月には引っ越しするんですけど・・・
では、引っ越すまで、新聞を購読しませんか？
column2: Well then, won't you subscribe until April?
I'm sorry, but no thank you!

column1: ドアを閉めますので、足どかしてください！！！！
column2: I'm closing the door, so please move your foot!

column1: あれ？もしかして・・・赤坂小学校の出身？
column2: Hmm? Are you...a graduate of Akasaka Elementary School?
Excuse me? Ken, is that you?!?

column1: 健ちゃん。。。新聞のセールスしているんだ。
column2: Ken...so you're a newspaper salesman now.

column1: あ・・・うん。学費のためにね。
わかった！じゃ、契約する。
to suffer a loss, to lose
みなさんこんばんは。ＤＪマキコです。
column2: Good evening, everyone. I'm DJ Makiko.

column1: 今日のゲストは　ベストセラー作家の、夏目五郎さんです。よろしくお願いします。
column2: Today's guest is the best-selling author, Goro Natsume. Thank you for joining us.

column1: では、最初の質問を読みますね。
column2: All right, I'll read the first question.

column1: ＤＪマキコさん、夏目先生、こんにちは。

column2: I'm a freshman in high school,

column1: 「数学」や「物理」などの理系の科目は嫌いではないのですが、「国語」が一番好きです。
column2: and while I don't dislike science-related subjects like math and physics, my favorite subject is Japanese.

column1: 将来は、小説家になりたいと思っているので、理系の科目は勉強しなくても良いですか。
column2: In the future, I'd like to become a novelist, so is it okay if I don't study science-related subjects?

column1: 結論を述べます。「絶対に勉強しなさい！」
column2: I'll jump straight to the conclusion. Definitely study them!

column1: そもそも、文系と理系に分ける考え方がおかしいんだ。
column2: It's strange to make the distinction between the arts and the sciences in the first place.

column1: どうして、おかしいんですか。
人間、知識を持っていて、損をすることはないんだよ。
column2: Human beings have nothing to lose having a lot of knowledge.

column1: 例えば、わたしは小説家だけど、SF小説を書くときには理系の知識が必要になる。
column2: For example, I'm a novelist, but when I write a science-fiction novel, I need to have knowledge about science.

column1: 理系の人は社交性がないというイメージもあるみたいですけど。
column2: Also, there's this image that those who study the sciences aren't very social...

column1: くだらない。どうして、そんなステレオタイプにだまされるんだ。
column2: That's ridiculous! Why are you fooled by such stereotypes?

column1: とにかく、しっかりと今は、何でも勉強するように！
column2: Anyway, now is the time to go and study anything and everything!

column1: having room for dessert, dessert stomach
ねえ、ユウキ、この前テレビで「デザート王国」を特集しているのを見たんだけど、行かない？
column2: Hey, Yuki, I saw a special on Dessert Kingdom on TV the other day - want to go check it out?

column1: 「フードテーマパーク」って言うのかな。聞いたことない？
column2: I guess you could call it a food-based theme park. Haven't you heard of it?

column1: 日本各地のおいしいデザートを、食べることができるんだよ。
column2: You can eat yummy desserts from all around Japan.

column1: へー。ホントに、沙織は食べるのが好きだよな。ま、いいよ。週末、行ってみようか。
column2: Wow. You really do love to eat, don't you! Well, that's fine. Let's go on the weekend.

column1: えっと、このチケットで、デザートを２０種類まで食べることができるのね。
column2: Sooo…with this ticket we can eat up to twenty kinds of desserts.

column1: 一人で20種類も食べるのは無理じゃない？
column2: Isn't it impossible for one person to eat twenty kinds of desserts?

column1: １０種類用のチケットを買ったほうが良くない？
column2: Wouldn't it be better to buy the ticket for ten types of desserts?

column1: 大丈夫大丈夫。私は鉄の胃袋の持ち主だから。
column2: It'll be fine! I've got a stomach made of steel.

column1: あ、プリンだ！勇気、食べよう！
column2: Oh hey, they have pudding! Yuki, let's eat!

column1: あーよく食べた。楽しかったねー。
column2: Ahh, I ate a LOT! That was fun, huh?

column1: でも、２０個じゃ、全然足りなかったね。
column2: But you know, twenty kinds just wasn't nearly enough.

column1: （ウップ）え？あ。。。そう？俺、腹が（ゴロゴロゴロ）・・・。うっ。
column2: (burp) Huh? Ah...you think so? My stomach...ugh...

column1: ね、勇気。駅前においしいクレープ屋さんがあるの。クレープ食ベて帰ろう！
column2: Hey, Yuki. There's a really good crepe place in front of the station. Let's get some and go home!

column1: 腹いっぱいだよ。これ以上食べるのは無理。（ウップ）
column2: I'm full! There's no way I can eat any more. (burp)
But there's always room for dessert!

column1: お帰り。どうしたの？元気ないけど。
column2: Welcome back! What's wrong? You look down.

column1: DVDが貸し出し中だったのよ。韓国ドラマ。
column2: The Korean drama DVD I wanted was rented out.

column1: 次のストーリーが気になって気になって、しょうがないのよ。
column2: I've been so curious about the rest of the story!

column1: あの店は、借りられているＤＶＤばかりで、本当に困るわ。
column2: The DVDs at that store are always rented out; I'm at a loss!

column1: だったら、ネットでＤＶＤを借りれば良いじゃない？
column2: Then why don't you rent it online?

column1: お店には置いてない作品もあるって、友達が言ってたよ。
column2: My friend said that they have lots of titles that they don't have at the store.

column1: インターネットで借りられるの？
そうそう。自分が観たいＤＶＤを予約すると、自宅に届くんだって。
column2: Yeah. She says that when you reserve the DVD you want to see, they'll deliver it right to your house.
Really?! And what about when you have to return it?

column1: 見終わったＤＶＤをポストに入れるだけ。
column2: You just slip the DVDs you've finished watching in the mail.

column1: へー便利ね！でも高いんでしょ？
column2: Wow, how convenient! But doesn't it cost a lot?

column1: そんなに高くないと思うよ。ちょっと、調べるね。
column2: I don't think it's that expensive. Let me look it up.

column1: あ、月額2000円で、八枚まで借りることができるって。
column2: Oh, it says for two thousand yen a month, you can rent up to eight DVDs.

column1: お母さんがいつも借りているお店より安いじゃない。
column2: That's cheaper than where I always go to rent DVDs.

column1: 最初の一か月は、ただで、借りることができるって書いてあるよ。
column2: It says here that you can rent DVDs for free for the first month.

column1: すごい。今すぐ、登録して。
column2: That's great! Sign me up right away.

column1: じゃ、私のアメリカのドラマも一緒に借りてね。
column2: Rent some American drama DVDs for me too, then.

column1: ダメよ。自分で借りなさい。
column2: I don't think so. Rent them yourself.

column1: 会社で回転寿司を食べられるという噂を聞いたのですが、本当なのでしょうか。
column2: I've heard rumors that say that you can eat conveyor-belt sushi at the office - but is it really true?

column1: 今日は、ここの会社に回転寿司が来ていると聞いたのですが。
column2: I've heard that today, they have conveyor-belt sushi at this very office.

column1: すごい！！オフィスの中で、お寿司が回っています！
column2: Wow! There is sushi making its way around the office!

column1: らっしゃい！ようこそ、出張回転寿司へ！
column2: Welcome to the traveling conveyor-belt sushi shop!

column1: 出張回転寿司？この機械は、持ってきたんですか。
column2: Traveling conveyor-belt sushi shop? You mean, you brought this device here?

column1: そうだよ。基本料金は2万。
column2: That's right. The basic fee is twenty thousand yen.

column1: それに食べた分の料金を加算するシステムだよ。
column2: It's a system where the fee for what's eaten is added on.

column1: そして、なんと、お寿司1皿は、普通の回転寿司とは、変わらない値段！
column2: And, what's more, the price of one plate of sushi doesn't change from that of regular conveyor belt sushi.

column1: 機械をセットアップする代金と、板前さんに来てもらう代金が２万円。
column2: So it's a charge of twenty thousand yen to have the device set up and to have you come.

column1: あとは、お寿司を食べた料金を払えば良いんですね。
column2: After that, you just pay for the sushi that you eat, right?

column1: それは、お手ごろですね！
どうして、出張回転寿司を始めたんですか？
column2: Why did you decide to start this traveling conveyor-belt sushi service?

column1: 自宅や会社で回転寿司を楽しみたいという意見があってね。
column2: A lot of people said they wanted to enjoy conveyor-belt sushi at home and work.

column1: 会社やイベントだけでなく、人がたくさん集まるホームパーティーなどでも、お勧めですね！
column2: I'd recommend it not only for the office and events, but also things like home parties where a lot of people gather as well!

column1: to become thin, to lose weight
久しぶりー。あれー？真由ちゃん、やせたー？
column2: Hey, long time no see...hm? Mayu, have you lost weight?

column1: あ、分かる？少し細くなったでしょ。
column2: Oh, you can tell? I'm a bit slimmer, aren't I?

column1: 実は、ダイエットしているんだー。
そうなんだー！何してるの？
column2: Really? What kind of diet are you doing?

column1: フルーツダイエット。すごく簡単だよ。
column2: A fruit diet. It's really easy.

column1: 毎朝、果物をたべるようにするだけ。
column2: I just make sure to eat fruit every morning.

column1: へー！いつ頃からはじめたの？
column2: Wow! When did you start it?

column1: 肌もきれいになったんじゃない？
column2: Your skin has gotten clearer too, hasn't it?

column1: いいなぁ・・・。私も頑張ろうっと。
column2: Lucky...I've got to work hard too.

column1: うん。実はウォーキングダイエットを始めたの。
column2: Yeah. I've started a walking diet.
Wow, that sounds really good for your health.

column1: 毎朝、公園を歩くようにしているの。
column2: I'm making an effort to walk through the park every morning.

column1: それから、夕飯も早い時間に食べるようにしているんだ。
column2: I'm also making an effort to eat dinner at an earlier time.

column1: へー。でも、毎朝歩くのは、大変でしょ。えらいねぇ。
column2: Oh yeah? But it must be tough to go walking every morning. Good for you.

column1: あたし歩くの好きだから、大丈夫。でも・・・
column2: It's fine because I love to go walking. But...

column1: ウォーキング始めてから太ったんだよね。
column2: I've gained weight since I've started going walking!

column1: 運動すると、お腹がすごい空くから、ご飯をたくさん食べるようになって・・・。
column2: When I exercise, I get really hungry, and I've started eating a lot...

column1: それに、夕飯の時間が早いから、夜10時にはお腹ぺこぺこなの。
column2: And plus, my dinnertime is early, so by ten at night I'm starving!

column1: だから、夜食を食べるようになって・・・。三キロくらい太った。
column2: So I've started eating late night snacks...I've gained three kilos!

column1: (food) to deep fry in hot oil
はい、今日ご紹介する新製品は、こちら！
column2: Okay! Today, the product we'll be introducing is this!

column1: シャーポの電子レンジ「ヘルカロ」です！
column2: A microwave called Herukaro from Sharpo!

column1: 大変人気の商品ですね。
column2: This is an extremely popular item!

column1: そうです！塩と油の量を減らすことができるので、とても健康に良いんです。
column2: That's right! With it, you can reduce the amount of salt and oil in your food, so it's very good for your health.

column1: たとえば、から揚げを作りましょう。
column2: As an example, let's make some fried chicken.

column1: このヘルカロは余分な油を落とします。
column2: This Herukaro model takes away any excess oil.

column1: 見えますか？油が落ちていますよね。
column2: Can you see? The oil is dripping down.

column1: うわー、本当ですね。ぽたぽた落ちてる・・・。
column2: Wow, you're right! It's dripping right down.

column1: このように、ヘルシーにから揚げを揚げることもできるんです。
column2: You can make healthy fried chicken just like this! Here you are.

column1: はい、どうぞ。食べてください。
（もぐもぐ）おいしい！ヘルシーなのに、おいしく揚がるんですね。
column2: (munch munch) It's good! Even though it's healthy, it's fried in a way that makes it delicious!

column1: そうなんですよー。しかも、この「ヘルカロ」はビタミンなども壊しません。
column2: That's right. And what's more, this Herukaro does not break down any of the vitamins!

column1: 栄養素がこわれないのは素晴らしいですね。
column2: That's wonderful that the nutrients stay intact.

column1: さらに！温めた料理のカロリーは、自動で表示されます。
column2: And that's not all! The number of calories in the food that's been heated up is automatically displayed!

column1: それは、便利な機能ですね！さすが、「ヘルカロ」！
column2: That's quite a convenient feature! Just as we'd expect from Herukaro!
And how about the price everyone wants to know about?
This time we have another surprising price!

column1: なんと、39800円！どうでしょう！
to do business, to open(a shop)
美香に会うのは、卒業以来だよな。どう？仕事は慣れた？
column2: I haven't seen you since graduation! How's work? Have you gotten used to it?

column1: うん、まあまあかなー。最近やっと慣れてきた感じ。
column2: Yeah, it's going all right I guess. Recently I feel like I've finally settled in.

column1: そうかー、おれもようやく仕事の流れがわかってきたよ。
column2: Oh yeah? I've also finally got the hang of how things work.

column1: 美香は、化粧品会社で働いているんだよね？
column2: You're working at a cosmetics company, right?

column1: そう。うちの会社、女性が多いから、社員食堂のメニューの横にはカロリーが書いてあるんだ。
column2: Yeah. There are a lot of women in the company, so they've got the calorie count written next to the menu items in the company cafeteria.

column1: 美容と健康のために、野菜をたくさん使ったメニューもたくさんあって、結構おいしいんだ。
column2: They have a lot of menu items that use vegetables for beauty and health, and they're pretty good!

column1: 女の人が多いとそうなんだね。
column2: I guess that's how it goes when there are a lot of women.

column1: あと、健康をチェックするためのコーナーもあるんだよー。
column2: Oh, and there's also a corner where you can do health checkups.

column1: 克夫の会社も社員食堂あるでしょ？
column2: Your company also has a cafeteria, right?

column1: あるある。うちの社員食堂、無料なんだ。
column2: Yeah, it does. Our company cafeteria is free.

column1: そう。すごいだろ？社員のために、って社長が決めたんだって。
column2: Yeah, isn't that something? The president made the decision, saying it was for the sake of the employees.

column1: 良いなー。お財布に優しいね。
column2: How nice...that's easy on the wallet.

column1: うん。でも、節約のためだけじゃなくて、働こうっていう気持ちが強くなるよ。
column2: Yeah. But it's not only for the benefit of saving money—we feel more motivated to work.

column1: しかも、会社に長く残っている人のために、夜も営業してるんだ。
column2: They're even open at night for those who stay late at the office.

column1: うらやましい！今度、こっそり食べに行きたい！
column2: I'm so jealous! I want to sneak in and go eat there next time!

column1: 今日は、ラーメンに詳しい、岩上さんと一緒に、最近話題になっているユニークなラーメン屋さんにいってみようと思います。
column2: Today, I'd like to visit a much-talked-about, unique ramen shop with Mr. Iwagami, who knows a lot about ramen.

column1: 岩上さん、よろしくお願いします。
column2: Mr. Iwagami, thank you for joining us.

column1: 今回紹介したいラーメン店はこちらの「一番★」（いちばんぼし）です。
column2: The ramen shop I'd like to introduce today is this one here, Ichiban boshi. (The first star)

column1: では、早速入ってみましょう。
（ガラガラガラ）まず最初に、この機械にお金を入れて、食券を買います。
column2: (door slides open) First, you put your money into this machine and buy a meal ticket.

column1: おや？カウンターのそれぞれ席の両脇に仕切りと、前にのれんがありますねー。
column2: Oh? There are partitions on the sides of the counter seats, as well as short split curtains hanging in front.

column1: この仕切りは、お客さんにラーメンの味に集中してもらうために作ってあります。
column2: These partitions were made so that the customer can focus on the taste of the ramen.

column1: このカウンター席に座ると、両脇も前も見えませんからね。
column2: When you sit at these counter seats, you can't see anything on either side of you or in front of you.

column1: あと、このシステムがあるため、女性のお客さんも多いんです。
column2: Because they have this kind of system, they get a lot of female customers.

column1: ああ、一人ではラーメン屋さんに入りにくい・・・と感じる女性は多いですからね。
column2: Ah, since there are a lot of women who feel that it's not easy to go into a ramen restaurant alone.

column1: それから、このお店のラーメンのスープはトンコツ味なんですが・・・はい、オーダー用紙と鉛筆。
column2: Also, the soup they use here for the ramen is tonkotsu flavor... Here you go, an order form and pencil.

column1: ん？このオーダー用紙に自分で書いて、注文するんですか？
column2: Hm? You place your order by writing it yourself on this order form?

column1: そうです。自分の食べたい味になるように、味を選ぶんです。
column2: Yes. You choose the flavor so that you get the one you want to have.

column1: オーダー用紙に書いてある項目にマルをしてください。
column2: Please circle the ones you want on the order form.

column1: へー。じゃ、わたしは・・・・スープは...こってり。（マルをする音）麺はかため・・・
column2: Wow. Okay, for me...for the soup, heavy...(circles) Noodles, somewhat hard...

column1: みなさん、こんばんは。DJマキコです。
column2: Good evening, everyone! I'm DJ Makiko.

column1: 今日は、推理小説家、東五郎先生に先生の新作「ダイングメッセージ」についてお話を伺いたいと思います。
column2: Today, I'd like to ask mystery writer Goro Azuma about his latest work, Dying Message.

column1: 先生よろしくお願いします。
column2: Mr. Azuma, thanks for joining us.

column1: はい。この小説は、「ダイングメッセージ」で犯人がわかったところから、物語が始まります。
column2: Sure. In this novel, the story starts from the part where we find out who the criminal is through a dying message.

column1: 「ある宝石店の店主が殺された。当然、鍵は閉めてあった。
column2: The owner of a jewelry shop has been murdered. Naturally, the doors were locked.

column1: 店の床には、ダイアモンドが何個も落ちていた。
column2: Several diamonds were scattered on the floor of the shop.

column1: 店主はダイアモンドをひとつ握っていたが、お店の宝石や現金は一つも盗まれていなかった。
column2: The owner had one diamond in his hand, but neither a single piece of jewelry nor any money whatsoever was taken from the shop.

column1: 警察は店主に恨みを持った者が犯人であると考え、野田節子、中村幸子、斉藤順子の3人が怪しいと考えた。
column2: The police believed that the criminal was someone who held a grudge against the owner and found three people, Setsuko Noda, Sachiko Nakamura, and Junko Saito, to be suspicious.

column1: 一人の刑事が、容疑者の誕生日を調べた。
column2: One of the detectives looked up the birthdays of the suspects.

column1: 野田は3月生まれ、中村は4月生まれで、斉藤は12月生まれである。」
column2: Ms. Noda was born in March, Ms. Nakamura was born in April, and Ms. Saito was born in December.

column1: おおお、簡単に犯人が分かりましたね。私にも犯人がだれか分かります。
column2: Ohh, they easily learned who the criminal was. I also know who it was.

column1: そして、そこから、犯人の悲しい人生、殺された店主の恐ろしい過去がわかっていく・・・という物語です。
column2: And then, from there, you learn about the sad life of the criminal and the terrible past of the owner who was murdered...that's the story.

column1: では、ここでコマーシャルが入ります。
General in Age of Civil War
みなさんは、「歴女」という言葉を聞いた事はありますか？
column2: Everyone, have you ever heard the word rekijo?

column1: 「歴史が好きな女の人」を短くして、「歴女」ですが、今回は、そんな「歴女」さん、山田花さんのお家を訪問したいと思います。
column2: Rekijo is made by shortening the phrase girls ('joshi') who like history ('rekishi'). This time, I'd like to visit the house of Ms. Yamada, who is one of those rekijo.

column1: こんにちは、よろしくお願いします。
おっと、ものすごい数のプラモデルが飾ってありますね。
column2: Wow, you've got a large number of plastic models on display!

column1: はい。これは、戦国武将のプラモデルなんです。
column2: Yes. These are plastic models of feudal warlords.

column1: おおお、本棚は、さすがに歴史関係の本ばかりですね。
column2: Ohh, and as expected, your bookshelf is filled with history-related books.

column1: これは年代順に並べてあるんですね？
column2: It looks like they are in chronological order?

column1: はい。これが、私の歴史ファイルです。
column2: Yes. And this is my history file.

column1: 集めた資料をファイルしておくんです。
column2: I file away documents I've collected.

column1: あと、休日に訪れたお城の写真も入れておきますね。
column2: I also put in pictures of castles I've visited on my days off.

column1: これを眺めるのが好きなんですよー。
column2: I just love looking at them!

column1: すごいですねー。ところで、どうして歴史が好きになったんですか？
column2: That's quite something! By the way, how did you come to like history?

column1: うーん。前に付き合っていた彼氏が、歴史のゲームをしているのを見て、面白そうだな・・・と思ったのが、きっかけです。
column2: Hmm...I got into it after seeing my ex-boyfriend play historical video games, and I thought they looked interesting.

column1: 気付いたら、彼氏よりも歴史の方が好きになっていましたが・・・ははは・・・。
column2: Before I knew it, I came to like history more than my boyfriend...ha ha ha...

column1: to feel at ease, to relax
a doll that children make to pray for fine weather
今日は、午後から雨の予報ですので、傘を忘れないでください。
column2: The forecast for today calls for rain in the afternoon, so don't forget your umbrella.

column1: また、今週一杯は、雨が続くようです。
column2: Also, it looks like the rain will continue all week.
Oh, no. It's going to rain?

column1: なーんだ。公園でお弁当食べたかったのにー。
column2: Aww, I wanted to eat lunch in the park...

column1: そうね。じゃあ、プランを変更する？
column2: Yeah. Should we change our plans?

column1: いや、大丈夫。公園に行けば、晴れるから。
column2: Nah, it'll be fine. When we go to the park, it'll clear up.

column1: そうだ。お父さんは、晴れ男なんだよ。
column2: Yup. I'm a fair-weather man, you know.

column1: お父さんが、大事なイベントで、外に出かけるときは、雨が降らないんだよ。
column2: When I go out to an important event, it doesn't rain.

column1: そういう人を「晴れ男」「晴れ女」って言うんだ。
column2: Those kinds of people are called fair-weather men and fair-weather women.

column1: そう言っても・・・外を見てよ。雨が降りそう。
column2: But even so...look outside. It looks like it's going to rain.

column1: そんなことを言っているから、雨が降っちゃうんだよ。
column2: It rains because you keep saying things like that!

column1: 予報も言っているし。今日は、家でのんびりしない？
column2: That's what the forecast says too. Why don't we just take it easy at home today?
Aww, I want to go outside.

column1: 昨日、照る照る坊主つくったの。だから、雨降らないよ。
column2: I made a doll for good weather yesterday. So it won't rain!

column1: 晴れ男と照る照る坊主で、鬼に金棒だろう？
column2: A fair-weather man AND a doll for good weather...that's unbeatable, don't you think?

column1: どうして、そんなに嫌なんだよ？
column2: Why don't you like the idea?
Well, actually, I'm a rain woman (it rains wherever I go).

column1: そうか、雨女だったのか･･･。それは、困ったな。
column2: Oh, so you're a rain woman…that makes things tough.

column1: もー、お外行こうよぉー。
column2: Come on, let's go outside already!

column1: みなさん、こんばんは。DJマキコです。
column2: Good evening, everyone, I'm DJ Makiko.

column1: 今日のゲストは、脳科学者の酒井教授です。先生、よろしくお願いします。
column2: Today's guest is brain scientist Professor Sakai. Thank you joining us, Professor!

column1: よろしくお願いします。
では、リスナーからの質問です。
column2: Now, a question from a listener.

column1: 「こんにちは。私には小学校一年生の息子がいます。
column2: Hello. I have a son who is in the first grade of elementary school.

column1: 息子は、左手で字を書いたり、箸を持ったりします。」
column2: My son uses his left hand to write, hold chopsticks, and more.

column1: おお、左利きの息子さんですね。いいじゃないですか。
column2: Ohh, a left-handed son! Isn't that great.

column1: 「最近、息子が、学校で先生に「右手を使いなさい」と、言われたようです。
column2: It seems as if my son was told by his teacher to use his right hand.

column1: 息子は右手に変えたくないらしいのですが、どうしたらいいでしょうか。」
column2: It appears that my son doesn't want to switch to his right hand. What should I do?

column1: 先生、これはどうなんでしょう？
column2: Professor, what do you make of this?

column1: 直す必要はありません。利き手を無理に変えるのは、脳の発達によくないです。
column2: There is no need to fix this. Changing one's dominant hand is not good for brain development.

column1: あ、そういえば、芸術家は左利きが多いらしいですね。
column2: Oh, come to think of it, apparently a lot of artists are left-handed, aren't they?

column1: そうですね。ダビンチやミケランジェロも左利きだったようです。
column2: That's right. Apparently DaVinci and Michelangelo were also left-handed.

column1: また、利き手を変えるのは、大変なストレスがたまるようです。
column2: Also, it seems that changing one's dominant hand builds up a lot of stress.

column1: ですので、息子さんが左利きのままで良いように、学校と相談するのが良いと思います。
column2: Therefore, I think it would be a good idea to consult with the school and tell them that he is fine as a lefty.

column1: そうですね。それが一番良さそうですね。
column2: Right, that seems like the best thing to do.

column1: 先生、今日はありがとうございました。
column2: Professor, thank you for your time today!

column1: to take, to receive, to undergo
うーん。もうちょっと・・・。
ヤベ！今日はカフェのバイトの面接だった！
column2: Oh no! I have an interview for the part-time job at the cafe today!

column1: 何だよー。この道、工事中？ふざけんなよ・・・。
column2: Aw, what? This road is under construction? Give me a break... Oh! I forgot that if you turn left here, you can get to the place! The interview's at one, isn't it? It's twelve-fifty right now, so I'll make it just in time.

column1: あ！ここを左に曲がって行けばお店に行けるんだった！
column2: (door opens) Um, excuse me. My name is Okada. I'm here for an interview...

column1: 面接は１時からだったよな。今５０分だから、ギリギリ間に合うな。
column2: Ah, so you're the one with the interview. Come right this way.

column1: あの、すみません。岡田と申します。面接を受けに来たのですが・・・。
あ、面接の方ですね。じゃ、こちらへどうぞ。
column2: Please have a seat. I'm the manager, Kataoka. Nice to meet you.

column1: どうぞ、座ってください。
column2: Soo...your name was Kenji Okada, right?

column1: 私は、店長の片岡です。よろしく。
よろしくお願いします。
column2: I looked at the resume you sent us earlier—you had experience working at a restaurant before, right?

column1: ええっと・・・岡田健二君だったね。
column2: Yes, I worked as a waiter. I also made drinks and desserts and other things.
Hmmm. You're a university student, right?

column1: この前送ってくれた、履歴書を見たんだけど、前にも、レストランで働いていた事があるんだったね。
はい。ウェイターをしてました。あと、飲み物やデザートを作ったりもしていました。
column2: Can you work late at night?

column1: ふーん。岡田君は大学生だったね。
column2: I believe you're open until twelve at night, am I right?
The shop is open until twelve, but the staff stays until one.
Sure, that's fine. But the hourly rate goes up a little at night, doesn't it?

column1: 夜は、１２時まででしたよね。
column2: Hahaha, you're pretty well-grounded! That's right. The rate goes up a bit. So will you be able to come in starting next week?

column1: 店は、１２時までだけど、スタッフは１時までだね。
why?, how?, what for?, how come?
to commute, to attend, to go back and forth;V1
to wake someone, to cause, to raise;V1
yikes! (young persons' slang); uh oh; terrible; amazing Adj(i)
うーん。え？8時？（バタバタバタバタ）
column2: Uhh. Huh? Eight o' clock? (rushing around)

column1: もう！お母さん、何で起こしてくれなかったの？
column2: Gah! Mum, why didn't you wake me up?
I woke you up countless times.

column1: 私の名前は野沢菜味。田畑高校に通っている高校二年生。
column2: My name is Nami Nozawa. I'm a second-year high school student at Tabata High School.

column1: やめてよ。「野沢」か、「菜味」って呼んでって何度も言っているでしょう。
column2: Stop it. I've told you however many times to either call me Nozawa or Nami, haven't I?
Hurry it up - we're gonna be late.

column1: 彼はうちの近所に住んでいる那須実。同じ田畑高校二年生。
column2: He's Minoru Nasu, and he lives near us. He's also a second-year at Tabata High School.

column1: 口も頭も悪いけど、実の弾くピアノはすごい。
column2: He has a foul mouth and he's not that smart, but he's great at playing the piano.

column1: 実のお母さんは、ピアノの先生で家にピアノが三台もある。
column2: Minoru's mother is a piano teacher, and they have THREE pianos at his house.

column1: ねぇ、実、冬休みの前に出た宿題、終わった？
column2: Hey, Minoru, did you finish the homework we got before winter break?

column1: 本を十冊読んで、レポートを百枚書く宿題。
column2: The homework was to read ten books and write a one-hundred page report.

column1: to be pleased with, to suit, to like;V1
to understand, to grasp, to know;V1
あけましておめでとう。
今年もよろしくね、桜子。ハワイはどうだった。
column2: Best wishes for this year too, Sakurako. How was Hawaii?

column1: 大葉さん、ハワイ 行ったの？
column2: Ms. Ōba, you went to Hawaii?

column1: うん。五泊七日で 行ってきた。おばあちゃんが 住んでいるんだ。
column2: Yeah. I went for seven days and five nights. My granny lives there, you know.

column1: はい、これお土産。気に入るかどうか わからないけど。
column2: Here, I have a souvenir for you. I don't know whether or not you'll like it, though.

column1: ありがとう！開けてもいい？
ブレスレット！かわいい！二本も？いいの？
column2: Bracelets! They're so cute! And there's two? Really?

column1: 似合うかどうか・・・。
column2: But whether or not they'll look good on you...

column1: 大葉さん、俺のお土産は？
column2: Ms. Ōba, what about my souvenir?

column1: あるよ。甘いものが好きかどうかわからなかったけど、チョコ買ったんだ。
column2: I have one for you. I didn't know whether or not you like sweet things, but I bought you some chocolate.

column1: はい、座って。あけましておめでとう。
column2: All right, sit down. Happy New Year.

column1: 先生からお年玉があります。
column2: I have a New Year's gift for you all.

column1: みんなが休み中に勉強したかどうか知りたいので今からテストをします。
column2: I want to know whether or not you all studied during the holidays, so we're going to have a test now.

column1: 問題用紙は全部で五枚。テスト時間は30分。
column2: There are five sheets of questions. The time for the test is thirty minutes.

column1: to play, to hang out; V1
counter for small to medium-sized animals
to go and visit (a friend), to go out to play, to go out (at night);V1
What!, exclamation to express disappointment or blame
ねぇねぇ、今から、家に 遊びに 来ない？家族が 一匹 増えたんだ。
column2: Hey, hey, why don't you come to my house now? My family has grown by one animal, you know.

column1: そう。その家族は これ。ジャーン！この写真が なにか わかる？
column2: Right! And that family member is...this! Ta-da! Do you know what this photo is of?

column1: ワンちゃんだ！ねぇ、実も 桜子の 家に 遊びに行こうよ。
column2: It's a doggy! Hey, Minoru, let's both go to Sakurako's house!

column1: う…ん。行きたいんだけど…。ちょっと…今 何時か わかる？
column2: Mmmm... I want to go, but... Um... Do you know what time it is now?

column1: やべ。ちょっと 先生に 話が あるんだ。あとで大葉さんの 家に 行くよ。
column2: Uh-oh. I have to talk to the teacher about something. I'll come to Ms. Ōba's house later.

column1: 家が どこか わかる？学校の 前の 白い家だよ。
column2: Do you know where my house is? It's the white house in front of the school.

column1: ああ、あの家ね。わかった。
野沢さん、実、どこに行ったか知ってる？
column2: Ms. Nozawa, do you know where Minoru went?

column1: 先生と 話があるって 言ってたよ。どんな話か 知らないけど。
column2: He said he had to talk to the teacher about something. I don't know what it was about, though.

column1: ああ、宿題 忘れたから、謝りにいったんだよ。多分。
column2: Oh, he forgot his homework, so he's probably gone to apologize.

column1: to forgive, to permit, to allow;V1
いいなぁ。やっぱり、犬、欲しいなぁ。
column2: Lucky... I definitely want a dog.
What does he weigh, about one kilogram?
Yeah. He's about eight hundred grams at the moment.

column1: 何才かわからないの。捨て犬だったんだ。
column2: I don't know how old he is. He was abandoned.

column1: 寒がっていたし、かわいそうだから、拾って来たんだ。
column2: He looked cold and I felt sorry for him, so I picked him up and brought him home.

column1: この犬・・・足、どうしたの？痛そう。
column2: This dog...what's wrong with his leg? It looks sore.

column1: 痛がっているんだよね。明日、獣医さんに連れて行くんだ。
column2: He looks like he's in pain, doesn't he? I'm taking him to the vet tomorrow.

column1: 犬を捨てる無責任な人がいるんだ…。許せない。
column2: There are irresponsible people out there who would abandon a dog. It's unforgivable.
Oh, he wants to go outside.

column1: 違うよ。えさを欲しがっているんだよ。
みなさん、いらっしゃい。

column2: Here you are, tea and cake.

column1: どうぞ、お構いなく。（グー）あ・・・。
column2: Please don't trouble yourself. (stomach rumbling) Ah...

column1: 遠慮しないでいいのよ。若いんだから。
column2: Go on, you don't have to be polite. You're young!

column1: すみません。じゃ、遠慮なくいただきます。
column2: Thank you. All right, I'll help myself.

column1: greengrocer, vegetable shop, seller of vegetables
あ、野沢さん？八百屋さんで アルバイト？
column2: Oh, Ms. Nozawa? You work part-time at the greengrocer's?

column1: あ、うちの親、八百屋を してるんです。
column2: Ah, my parents run the greengrocer's.

column1: はい。重いもの 運ばなきゃいけないから、体 痛くなっちゃうし、お金も もらえないし、ほんと、やに なりますよ。
column2: Yes. I have to lift and carry heavy things, so my muscles hurt, and I don't get any money for it, so I really get fed up.
So Mr. Momoya, what are you buying?

column1: 今日は…キャベツは 2割引、なすと玉ねぎは 半額っすよ。
column2: Today, cabbages are twenty percent off, and aubergines and onions are half-price.

column1: じゃ、なすと 玉ねぎと キャベツ、ちょうだい。
column2: All right, please give me cabbage, aubergines, and onions.

column1: キャベツ、4分の１しか　いらないんだけど…。
column2: I only need a quarter of a cabbage, though...

column1: あ、いいっすよ。切ります。
column2: Oh, that's fine. I'll cut it.

column1: えっと…。120＋100＋25＝245。で、消費税が5パーセントだから…。
column2: Um... 120 plus 100 plus 25 is 245, and consumption tax is 5 percent, so...

column1: to raise, to keep (as a pet); V1
by nature, by birth, native, congenitally
to search for, to look for;V1
visiting ill or otherwise troubled people, get-well gifts
to trip over, to fall over; V1
先生、栗林君は休みですか？
ああ、道場に行くときに、転んで足を折ったそうだ。
column2: Yeah, it seems like when went to the martial arts hall, he tripped and broke his leg.

column1: ええ？転んで腰を打った？痛そう。
column2: Huh? He tripped and hit his hip? That's got to hurt.

column1: なあ、聞いたか？うわさによると、栗林、道場に行ったときに、腰を折ったみたいだぞ。
column2: Hey, did you hear? There's a rumor that when Kuribayashi went to the martial arts hall, he broke his hip.

column1: ええ？大変！授業が終わってからみんなでお見舞いに行こうよ。
column2: What? Yikes! Let's all go see him together after class is over.

column1: お見舞いに行く前に、お花を買わない？
column2: Should we buy some flowers when we go to visit him?

column1: じゃ、この赤い花がいいよ。栗林、赤が好きだし。
column2: Okay, then let's go with these red flowers. Kuribayashi likes red.

column1: お見舞いに行く時、赤い花を持っていっちゃいけないって聞いた事がある。
column2: I've heard that you're not supposed to take red flowers when you go visit someone in the hospital.

column1: へー。じゃ、他の色にしよう。
column2: Really? Then let's go with a different color.

column1: こんにちは。これ、お見舞い。
column2: Hello! This is a get-well gift for you.

column1: 空手の練習中に腰を折ったって…。
column2: We heard that you broke your hip during karate practice...

column1: 僕は、「道場に行くときに、転んで足を打った」って言ったんだけど…。
column2: But I said that on the way to the martial arts hall, I tripped and hit my leg...

column1: to mix, to stir, to blend;V2
in the first place, originally, from the start
２０分位前に、ペパロニピザを3枚注文した野沢ですけど...まだですか。
column2: This is Nozawa. Twenty minutes ago I ordered three pepperoni pizzas... are they ready yet?

column1: 申し訳ございません。今作っているところなので、もう少しお待ちください。
column2: I'm very sorry. We're in the middle of making them, so please wait a little while longer.

column1: 店長、ピザできましたか？
今、レシピ本を読んだところなんだ。
今から生地を作るところだから、もう少し時間がかかるなぁ。
column2: I'm just about to make the dough now, so it'll still take a while.

column1: さてと、小麦粉300gとお湯200ccを混ぜて・・・。
column2: All right, so...mix together three hundred grams of flour and two hundred cubic centimeters (cc) of water...

column1: ところで、店長、ペパロ二って何ですか。
column2: By the way, Manager, what's pepperoni?
Something related to macaroni, I think.

column1: さすが店長。でも、初めてピザの注文が来ましたね。
column2: Manager, I'm impressed! But...this is the first time we've gotten a pizza order, isn't it.

column1: そうだな、そもそも、うちはそば屋だからな。
column2: Yeah, you're right... Well, we ARE originally a soba shop, so...

column1: あ、もしもし？あ、すみません。今、お店を出たところなんです。もう少しお待ちください。
column2: Yes, hello? Oh, I'm sorry. They've just left the shop. Please wait a little while longer.

column1: to be annoyed, to give up, to be beaten
to be popular, to be attractive to the opposite sex;V2
to meet by chance, to come across, to happen to encounter;V1
那須実さん。出会ったばかりで、まだ あなたのことを よく 知らないけど、超タイプです。
column2: Mr. Minoru Nasu. We've just met, and I don't know you very well, but you're just my type.

column1: 実君を 見るたび、胸が どきどきするの。大好き。私と 付き合って。
column2: Whenever I see you, my heart pounds. I love you! Will you go out with me?

column1: 高校に 入学して以来、ずっと 那須君のことが 好きでした。私と 結婚してください。
column2: I've liked you ever since I entered high school. Marry me, please!

column1: 実のことが 大好き。
あなたのことを 愛しています
ムニャムニャ・・・・。もてる男は つらいなぁ。でへへへへ。参ったなぁー。
column2: (mumbling in his sleep) It's tough being popular~ te he he. What do I do?

column1: ねぇ、「図書館で みんなで 一緒に 勉強しよう」って誘った人は 誰だった？
column2: Hey, who's the one who invited everyone to study together in the library?

column1: 実だね。でも・・・来たとたん 寝ちゃったね。
column2: Oh, that was Minoru. But...the moment we got here, he fell asleep.

column1: いい夢 見ているんでしょう。笑いながら 寝てる。
column2: He must be having a good dream. He's smiling in his sleep!

column1: ここは日光東照宮です。
column2: This is the Nikko Toshogu Shrine.

column1: これは1636年に徳川家光によって完成されました。
column2: It was completed in 1636 by Tokugawa Iemitsu.

column1: 「左甚五郎によって作られた」と言われています。
column2: It is said that it was made by Hidari Jingoro.

column1: 見てください。ネコの裏には、スズメが彫られています。
column2: Please look. There are sparrows engraved behind the cat.

column1: 普通、スズメはネコに食べられてしまいますよね。
column2: Normally, the sparrows would be eaten up by the cat, wouldn't they?

column1: でもすぐそこにスズメがいるのに、ネコはスズメを食べないで眠っていますね。
column2: But even though the sparrows are right beside it, the cat doesn't eat them but sleeps on.

column1: これは「平和な世界が徳川幕府によって作られた」という意味だと言われています。
column2: It is said that this symbolizes the idea of the Tokugawa Shogunate having created a peaceful world.

column1: では、今から一時間、お昼休憩をとりましょう。
column2: All right, let's have a one-hour lunch break now.

column1: 集合時間は1時半。集合場所はバス。いいですか？
column2: Gathering time is one-thirty p.m. The gathering place is at the bus. Does everyone understand?

column1: 特に、那須君、野沢さん、遅刻をしないでください。
column2: Especially you, Mr. Nasu, Miss Nozawa—please don't be late.

column1: prophetic dream, dream that comes true
この前、たくさんの女の子たちに好かれる夢を見たんだ。正夢かな。
column2: A while ago, I had a dream where loads of girls were in love with me. I wonder whether it was a prophetic dream.

column1: 実は幸せだな・・・。僕、今週、本当についてなかったよ。
column2: It's all right for you, Minoru... This week really wasn`t my week.

column1: 月曜、犬にほえられて、転んで足を打ったし・・・。
column2: On Monday a dog barked at me, and I tripped and hit my leg...

column1: 犬にほえられたから転んだのか？でも、かまれなくてよかったじゃん。
column2: So you tripped because a dog barked at you? But at least you weren't bitten, right?

column1: まあね。で、火曜に、お気に入りのジーンズを 親に 洗われたんだ。
column2: I guess. So then on Tuesday, my mom went and washed my favorite jeans.

column1: え？ジーンズ 洗わないの？
column2: Huh? You don't wash your jeans?

column1: 洗わないよ。あれ、ビンテージジーンズで 高かったんだよ。
column2: No! They're vintage, and they were expensive!

column1: ・・・っていうか、親が 洗濯してくれるんだ。
column2: ...That aside, your mom does your laundry for you?

column1: いいなぁ。うちの親、洗濯してくれないよ。
column2: That must be nice. My mom doesn't do my laundry for me.

column1: ふーん。それから、水曜日は道場で先輩に顔をけられて、口の中を切っちゃったし。
column2: Really... And then, on Wednesday at the dojo, I was kicked in the face by my senpai, and I cut the inside of my mouth.

column1: 昨日の遠足は、雨に降られたし、全く、ついてないよ。
column2: And then yesterday's class trip was rained out. I really have no luck.

column1: book report, written description of one's thoughts
to stand, to stand up; V1
那須実の母です。先生、質問があるのですが。
column2: I'm Minoru Nasu's mother. Teacher, I have a question.
Could she be a monster parent?

column1: この学校では生徒に掃除させているんですか。
column2: At this school, do you make the students do the cleaning?

column1: ええ、そうですよ。教室やトイレ、庭を掃除させます。
column2: Yes, we do. We make them clean the classrooms, the toilets, and the garden.

column1: 生徒達にたくさん本を読ませるそうですね。
column2: It seems as if you make the students read a lot of books.

column1: はい。その後で、感想文も書かせます。
column2: Yes. Afterward, we get them to write book reports.

column1: 生徒に君が代を歌わせると聞きましたが、それは本当ですか。
column2: I heard that you make the students sing (the Japanese national anthem) Kimi ga Yo; is that true?

column1: ええ。立たせて国歌を歌わせますよ。生徒に国歌を覚えさせるためです。…
column2: Yes. We make them stand up and sing the national anthem. It's to get them to remember the national anthem...

column1: お母さん、うちの学校は私立ですからね。もし嫌だったら、公立に行かせてください。
column2: Madam, our school is a private school. If you don't like it, please send your child to a public school.

column1: いえいえ。気に入りました。今後もうちの息子をよろしくお願いします。
column2: No, no. I like it. Please keep teaching our child!

column1: 先生、これ、つまらないものですが、どうぞ。
column2: Teacher, this is just a little thing, but please accept it.
All right, if you'll excuse me.

column1: to be surprised, to be astonished;V1
どうして泣いてるの？桜子。
こら、実。女の子を泣かせるな。何したのよ。
column2: Hey, Minoru. Don't make girls cry! What did you do?

column1: 泣かせたつもりはないんだけど。
column2: I didn't mean to make her cry.

column1: 違う、違う…。菜味、心配させてごめん。でも、実君が笑わせるから…。
column2: No, no... Nami, I'm sorry I made you worry. It's just that Minoru makes me laugh...

column1: 笑わせたつもりもないんだけど。
column2: I didn't mean to make her laugh, either.

column1: なんだ、笑ってたの？驚かせないでよ。
column2: What, so you were laughing? Don't surprise me like that.

column1: 昨日、兄貴の床屋に髪を切りに行ったんだ。
column2: Well, I went to get my hair cut at my older brother's barbershop yesterday.

column1: ああ、お兄さん、床屋さんだよね。
column2: Oh, your older brother's a barber, isn't he.

column1: 最初は楽しく話していたんだけど、野球の話を始めて、怒らせちゃったんだ。
column2: At first we were having a fun conversation, but then we started talking about baseball, and I made him angry.

column1: ほら、俺はジャイアンツファンだけど、兄貴はタイガースファンだから。
column2: Because I'm a Giants fan, you know, but my older brother's a Tigers fan.

column1: 今年、ジャイアンツ調子いいけど、タイガースは調子悪いからね。
column2: This year the Giants are in good form, but the Tigers aren't doing so well, are they?

column1: ああ。で、丸刈りにされて、眉毛もそられた。
column2: Yeah. So then he went and gave me a buzz cut and shaved my eyebrows off too.

column1: to put on shoes, socks, lower body clothing
こんにちは。近森渡の「ちょこっとマナー」の時間です。
column2: Hello. It's time for Wataru Chikamori's A Little Bit of Etiquette!

column1: マナー講師の持田かね先生に色々教えてもらいましょう。
column2: We're going to have etiquette teacher Kane Mochida teach us about a few different things.

column1: よろしくお願いいたします。
まず、ある高校生からの質問を 読ませてください。
column2: Firstly, please allow me to read a question from a high school student.

column1: 「親せきのお葬式に行きます。
column2: I'm going to the funeral of a relative.

column1: 制服はつまらないので、黒いミニスカートを履こうと思っています。
column2: My school uniform's boring, so I'm thinking about wearing a black miniskirt.

column1: どう思いますか。意見を聞かせてください。」
column2: What do you think? Please let me know your opinion.

column1: じゃ、質問させてください。
column2: All right, let me ask you a question.

column1: どうしてミニスカートを履きたいんですか。
column2: Why do you want to wear a miniskirt?

column1: ちょっと、言わせてください。
column2: Let me just say this, please.

column1: お葬式はファッションショーじゃないんです。喪服を着なさい。
column2: A funeral is not a fashion show. Wear mourning attire, please.

column1: あ、先生、この人は高校生みたいです。
column2: Um, Ms. Mochida, it seems that this person is a high school student.

column1: じゃ、制服が一番いいと思いますよ。
column2: Well then, I think a school uniform would be best.

column1: on this occasion, at this time, now
condolence gift, gift of money brought to a funeral
the other day, a few days ago
definitely, absolutely, at any cost, unconditionally; Adv.
近森渡のちょこっとマナーの時間です。
column2: It's time for Wataru Chikamori's A Little Bit of Etiquette.

column1: 今日も持田かね先生が皆さんの質問に答えてくれますよ。
column2: Again today we have teacher Kane Mochida answering your questions.
So this is the first question.

column1: 「私は留学生です。私の教授はとても親切で、大学でアルバイトさせてくれたり、おいしい料理を食べさせてくれたりします。
column2: I'm an exchange student. My professor is very kind and lets me do part-time work at the university, gives me nice food to eat, and so on.

column1: 先日、先生が飼っていたイグアナが死んだので、お葬式に行くつもりです。
column2: The other day, the iguana that my teacher kept as a pet died, so I'm planning on going to its funeral.

column1: うーん。人間の葬式ではないので香典は必要ないと思いますよ。
column2: Hmm. It's not a funeral for a human being, so I don't think a condolence gift is necessary.

column1: 教授には何と言ったらいいですか？
column2: What should this student say to his professor?

column1: 「この度は、ご愁傷様でした」とか「お悔やみを申し上げます」ですか。
column2: Something like I share your sorrow on this occasion or I'd like to offer my deepest sympathy?

column1: そうですね。「この度は、どうも…」だけでもいいです。
column2: That's right. Simply saying On this occasion... is fine, too.

column1: 「新しいペットを飼った方がいい」とか 絶対に 言ってはいけませんよ。
column2: What you definitely must not say is You should get a new pet!

column1: to get caught, to be arrested; V1
桃屋君、結婚 おめでとう。
結婚式に 出席できなくて、ごめん。
column2: Sorry I couldn't come to the wedding.

column1: 仕事 休めなかったんだ。
column2: I couldn't get the time off work.

column1: これ、お祝い。気に入るかどうかわからないけど。
column2: Here, this is for you. I don't know if you'll like it or not, though.

column1: で、どうだった、結婚式は？
column2: So how was it, the wedding?

column1: うーん。人の前で キスをさせられて、恥ずかしかった。
column2: Yeah...being made to kiss in front of people, that was embarrassing.

column1: ははは。披露宴は どうだった。
column2: Ha ha ha. How was the reception?

column1: ああ。たくさん お酒を 飲ませられたよ。
column2: Yeah. I was made to drink a lot.

column1: 次の日、一日中、気持ち悪くて大変だった。
column2: I felt sick the whole next day. It was really awful.

column1: へぇー。新婚旅行へは もう行ったの？
column2: Really...? And have you already been on your honeymoon?

column1: ああ、北海道に 行ったんだ。楽しかったよ。
column2: Yeah, we went to Hokkaido. It was fun.

column1: でも…。警察に捕まっちゃったんだ。
column2: But...I got caught by the police.

column1: ああ、罰金払わせられた。
column2: Yeah. I was made to pay a fine.

column1: うわー。8万円も払わせられたの？
column2: Whoa! They made you pay as much as eighty thousand yen?

column1: to trick, to cheat, to deceive; V1
to escape, to run away; V2
ニュースです。午後2時半頃、ILLジュエリーから1億円のダイヤが盗まれました。
column2: This is the news. At around two-thirty p.m., a diamond worth one hundred million yen was stolen from ILL Jewelry.

column1: 2時頃、65歳くらいの男性と若い女性のお客様が入ってきました。
