column2: At about two o'clock, two customers, a man aged about sixty-five and a young woman, came in.

column1: 指輪を見に来たと言っていました。
column2: They said they'd come to look at rings.

column1: 突然、男性のカバンから白い煙が出てきたんです。
column2: Suddenly, white smoke started coming out of the man's bag.

column1: 涙がたくさん出てきて、何も見えなくなりました。
column2: Tears were streaming down my face, and I couldn't see anything.

column1: …え？その男性ですか？はい。もちろん、ダイヤを持って逃げていきました。
column2: ...Huh? That man? Yes, of course...he took the diamond and ran off.

column1: 男の人が話しかけてきたんです。
column2: A man came and started talking to me.

column1: ILLジュエリーはどこかと聞かれました。
column2: He asked me where ILL Jewelry was.

column1: 引越してきたばかりで、道がわからないって言っていました。
column2: He said that he had only just moved here and didn't know where anything was.

column1: 娘の指輪を見に行くんだけど、選んでくれませんかって言われたんです。
column2: Then he said to me that he was going to look at rings for his daughter and asked whether I could I pick one out for him.

column1: とてもやさしそうな人だったので、連れてきてあげたんです…。
column2: He seemed like a really nice person, so I brought him to the shop...

column1: 私、だまされたんですか。
great!, amazing!; highest, the best, the most
suddenly, all on a sudden; Adv.
to precipitate, to fall (rain, snow, etc.); V1
こんにちは。天気予報のお時間です。
column2: Good afternoon. It's time for the weather forecast.

column1: 最近、暖かくなってきましたね。
column2: It's become warm recently, hasn't it?

column1: 今日から連休が始まりますが、今日の午後から暑くなってくるでしょう。
column2: The consecutive holidays start from today, and the weather will get hot from this afternoon.

column1: 外に行くとき、帽子を忘れないでくださいね。
column2: When you go outdoors, please don't forget a hat.

column1: うわー。ネズミーランド最高。楽しいね。
column2: Whoa, Mouse Land is great! It's so much fun, isn't it?

column1: うー。急に涼しくなってきた。
column2: Ooh, it just got cool all of a sudden.

column1: 空も暗くなってきた。雨が降りそう･･･。
column2: The sky's gotten dark, too. It looks like it's going to rain...

column1: いてっ！あれ？これ、おたまじゃくし？
column2: Ow! Huh? Is this a tadpole?

column1: ええ？おたまじゃくしが降ってきたの？
今、入ったニュースです。午前11時半ごろ、おたまじゃくしが降りました。
column2: This just in...at around eleven-thirty A.M., it rained tadpoles. At around eleven-thirty A.M., at Tokyo Mouse Land in Chiba prefecture, it appears that it rained thirty tadpoles and two frogs.
And now for the next news item.

column1: ４月１日にZENバーガーが発売した「わびさびバーガー」が人気のようです。
column2: It seems as if Zen Burger's Wabisabi Burger, which went on sale on April 1, is enjoying popularity.

column1: ハンバーガーから、肉、野菜、ピクルスなどの具をすべて抜いたパンだけの大変シンプルなハンバーガーです。
column2: An extremely simple burger, it has no meat, vegetables, pickles, and so on…just bread.

column1: わびさびバーガーを発明したチン・ゲンサイ社長は
column2: Company president Chin Gensai, who came up with the Wabisabi Burger, gave the following comment.

column1: 「今まで30年間ハンバーガーを作ってきた。
column2: I've been making burgers for thirty years.

column1: 肉が嫌いなので、ハンバーガーをおいしいと思ったことはない。
column2: I hate meat, so I've never once thought that burgers were delicious.

column1: もともと、エイプリルフールの冗談としてわびさびバーガーを発売した。
column2: Originally, we put the Wabisabi Burger on sale as an April Fools' joke.

column1: どうして人気が出てきたかわからないが、これからも、面白いハンバーガーを作っていきたい。」
column2: I don't know why it's become popular, but I still want to keep on making interesting hamburgers.

column1: というコメントを発表しました。
column2: Starting next month, Zen Burger is apparently planning to also put on sale Wabisabi Tacos, the Wabisabi Pizza, and Wabisabi Sushi.

column1: to cook, to boil, to simmer;V2
鶏のテリヤキを作りましょう。
材料は、鶏肉１枚、しょうゆ５０cc、酢５０cc、砂糖30グラム。
column2: The ingredients are one piece of chicken, fifty milliliters of soy sauce, fifty millliters of vinegar, and thirty grams of sugar.

column1: 皆さん、材料はありますか。
column2: Everyone, do you have your ingredients?

column1: では、作り始めましょう。
しょうゆと、酢、と　砂糖を混ぜてください。
column2: Please mix together the soy sauce, the vinegar, and the sugar.

column1: ほら、野沢さん、那須君、作り始めてください。
column2: Hey, Miss Nozawa, Mr. Nasu, please start cooking.

column1: 砂糖が溶けるまで、混ぜ続けてくださいね。
column2: Please keep mixing until the sugar dissolves.

column1: 次に、鍋にたれと鶏肉をいれます。
column2: Next, we're going to put the mixture and the chicken in the pan.

column1: それから、火をつけてください。
column2: Then please turn on the heat.

column1: じゃ、火を弱くしてください。10分間煮てください。
column2: Then please turn down the flame. Let it cook for ten minutes, please.

column1: じゃ、ひっくり返して、また10分煮てください。
column2: All right, so turn it over and let it cook for another ten minutes.

column1: 先生、食べ始めても良いですか。
column2: Teacher, is it all right if we start eating it?

column1: 実、もう食べ終わったの？はやいなー。
column2: You've finished eating already? That was fast!

column1: in short, in other words, that is to say, I mean
to be aware (of), to be conscious (of);V3
ここに「常用漢字」についての記事があります。
野沢さん、読んでくれますか。
column2: I have here an article about the standard-use kanji.

column1: はい。「文章を書く時に、常用漢字を意識するかどうか、質問をした。
column2: Miss Nozawa, would you read it for us?

column1: 意識すると答えた人は38%。意識しないと答えた人は約60%であった。」
column2: Yes. We asked the question, when you write something, are you conscious of the standard-use kanji?

column1: ありがとう。つまり、「この漢字は常用漢字かな」と考えながら、漢字を使っている人は少ないんだね。
column2: Thirty-eight percent of respondents answered that they were conscious of the standard-use kanji, while sixty percent answered that they were not.

column1: じゃ、次を大葉さん、お願いします。
column2: Thanks. Basically, there's not many people who use kanji while thinking Hmm, is this character one of the standard-use kanji?
All right, next is Miss Ōba, please.

column1: 「憂鬱(ゆう・うつ）の鬱、語彙（ご・い）の彙、処方箋（しょ・ほう・せん）の箋は、2010年に常用漢字になった。
しかし、3つの漢字が全て書けると答えた人は4%、書けないと答えた人は58%であった。
column2: In 2010, the character 鬱 ('utsu') of 憂鬱 ('yūtsu,' 'depression'), the character 彙 ('i') of 語彙 ('goi,' 'vocabulary') and the character 箋 ('sen') of 処方箋 ('shohōsen,' 'prescription') became standard-use kanji.

column1: これが現実なのであろう。」
column2: However, the percentage of people who answered that they could write all three of these kanji was four percent, while the percentage of those who could not was fifty-eight percent.

column1: 書けない人は俺だけじゃないんだ！
column2: I'm glad. It's not just me who can't write them!

column1: numbered tag or ticket, window ticket
to take, to pick up, to get, to pass;V1
こちらの番号札をお取りになって、お待ちください。
column2: Please take this number ticket and wait.

column1: 三番の番号札をお持ちのお客さま、カウンターへどうぞ。
column2: Would the customer with ticket number three please come to the counter?
Uh, yes. I'm thinking about going with my wife to a hot spring resort this weekend, but can I still make reservations?

column1: 今週末、妻と一緒に温泉に行こうと思っているんですが、まだ予約できますか。
column2: Which hot spring resort are you considering?

column1: どちらの温泉をお考えですか。
column2: I'm not sure what it's called, but it's the Japanese-style inn and hot spring in this photo.

column1: 名前はちょっと分からないんですが、この写真の温泉旅館です。
column2: Ah, this inn is in Akita prefecture. It's summer now, so there won't be any snow, but...

column1: あ、これは秋田県の旅館ですね。今は夏なので、雪はございませんが…。

column2: So it's two people for two days and one night, is that right? Do you smoke?

column1: 二名様、一泊二日ですね。お煙草はお吸いになりますか。
column2: No, we don't. Oh, but my wife has a tattoo on her arm...
Sir, those with tattoos cannot enter hot springs, you know... This inn doesn't have a private outdoor bath, so I think it would be better if you went for another inn. How do you feel about this one?

column1: to spread out, to lay out
counter for floors of a building
桃屋様、客室係の梨本と申します。
column2: Mr. Momoya, my name is Nashimoto, the room steward.

column1: お部屋までご案内いたします。
column2: I will show you to your room.

column1: お荷物お持ちいたします。
では、館内の説明をいたします。
column2: Now, I will explain the layout of the hotel.

column1: こちらは非常口でございます。
お風呂は全て1階にございます。
column2: All of the baths are on the first floor.

column1: ご利用時間は朝4時から、夜12時まででございます。
column2: The bath hours are from four o' clock in the morning until twelve o' clock at night.

column1: 桃屋様のお部屋はこちらでございます。
column2: Mr. and Mrs. Momoya, your room is here.

column1: うわー、いい部屋ですね。
column2: Wow, it's a nice room, isn't it!

column1: 浴衣とタオルはこちらに入っております。
column2: Yukatas and towels are all in here.

column1: ではお茶をお入れいたしますね。
column2: Now I'll put on some tea.

column1: 本日、ご夕食は７時でいかがでしょうか。
column2: Would dinner tonight at seven be acceptable?

column1: では、7時ごろに夕食をお部屋にお運びします。
column2: Very well. I will bring dinner to your room at around seven.

column1: 今からお風呂に行くので、その間に布団を敷いてもらえますか。
column2: We're going to the baths now, so could I ask you to lay out the futons while we're there?

column1: かしこまりました。では、失礼いたします。
to be raised, to grow up ; V1
近森渡のちょこっとマナーのお時間です。
column2: It's time for Wataru Chikamori's 'A Little Bit of Etiquette'.

column1: 持田かね先生、今日もよろしくお願いいたします。
column2: Teacher Kane Mochida, thank you for being with us again today.

column1: 「こんにちは。俺は海外で育ったので、敬語が苦手だ。
column2: Hello. I was brought up abroad, so I'm no good at using polite language.

column1: この前先輩に『手伝ってほしいですか』と言ったら、むっとされた。
column2: The other day, when I said to an older student Do you want me to help?, he got all offended with me.

column1: でも目上の人に「てほしいですか」は使わないほうがいいですね。
column2: However, it's best not to say Do you want me to...? to your superiors. Shall I help? or Please allow me to help.

column1: 「手伝いましょうか」とか「手伝わせてください」。
column2: More simply, you can also say I'll help.

column1: もっと簡単に「手伝います」と言うこともできますよ。

column2: Um... Teacher, usually we don't use ore in letters, do we?

column1: あの･･･先生、普通手紙で「俺」は使わないですよね。

column2: When you write a letter to someone you don't know, please write politely using desu and -masu.

column1: 知らない人に手紙を書く時は、「です」「ます」を使って丁寧に書きましょうね。
column2: Rather than What's up with that?, you should say What was wrong with that? or I wonder what was wrong with that?

column1: 鈴木さん、久しぶりですね。この授業は嫌いですか？
column2: Long time no see. You don’t like this (my) class?

column1: いいえ、山田先生の授業は大好きです。ただ、最近忙しいんです。
column2: I love your class! It’s just that I’m busy these days.

column1: 締め切りは来週ですよ！
はい。ちゃんと出します。
column2: Yes, I will make it in time.
I will give it my best!

column1: さゆり来た！さゆりちゃん、こっち。
column2: Sayuri is here! Sayuri! Over here.

column1: 二人はいつもスタバね。何で？
column2: You guys are always at Starbucks. Why?

column1: 禁煙だし、モカラテがうまい！
column2: It’s nonsmoking and their Mocha latte is great!

column2: Sayuri is rewriting her thesis. Hideo is still looking for a job. He got a job at Livedoor, but in this current situation, he may not be able to enter the company. I still don’t know if the two of them can go on the graduation trip
Just the two of us! Nice?

この旅行楽しみですね。どこがいい？

taco minus the shell plus rice

His job hunting is not going well. I don’t know whether or not he’ll find a job.

ずいぶん古いものですね。少々お待ちください。こちらで座って待っていてください。

column1: お金が必要なんですか。
今回の弁護料で新しい車を買うつもりなんだよ。子供の頃、ずっとイタリアのランボルギーニがほしくて、あるいは、フェラーリも悪くないなあ。まだ決めてないけどね。弁護士でよかったよ。
column2: I'm going to buy a new car with the money I get from this case. Since I was a child I've always wanted an Italian Lamborghini. Or, a Ferrari is not bad either. I haven't decided yet. It's good to be a lawyer.

陽子ちゃんは何しに来たの？

column2: Ma'am, we have an estimate on your car. You will have to pay us 20, 000 yen.

column1: えぇぇっ！それじゃ弁護士料払えないよ。
column2: Your car is worth nothing. To take care of it, it's going to cost 20 000 yen.

column1: ん～、じゃ今夜一緒に食事しながら、ゆっくり話しましょう。おいしい店いっぱい知ってるんだ。むふっふっふ・・・
column2: Eh, now I won't be able to pay the legal fees.

column2: I have a reservation for the best French restaurant in Tokyo, Saturday night, six o’clock. At five thirty, I’m coming to pick you up in my new Ferrari.

column1: では、土曜日に。むふっふっふ・・・
どうしょう！？かなりやばい。どうしよう！本当に困った。あっ、分かった！こういう時には智子だ。高校の親友で、困ったとき遠慮なく相談していいって約束した。きっと智子が助けてくれる。しかし４年ぶりで、大丈夫かな。
column2: What shall I do? It’s really bad situation. It’s really bad! What shall I do? I’m really in trouble. I know! At a time like this, Satoko, my best friend from high school. We promised that at times like this, I can count on her. Satoko will surely help me. But, it’s been four years. I wonder if it’s OK.

column1: もしもし、久しぶり・・・

column2: Long time no see. How are you?

column1: あんまり。最近ちょっと困ってる。ごめんね。ずっと連絡がなくて急に電話して。でも、今すごく困ってるんだ。ごめん、どうしても智子に力になってほしいことがある。今すぐ智子が必要なんだ。
column2: Not so good. I’ve gotten into some trouble recently. I’m sorry. I haven’t contacted you for so long and I call you all of sudden with this. But, right now, I’m in a real bind. I’m
sorry but, there is something I need your help with by any means possible. I need your help now, Satoko.

column1: でも、何の問題とか、まだ何も説明してないよ。
column2: I’ve got it. I will go right away!

column1: 大丈夫。着いたら教えて。どんな問題でも解決できるから！
column2: But you don’t know what the problem is. I haven’t explained anything.
You made it. Please sit down.

column1: 実は、今日、私の友人も一緒なんです。
column2: The truth is I’m here with my friend.

column1: いやぁ、かわいい、かわいい。はじめまして。私は・・・
column2: Oh…you are cute, too. Nice to meet you. My name is…

column1: いや、もうわかってます。陽子から戸鍋先生の話はもうすでに聞いていますから。大したことありませんね。私は高橋智子です。国際弁護士として、現在、ニューヨークとチューリヒで仕事しています。司法試験の最年少合格者です。世界で一番優秀な弁護士でございます。さて、今夜のこのミーティングなんですが、もちろん仕事の話でしょうね。そうじゃないとあなた、免許を失う可能性がありますよ。
column2: Listen buddy, I heard. I’ve already heard about you from Yoko. No big deal.
I’m Satoko Takahashi. I’m working as an international lawyer in New York and
Zurich. I’m the youngest person ever to pass the Japanese bar. And I’m the best

column2: lawyer in the world. OK, down to business. Now, about tonight’s meeting, of course

column2: this is about business, right? If it isn’t, there is a possibility you could lose your

column1: プラス、今夜ごちそうしていただきます。
そうですね。そうします。
では、ソムリエさん、ロマネコンティを3 本お願いします。
column2: Satoko, that was amazing! Tonabe Esq., so that was your real intension?
I’m so sorry. I was very different long ago, completely different. But long
ago, I was hurt badly by a girl. Since then, I changed. Please forgive me. The real me

column1: above all else, more than anything else
to fit in, to become accustomed to
なかなか難しいケースですね。どうやったら二人を助けられるか・・・
column2: This is quite a difficult case. What can we do to help them?

column1: そうですか？簡単ですよ。一体、何年弁護士やってるんですか。まったく。
column2: Really? It's easy! Just how long have you been a lawyer? Unbelievable!

column1: そ、そうですか。さすが、最年少合格者！
column2: Is that so? Just what one would expect from the youngest person to pass the test.

column1: あっ、そういえば、メルから手紙が来たんだった！うっかり忘れるところだった。今、読むね。
column2: Speaking of that, I just got a letter from Mel. It was just about to slip my mind. I'll read it now.

column1: 陽子ちゃん、元気にしてますか。優秀な弁護士にはちゃんと会えましたか。学長の親友ならきっと親切な人だろうと思います。
column2: Yoko, how have you been? Were you able to meet the top-notch lawyer? If he's a friend of the dean, I think that he'd be a really nice guy.

column1: 何言ってるんですか、ずうずうしい。
column2: What are you talking about, you cheeky guy.

column1: まあ、待って。続きがあるから。えっと、
column2: Wait, hang on, there's more. Hmm...

column1: こんなことを言うと陽子ちゃんがあきれるかもしれないけど、僕と学長はここでの生活を楽しんでます。
column2: When I tell you this, you're probably going to be unpleasantly surprised. The dean and I are enjoying this lifestyle.

column1: ここは最高！食事がただで食べ放題。そして、何よりも、毎日ただで日本語のレッスンし放題！東京では誰も日本語で話しかけてくれなかったのに、ここではみんな全部日本語！
column2: It's the best here! Here, they have an all you can eat and it's free! And above all, every day it's an all-I-can-study Japanese class. In Tokyo, no one would talk to me in Japanese. Here, everybody speaks Japanese to me.

column1: 陽子ちゃんには悪いけど、しばらくここでの生活を楽しみたくなってきました。
column2: I'm so sorry Yoko, but it has come that I would like to stay and enjoy this lifestyle a bit longer.

column1: 学長もいっぱい友達ができて、毎日楽しそうです。僕らにもうしばらく時間をください。また手紙書きます。あばよ！メル。
column2: The dean too. He has made many friends. He seems to be having fun every day. Please, give us a bit longer. I'll write again. Farewell. Mel.

column1: いいなあ、メル君、すっかりなじんでて。うらやましいなあ。
column2: Good for Mel. He's completely fit in. I'm jealous!

column1: こんなろくでなしとつきあってたの？こんな人たちのために私を呼んだなんてあり得ない！陽子にはがっかりよ。
column2: You hang around with these morons? This is unbelievable. You called me for these people? I'm disappointed in you Yoko.

column1: none of your business, not related
もういい、陽子、私帰る！こんなことで時間を無駄にしたくない。
column2: Enough. Yoko, I'm going home. I don't want to waste my time on something like this.

column1: ちょっと待って、智子、もう少しだけ話を聞いて！お願い！お願いだから！
column2: Wait a second. Just listen to me a bit more! Please! Please!

column1: こんばんは、どこまでですか。
空港ですと十万を超えますよ。
column2: If you are going to the airport, it will cost you over 100,000 yen.

column1: いくらでもかまわない。とにかく空港へ行って。早くここを出たいの。早く自分のおしゃれな生活に戻りたい。やっぱり戻ってきたのは失敗だった。早くここを忘れたい。
column2: However much it is, I don't care. Anyway, to the airport. I want to get out of here quick. I want to return to my stylish lifestyle. I knew it, coming back was a mistake. I want to forget this place quickly.

column1: どうしましたか。けんかでもしましたか。
column2: What's wrong? Did you fight or something?

column1: けんかしてきたばかりよ 。でもあなたに関係ないでしょう。
column2: I was just fighting. But it has nothing to do with you, does it?

column1: いや、関係あります。私のお客様ですから。お客様の幸せが私の幸せです。お客様が悲しいと私も悲しいです。
column2: You are wrong, it does have something to do with me. Because you are my customer. My customers happiness is my happiness. When a customer is sad, I am sad.

column1: すみません。やっぱり私の態度が悪かった。ごめんなさい。
column2: I'm sorry. I was rude. Apologies, I'm sorry.

column1: いや、問題ございません。　でも、そんな気持ちで旅立たないでください。私でよければ、気分転換のお手伝いをしますよ。
column2: It's no problem. But please don't leave on a trip feeling like that. If I'm allright, I'll help you change your mood.

column1: そうね。そう言われたらお腹がすいてきたわ。
column2: Yeah, when it's said like that, I have become a bit hungry.

column1: もしよかったら、いいラーメン屋を知ってますよ。東京で一番汚いけど、一番安くて、一番おいしいラーメンです。
column2: If it's ok, I know a really good ramen place. It's the most dirty in Tokyo but it's the cheapest and the most delicious.

column1: じゃあ、そこへ行って。もしよかったら、運転手さんも一緒にどう？
column2: OK, please go there. Driver, If it is ok, would you like to join me?
It will be my humble pleasure.

column1: Expression used when you haven't seen someone for a long time. Lit.:no affair
set out to earn money (with the intention of bringing it back home)
いらっしゃい・いらっしゃいませ

column2: How many? Oh my! Ryuta, it's been so long. How are you?

column1: おかげさまで。ご無沙汰していました。お元気ですか。
column2: Thanks to you (I'm fine.). I'm sorry I haven't been in contact for a while. How are you?

column1: 元気いっぱいですよ。お友達ですか。
column2: I'm feeling like a million bucks. Is this your friend?

column1: はじめまして、よろしくお願いします。
column2: Nice to meet you. Please be kind to me.

column1: こちらこそ、さぁー、こちらへどうぞ。
嘘じゃなかったんですね。本当に汚いな。あ！ゴキブリ！
column2: It wasn't a lie. It's filthy. Ah! A cockroach.

column1: まあまあ、大丈夫ですよ。ゴキブリは美味しいという印ですよ。気にしないで。
column2: Okay, okay, it's okay! Cockroaches is a sign that the food is delicious. Don't worry about it.

column1: 味噌ラーメンください・味噌ラーメンお願いします。
お二人、気が合いますね。お父さん、味噌二丁。
column2: The two of you go together well. Darling, two miso ramens.

column1: すごいおばあさんですね。
column2: Wow, what an amazing old woman.

column1: でしょう！ここに来ると地元を思い出します。
column2: Right? When I come here, I remember home.

column1: ご出身はどちらですか。
北海道の田舎から来ました。
column2: I'm from the countryside in Hokkaido.

column1: え？私も北海道です。でも田舎が大嫌いで、どうしても北海道を出たくて、一生懸命勉強して、東京の大学に入りました。
column2: Really? I'm also from Hokkaido. But I hate the countryside, and I wanted to leave at any cost. I studied as hard as possible, and I entered a university in Tokyo.

column1: 私は逆です。ここが嫌いだけど、出稼ぎのために出てきました。たまには帰ったりしますか。
column2: I'm the opposite. I hate it here, but to earn money, and then go back home, I came here. Do you go home sometimes?

column1: 全然帰ってないです。もう六年経ちます。
column2: I haven't gone home once. Six years have already passed.

column1: ところで、北海道のどこですか。
column2: By the way, where in Hokkaido?
Really? Wakkanai? I'm also from Wakkanai!

column1: 本当に稚内？じゃ、一緒ですね。
column2: Are you really from Wakkanai? We are from the same place.

column1: 世間は狭いですね。二人は意外とお似合いですよ。お父さん、私たちも昔に戻りたいね。
column2: It's a small world, isn't it? You two go surprisingly well together. Hubby, I want to go back to the old days.

column1: a sentence ending particle (feminine) used at the end of questions addressed to oneself or members of an intimate group

column2: In the year 2010, a kindhearted old man and woman were living in Roppongi Hills, Tokyo.

column1: ねえ、ばあちゃん。子供がいなくて寂しいと思うことはないかい。ばあちゃんはずっとほしかったのに、わしがずっとロボットの仕事で忙しくて・・・もうこんな歳になっちゃったなあ。
column2: Hey grandma. You never think it's sad that we don’t have kids? You always wanted kids. I was always busy with my robot work, and now we’re already this old….

column1: あなた、何言っているの。あなたとあなたの手で作ったこのロボットたちが私の宝物ですよ。私は今、十分幸せですよ。ほら見て。ここにいる500のロボットたちはみんな家族ですよ。
column2: What are you saying, dear? These robots you made with your own hands are my treasures. This is more than enough for me. Look, the 500 robots here are all family.

column1: ありがとう。ばあさん。本当にありがとう。ところで、明日はお正月だよ。寿司でも買ってこようか。
column2: Thank you, Grandma. Really, thank you. By the way, tomorrow is New Year's Day. How about going out and buying some sushi?
Long time since we've gone for a drive, huh.

column1: 久しぶりのドライブですね。

column2: This is the first time I’ve been in this Lexus!. Open up the top. What a great feeling!

column1: このレクサスに乗るのは初めて。ルーフを開けて。。。いい気持ち！

column2: Ah! Look over there! What could he be doing in a place like this?

column1: あっ！あれ見て！こんなところで何やってるのかしら。
轢かれた！かわいそうに。
＜おじいさん、アイボを取ってくる。＞

column2: It’s pretty bad. I have to take it back home quick.

column1: かなりひどいよ。早くうちへ連れて帰らないと。

column2: It’s been 3 days, and his condition hasn’t changed much.

column1: もう3日だが、あまり様子が変わらないなあ。全然動かないし。もう駄目かな。
column2: And it’s not moving at all either. Maybe it’s too late.

column1: そんなに簡単にあきらめないで。ほら。
column2: Don’t give up that easily! Look.

column1: 動いた！よかった。本当によかった。じゃ、散歩に行こう。
column2: It moved! I’m relieved. I’m really relieved. Okay, let’s go for a walk.

column1: あなた、まだ早いですよ。ちゃんと治るまで待ちましょう。
column2: Calm down, Darling, it’s too early. Let’s wait till it completely heals.

column1: そうだな。さすが、ばあさん。
column2: Right. That’s just like you, Grandma.
Welcome back to the both of you.

column1: ばあさん、ついに完全に治ったよ！
column2: Grandma, he's completely healed at last!

column1: あなたが直したんでしょう。
せっかく家族になったのに、寂しいけど・・・元気になったから、そろそろSONYの店へ返さなきゃ。
column2: It's so sad; just when he became a part of the family, and now because he's gotten his spirit back, we have to take him back to the SONY store.

column1: はい、分かりました。アイボ、そろそろほんとのお家へ帰ろうか。
column2: Okay, I know. AIBO. How about going back to your real home.

column1: ＜おばあさんとおじいさんがSONYに着く＞
ここが噂のSONYビルですか。
column2: So this is the fabled SONY building?

column1: ＜おばあさんとおじいさんが帰ろうとすると、おばあさんが何かに気づく。＞
column2: Right. AIBO! So this is where you escaped from. How does it feel to be home after a while? Your friends are waiting. Look, everyone is looking this way. Okay, from here you go alone. Grandma, lets go home. If we look, we’ll be sad.

column1: ＜店のマネージャーが迷子だったアイボを見つけ、二人に気づく。＞
column2: Look, all the AIBOs are coming this way!

column1: ありがとうございました！１週間前に行方不明だったんです。無事に返してくださって、ほんとにありがとうございました。
column2: Thank you so much! He disappeared a week ago. Thank you for returning him safely.

column1: いいえ、とんでもないです。
少々お待ちください。はい、これはお礼です。少ないですが、イタリア料理の招待券とSONYの商品券です。
column2: Please wait a moment... Here is a sign of my gratitude. It’s not much, but here is a gift certificate for an Italian restaurant and Sony goods.

column1: お礼なんていらないんですよ。アイボのおかげで楽しい時間を過ごしました。
column2: We don’t need anything like that. Thanks to AIBO, we spent some great time together.

column1: おや、おかしいですね。アイボたちがみんなでこっちに来てます。こんなの見たことないです。よし！じゃ、みんなで、車までお見送りしましょう。
column2: Oh, how strange. All the AIBOs are coming this way. I’ve never seen anything like this. Okay everyone, let's see them off to the car.

column1: polite form of いる・iru, to exist for animate, living things1
repayment, return the favor, show one's gratitude
そろそろ行きましょうか。
そうですね。行きましょう。
おばあさん、お会計お願いします。
ええと、味噌ラーメン二つだから、700円でございます。
column2: You had two miso ramen, so that is 700 yen.

column1: ええ、あんなに美味しかったのに、そんなに安いんですか。信じられないです。ごちそうさまでした。
column2: Even though it was that delicious. Is it that cheap? I can't believe it. Thank you for the good meal.

column1: 気に入ってくれてよかった。
column2: I'm glad that you liked it.

column1: （おばささん）:おじいさん、いいから！
column2: Every time. Please listen, listen. Listen. This ramen, these noodles..the stiffness...

column1: また、いっらしゃってね。
また彼女もいっしょにね。

column2: Yeah, I wonder if that will happen.

column1: 可能性はなくもないですね。ね、竜太さん。
どうも。気分はどうですか。
column2: Thank you. How do you feel?

column1: すっきりしました。本当にありがとうございます。
column2: I feel refreshed. Really, thank you.
Um, and was it the airport?

column1: どこへ行くんでしたっけ？
column2: And, where was it you were headed again?

column1: チューリッヒに帰るつもりでしたけど、今から海外へ行く気分ではなくなりました。あのおばあさんと会って、あのラーメンを食べて、久しぶりに北海道へ帰りたくなりました。
column2: I was intending to go back to Zurich, but now I don't feel like going overseas. After meeting that grandmother, and eating that ramen, I feel like going back to Hokkaido for the first time in a while.

column1: いいな〜。私も帰りたいな〜。でも出稼ぎ中だし。
column2: That sounds nice. I wish I could go back.. But I am in the middle of saving money, among other things.

column1: じゃ、この際一緒に行きませんか。
column2: This time, won't you go together with me?

column1: わ、私ですか。しかし、仕事がありますし。お金もなくて。
column2: M, me? But I have work, and...I don't have money.

column1: あなたのおかげで、私の気分が転換できて、何か恩返ししたいんです。せっかく同じ地元じゃないですか。
column2: It's no problem. I'll cover everything. How about that? Thanks to you I was able to feel better. I want to pay you back with something. Plus, we have the same hometown.

column1: あ、ありがとうございます！行きましょう！
as a matter of fact, the truth is
to receive, to take (humble form of もらう); V1

column2: You're late! What were you doing?!

column1: すみません部長、特別なお客様がいまして。
column2: Sorry boss. There was a special customer..

column1: なんだそりゃ！特別な客？客に特別も何もないだろ。これはビジネスだ！
column2: What on earth are you talking about?! A special customer! There is no such thing as a special customer. This is a business!

column1: 二度とないように気をつけろ。
column2: Make sure there isn't a second time!
Hurry up and get back to work.

column1: 実は、ちょっと話があります。
column2: Well, I actually have something to talk to you about.

column1: ここでお世話になり始めてもう３年です。
column2: It's been 3 years since I started here...

column1: 辞めるとか言うつもりか？無理だよ。君はうちの一番いいドライバーだから。さっきは悪かった。すまん。たのむ、辞めないでくれ！
column2: Do you intend to quit?! Impossible! You're our best driver! I was wrong just now. I'm sorry. Please don't quit! I'm begging you.

column1: まさか。ただ、ここに入ってから、まだ一度も休んでいません。明日から１週間休みをいただきたいんですが。
column2: Are you alright? It's just that I still haven't taken a vacation since I started here, and I would like to take a weeks vacation from tomorrow.

column1: ああ、そういうことか。いいけど。でも今回だけだぞ。で、何をするつもりなんだ？
column2: Ahh, so that's it. I guess, but just this time. What are you going to do anyway?

column1: 北海道へ帰って来ます。
column2: I'm going to go back to Hokkaido.

column1: よし、分かった。はい、今からスタートな。
column2: Okay, I got it. Your vacation starts from now.

column1: to make it in time for
あー間に合いました。もう名前呼ばれたから、あまり時間がないですよ。出発まで１０分ですから、急がないと。
column2: You made it. Because they've aready called our names, there isn't much time. Because there's only 10 minutes until takeoff, we have to hurry or...

column1: ごめんなさい。おみやげです。東京で一番うまいパン屋さんによって来ました。焼きたてです。
column2: I'm sorry. Here's a souvenir. I stopped by Tokyo's best bakery on the way. Fresh from the oven.

column1: パン屋！パン屋に行ってて遅れたんですか！
column2: A bakery?! You're late because you went to the bakery?

column1: そうです。智子さんのご家族のお土産を買って来ました。
column2: Yes. I bought this for your family.

column1: もちろん。智子さんが買う暇がないと思って、私は買いにいきました。
column2: Of course. I thought that you wouldn't have time to go and buy it, so I went to buy it.

column1: すみませんでした。短気な性格でごめんなさい。竜太さんみたいな思いやりのある人と会うのは久しぶりです。
column2: I'm sorry. I'm sorry I have a short temper. It's just that it's been a while since I met someone caring like you Mr. Ryuta.

column1: いいえ、こちらこそ。東京に来てから、さとこさんみたいなやさしい人は初めてです。
column2: No, same here. Since coming to Tokyo, this is the first time I've met someone kind like you, Ms. Satoko.

column1: 札幌行き321便でご出発の高橋さん、最終案内です。
column2: Last call for Ms. Takahashi, Flight 321 headed for Sapporo.
I wonder if we'll make it.

column1: to calm down, to feel at ease; V1
札幌行き３２１便はまもなく札幌空港へ着陸致します。現在の札幌の天候は晴れ。気温は二十度となっております。またのご利用を心からお待ちしております。
column2: Flight 321 headed for Sapporo will soon land. The weather in Sapporo is now sunny. The temperature is 20 degrees. We're looking forward to serving you again.

column1: 理由がわからないけど、急にどきどきしてきました。
column2: I don't know the reason, but I suddenly became nervous.

column1: おかしいです。すごくおかしいです。
こんな気分久しぶりです。私は普段世界貿易機関で冷静に話せるのに、なんで地元のことを考えると緊張するんでしょう。
column2: I haven't felt like this in a long time. Even though I can speak calmly in front of the WTO, why do I become nervous when I think about my hometown?

column1: まあ、人生とはそういうものです。時間が経つほど、記憶がゆがんでいく。
column2: Well, that's life. The more time passes, memories change.

column1: 心が記憶を少しずつ変えていく。例えば、昔の彼女がそうです。当時、彼女はすごくきれいでした。別れてから全然会っていません。頭の中で時間が止まっているから、彼女はずっと美しいんです。
column2: Your heart changes your memories bit by bit. For example, my old girlfriend. At the time, she was really beautiful. After breaking up, I haven't seen her once. But, because in my mind time stants still, she is always beautiful.  Besides that, the heart plays tricks and she has become even more beautiful. But, if I met her in real life, she would be totally different from the girl in my mind. Well... What I want to say is, in other words, it isn't as bad in real life as it is in your head.  You'll understand when we return.
Thank you, Ryuta. When I'm together with you, I can somehow relax.

column1: （電車の案内）間もなくドアが閉まります。ご注意ください。
column2: The door is about to close. Please be careful.

column1: ああ、ぎりぎり間に合った。
よかった。まさか！こんなところで！
column2: It's good we made it. No way! At a place like this...

column1: 大学の同級生。陽子ちゃん。いつも話してたじゃない。
column2: A college classmate. Yoko. I was always talking about her.

column1: すごい。あの、陽子ちゃん？
元気そうに見えないけど、大丈夫かな。陽子ちゃん。
column2: I wonder if she's okay. She doesn't look good. Yoko.

column1: さゆりちゃん！こんなところで！
column2: Sayuri! At a place like this!

column1: まあ、最近いろいろ。親友がいなくなったり、仕事がなくなったり。かなり大変だったんだ。
column2: Yeah. A bunch of things recently. I lost my best friend, my job, and... It was pretty bad.

column1: 相談すればよかったのに。力になれたかも。
column2: It would have been good if you had confided in me. Maybe I could have helped.

column1: まあ、でも、私のことはどうでもいいよ。さゆりちゃんは？
column2: Yeah. But, forget about me. How are you?

column1: かなりいい感じ。私達、今、表参道へ向かってるとこ。今日は婚約者の彼と一緒に部屋を探しに行くの。
column2: Pretty good! We're heading to Omotesando. I'm going to look for a place together with my fiance today.

column1: 初めまして。谷ヒロと申します。どうぞよろしくお願いします。よくさゆりから、話を聞いています。
column2: Nice to meet you. I am Hiro Tani. Please be kind to me, as I will to you. I've often heard stories from Sayuri.

column1: どうも。初めまして。素敵！ぴったり！しかもあたしのタイプ！うらやましい。どこで知り合ったの？
column2: Hello. Nice to meet you too. Good looking! Perfect fit. And also, my type. I'm envious. Where did you meet?

column1: 仕事で。彼は副社長だよ。
column2: At work. He is the vice president.

column1: いいな〜。無事に卒業した？
うん、危なかったけどね。私その日からずっとついてるみたい。実は、この仕事、決まってた人がいたんだけど、その人が来なかったから、私が入って、ヒロと出会って、あっというまに意気投合。
column2: Yeah, but it was close. From that day on, it seems like I've been lucky. The truth is, this job, someone had been chosen, but because that person didn't show up, I got the job, met Hiro, and quickly hit it off!

column1: 会社はほとんど男だったから、さゆりが入ってくれて、本当によかったです。
column2: The company is mostly guys. That Sayuri joined us was really great.

column1: SONYじゃなくて、SOMYっていう会社。
column2: A company called SOMY, not SONY.

column1: 知ってる？ね、陽子ちゃん、どうかした？なんか言ってよ。
column2: Do you know it? Hey, Yoko, what's wrong? Say something!

column1: to raise, to keep (as a pet); V1
久しぶりに札幌の空気を吸った。本当にきれいですね。
column2: It's been a while since I've breathed Sapporo's air. It's really clean, right?

column1: そうですね。やっぱり、北海道がいいです。
column2: Right. As expected, Hokkaido is good.

column1: でも、今１０時です。稚内までの電車がなくなった。どうしよう？
column2: But, it's 10 o'clock. There are no more trains for Wakkanai. What should we do?

column1: よかった。実は、行く前に、見せたいところある。僕を信用している？
column2: Good. The truth is, before we go I have a place I want to show you. Do you trust me?

column1: はい、到着。降りましょう。
column2: Okay, we've arrived. Let's get out.

column1: 今日は何の日でしょう？
あ！天の川が見える！あの物語、なつかしいわ。覚えてる？
column2: Ah! You can see the Milky Way! The story brings back memories. Do you remember it?

column1: むかしむかし、天の川のそばには天の神さまが住んでいました。
column2: A long long time ago, next to the Milky Way, there lived the god of the heavens. The god of the heavens had one daughter. Her name was...

Orihime. Orihime used the loom, and did the work of making the kimonos for the gods. Before long, Orihime became of marrying age, and the god of the heavens thought that he should get her a husband. He searched a lot, and what he found was a boy called Hikoboshi keeping heaven's cows at the shores of the Milky Way.

column1: 天の神さまには、一人の娘がいました。名前を
column2: Impressed! Hikoboshi was a fine young man. Orihime was also a very fine daughter. It was love at first sight for the two of them.

The two married, and it came to be that they spent their happy life together. But having too good of a relationship is also a problem, and the two forgot their work and they began to do nothing but play.
As Orihime hasn't been weaving, everyone's kimonos are becoming old and worn. Please make new kimonos quickly!

column1: おり姫ははたをおって、神さまたちの着物をつくる仕事をしていました。おり姫がやがて年頃になり、天の神さまは娘に、おむこさんをむかえてやろうと思いました。
column2: As Hikoboshi hasn't taken care of them, the cows are becoming sick!
It came to be that everyone came and complained to the god of the heavens. The god of the heavens became really angry,

column1: やるね。ひこぼしは、とても立派な若者でした。おり姫も、かがやくばかりに美しい娘です。
column2: You two should live separated east and west of the Milky Way! he said, and separated Orihime and Hikoboshi.
But the god of the heavens saw that Orihime was really sad, and said this:

column1: 二人は結婚して、楽しい生活を送るようになりました。でも、なかが良すぎるのも困りもので、二人は仕事を忘れて、遊んでばかりいるようになったのです。
column2: Just once a year, only on the night of the 7th day of the 7th month is it alright for you to meet Hikoboshi.

column1: 「おり姫がはたおりをしないので、みんなの着物が古くてボロボロです。はやく新しい着物をつくってください」
column2: From then on, looking forward only to the one day of the year when they could meet, Orihime worked hard at the loom every day.

column1: 「ひこぼしが世話をしないので、ウシたちが病気になってしまいます」
column2: Also, Hikoboshi, on the other side of the Milky Way, put his back into the work of caring for the cows. Then, on the evening of the 7th day of the 7th month that they were waiting for, Orihime crosses the Milky Way and goes to Hikoboshi's place to meet.

column1: 天の神さまに、みんなが文句を言いに来るようになりました。神さまは、すっかり怒ってしまい、
column2: But, because when it rains the Milky Way's water-level rises, Orihime can't cross the river. On such occasions, a magpie flies out of nowhere, and places a bridge over the Milky Way for her.
You should also look up to the night sky and bless their reunion. The end.

column1: でも天の神さまは、おり姫があまりにも悲しそうにしているのを見て、こういいました。
column2: Satoko, you're also quite the Tanabata expert.

column1: to dispatch, to take or escort
本当に楽しかった。今夜どうする？かなり遅くなった。
column2: It was really fun. What are we going to do tonight? It has become quite late.

column1: そうですね。じゃ、寝ないでこのまま稚内へ帰る？
column2: Indeed. Well, go back like this, without sleeping?

column1: でも、車だと竜太はずっと運転してリラックスできないから。電車の方が楽でなにも考えなくていい。
column2: But if we go by car, Ryuta has to drive all the way and can't relax. So the train is more confortable, and we don't have to think.

column1: 僕は全然かまわない。運転することと考えることが好きだし。全然問題ない。慣れてるよ。毎日お客さんを遅くまで送っているから。本当に平気。
column2: I don't mind at all. I like to drive and to think, so.. No problem at all. I'm used to it. Because I drive customers until late every day. Really, no sweat!

column1: あたしはお客さんじゃない。
ゆっくりしたいの。最近、最後にゆっくりしたのはいつ？
column2: I want to take it slowly. Recently, when was the last time you took it slow?

column1: 決まり。ゆっくり行きましょう。
column2: It's decided. Let's take our time and go.

column1: さとこ、いくらぐずぐずしてもいつかは帰らないといけないよ。
column2: Satoko, no matter how much you procrastinate, you have to go home sometime.

column1: ね、竜太、ちょっと気になってるんだけど、
column2: Hey, Ryuta, this bugs me a bit.

column1: 私はたくさんの優秀な人と出会ったのに、竜太みたいな人ははじめて。タクシーの運転手さんらしくない。
column2: Even though I've met many smart people, some one like you is a first. Not typical for a taxi driver.

column1: 今まで何人のタクシー運転手と話したことがある？
column2: Up until now, how many taxi drivers have you spoken to?

column1: ほら、また深い話をする。こんなに鋭くて変わっている人、なにか裏があるみたい。絶対見抜いてみせる。
column2: See? Again with the deep talk. Such a sharp and rare person, it would seem you have a hidden side. I'll definitely find out.

column1: 見抜いてみてください。その間どうしよう？
column2: Please, try to find out. In the meantime, what will we do?

column1: 了解！ベルトしてください。行きましょう。
column2: Ten four. Fasten your seatbelt. Lets go!

column1: ね、あの店まだあるね。懐かしいな～。そこで食べよう。
column2: Oh, that store is still here. How nostalgic. Let's eat there.

column1: ちょっとお手洗いに行ってくる。
column2: I'm gonna go to the bathroom.

column1: 竜太がこの街に戻ってくると思わなかった。あの事件の後、急にいなくなって・・・どうしたの？どこにいってたの？何考えてるの？辛かったのは自分だけと思っているの？いなくなっちゃうなんて！
column2: I didn't think you would return to this town. After that incident, you suddenly disappeared. What happened? Where were you? What was going through your mind? Do you think you were the only one having a hard time? Disappearing like that!

column1: 落ち着いて落ち着いて！分かった、分かったから。深呼吸してごらん。
column2: Calm down, calm down. I got it. Try to breathe deeply.

column1: とにかく、あなたに会いたがっている人がいっぱいいるよ。行こう！
column2: Enough about that, there are many people who want to meet you. Let's go!

column1: 分かった。ちょっと待ってね。友達にメモを書く。彼女にこのメモを。よろしくお願いします。
column2: Okay. Just wait a second. I'm gonna write a note to my friend. Give this to her. Please.

column1: すみません。私の友達を知りませんか。
column2: Excuse me, do you know where my friend is?

column1: どうして知っているんですか。
この町で竜太君を知らない人はいないよ。
column2: There isn't a person in this city that doesn't know Ryuta.

column1: 多分この手紙を見れば、分かるんじゃないかな。
column2: Probably, if you read this letter, I'd say you'll understand.

By the time you read this letter, I won't be here anymore, but don't misunderstand me. The truth is, not only you, but I also have a past in this town that I can't forget. I didn't think that it would happen this sudden, but the time to confront that came suddenly. I can't explain now, but the next time we meet, I will definitely explain. To tell you the truth, it's hard to become this close to you and seperate here. But my work is done. Because the purpose of this trip was to help you confront your past. Take care until we meet again. Ryuta.
You know, it feels like I've seen your face somewhere before.
No, I don't think so. Excuse me.

column1: to make meet, to expose to
二千六百円でございます。どうも有り難うございました。
column2: That will be 2,600 yen. Thank you very much.

column1: 只今！お母さん、お父さん、皆出かけてるの？
column2: It's nostalgic. When I was a kid, I used to climb up that tree and barbeque in that garden. But, wait... why is the house so beat up like this? It's completely different from a long time ago. I'm home! Mom? Dad? Has everyone gone out?

column1: ああ、どうも。こんにちは。
隣の鈴木と申します。誰かをお探しですか。
column2: I'm Suzuki from next door. Are you looking for someone?

column1: はい、ここに住んでいる高橋ですが。
column2: Yes. I'm looking for the Takahashi's that live here.

column1: ああ、智子ちゃん。お帰りなさい。
えっ、何でわかるんですか。
当然ですよ。あなたがここにいた頃は、毎日顔合わせていましたよ。残念ですが、今は誰もこの家に住んでいませんよ。
column2: It's natural. Of course I know. We saw eachother's faces every day when you were living here. It's regrettable, but now, nobody lives here.

column1: どういうこと？何があったの？教えてください！
column2: What do you mean? What happened? Please tell me!

column1: 長い話になります。お茶を飲みながら、ゆっくり話してあげます。私の家に行きましょう．
column2: It's a long story. Let's take our time. I'll tell you while we drink tea. Let's go to my house.

column1: あら、智子ちゃん？お久しぶりです。元気にしてた？
column2: Ah, Satoko. It's been a long time. Have you been well?

column1: 大人の女性になったわね。国際弁護士の仕事はどう？
column2: And look at the grown woman you've become! How's your job as an international lawyer?

column1: ええ、何でそんなことをご存知なんですか。
column2: Huh, how do you know that?

column1: 智子ちゃんはこの町の誇りよ。智子ちゃんがやっていることは皆知ってる。
column2: Satoko, you're the pride of this town. Everyone knows what you are doing.

column1: 有り難うございます。だけど、鈴木さん、お願いします。私の家族はどこへ？
column2: Thank you. But, Ms. Suzuki please, where has my family gone?

column1: 私はお茶を持ってきます。
ええ、何で泣いているんですか。
悲しい知らせがあるのよ。連絡しようとしたんだけど。連絡が取れなくて。
column2: I have some sad news. I tried to contact you, but...

column1: to get on, to condemn, to blame;V2
竜太！いつ帰ってきたの？
column2: Ryuta! When did you come home?

column1: 今朝。食堂に入ったら、さくらと会って、すぐここに来た。調子はどう？
column2: This morning. I went into a diner, saw Sakura, and then came straight here. How are you?

column1: お金はちゃんと届いてる？
column2: Have you been getting the money okay?

column1: リハビリはうまくいっている？
うん。がんばってる。竜太、なんであの事故の後、すぐ町を出たの？竜太が必要だったのに。
column2: Yes. I'm doing my best. Ryuta, why did you leave town right after the accident? I needed you.

column1: ごめん。本当にごめん。でも、お金が必要だと思ったから。沢山必要ってわかっていて。
column2: Sorry. I'm really sorry. But, I thought we needed money. I knew we needed a lot.

column1: あの事故は竜太のせいじゃないよ。自分を責めるのをやめないと・・・
column2: The accident was not your fault, Ryuta. You have to stop blaming yourself...

column1: でも、僕が運転していたら、きっと皆は大丈夫だった。お父さんとお母さんもあの家族も死んでなかったし、姉さんもけがをせずにすんだ。
column2: But, if I had been driving, everyone would have surely been okay. Dad, mom, and that family wouldn't have died, and you wouldn't have gotten injured.

column1: いえ、もうやめましょう。済んだことを言っても仕方がないわ。あなたは一生懸命私のために仕送りしてくれているのに。ごめんね。
column2: No, let's stop this already. There is no use talking about what has already happened. Though, you have been working so hard to send me money. I'm sorry.

column1: いいよ、姉さんは早く良くなることだけを考えて。もうどこにも行かないから、安心して。
column2: It's alright, you just think about getting better, sis. I'm not going anywhere, so relax.

column1: to be solved, to come untied
to get offended, to get upset
to clutch, to hold in one's arms
すみません、子供のとき以来お墓参りしていないので、どうしたらいいのかわからなくて。教えていただけますか？
column2: Excuse me. As I haven't visited a grave since I was a kid, I don't know what to do. Would you tell me what to do?

column1: あ、そうですか。まず、お墓をきれいにお掃除してあげてください。それからお花とお線香をあげてあげたらいいでしょう。
column2: Oh I see. First, please clean the grave. After that, you should offer flowers and incense sticks.

column1: バケツや何かは、あの小屋にある物を使ってください。
column2: Please use the bucket and other things from that shed.

column1: どうも、ありがとうございます。
お父さん、お母さん、どうして．．．
私、何も親孝行出来なくてごめんね。やっと、一人前になって、これからだと思って帰ってきたのに．．．お父さんとお母さんが事故にあった事も知らずに．．．
column2: I'm sorry I couldn't be a good daughter. I've finally grown up, and I thought I could make up for it and come back, but... I didn't even know that you were in an accident...

column1: あー、智子ちゃんか。覚えてないだろうな。あの頃はまだこんなに小さかったから。むかしよくお父さんとお母さんとお盆のお墓参りに来ていたんだが。こんなに大きくなって。
column2: Ahhh, Satoko? You probably don't remember, as you were still so small at that time. You used to come to the graveyard with your father and mother for Bon festival. You've grown up.

column1: あの頃の事は何となく覚えています。私がお墓に来るのが怖くて泣いているのを、父が抱きかかえてくれて、母が「智子が来たからおじいちゃんもおばあちゃんも喜んでいるわよ。」って慰めてくれて。
column2: I somehow remember the time. I was afraid of coming to the graveyard and I cried, so my dad held me and my mom comforted me by saying, Your grandpa and grandma are happy because you came.

column1: この度はいろいろ、大変だったね。でもお父さんとお母さんは毎年ここへ来ては智子ちゃんの事を自慢に話してくれていたよ。
column2: I'm sorry about this unfortunate incident. However, your father and mother came here every year and talked about you so proudly.

column1: ああ、世界一の娘だって。本当にこんなに立派になって。天国のお父さんもお母さんも心配いらないな。
column2: Yes, they said you were the best daughter in the world. You really became so impressive. Your father and mother in heaven don't have to worry about you anymore.

column1: でも、私これから一人でどうしたらいいのか。
column2: But I don't know what to do just by myself.

column1: 智子ちゃん、智子ちゃんのお父さんとお母さんは、天国へ行ってもいつも智子ちゃんと一緒だよ。辛いけど自信を持って生きていきなさい。
column2: Satoko, your father and mother are always with you even though they went to heaven. I know it's hard, but you have to live your life with confidence.

column1: ありがとうございます。なんだか気分が楽になりました。私がんばります。天国にいるお父さんとお母さんのためにも。
column2: Thank you. I feel better now. I'll hang in there. For my dad and mom in heaven.

column1: おや、あの方もお知り合いですか。
column2: Oh, is that person someone you know?

column1: to be cured, to be mended

column2: I don't know what to say...

column1: なんて残酷な世界．．．最初から知っていたの？
column2: What a cruel world. Did you know from the beginning?

column1: いや、そんなことはない。最初は知らなかった。それは事実だよ。
column2: No, it's not like that. I didn't know from the beginning. It's the truth.

column1: でも、途中で気づいてたでしょう。でしょう！
column2: But you realized in the middle, didn't you!

column1: 何で言わなかったの。何で黙ってたの？何で！
column2: Why didn't you say it? Why didn't you tell me? Why?

column1: 落ち着いて、落ち着いて。
こんな広い世界で何であなたと出会ってしまったの？？何で黙っていたの。知っていたんでしょう？
column2: In such a big world, why did I meet you? Why didn't you tell me? You knew it, right?

column1: 本当にごめんなさい。時間が経てば経つほど僕の、僕が．．．つまり、言いづらくなって、だって、智子はあんなに幸せで．．．正直いうとわからない。
column2: I'm really sorry. The more time passed... my... I... Basically, it became so hard to say, because you were so happy. To tell the truth, I don't know why.
I don't want to hear it anymore.

column1: 智子、君は僕が何言っても、何て説明しても、絶対に聞かなかった。
column2: Satoko, I know you wouldn't have listened to me even if I told you or explained it to you.

column1: そんなことはわからないでしょ。
こういう場合、僕が何言っても、智子は怒っていた。それは当然な反応だ。今は確かにつらいけど、知ったばかりだから。時間が経てば、傷は治るんだ。
column2: With something like this, you would have been angry at whatever I said. That's the natural response. It's really hard right now because you just found out. As time goes by, your wound will heal. Every day, I think to myself, I could have prevented this accident. But I can't run away from this reality. I came here to apologize and say good bye. Take care.

column1: 僕は毎日この事故を防ぐことができたと思い返すんだ。その事実からは逃げられない。僕はお詫びとさようならを言いにきた。お元気で。
some living thing is completely gone
え、智子、大丈夫？どうして電話くれなかったの？
column2: What? Satoko, are you alright? Why didn't you call me?

column1: え、もどったの？どうして？仕事は？
column2: What? You went back? Why? What about your job?

column1: 陽子、ごめんなさい。あんなくだらない事で怒ったりして。本当にごめんなさい。
column2: Yoko, I'm sorry for getting upset over such a small thing. I'm so sorry.

column1: いつの間にか皆いなくなってしまう。光陰矢の如しね。
column2: Before you know it, people die. Time flies.

column1: 一体どうしたの？なんだか怖いわ。
column2: What's going on? You're scaring me.

column1: ごめん、いろいろあったから。でも、私は大丈夫よ．ただ、陽子の声を聞きたかったの。いつ最後になるかわからないから。
column2: Sorry, I had a lot going on. But I'm fine now. I just wanted to hear your voice. I learned a lot in these two weeks, and I realized how important you are to me. So I wanted to apologize. Can you forgive me?

column1: この２週間でいろんな事を学んで、陽子の事がどれだけ大切か分かった。そういう訳で謝りたかったの。許してくれるかな？
column2: Of course. I don't care at all about that.

column1: もちろん。私は何にも気にしてないよ。
column2: I'm going to stay in Wakkanai for a while, but I have someone I want to introduce you to.

column1: 私はこれからしばらく稚内に残るけど、ちょっと紹介したい人がいるの。

column2: His name is Ryuta. It didn't work out between us, but I think you two would be perfect together.

column1: 彼の名前は竜太。私には縁がなかったけど、あなたにならピッタリだと思うわ。
お待たせしてすみません。
いいえ、私も今来たところです。本当にごめんなさい、初対面なのに急に呼び出したりして。
column2: No, I just got here, too. I'm really sorry for having you come out on such short notice, as it's our first time to meet.

column1: いいんですよ。最近仕事をくびになって、暇してたところなんで。
column2: It's alright. I recently got fired from my job and I was bored, so.

column1: え、そうなんですか。私も今仕事がなくて。何か偶然ですね。
column2: Oh, really? I also don't have a job right now. What a coincidence.

column1: 最近何もかもがうまく行かなくて。
column2: Nothing goes well for me nowadays.

column1: そういう事もありますよ。でも、雨降って地固まるって言うじゃないですか。
column2: You know, things happens. But they say after a storm comes the calm, right?

column1: それに奇麗な虹だって雨の後にしか出ませんからね。
column2: And also, you can only see such a beautiful rainbow after it rains.

column1: 竜太さんてすごい、ロマンチックですね。
笑顔もすてき。ねえ、今日どうしましょうか？
column2: You have a great smile, too. Hey, what should we do?

column1: 代々木公園でピクニックはどうですか！材料を買いに行って。
column2: How about going on a picnic in Yoyogi park! First, let's go buy some food.

column1: でも、天気予報によると今日は午後から雨だそうです。
column2: But it's supposed to rain in the afternoon according to the weather report.

column1: なんでだろう。初対面なのにこんなに．．．何て言うか．．．
column2: I don't know why, but even though it's our first time to meet...I say...

column1: ええ．．．不思議ですよね。そうだ、実はこの近くにすごくおいしいラーメン屋さんがあるんです。東京で一番汚いけど一番おいしいラーメン屋です。
column2: Yeah... It's strange, isn't it? Hey, there's a really good ramen place near here. It's the dirtiest restaurant in Tokyo, but it's the best.
グラフィックデザイナー

column1: さあ、もう行かないと電車に遅れちゃう。
column2: Alright, I gotta go or I'll be late for the train.
47 departure headed for Tokyo, will soon depart from track 3.

column1: 東京で１人暮らしかー。私に出来るかな？でも、福島の田舎で終わる訳にはいかないもんね。やっと決心したんだもん。頑張らないと。私、ファイト！
column2: Living alone in Tokyo. I wonder if I'll be alright. But I just can't end my life in the countryside of Fukushima. Come on, I made up my mind. I gotta give it a try. You can do this, Agnes!

column1: えーと、六列目の右から２番目っと。お、ここか。失礼しますよ。
column2: Hmm, the 6th row, second from the right. Ah, right here. Excuse me.

column1: いやー、やっぱり電車の旅はいいねー。おや、こんなに大きなカバンをもって、お嬢さんどちらまで？
column2: Hmm, a trip on a train is always nice. Well young lady, where are you headed with such a big bag?

column1: 東京です。仕事を探しに。
column2: To Tokyo. I'm going to look for a job.

column1: グラフィックデザイナーです。
それはいい。若いうちに何でも挑戦しないと。
column2: That's nice. You gotta try everything while you're young.

column1: 私そんなに若くないですよ。
column2: Well, I'm not that young. Just to let you know.

column1: はっはっは、私の年になるとみんな子供に見えてねー。
column2: Hahaha, everyone looks like a child to me... when you get to this age.

column1: 私、村上アグネスと申します。
お若いのにしっかりしてるね。遅れました。横田満夫です。
column2: You are so polite even though you are still so young. Where are my manners. I'm Mitsuo Yokota.

column1: 初めまして。アグネスか珍しい名前だね。
column2: How do you do. Agnes, that is one unique name.

column1: ええ、母がフィリピン人で。
でも、ただ父がアグネスチャンの大ファンっていうだけなんですけどね。本当のところ。
column2: But, to tell you the truth, it's just because my dad is such a big fan of Agnes Chan.

column1: それはいい、私も大ファンだ。まあ、これも何かの縁だ。東京で困った事があったらいつでも連絡しなさい。これは私の名刺です。
column2: Agnes Chan? Haha, that's good. I'm a big fan, too. Well, there must be someting to our meeting. If you ever need any help in Tokyo, just contact me any time. This is my card.

column1: どうもありがとうございます。
さあ、これから新しい生活が始まる。ちょっと心配だけど頑張らないと。あっ、そういえばあの人どこか大きな企業の社長さんだって。幸先いいかも。
column2: Alright, my life is beginning. I'm a little worried, but I gotta try. Oh, and that gentleman turned out to be a president of a big company. This must be a good sign.

column1: to humble oneself, to act in a humble manner

column2: Thank you for riding JR East Japan today. Yamabiko # 52 will arrive at Tokyo station momentarily.

column1: お嬢さん、起きて！東京に着きましたよ。
column2: Young lady, wake up! We're in Tokyo.

column1: まあ、これから色々あると思うが自分の夢に向けて頑張ってください。
column2: Well, I think you're gonna face a lot of challenges from here on, but hang in there and go get your dream.

column1: はい、どうもありがとうございました。
そうそう、それから何かあったらいつでも連絡してきなさい。
column2: Oh, and one more thing, make sure to contact me if anything comes up.

column1: さあ、まずはホテルに行かないと。
column2: Okay, I have to go to the hotel first.

column1: こんにちは。予約した村上です。
column2: Hi, I have a reservation. I'm Murakami.

column1: はい、少々お待ち下さい。はい、村上アグネス様ですね。こちらがお部屋の鍵になります。御二階の右側です。
column2: Yes, one moment please. Yes, Miss Agnes Murakami, right. This is your room key. It's on the right side of the second floor.

column1: はい、ありがとうございます。
あれ、この部屋禁煙じゃないんだ。私タバコ吸わないのに。フロントに言って変えてもらおうっと。
column2: Come on, this is a smoking room. And I don't even smoke. I'm gonna call the front desk and get another room. (Phone) Excuse me, but may I change this room with a non-smoking one?
Oh yes, I'm sorry. We'll change the room right away.

column1: はい、申し訳ございません。今すぐ変えさせて頂きます。
こちらのお部屋でよろしいでしょうか？
column2: Yes, it's fine. Thanks. And can I have a wake up call at 7 tomorrow morning, please?

column1: はい、大丈夫です。ありがとうございます。それから、明日の七時にモーニングコールをお願いします。
はい、かしこまりました。
column2: Alright, time to take a bath and get cleaned up. I need to get up in the morning and go look for a room. I hope I can find a good place. I can do it!

column1: こんにちは。部屋を探しにきたんですが。
column2: Hello. I came to find a place.

column1: いや、お客さんはついてる。何と言ってもここは世界で一番親切な不動産屋ですから。私に任せておけば必ずいい部屋見つかるよ。
column2: You're in luck. After all, this is the most caring Real-estate office in the world. If you leave it to me, we'll find you a good place!

column1: よろしくお願いします。
どういう所をお探しですか？
column2: What kind of place are you looking for?

column1: １ルームでキッチンとお風呂とトイレが付いている所を探しているんですが。
column2: I'm looking for a place with a kitchen and bath included.

column1: そうですねー。あ、この近くに４畳半のアパートがあるけど。
column2: Hmm. Oh, there is 4.5 mat room near here.

column1: もっと大きなお部屋はないですか。六畳ぐらいの。
column2: Is there not a bigger room? About six mats?

column1: えー、ご予算は？月どれくらい？
まあ、５、６万円ぐらいで。出来れば駅から近い方がいいんですけど。
column2: Well, around 50 to 60 thousand yen. And the closer to the station the better.

column1: 駅の近くは少し高くなるけど。ああ、６万５千円で駅から徒歩五分って所があるよ。
column2: Near the station gets a bit pricey, but oh, there's a place for 65 thousand yen. A five minute walk from the station.

column1: ああ、きれいな所ですね。他にはありますか？
column2: Oh, that looks nice. Are there any others?

column1: 後は月５万円の所があるよ。新しくはないがアパートの二階で日当たりはいいね。駅からは少し歩くけど。
column2: We also have a place for about 50 thousand yen. It's not new, but it's on the second floor and gets a lot of sun light. It's a bit of a walk from the station, though.

column1: ところでお嬢さんはどちらの方？
column2: By the way, where are you from young lady?

column1: 何もありませんが。自然はきれいです。
column2: There's nothing there, but the nature is beautiful.

column1: この二つ見てみますか？
column2: Would you like to have a look at these two places?

column1: 今日はこれから他の所を見せないといけないから、明日は空いてますか？
column2: I have to show a few other places today, so are you free tomorrow?

column1: はい、じゃあ、明日お願いします。
お忙しい中時間を割いていただきましてありがとうございます。
column2: Thank you so much for taking time out of your busy schedule.

column1: いやいや、気にしないで。これが仕事だから。それに今日はそんなに忙しくないんだよ。
column2: No, no, it's no trouble at all. After all, it's my job. And, actually, I'm not that busy.

column1: じゃあ、一つ目の所に行ってみましょうか。
column2: Alrighty then, let's go and see the first one.

column1: ここが、６万５千円のアパートです。
え、写真と少し違いませんか？あっゴキブリ。ここって高い割には汚い限り。ちょっとここは．．．
column2: Really? Isn't it a bit different from the photo? Look! Roaches! This place is the dirtiest, even though it's expensive! This place is really not for me.

column1: まあ、駅から近いからとても便利ですけどね。
column2: But it's very close to the station, so it's convenient.

column1: 近いのはいいですけど線路の隣だと少しうるさくないですか？
column2: Nearby the station is good, but the railway track is next door, so isn't it a bit loud?

column1: まあ、すぐに慣れると思うけど。
column2: Yeah, but you'll get used to it quick.

column1: ちょっと、写真で見たのと雲泥の差があるな。
column2: The difference between the photo and what I've seen is night and day!

column1: まあ、こんな感じかな。つぎの所も行ってみますか？
column2: Well, this is kinda what the place is. Shall we try the next one?

column1: さあ、こちらです。古い建物だけど、手入れされてるからきれいだよ。
column2: Here it is. It's an old building. However, it's kept in good condition, so it's clean.

column1: へー、とても感じのいい所ですね。
日当たりもいいですよ。さあ、どうぞ。
column2: It gets a lot of sunshine too. Here we are. Please go in.

column1: うわー、新しい畳、このにおいがたまらない。
column2: Wow. New tatami! I can't resist this smell.

column1: この前変えてもらったばかりですからね。窓の外を見てごらんなさい。
column2: We just had new ones put in recently. Look out the window.

column1: はい、すごい、陽も入るしきれいですね。
column2: Wow, what a view! There's lots of sunshine, and it's so beautiful.

column1: まあ、駅からもそう遠くはないから。
column2: Also, it's not that far from the station.

column1: ありがとうございます。ではお店に戻って手続きさせて頂きますね。
column2: Thank you very much. Let's go back to the office, and I'll have you take care of some paperwork.

column1: to put things in order, to get something ready
with trouble, at great pains, long-awaited
いらっしゃいませ。何かお探しですか？
column2: Welcome. Are you looking for something?

column1: はい、実は一人暮らしを始めるので色々買い出しに。
column2: The truth is, I just started living on my own, so I need to buy a bunch of things.

column1: あ、そうですか。今丁度冬の大セールをやっていまして、ベッドや棚などお安くなっていますので、そちらもぜひご覧になっていってください。
column2: Ah, I see. Right now, there's a big winter sale going on. Beds, shelves, and many other things have been marked down, so please make sure to take a look.

column1: はい、ありがとうございます。
column2: Thank you. Wow, great timing. It looks like I'll be able to get a lot of things. Oh, this table is cute. Hmm, I may buy more than I need.

column1: へー、ちょうど良かった。色々揃えられそう。うわー、このテーブルかわいい。何だか必要以上に買っちゃうかも。
column2: This table and chair are a special deal.

column1: このテーブルと椅子はお買い得ですよ。
あのー、配達は出来ますか？

column2: Then, I don't have to worry about carrying them.

column1: じゃあ、運ぶ心配はないわね。
column2: However, today's things will be delivered tomorrow.

column1: ただ、今日の分は明日以降になってしまいますが。
column2: Yes, that's fine. I'm going to be living on my own after all, so I might as well get lots of different things. This, and uhh, that too.

column1: せっかくの一人暮らしだし色々揃えちゃおうかな。これに、あっ、あれも。
えー、合計が３万４千６５０円になります。
column2: Thank you. Alright then, we will be by your house sometime tomorrow in the morning.
I bought this much stuff. But it was fun. After I get home, I have to think about where to put all this stuff. I wonder if I can do it alone. Well, I won't know if I don't try.

column1: dear (often used as the opening greeting of a letter)
making friends with, getting along well with
to assemble, to set up, to construct;V2
sorting, arrangement, organization, putting in order, adjustment, regulation, liquidation
はーい、こちらにお願いします。
はい、こちらでよろしいですか？
column2: Alright, is this okay right here?

column1: それではどうもありがとうございました。
はい、どうも、って、あれ、でも全部箱に入ったままだ。えー、自分で組み立てないといけないの？どうしよう．．．でも、やってみないと。よし、がんばるぞ。
column2: Yes, thanks. Oh, but it's all still in the box. Do I have to put this stuff together myself? What should I do... well, I won't know if I don't try. Alright, you can do this!
Ugh, this is harder than I thought.

column1: もしもし、え、もしかして満子？
うん、アグネス？久しぶり。
えー、何年ぶりかしら。元気にしてた？
column2: Yes, Agnes? It's been a while.

column1: うん、相変わらずよ。アグネスはどうしてるの？
column2: Yeah, I wonder how many years it's been. How have you been?

column1: 実はね今東京に出てきてるんだ。
column2: Yeah, same same. How about you Agnes, what're you up to?

column1: うそー、何でもっと早く言ってくれないのよ。
column2: To tell you the truth, I'm in Tokyo now.

column1: だってまだ出てきたばっかりよ。こっちで仕事を探そうと思って。
column2: Really! Why didn't you tell me earlier?

column1: そうなんだ。で、今どこに住んでるの？
column2: Because I just got here. I thought I'd look for a job here.

column1: 中野の近くなんだけど。
column2: I see. And where do you live now?

column1: へー、今日は何してるの？
さっきIKEAから家具が届いたから、それを組み立てたり、色々整理しようと思って。
column2: Okay, what are you doing today?
Some furniture arrived from IKEA, and I thought I would put it together and tidy up.

column1: 田中満子:じゃあ、また電話するから。
ふー、これで完成。やったー。できたわ。さあ、シャワーを浴びたら、窓際のこの新品のテーブルでさっそくビールを飲もうっと。明日は満子と会えるんだ。楽しみ！
to become thin, to lose weight
ううん、そんなに待たされてないよ。アグネス、久しぶり！ねえ、ちょっとやせた？
column2: You didn't keep me waiting too long. Long time! Did you lose weight?

column1: 時々そう言われるけど、変わってないよ。満子はきれいになったね！
column2: Once a while I get that, but I'm the same. You, you've become more beautiful!

column1: このお店、すごくお洒落だね。
column2: This place is really chic, isn't it?

column1: おお、この人が満子が言ってた人か。うわあ、本当にきれいな人だなあ。あ、すみません、隣に座ってもいいですか？
column2: Oh, so this is the girl Michiko was talking about? Wow, you're very pretty. Umm, may I sit down next to you?

column1: おい、お前ちょっと図々しいよ。
column2: Hey man, you're a little forward there.

column1: ちょっとちょっと、満子。どうなってるの？
column2: Umm, uhh, Michiko... what's going on here?

column1: ああ、ゴメンね。アグネスを紹介して、って頼まれたの。こちらが松田浩君。私の職場の同僚。
column2: Oh, sorry. I've been asked to introduce you. This is Hiroshi Matsuda. He's a co-worker at my office.

column1: どうもー、こんにちはー。で、こっちが俺の中学校時代の友達で、橋本雄介っていいます。こう見えても医者なんですよ。
column2: Hey, hello. And, this is my friend from middle school. Call him Yusuke Hashimoto .  Although he looks like this, he's a doctor.

column1: どうも、はじめまして。今日は浩に連れてこられちゃって…
column2: Hello, nice to meet you. Hiroshi brought me with him today.

column1: まあ、お医者様なの！かっこいい！
いやいや、たいしたことないですよ。
column2: No, no, no. It's no big thing.

column1: 村上アグネスさんって言うんでしょ？満子から話を聞かされて、一度会いたいって思ってたんだ。
column2: Agnes Murakami, right? I heard about you from Michiko, and thought that it'd be nice to meet you.

column1: 何これ、合コン？ひょっとして私、利用された？
column2: What is this? A mixer?? Could it be that I was used?

column1: to be exchanged, to be replaced
お母さん！朝からどうしたの？
column2: Hi, Mom! What's the matter early in the morning?

column1: まあいやだ、この子ったら。朝どころかもうお昼過ぎよ。今まで寝ていたの？
column2: Oh my god, Agnes! It's not morning, it's already early afternoon.  D id you sleep until now?

column1: ええ？あ、本当だ。うーん、昨日ちょっと遅くまで友達と飲んでたから。
column2: Really?  Oh, that's right.  Last night I was drinking with my friend until pretty late.

column1: あら、もうそっちでお友達ができたの？
column2: Wow, you've already made friends there?

column1: ううん、高校時代の友達の田中満子。今東京にいて、連絡くれたんだ。
column2: No, it's Mitsuko Tanaka, my friend from high school.  She's in Tokyo now, and contacted me.

column1: まあ、そうなの。どうしてるかと思ったけど、元気みたいね。ちょっとお父さんと替わるわ。
column2: Oh, I see. I was wondering how you were doing, but you seem to be fine.  Dad wants to talk with you a bit.

column1: もしもし、アグネスか？元気でやってるか？一人で寂しくないか？
column2: Hi Agnes.  Are you doing well?  You're lonely by yourself, aren't you?

column1: やだ、お父さん。私、子供じゃないんだから。寂しいどころか、毎日忙しくて、お父さんとお母さんに電話するのも忘れちゃってたわ。
column2: Oh no, Dad.  I'm not a kid anymore.  I don't feel lonely at all.  I'm so busy everyday that I forgot call you.

column1: そうか、それはよかった…。アグネスは寂しくないんだな…。
column2: I see, that's good, Agnes.  So you aren't lonely, eh?

column1: ん、どうしたの、お父さん？
いやいやなんでもない。また母さんに替わるよ。
column2: Nothing.  I'll put your mom back on.

column1: アグネス、遊ぶのもいいけどちゃんと規則正しい生活をして、早く仕事を見つけなさい。
column2: Agnes, it's good to have fun , but you need to keep regular hours, and get a job soon.

column1: はあい。ねえお母さん、お父さんはどうしたの？ちょっと元気がなかったけど。
column2: I know, I know.  Mom, what's wrong with Dad?  He seems to be a little out of sorts.

column1: 元気がないどころか。お父さんったら毎日、子供の頃のアグネスの写真を見ながら泣いてるのよ。
column2: To tell the truth, he's not fine. Every day he cries while looking at pictures of when you were a kid.

column1: 何を言うんだ母さん！アグネス、お父さんは元気だぞ。泣いてなんかいないぞ！
column2: What are you talking about?  Agnes, I'm fine. I'm not crying.

column1: お父さん、あんな強がり言ってるけど、アグネスがいなくて寂しいのよ。
column2: He's tries to hide it, but he misses you.

column1: あーあ、なんだか心配になってきちゃった。お父さん、大丈夫かしら。
column2: Oh no.  I'm worried about Dad.  Is he going to be okay?

column1: to be saved, to be helpful
(hum) to visit, to inquire, to hear
村上アグネスさんですか？
デザインオフィスの杉田と申します。先日履歴書をお送りいただいた件でお電話しました。
column2: This is Sugita from the design office. I'm calling about the resume that you sent us the other day.

column1: あ、はい！お電話ありがとうございます。
column2: Oh, yes! Thank you for calling.

column1: グラフィックデザイナーの職をご希望ということで、間違いないですね。
column2: You applied for the position of graphic designer, correct?

column1: はい。よろしくお願いします。
早速ですが、近いうちにこちらに来ていただいて、直接お話をお聞きしたいのですが。
column2: To get straight to the point, I'd like you to come to our office to meet sometime soon.

column1: わかりました！今日すぐにでもうかがいます。
column2: No problem! I can even come today.

column1: いえ、今日はちょっと…。水曜日の夕方4時ではいかがでしょうか？
column2: Well, today might not work. How about 4 o'clock in the afternoon on Wednesday?

column1: あ、申し訳ありません、その日は予定が入っておりまして…。午後の早いうちなら空いているんですが…。
column2: Oh, I'm very sorry but I have a previous engagement that day. The early afternoon would be fine, though.

column1: それでは木曜日の午前中はいかがですか？
column2: In that case, how about Thursday morning?

column1: はい、それならうかがえます。
承知いたしました。あ、すみません、会社は青山でしたよね？
column2: Okay. Umm, the office is located in Aoyama, right?

column1: そうです。表参道の駅から5分くらいです。地図をファックスしましょうか？
column2: Yes, it's about 5 minutes from the Omotesando station. Shall I fax you a map?

column1: ぜひお願いします。まだ東京に慣れていないので、地図があると助かります。
column2: Yes, please do. I'm not too familiar with Tokyo yet, so a map would be helpful.

column1: わかりました。履歴書にあるこちらの番号でいいんですね。では、後ほどファックスをお送りします.
column2: Okay. The number on your resume will do, right? I will send the fax afterward.
Thank you for your kindness. I'm looking forward to seeing you.

column1: やった！早速面接だ！よーし、今日のうちにスーツにアイロンかけておこうっと。

column2: Once upon a time, on Hakone Mountain, there lived a man named Amanojaku who fell from the sky.  Amanojaku had great power, but curiously, it was only at night that his power came out. One clear day, Amanojaku was standing on the top of Hakone Mountain and looking over the surroundings.
“Oh, today I can see distant mountains, but my Hakone Mountain is the best.”
Amanojaku was in good spirits, but suddenly his face changed when he glanced to the west.

column1: ううむ、富士はやはりきれいな山じゃのう。背たけも高くて、人々が朝に夕に手を合わせる気持ちもわかるわい。
column2: For between the clouds to the west of Hakone Mountain, Japan’s number one mountain, Mt. Fuji, made its beautiful shape seen.
“Well, of course, Mt. Fuji is beautiful! It’s high, and I can understand why people pray toward it in the morning and at night.”

column1: だめだ、だめだ！　富士がいるおかげで、わしの箱根山の美しさがかすんでしまう。人間どもは箱根に尻(しり)を向けて富士ばかり見ておる。なんとかしなくては・・・
column2: “Oh no! Because Mt. Fuji is there, the beauty of my Hakone Mountain gets hazy. People look only at Mt. Fuji, turning their back to Hakone mountain. I have to do something.”
Amanojaku was thinking about that with his arms crossed and after a while, came up with a good idea.

It was to throw rocks from the top of Mt. Fuji into the sea to make Mt. Fuji shorter. That night, after people fell asleep, Amanojaku struggled up Mt. Fuji carrying a mokko, which is a tool for carrying soil. Then, he grabbed rocks on the top and put them into the mokko. He climbed down Mt. Fuji, and threw the rocks away from the shore into the sea. After that, every night Amanojaku climbed Mt. Fuji and took the rocks on the top and threw them into the sea. Amanojaku threw away so many rocks that many islands were created in the ocean. These are Oshima, Toshima, Niijima, Shikinejima, Kōzushima, Miyakejima, and Mikurajima - all of which make up Izushichito. And, it is said that he failed to throw away one rock and dropped it into the sea near the shore, and that it became Hatsushima.
But, even after so many rocks were taken away, Mt. Fuji was still the highest in Japan.

column1: しまった。夜が明けてしまっては、わしの力がなくなってしまう。
column2: “Dammit! Tonight, I’m going to carry as many rocks as I can!”

Again Amanojaku set out for Mt. Fuji that night. It took a lot of time because he picked up a larger rock than usual. So, by the time he climbed down Mr. Fuji and walked around to Hakone, the first rooster crowed “cock-a-doodle-doo.”
“Oh no, I’m finished! When dawn breaks, I lose my power!”

column1: numbered tag or ticket, window ticket
certification of official registration of a seal
えーと、市役所はどこかしら。あ、ここね。
column2: Hmm, I wonder where the city hall is. Ah, here it is.

column1: すみません、転入届の受付はどちらですか？
column2: Excuse me, where can I file a moving in notification?

column1: はい、3番の窓口になります。まず、あちらにある書類に記入してから窓口でお申し込みください。
column2: Counter number three. Please fill in the documents over there first, and then take it to the counter.

column1: ただいま受付が少々混雑しておりますので、あちらの番号札を取ってください。順番にお呼びします。
column2: It's a bit crowded right now, so please take a number from over there. You'll be called in order.

column1: わかりました。ありがとうございます。
番号札105番でお待ちの方、窓口までどうぞ。
column2: Ticket number 105, please come to the counter.

column1: えーと、転入届を出したいんですけど。
column2: Umm, I'd like to file a notification of moving in.

column1: はい、転出証明書をいただけますか？
column2: Sure, I'll need your change of address certification.

column1: 本日、運転免許証やパスポートなどの身分証明書はお持ちですか？
column2: Do you have a driver's license, passport, or some other type of ID with you today?

column1: え…私、免許は持っていないんですけど…。
column2: Well, I don't have a driver's license...

column1: 申し訳ございませんが、転入届の受付にあたっては、身分証明書をご提示いただく必要がございまして。
column2: I'm sorry, but you need to present some kind of ID when filing a new resident notification.

column1: あのう、前の市役所では年金手帳を持って行ったら大丈夫だったんですけど。だから今日は年金手帳を持ってきました。
column2: Well, it was okay to use my pension book at the previous city hall, so I brought it with me today.

column1: そうですか。ちょっと拝見してよろしいですか？少々お待ちください。
column2: I see. May I have a look at it? Please wait a moment.

column1: お待たせしました。こちらで大丈夫です。お引越しにあたって、印鑑証明の手続きなどもなさいますか？
column2: Thank you for waiting. This will work. Would you like to register your seal at this time, as well?

column1: いいえ、それは今回必要ありません。
column2: No thank you, not at this time.

column1: では、これで手続きは終了です。
ありがとうございました。
to boost, to force up, to push up
to get strong, to gain strength

column2: Long, long ago, an old man and woman lived by the seaside with their son and daughter-in-law. Every day the old man and his son used to go fishing far out at sea, and the old woman and her daughter-in-law would weave. One day, while the old man and his son were fishing far off the shore, the weather suddenly began to worsen.
Dad, let's go onto that island.
The two of them hurried to a nearby island.

column1: お父っつぁん、こりゃあ。
column2: While the rain and wind were getting stronger and stronger, they managed to pull the boat up onto the shore. They took shelter in a cave and spent the night keeping still and watching the ocean grow rougher and rougher.  The next morning, the heavy rain stopped, and they launched their boat and started catching fish.  When they put a fishing net into the sea, they felt something heavy.  They managed to pull out the net and in it found a 25 or 26 year-old man dressed in a lavish kimono.
Well, I guess he was swept away by the storm last night.  What a pity.  He's already dead.

column1: 今日は、ひきあげよう。おばあさんに頼まれていた物を買ってから帰ろう。
column2: They dug a hole on the island so that the man could be buried respectfully.
We have to leave now.  Let's go home after we buy what I was asked to get by my wife.

column1: もし、あなたたちは、昨夜の大雨の時、どうしていましたか？
column2: They rowed the boat into the harbor of a big town.

column1: はい、わしたちは危ういところで島に逃れられました。
column2: When they stopped by a rice shop to buy miso and rice, the shopkeeper spoke with them.

column1: そうでしたか、それはよろしゅうございました。ところでここへ来る途中、千石船(せんごくぶね・江戸時代、米を千石ほど積める大形の和船)を見かけませんでしたか？
column2: Excuse me, what were you doing during the heavy rain last night?

column1: いいや、見なかったですな。ですが今日、わしらのアミに若い男の死骸(しがい)がかかって、島にうめてきました。
column2: Luckily, we managed to get to an island.

Did you?  That’s good.  By the way, did you see a Sengokubune? (This is a Japanese ship that was large enough to carry 1,000 koku of rice, which is roughly 150,000 kg of rice, enough to feed 1 thousand people for 1 year.)

column1: なにか、心当りでもありなさるのか？
column2: No, we didn't. But, we retrieved the dead body of a young man caught in our net and buried him on the island today.

column1: 実は、息子が大阪に千石船で米を積んで出て行ったのですが、そこへあの大雨。心配しているところです。
column2: Did you say a dead body?
Is there something on your mind?

column1: ごめんどうをおかけしますが、わたしをその島へ連れて行ってもらえますまいか？
column2: Well, to tell the truth, my son sailed out to Osaka carrying rice on a sengokubune.  Then, then the heavy rain came, so I am very worried.
Yes, I see what you mean.
I'm sorry to trouble you, but could you please take me out to that island?
They took the shopkeeper on board and returned to the island.  Once they dug up the body, the shop owner went pale.

column1: あなたたちには、すっかりお世話になりました。わたしの心からのお礼を港に用意しました。どうか受け取って下さい。
いや、お礼なんぞいりません。
column2: The old man and his son took the body on board and returned to the harbor again.  They also attended the great funeral.
Thank you for everything.  I've prepared something for you at the harbor as a token of my sincere appreciation.  Please accept it.
Oh, it's nothing.  You don't need to do that.
Not only did you bury my son respectfully, but you put all the money he carried together with his body.  I was so impressed by your honesty.  So please accept it.

column1: Click here to listen to the whole story
column2: They decided to accept it because the shop owner insisted.  But, they were shocked when they were taken to the harbor by the shop owner. The token of appreciation that the shop owner had prepared was the Sengokubune, which, in addition, had 1,000 koku of rice loaded.  Furthermore, he gave them more than 100 ryo (it is more than 700 million yen).  Instantly, they became very rich, and then went back home where the old woman and daughter-in-law were waiting for them.

column1: ごめんください。本日4時から面接をしていただく予定になっている、村上アグネスと申します。
column2: Excuse me.  I'm Murakami Agnes.  I'm supposed to have an interview from 4 o'clock today.

column1: はい、うかがっています。少々お待ちください。
column2: Yes, we've been expecting you.  Please wait a minute.

column1: うわあ、いよいよ面接か。緊張するなあ。
column2: Wow, I'm finally getting an interview. I'm getting nervous.

column1: どうぞお入りください。
初めまして、人事担当の杉田と申します。
先日はお電話をありがとうございました。村上アグネスと申します。
column2: Nice to meet you.  I'm Sugita, the one in charge of personnel administration.

column1: どうぞおかけください。
column2: Thank you for calling the other day. I'm Agnes Murakami.

column1: まず、うちの会社に応募されたきっかけは？
個人的な理由なのですが、学生の頃から音楽が好きなんです。それで、自分の好きなアーティストのCDジャケットのデザインを、こちらのデザインオフィスJさんが担当されているのを知って、興味を持ちました。
column2: First, please tell me what prompted you to apply to our company.

column1: 我が社の仕事をご存知でしたか。では、やはりそういった音楽関係の仕事をご希望ですか？
column2: It's kind of personal, but I applied because I've liked music since I was a student. So, I became interested when I learned that Design Office J was in charge of the CD jacket design for my favorite artist.

column1: ええ、やってみたいという気持ちはあります。
column2: Oh, you know about our work. So, do you want to work on music-related projects?

column1: ただ、うちの仕事は音楽関係が特に多いというわけ ではないんです。たとえば包装紙のデザインなど、地味な仕事も多いですよ。
どんなに地味な仕事でも構いません。デザインという仕事を一生懸命勉強したいと思っています。
column2: But, we don't have many music-related projects. For example, we have many low-profile projects like designing wrapping paper.
No matter how low-profile a project is, I would do my best. I want to learn a lot about design.

column1: 恐れ入ります。経験がないので、気持ちだけは前向きに、と思っています。
いいですね、仕事に前向きな人は歓迎ですよ。 それでは後日、改めてうちの社長とお会いになってください。昼食でもご一緒しながら、色々お話をうかがいたいので。
column2: Thank you very much. Since I have no experience, I try to at least maintain a positive mindset.

column1: はい、ありがとうございます！
column2: We welcome positive workers.  Alright, please meet our president at a later date.  We would like to talk some more over lunch.

column1: 実は、うちの社長はかなり個性的な人物なので…社長との相性が結構大切なのですよ。
え…個性的？どんな方なんだろう…。
column2: To tell you the truth, our president is very unique... So, it's very important for employees to get along with our president.

column1: essential, fundamental, crucial, vital, main; Adj(na)
Just who I was looking for.
失礼します。本日、社長に面接をしていただく予定の村上アグネスです。お昼をご一緒するとうかがっているんですが。
column2: Excuse me. My name is Agnes Murakami. I'm scheduled to meet with President Fujimoto today. I was told I would accompany him for lunch.
Yes, of course. Please proceed to the president's office in the back.

column1: あ、君！ちょうどよかった！そこの塩を取ってくれ！

column2: Oh, you there! Perfect timing! Get me the salt over there!

column1: そうそう！よし、これでばっちりだ！ああ、君が村上アグネス君？

column2: Right! Yes, that's perfect! Uh... Are you Agnes Murakami?

column1: 社長の藤本だ。よろしく。まあ、座って座って。
このテーブルのところでいいんでしょうか？
column2: I'm President Fujimoto. Nice to meet you. Well, have a seat, have a seat.

column1: そうそう、そこ。実は僕は料理が趣味なんだ！料理をしているとデザインのインスピレーションも湧くんだよ。今日は君に僕の手料理を食べてもらおうと思ってね。
column2: Shall I sit around this table?

column1: だから、社長室にキッチンがあるんですか？
column2: Yeah, right there. The truth is cooking is a hobby of mine. I get inspirations for design when I'm cooking. I thought I would ask you to try my cooking today.

column1: そうそう。なかなかいい設備だろう？南フランスのレストランっぽいデザインにしてみたんだ。
column2: Is that why there's a kitchen in the president's office?

column1: え、ええ。このデザインなんか、素敵ですね。
column2: That's right. Not a bad facility, eh? I designed it to look like a restaurant in southern France.

column1: おお、これに注目するとは、なかなか芸術家っぽいセンスがあるね！デザイナーとして見所があるぞ！
column2: Well, the design here is wonderful, isn't it?
Ah-ha! for you to notice the design in that particular place shows that you have artistic talent. You're a promising artist!

column1: うん、でも肝心なのは料理を味わうセンスだな。まあ、これを食べてみてくれ。最近の自信作なんだ。

column2: Uh-huh. But the most important thing is the sense of taste for distinguishing ingredients. Here, try this. It's my specialty.

column1: どうだい？ソースの隠し味がわかるかな？
とても美味しいです。えーと…この黄色っぽいの、なんでしょう…。ショウガかしら？
column2: What do you think? Can you tell what the secret ingredient is?

column1: 正解だ！すばらしい！君、いいセンスをしているよ！採用だ！
column2: It's delicious. Uhmm...this yellowish thing, what is it? Is it ginger?

column1: to be helpful, to be useful
こんにちは、村上アグネスさんですか？
突然の電話で、失礼します。僕、橋本雄介です。先日、田中満子さんと一緒にお会いした、松田の友人です。
column2: I apologize for the sudden call. My name is Yusuke Hashimoto. I'm a friend of Matsuda's. We met the other day along with Mitsuko Tanaka.

column1: え～と…ああ！あのお医者様の？
そうです。松田から無理矢理電話番号を聞き出しちゃいました。
column2: Yes. I got your phone number from Matsuda, sort of by force.

column1: そうなんですか。びっくりした～。
column2: Is that so? What a surprise!

column1: 驚かせてごめんなさい。実は、アグネスさんがデザイナーだって聞いて、折り入ってお願いがあるんですけど…。
column2: I'm sorry to surprise you. Actually, I heard that you were a designer and I have a rather serious favor to ask you.

column1: いえ、私、本格的なデザイナーじゃなくて、まだ見習いですよ！
column2: Well, I'm not a full-fledged designer yet. I'm still in training.

column1: いやいや、そういうセンスのある人の意見を聞きたいんですよ。
column2: Oh that's fine. I wanted an opinion from someone who has artistic talent.

column1: 私でお役に立てるかしら。どんなことですか？
column2: Well, I'm not sure I can be of help, but...What can I do for you?

column1: う～ん、電話ではちょっと説明しづらいなあ。もし差し支えなければ、近いうちに一緒に食事でもいかがですか？そのときにゆっくりご説明します。急ぐ話じゃないんです。
column2: Umn. It's kind of hard to explain over the phone. If it's not too inconvenient for you, could we have dinner some time soon? I can explain then. It's no hurry though.

column1: ええ、私は構いませんよ。
そうですか、よかった。いつがいいですか？
column2: Great to hear that. When is good for you?

column1: 来週から新しい仕事が始まるので、差し支えなければ今週中がいいんですが。
column2: Well, I start a new job next week, so if you don't mind, could we meet sometime this week?

column1: わかりました。では、明後日の夜はいかがですか？
column2: Sure. How about dinner two nights from today?
Okay. Then I'll contact you again about when and where we can meet. Thank you. I look forward to seeing you!

column1: やった！あのとき、満子の友達はちょっとしつこい感じだったけど、この人は感じのいい人だな。最近の私、ついてるみたい！
いらっしゃいませ。何かお探しですか？
ウィンドウにあったワンピースが素敵だな、と思って。見せていただけますか？
column2: I think the one-piece dress in the show window is nice. Can I take a look?

column1: こちらですね。どうぞ、お手にとってご覧ください。これはこの春の人気商品なんですよ！春らしい感じで、お勧めです！
column2: Here you are.  You can touch and check it out.  This is a very big seller this spring.  It's full of spring taste, so I'd like to recommend it.

column1: でも、このピンクは私には可愛らしすぎるかなあ。色違いはありますか？
column2: But, this pink might be too sweet for me.  Do you have any other color?

column1: 申し訳ございません、こちらの商品はこの色だけなんです。でも、きっとお似合いだと思いますよ。よろしかったら、ご試着なさいますか？
column2: I'm sorry, but we only have this color for this one.  But I'm sure this would fit you nicely.  Do you want to try it on?

column1: 店員:（ノックの音）お客様、いかがですか？
column2: Please use the vacant fitting room.

column1: うーん、あの…ちょっと小さいみたいで…もう一つ上のサイズはありますか？
店員:（ノックの音）お客様、いかがですか？

column2: Umm, it seems too small.  Do you have one in a bigger size?

column1: わあ、とてもお似合いですよ！お客様のイメージにぴったり！
全然そんなことありませんよ！お客様は脚が長いし、とてもスリムに見えます。
ええー、そうですか？でも、たまにはこういう色もいいかな。
こちらの黒いカーディガンを合わせていただくと、落ち着いた感じになりますよ。
column2: Wow, you look so nice! It's perfect for you.

column1: あ、本当。これなら大人っぽく見えますね。じゃあ、このワンピースとカーディガンをいただきます。
column2: You don't think I look fat, do you?

column1: ありがとうございます。
column2: No, not at all!  You have long legs and look so slim.

column1: こんばんは。ごめんなさい、お待たせしちゃいました？
column2: Good evening. I'm sorry. Did I keep you waiting?

column1: あ、こんばんは！こちらこそ、突然お誘いしちゃってすみません。
column2: Hi, good evening to you, too! Oh no. I should be the one apologizing for suddenly asking you out.

column1: 橋本さん、今日はお忙しかったんじゃないですか？
column2: Mr. Hashimoto, you must've been busy today.

column1: いえいえ。僕も今日は比較的暇だったんです。それより、橋本さん、なんて堅苦しいので、雄介でいいですよ。
column2: Oh no. I had some free time today. By the way, call me Yusuke. Mr. Hashimoto sounds so formal.

column1: じゃあ、雄介さん。お仕事先は病院なんですか？
column2: Okay then. Yusuke, do you work at a hospital?

column1: ええ、そうです。この近くにある大学病院です。でも、僕は診療じゃなくて研究の方なんですよ。
column2: Yes, I work at a nearby university hospital. But I do mostly research and not clinical work.

column1: わあ、研究なんて、かっこいい！
いやー、実態はひどいんです。普段は頭もぼさぼさで、白衣もよれよれ。その格好で夜中に実験用のマウスに餌をやってるところは、ちょっと女性には見せられないね。
column2: No, the reality is pretty glim. Usually, my hair is a mess, and my lab coat is wrinkled. I couldn't let a woman see me looking like that and feeding a lab mouse late at night.
Actually, I'd like to see that.

column1: やめてくれよー。それよりアグネスさんの方がかっこいいよ、デザイナーなんて。
column2: No way! You're so much cooler! A designer!

column1: 全然。それにまだちゃんと仕事をしているわけじゃないの。
column2: Not at all, I haven't even had a real job yet as a designer.

column1: そういえば、こっちで仕事を探してるんだっけ。
column2: By the way, are you looking for a job around here?
