column1: そう！この間面接に行って、採用になったの。明日が初出勤なんだ。
column2: Yes! I just went to a job interview the other day and got a job offer. Tomorrow is my first day at work.

column1: えー、おめでとう！じゃあ、お祝いに美味しいワインを開けようよ。今日は僕がおごるから。
column2: Wow, congratulations! Then let's open a bottle of good wine to celebrate. Today it's on me.

column1: え、いいの？あれ、そういえば何か相談があるって話じゃなかった？
column2: Really? Are you sure? By the way, didn't you have something you wanted to talk to me about?

column1: いいのいいの、その話はまた今度でも。じゃあ、アグネスの就職にカンパーイ！
column2: Oh no. That can wait til next time. First, let's have a toast to celebrate your new job. Cheers!

column1: ありがとう。カンパーイ！
to have, to carry, to hold
pull oneself together, give it one’s all
おはようございます、社長。
昨日、ゴリから電話があったらしいな。今内容を確認したんだが、まったく、無茶な注文だよ。この忙しい時に！君が電話を受けたのか？
column2: I heard that we got a call from Gori called yesterday. I just checked what it was about, but what a reckless order. At a busy time like this! Did you respond to the call?

column1: すみません、お断りするべきでしたか？
column2: Yes. I'm sorry. Should I have turned it down?

column1: いや、断るのは無理だろう。あいつは昔から強引なんだ。それにいつもの倍の金額を払うと言っている。おいしい仕事だよ。この仕事は受けるべきだな。
column2: No, it's not possible to turn him down. He's always been pushy. But he's offering to pay double the normal rate. So it's a lucrative job. So we should accept it.

column1: よし、この件は君が担当しなさい。初仕事だ。
column2: Alright. you take the job. It's your first project.

column1: 他のスタッフは皆、急ぎの仕事を抱えていて手一杯なんだよ。後でゴリには電話をしておくから、今週の金曜日までにプレゼンの準備をしてくれ。できるか？
column2: The other staff are all busy with other work. I'll call Gori later, so could you prepare a presentation by this Friday? Can you do it?

column1: は、はい！何とかなると思います。
column2: Ah, yes. I think I'll handle it somehow.

column1: よし、いいぞ！これが仕様書だ。詳しいことは、野村や他のスタッフに聞きなさい。
column2: That's the attitude! Here are the specs.  Ask Nomura and the other staff about the details.

column1: はい。内容は、就職活動の学生向けのパンフレットですか…。
column2: Yes, sir. So the project is a pamphlet for students who are job hunting...

column1: あいつの会社は今景気がよくて、今年は優秀な人材をたくさん採用する気でいるんだ。気合いを入れろよ！この仕事が取れたら、特別ボーナスだ！
column2: Yeah. His company is doing really well right now, and it plans to hire a lot of qualified people. Put a lot of effort into this project, Ms. Murakami. If you get this job, you'll get a special bonus!

column1: 今日の道徳の時間は、みんなでビデオを見ますよ。
column2: In today's ethics class, we're going to watch a video together.

column1: 先生、どんなビデオを見るんですか。
column2: Teacher, what kind of video are we going to watch?

column1: 今日は、地球の自然環境が、どんどん悪くなっていることについてのビデオを見ます。じゃあ、みんなテレビの前に集まって。
column2: Today, we'll watch a video on how the earth's environment is getting worse. Get in front of the TV now, kids.

column1: ーーーーーーーーーーーーーーー
年々、私たちを取り巻く自然環境はどんどん悪化しています。私たち人間は、自然を破壊し、汚染し続けてきました。地球温暖化やオゾン層の破壊、異常気象、酸性雨、森林破壊、砂漠化、食糧危機、資源の枯渇。順調に文明が発達してきたはずの地球に、今何が起こっているのでしょうか。そして、私たちは今何をすべきなのでしょうか。自然破壊が進む今、どのような影響が出ているのか見てみましょう。

column2: Every year, the earth's environment is getting worse. We humans have continued to destruct nature and contaminate the earth. For example, (we have caused) global warming, destruction of the ozone layer, abnormal climate, acid rain, deforestation, desertification, a food crisis, and a drying up of our natural resources. Civilizations should have been developing smoothly. What is happening to our earth now?  And what should we do now?  Let's look at how environmental destruction is affecting our lives.

Destruction of the ozone layer - The ozone layer shuts out harmful ultra-violet rays and protects human bodies. Chlorofluorocarbon gas, created by mankind, is making a hole in the ozone layer. This is feared to have adverse affects on the human body. Every time we lose 1% of this ozone layer, we reportedly see a 3-5% increase in the number of skin cancer patients and a roughly 1% increase in patients with cataract.

Global Warming - This is said to be caused by an increase in carbon dioxide levels, caused by exhaust gas emitted from factories and vehicles. As a result, the earth's temperature has been rising for the past few years. Because of global warming, the ice on the South Pole has been melting slowly and raising the ocean's water levels. If we continue at this pace, we can't deny the possibility of all continents submerging under water.

Acid rain - This is a phenomenon caused by contaminated substances emitted from cars turning into acidic rain. Acid rain is expected to have a huge impact on not only humans but on other living species. And there is the risk of acid rain changing the quality of soil and water and ultimately killing forests.

Water pollution - Humans cannot live without water. Yet, we are losing beautiful water, mainly due to domestic wastewater.  This means that not only is our drinking water contaminated, the fish who lived in these waters are contaminated as well. If we consume these contaminated fish, harmful substances could accumulate in our bodies and cause health problems.
Environmental destruction is progressing right under our radar. The affects of environmental destruction can be seen in many areas.

Then what should we do to prevent further damage to the environment? Let's start with something we can easily do in everyday life, such as sorting the garbage. We can at least prevent the release of harmful gases by obeying rules on garbage sorting. Littering is obviously out of the question. But it's useless if only one of us follows the rules. When we all obey the rules, we can produce results and prevent environmental destruction. So it is important now for us to do what we can in our day to day lives.
Everyone! Do you understand now how scary environmental destruction can be? The video said that there is something we can all do to protect the environment. Who knows what that is?

column1: みんな、自然破壊がどれだけこわいものかわかったでしょう。自然を守るために、みんなができることがあるって言っていたけど、それが何かわかる人。

column2: We can sort the trash before taking them out. And we should never litter!
That's right.  So all of you should think more about the environment when taking action. Do you understand?

column1: はい。ゴミを出す時は、分別して出すことです。それと、ポイ捨ては絶対しないことです。
その通り。みんなもこれからは自然のことを少し考えて行動すること。わかったわね。
（授業終わりのチャイムが鳴る）
column2: That's the end of today's lesson.

column1: あ、雄介さん？こんばんは。
遅くにごめんね。今、大丈夫かな？
column2: Sorry to call you so late. Can you talk right now?

column1: えっ、こんな時間まで？もう12時過ぎてるよ！どうしたの？
column2: What? This late in the evening? It's past midnight! What's up?

column1: うん、入社早々大きな仕事を任されちゃって、全然終わらないんだ。
column2: Well, I was given a huge project immediately after joining the company. And I can't seem to finish it.

column1: そうか、大変だなあ。でも、すぐに大事な仕事を任されるなんて、期待されてるね。
column2: Wow, that sounds tough. But they must have a lot of faith in you for them to give you such a huge project.

column1: うーん、どうかなあ…。あ、それより、何か用事だった？
column2: Umnn. I'm not so sure about that. Anyway, why did you call?

column1: いや、また週末にでも食事にどうかなあ、と思って。
column2: Well. I thought we could do dinner this weekend.

column1: そうねえ、この仕事のプレゼンが金曜日なの。だから、週末なら行かれると思うわ。
column2: I guess so. The presentation for this project is on Friday. So I could go out if it's on the weekend.

column1: そうか、よかった！じゃあ、また電話するよ。忙しいところごめんね。頑張って。
column2: Oh great! Then, I'll call you again. I'm sorry to interrupte you while you were busy. So good luck with your work.

column1: はい、デザインオフィスＪでございます。
あ、担当の村上でございます！
おお、アンタか。遅くまで仕事させて、悪いねえ。ちょっと確認したいんだけどさ、俺、昨日の電話で表紙は青がいいって言ったっけ？

column2: Oh. This is Murakami. I'm in charge of your project.

column1: やっぱりそうかー。あのさ、今から赤に変えられる？
column2: Oh, it's you. I'm sorry I have you working late. I wanted to confirm something.  On the phone yesterday did I say that I wanted a blue cover?

column1: えっ…と、承知しました。ご連絡ありがとうございました。

column2: Oh, I did, did I? Um. Can I change that to red?

column1: うわぁ、今さら色を変えるなんて、本当に金曜日に間に合うのかしら。あ、いけない！もうこんな時間！終電に間に合わなーい！
column2: Uhhh.. I understand. Thanks for contacting us.

column1: あのさあ、今日、下の子の授業参観に初めて行ったんだけど、すごく面白かったよ。
column2: Today I went to see my kid's Parents' Day.  It was really interesting.

column1: ーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーー
column2: I observed the Math class and it went something like this...

column1: はじめにボールが3つ、ありました。あとで4つ、ふえました。ぜんぶでいくつになったかな？。。わかる人！

column2: First we had 3 balls, then we got four more balls.  Now how many balls do we have in total?  Who knows?

column1: じゃあ、レオ君。わかるかな。

column2: OK, Leo.  What do you think?

column1: そう！ほんとう？ほかにだれか、ちがうと思う人は？

column2: Is that so?  Really?  Anyone else who thinks it's different?

column1: ああ、そう。7ですか。ほかには？ほかの答えは？

column2: I see.  7, huh?  Anyone else?  Any other answers?

column1: ユウキくん、わかるかな。
う〜ん。7かあ。ほかには？答えわかる人は？
ーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーーー
column2: OK.  7, huh?  Anyone else?  Who else knows?

column1: ってまあ、ずっとこんな調子で、さらに２回も、子どもたちのハイハイハイ！が続いてさあ。驚いちゃったよ。
なるほどね。小学一年生ってそんなもんなのよね。
まさに、異文化コミュニケーション。子どもの世界ってすごいな。
column2: So, the class was like that the whole time.  I was surprised at the children saying 'me! me! me!' and it kept up like that 2 more times.

column1: お兄ちゃんも仕事ばっかりじゃなくて、たまには子どもとゆっくり過ごしなさいって。
column2: Yeah.  First Graders are just like that!
It's truly inter-cultural communication. The mind of a child is amazing!

column1: it can't be helped, it's inevitable; Adj(i)
if you do this for me, i'll be forever indebted to you.
column2: そうしてもらえると、 大変ありがたいです

column1: うちの子供から聞いたんですが、今度、ヤクルトが小学生を無料で野球観戦に招待してくれるんですって。一緒に行きませんか。
column2: I heard from my child that the (professional Japanese baseball team) Yakult Swallows is inviting elementary school kids to their games for free. Would you like to join us?

column1: すごいですね。無料招待なんて。。。ぜひ、ご一緒させてください。
column2: Wow. That's amazing. A free invitation? We would love to join you.

column1: いくつか候補日があるんですが、どの試合にしますか？やっぱり、巨人戦かな。
column2: We have a couple of dates in mind, but which game would you like to see? Perhaps the one against the Yomiuri Giants?

column1: そうしましょう！私は大の巨人ファンなので、そうしてもらえると、大変ありがたいです！
column2: I am a huge Giants fan, so I'd love that!

column1: 山田さんって、巨人ファンだったんですね。でも、ヤクルト側の席ですよ。それでもいいですか？
column2: Ms. Yamada, you're a Giants fan? But the seats are on the Yakult side. Is that alright?

column1: えー！それは、巨人ファンとしては耐えられないです。私だけ巨人側に座ってもいいですか？
column2: What? Um. As a giants fan, that's unbearable. Can I sit alone on the Giants side?

column1: うーーん、多分それはできないと思いますよ。
column2: Umnn. I don't think that's possible.

column1: あのぉ、こんなことお願いするのは、大変恐縮なのですが、うちの子供だけ連れて行ってもらえませんか？
column2: Well, this is very difficult for me to ask, but can you take my children to the game?

column1: 仕方ないですね。じゃぁ、私が連れて行きますよ。
column2: I guess I could. Sure, I'll take them.

column1: すみません。お手数をお掛けします。実は、私、巨人の応援団員なので、他球団の席に座るなんてことはもっての他なんです。勝手を言って申し訳ありませんが、どうぞよろしくお願いします。
column2: I'm so sorry to inconvenience you. Actually, I'm a member of the Giants' official cheering group and it would be unacceptable for me to sit on the side of another baseball team. I apologize for my selfish request, but I would appreciate your help very much.

column1: いつ読んでもドラゴン・ボールは最高だよな。
column2: Dragon Ball is the best, no matter when I read it. Don't you agree?

column1: アンタ、授業中に漫画読んでたでしょ。
column2: Dude. You were reading manga during the class.

column1: 女には、ドラゴン・ボールのロマンはわからないだろうなあ。「カ・メ・ハ・メ・波ぁぁ～！」やっぱりコレだよな。
column2: Women just can't understand the romance behind Dragon Ball. Kamehamehaaaaa! (Sound of a character blowing a Force-like energy ball) This is the one!

column1: 何よ。悟空なんて子供じゃない。亀仙人はただのエロじじいだし。やっぱり、北斗の拳よ。
column2: What are you talking about? (The main character) Goku is a kid. The Kame Sennin is just a perverted old man. The manga Hokuto no Ken is so much better.

column1: 「お前はもう、死んでいる。」ケンシロウ格好良すぎ！
column2: You are already dead! (Famous quote from the manga)  Kenshiro is soooo cool!

column1: お前 一応、女 だろ。「動物のお医者さん」とか、普通はそういうんだろ。
column2: You are a woman, at least last time I checked right? Women usually think veterinarians or something are cool.

column1: 何よ、その一応、女って。れっきとした乙女ですう。「あたたたたたたたたたたたたたたたたたたたた・・・」ケンシロウの北斗百裂拳ってほんとうに最高だわ。しびれるう～。
column2: How dare you question whether I'm a woman! I am too a noble woman! Atatatatata (sound of Kenshiro beating up an enemy) Kenshiro's Hokuto Hyakuretsua (One hundred blows) is the best! He makes me weak at the knees...

column1: この間タツオの家に遊びに行ったら、タツオ、「ドラえもん」全巻持っててさあ。
column2: I went to Tatsuo's house the other day, and he had the entire collection of the Doraemon comic series.

column1: お父さんに買ってもらったんだって。
column2: He said his father bought it for him.

column1: あの、ドラえもんが四次元ポケットからひみつ道具を出す時の、あれ。「（ドラえもんになりきって）タケコプター」ってやつ。あれ聞くとすごくワクワクするよね。
column2: I get really excited when I hear Doraemon's voice as he takes out a secret tool from his four-dimensional pocket. (Immitating Doraemon,) Take-copter! (Bamboo helicopter)

column1: ひみつ道具でしょ。すっごいワクワクする。私はね、「（ドラえもんになりきって）どこでもドア」が一番わくわくするね。
column2: His secret tools, right? I get most excited at (Immitating Doraemon) Dokodemo doa (door to everywhere.)

column1: 恋人にするなら、シズカちゃんより断然ドラミちゃんだね。
column2: If I were to choose a girlfriend, I would definitely choose Dorami-chan over Shizuka-chan.

column1: だって、四次元ポケット持ってるじゃん。ドラミちゃん歌もうまいし。楽しいって。
column2: Because she has the four-dimensional pocket. Dorami-chan is also good at singing. She's fun, I'm telling you!

column1: clear weather after a typhoon has passed
七月になって台風が多いよな
column2: There are a lot of typhoons in July, aren't there?

column1: そうそう、七月から九月だけで３０個ぐらいは日本に上陸するもんね。
column2: That's right. About 30 typhoons hit Japan between July and September.

column1: 大雨だし、強風だし、、、けど台風が来れば学校が休みになる可能性も高いけどね。どこにも行けないけど。。
column2: Because of heavy rains, strong winds... But if a typhoon lands, there is a high possibility that we'll get some time off school, although we won't be able to go anywhere...

column1: どうやら、ニ、三日したら、台風４号が来るかもしれないらしいよ。
column2: It seems like Typhoon No. 4 is going to hit Japan in two or three days.

column1: えーっ！今度の日曜日、釣りに行こうと思ってんのに。。。ダメじゃん。。。
column2: What? I'm thinking of going fishing this Sunday... I won't be able to go...

column1: そりゃー、しょうがないわ。
column2: Well, you can't do anything about it.

column1: しかも台風が過ぎた後は台風一過ですごい晴れて、めっちゃ気温が上がって。良いことないわ。
column2: On top of that, after a typhoon we get really sunny weather which causes temperatures to rise rapidly. Nothing good comes out of this.

column1: to start over, to do over
おはようございまーす。
あ、野村さんおはようございます。
アグネスさん、今朝も早いね。昨日も遅くまで残業していたでしょ？
column2: Agnes. You're here early again. You were working late last night, weren't you?

column1: 昨日、ゴリさんから電話があって。。。色を変えなきゃならなくなったんです。だから間に合うかどうか心配で。
column2: I got a call from Gori-san yesterday and I had to change colors. So I was worried about whether I could meet the deadline or not.

column1: ええっ！今から？それはひどいねー。
column2: What? Changes this late in the project? That's awful!

column1: 違う色でやり直してたら、全体を修正しないわけにはいかなくなってしまって。。。
column2: When I changed colors, I had to redo the entire thing...

column1: 大丈夫？プレゼンは明日でしょう？
column2: Are you okay? The presentation is tomorrow, isn't it?

column1: でも、クライアントの要望だから聞かざるをえないですよねぇ。
column2: Yes. But we have to listen to clients' requests, don't we?

column1: そうねえ。。。そういう困ったクライアント、多いのね。あ、今の、社長には内緒よ。
column2: I guess so...There are so many problem clients like that, you know. Oh, don't tell the president I just said that.

column1: 社長のお友達ですもんね。
column2: He is the president's friend, isn't he?

column1: だから、言うことを聞かないわけにいかないんだけどね。
column2: That's why we can't ignore what he says.

column1: ああー、どうしよう。間に合うかしら。
column2: Oh, gee. What should I do? I wonder if I'll make it in time.

column1: 僕、今日の仕事が一段落したら手伝ってあげるよ。この仕事は落とすわけにはいかないでしょう。
column2: I'll help you today when my own work winds down. We can't afford to lose this project, okay?

column1: いいんですか？ごめんなさい。
column2: Are you sure? I'm sorry to be such bother.

column1: いいんだよ。入社したばかりでこんなきつい仕事、大変だろう。後で誰か他にも手伝えるかどうか聞いてみるよ。
column2: That's alright. This must be a tough job for someone who just joined the company. I'll ask around later to see if anyone else can help as well.

column1: ありがとうございます！
（いきなり陰から出てきて、ぶつかってきたのはあなたじゃないですか。なんなんですか）
column2: (You're the one that suddenly jumped out of the shadows and bumped into me. What are you talking about?)

column1: 肩がいてーなー。どうしてくれんだよー。
column2: My shoulder hurts. What are you going to do about it?

column1: （1,2,3...3人組か。モヒカンを筆頭に全員チンピラ風。これって・・・世に言うオタク狩りってやつ！？）
column2: (He's in a group of 1, 2, 3? They all look like thugs, especially the one looks like a leader with a mohawk. Is this what is generally known as an Otaku-Gari? Otaku Hunting?)

column1: 許してほしければ、ドラゴンボールのマンガ全部とPSPを渡しな。
column2: If you want us to forgive you, hand over all your Dragon Ball magazines and your PSP.

column1: （あっ、やっぱりオタク狩りってやつですか。。。）
column2: (Oh, I knew it. This is the so-called Otaku Gari...)

column1: （男、持っていた日本刀をだす。ひるむ若い男達。）
column2: Hey. (The man pulls out a Japanese sword. The young men flinch)

column1: おっオタクが、そっ、そんな物だしていいのか。
column2: What? Are otaku allowed to pull out a sword?

column1: (look of) stores and houses on street
来月にアジア方面に旅行を考えているんですが、どこかオススメの場所はありませんか。
column2: We're thinking of going to Asia next month. Do you have any recommendations?

column1: 何日間くらいを考えていらっしゃいますか。
column2: How many days are you thinking of going?

column1: ちょっと調べてみますね。少々お待ちください。二名様でよろしいですか。
column2: Let me look into it. Please wait a moment. Will that be for a party of two?

column1: はい。お願いします。(三、四分後)
お待たせしました。今、一番のオススメは中国の上海ですね。7泊8日ホテル付きで１名様68,000円です。
column2: Thank you for waiting. Our top recommendation is Shanghai, China. It would cost 68,000 yen per person for seven nights, eight days including (airfare and) hotel fees.

column1: 上海は今人気ですよ。ヨーロッパ文化と中国文化がミックスされた町並みは上海独特できれいですし、上海はアジアのグルメ天国と言われてますから、食べ物もすごくおいしいですよ。
column2: Shanghai is very popular now. The unique landscape mixing European culture and Chinese culture is very nice, and Shanghai is called Asia's gourmet heaven so food is really delicious, too.

column1: どうする？（同席のユミに聞く）
column2: What do you think? (He asks Yumi, who is sitting next to him)

column1: 真夏の上海はものすごく暑いって聞くけど大丈夫かしら。
column2: I heard it's really hot in Shanghai in the midst of summer. I wonder if we'll be okay.

column1: この時期、アジアはどこでもうだるような暑さだよ。
column2: During this season, it's hot everywhere in Asia.

column1: そうよね。中華料理食べ尽くしっていうのもいいわねえ。
column2: I guess so. Eating Chinese food until we drop sounds good.

column1: じゃあ、決まり！すいません、では上海でお願いします。
column2: Alright then, it's set! (to employee) Sorry about that. We'd like to sign up for Shanghai.

column1: ありがとうございます。では早速予約を入れたいと思いますので、この用紙に必要事項をご記入ください。
column2: Thank you very much. Please fill out this form with necessary information because I'd like to make reservations for you.

column1: to throw something on the scrap
at the last moment, just barely
best if eaten by this date
フードバンクっていう活動、知ってる？この間、たまたま雑誌で読んだんだけど、それを読んだら、今までの私のスーパーでの食品の買い方を反省させられちゃったわ。
column2: Do you know what food banks do? I read about them in a magazine the other day and it made me reflect on my past grocery shopping patterns at supermarkets.

column1: フードバンクって何のこと？
フードバンクって、企業が食品を製造販売する過程で、商品にならなくなってしまったものを、無償で引き取って、それを非営利の福祉団体などを通して、食べ物に困っている人々へ無償で配給しようとするシステムなんですって。
column2: Food banks are a food redistribution system. During the manufacturing process, food manufacturers take back for free foods that can't be sold, and redistribute them for free to hungry people through non-profit welfare agencies and other organizations.

column1: アメリカでは、ずいぶん浸透しつつある活動らしいよ。
column2: The system has apparently taken root in the United States.

column1: ふーん、だけど、なんで、それがスーパーでの食品の買い方と関係があるわけ？
column2: Hmmn. But why does that have anything to do with your purchasing patterns at supermarkets?

column1: たとえば、牛乳を買うときは、賞味期限ができるだけ先の牛乳を選んで買ってたんだけど、みんながそういう買い方をするから、賞味期限ぎりぎりの牛乳ばかりが残っちゃって、それが結局廃棄処分になるわけよ。
column2: For example, when I bought milk, I used to choose milk cartons that had the furthest expiration date. But because we all do that, the cartons with the shortest time till the expiration dates get leftover and they all get tossed out eventually.

column1: なるほどね。みんながなるべく賞味期限が近いものを買っていけば、それだけ廃棄される食べ物が少なくなるもんな。
column2: I see. If we all bought foods that were closest to their expiration dates, less foods would be thrown away.

column1: そういうことよ。それに、パッケージがちょっとでもへこんでたりする商品は買わなかったりするでしょ。だから、中身に何の問題もなくても、パッケージが汚れたり傷ついたりした商品は廃棄処分されているのが現状らしいわ。
column2: That's right. And consumers tend not to buy food packages that are a bit bent. In reality, packages that are damaged or dirty end up being disposed of also.

column1: 確かに、わざわざパッケージが汚れている商品は買わないよな。
column2: That's true. We don't go out of our way to buy dirty food packages.

column1: フードバンクの活動が浸透することは大切だけど、それと同時に、私たち消費者も食品が無駄に廃棄されていることを認識する必要があるわね。
column2: It's important for the food bank system to take root, but at the same time, we consumers have to acknowledge the fact that many foods are unnecessarily thrown away.

column1: なんか、今日の君は、ずいぶん社会派だね。
column2: Wow. You sound so socially minded today.

column1: うーん…あ、もう朝？昨日も終電まで残業してたから、眠い…あと少しだけ寝よう…。
column2: Ugh...what? It's morning already? I was working until the last train again last night so I'm so tired... I think I'll get a little bit more sleep...

Oh no! It's already this late! I fell asleep again after waking up. I have a presentation in the morning today so I wanted to get to the office early to prepare. But now I barely have enough time. This is no time to be eating breakfast.

column1: お客様にお知らせします。先ほど人身事故が発生いたしました関係で、ただいま全線で運転を見合わせております。
ええーっ！人身事故！いつ動くのかしら？
column2: Attention, please. Due to an accident involving injuries, all trains on this line have been stopped.

column1: あ、駅員さん、すみません。運転再開まで、どれくらいかかりそうですか？
column2: What? An accident? I wonder when are the trains going to resume?

column1: 申し訳ございません、ただいま再開のめどが立っておりません。
column2: Umm. Sir. Excuse me. How long will it be until the trains start moving again?

column1: そんなあ！私、今日だけは遅刻できないのに…。
column2: I'm sorry, ma'am. We currently have no idea when the trains will resume.

column1: バスで別の路線の駅に向かっていただけないでしょうか。
column2: But that can't be! I really can't be late today...

column1: そんな遠回りしている場合じゃないのよー。仕方がないわ、タクシーで行こう。
column2: Could you take a bus to a different train line?

column1: うわあ、タクシー乗り場も長蛇の列！これじゃ間に合わない。あ、そうだ、会社に電話しなきゃ。
column2: This isn't the time to be taking a roundabout route. I have no choice. I'll take a taxi.

column1: はい、デザインオフィスＪでございます。
column2: Wow. There's a long line at the taxi stand.I won't make it. Oh, I should call the office.

column1: もしもし、村上アグネスです。実は、人身事故で電車が止まってしまって、会社に遅れそうなんです。
column2: Hello. This is Design Office J.

column1: ええっ！だって今日、10時からプレゼンだろ？
column2: Hello. This is Agnes Murakami. I'm about to be late for work due to an accident that's stopped the trains from running.

column1: この先渋滞中だってさー。
column2: Apparently there's a traffic jam up ahead.

column1: えー、どれぐらい渋滞してるのー。
column2: Oh no. How bad is it?

column1: ラジオでは談合坂を先頭に25キロの渋滞。。。たぶん、河口湖に着くのは昼過ぎになっちまうかも。
column2: The radio says it's a 25km congestion starting from Dangōzaka...It might be noon by the time we make it to Lake Kawaguchi.

column1: まーじーでー。下道（したみち）で行ったらどんくらいかかる？
column2: No way, really? How long will it take if we took the road below?

column1: んー。。これくらいの渋滞だったら、上で行っても、下道（したみち）で行くのと変わんねぇんじゃねーの。
column2: Hmnn. At this congestion level, I don't think it would make any difference if we took the high road or low road.

column1: だから休みの日に出かけるのは嫌なんだよねー。
column2: That's why I hate going out on holidays.

column1: よし、太郎、そこで壁をジャンプして逆立ちで着地するんだ！
column2: Okay, Taro. Jump off that wall and land in a handstand!

column1: いいぞ、太郎！でかした！！この技を習得するのに一年もかかったなぁ。
column2: That's right, Taro. That's great! It took a year for you to learn this trick. But now you can join the ranks of professional monkey performers. You can do a handstand and you can jump a high wall. And above all else, you can go shopping, cook and clean rooms.

column1: だが、これでお前も一人前のサルの一員だな。
逆立ちはできるし、こんなに高い壁だって跳べるんだ。
column2: Are you saying you're happy? Alright, alright. I'm happy, too, Taro. I've been training you with great care for the last two years. I'm not embarrassed to present you in front of people. Now all you have to do is learn to wash the bath tub and the toilet bowl. Then, you'll be perfect! Right, Taro?

column1: term of contempt used for monkeys
もうそろそろ、メシの時間じゃねーの？おい、太郎、メシはまだか？！早くしろよーっ。
column2: It's almost time for a dinner, isn't it? Hey, Taro. Is my meal ready yet? Make it quick.

column1: おっ、今日はハンバーグかぁ。今日は魚の気分だったんだけど。。。まぁいいや…
column2: Oh, we're having hamburgers tonight. I was in the mood for fish, but..oh well..Hey, Taro. I found your hair in my food...

column1: おい、太郎。お前の毛がちょっと入ってんだけど。。。
column2: Hey, is my bath ready? I want to take a bath after I eat, so make sure it's ready.

column1: あっ、風呂はもう沸いてんのか？メシ食ったら風呂に入りたいんだから、さっさと用意しとけよ。
column2: Hey! Did you iron my shirt? I have a big sales deal tomorrow, so I have to wear a crisply ironed shirt.

column1: あっ！ワイシャツにアイロンはかけといたのか？明日は大事な営業があるんだから、しっかりアイロンかけたシャツを着ていかないと。
column2: Oh, that's right. My girlfriend is coming over tomorrow so you need to sleep someplace outside!

column1: あっ、そうだそうだ、それから。。。

column2: What? Taro? ...Taro? Did a monkey just run away from home? ....Wait!!! It took me two years to train you! That damn monkey. I'm gonna catch him!

column1: 成田発、バンクーバー行きのお客様の搭乗手続きをまもなく締め切らせていただきます！
column2: The boarding process for the flight departing Narita to Vancouver has just finished.

column1: 待ったー！！！！まてまてまてまて！ここにもう一人、搭乗者が居ます！
column2: Wait, wait, wait, wait! There is one more passenger.

column1: お客様、お急ぎ下さい、あと三十分（30分）でバンクーバー行きが出発してしまいます。パスポートと搭乗券を拝見させていただきます。
column2: Please hurry, sir.　The flight will depart in 30 minutes.  Your passport, please.

column1: はい、お預かりします。。。。お客様、このパスポート、どうやらお母様かどなたかのパスポートではないでしょうか？
column2: Thank you, Sir. Ah, Sir, this passport must be your mother's or someone else's.

column1: はっ！やべー、しまった、オカンのパスポート持って来ちゃったよ！待って確かにこの中に入れたはずなんだ。。。ほらあった！！これでしょ、これ、はい！！
column2: What, oh shoot. I brought my mother's passport. Wait a minute. I'm sure I put mine in here. Oh! here it is.  This is it. Here it is.

column1: はい、確かに。それではお荷物の方なんですが、、、三つ（3つ）でよろしいですか？
column2: Thank you, Sir.  Uh, about your luggage, will be there three pieces?

column1: 恐れ入りますお客様。当機でのお一人様の最大積載重量は三十キロ（30ｋｇ）となっております。
column2: Excuse me, Sir.  The upper limit on the baggages is 30kg.
Your luggage weight 60kg. We're going to have to charge you 100,000 yen for the extra weight.  Would that be alright?

column1: しょうがない。。。はい大丈夫ですよ。
column2: What am I going to do? Sure, that's fine.

column1: はい、ではお客様、出発の準備はすべて整いました。
column2: Well, then, you are ready to board, Sir. Please hurry to Gate 45.

column1: to get tired of, to lose interest in
ゲート45、ゲート45・・・どこだぁ？！。。。あ、あった！
column2: Gate 45, gate 45... Where is it?... Oh, I found it!
Are you Mr. Yamada? Please hurry. It's already past the scheduled departure time.
(The plane takes off) Phew. I made it somehow although all the packing took some time. Well, I'm tired. I'm going to take a nap. zzzz

column1: ああああぁぁぁあ（あくび）、やっとバンクーバーに着いた。エコノミークラスは窮屈でたまらんなぁ。まぁ、なんとか税関もすぐに抜けられたし、安心安心。
column2: (The plane arrives in Vancouver) Haaaa (yawns) I'm finally in Vancouver. Economy class was so tiny. I couldn't stand it. Well, I somehow got through customs really quickly so I'm relieved.
Oh! I forgot! I have to open the trunk or she'll die! Mom! We're here in Vancouver!

column1: イヤーしんどかった。。。肩、腰が痛い。。トランクの中に10時間て、どんだけー！
column2: (Mom comes out of the trunk) My goodness that was rough....My shoulders and hip hurt. Could you imagine being inside a suitcase for 10 hours?
It was hot, I was hungry, I ran out of water half way through... I thought I was going to shrivel up.
But it was a good idea to pack the PSP and Nintendo DS with me. I didn't get bored. But despite all my efforts, the first day in Vancouver is rainy?

column1: opening of a country (e.g., Japan) to the world
殿ぉ！お誕生日、おめでとうございます！今日は11月23日。マーキー様の50才の誕生日ですぞ！こうしては居られません。盛大に殿のお誕生日を祝いましょう。
column2: My Lord, Happy Birthday!  Today is November 23rd.  It's your 50th birthday, Lord Marky. We shouldn't be standing around like this. We should be celebrating your birthday lavishly.

column1: そうよのー、なにかクレージーな事をせねばの。
column2: Yes. We should do something crazy.

column1: 何か、やりたいこと、欲しい物はありますか？
column2: Is there anything you would like to have or do?

column1: それでは、姫路城を貸し切ってしまおう。
column2: As a matter of fact, there is... let's rent out the entire Himeji Castle.

column1: 。。。。。えっ？姫路城をですか？何を言ってるんですか、殿？
column2: What?  Himeji Castle?  What are you saying, my Lord?

column1: いや、だから、姫路城でパーティーをせねば。ふんどしで。姫路城城主、酒井忠顕（さかいただてる）にはワシから申しておく。
column2: Hmmmm. So...  we should have a party at Himeji Castle… in a fundoshi!  I'll ask the owner of Himeji Castle, Tadateru Sakai, myself.

column1: 姫路城で。ふんどしで。殿、殿は最近お忙しくお疲れの様子。どうやら熱でも出されているのでしょう。少しお休みになられた方が良いのではないかと。。。
column2: At Himeji Castle? In our underwear? My Lord, I believe you are simply exhausted from all the work recently.  You probably have a fever.  I believe it's best that you get some rest...

column1: （パーティー in 姫路城）
column2: I'm not tired.  I'm serious!  Oh and that's right, let's invite that Perry guy who's visiting from America.  He's an American, so he should be used to partying.  It'll be fun!

column1: Wooo-hooo!!!! どうだ、家来、楽しいだろ！！
はい、大変楽しゅうございます！！
column2: Wooo-hooo!!!  Hey vassal, what do you think?  This is fun, isn't it?

column1: あ、ペリー君！来てたのかね！どうだ、これが日本のパーティーだ。すごいだろ？！
開国シテクダサーイよ～！
column2: Well, Lord Sakai. Thank you so much for allowing us to rent out your castle today.  Oh. Mr. Perry!  You came!  What do you think?  This is a Japanese party. Isn't it great?!

column1: ん？開国？うむうむ、わかったわかった。わしから幕府の方に開国するように申しておこう。今宵は最後まで楽しむぞよ！！！
column2: Please open up your country (for international trade).

column1: はい、こちら北山クリニックです。
本日うかがいたいのですが、診察時間は何時までですか？
column2: I would like to visit today.  Can you tell me how late you're open?

column1: 本日は土曜日ですので、診察の受付は午後1時までとなっております。土曜日は混み合いますので、お早めにおいでください。
column2: Today is Saturday, so we offer examinations until 1 in the afternoon.  Saturday gets packed, so please come early.

column1: 村上さん、村上アグネスさーん。
村上さん、本日はどうされました？
column2: Please go to the examination room.

column1: あのう、昨日の夜から胃が痛くて…。
column2: Ms. Murakami, what is the matter with you today?

column1: ふむ。どんな痛みですか？しくしく痛いとか、締め付けられるように痛いとか…。
column2: Since yesterday evening, I've had a stomachache.

column1: ええ、断続的にキリキリ痛みます。
column2: Hmmm.....  What kind of pain is it?  Do you have a gripping pain in the stomach, or do you feel like it is clenched into a tight knot?

column1: 吐き気や下痢など、他に症状はありますか？
column2: Yes, I have a sharp on-and-off pain.
Do you have any other symptoms such as nausea and diarrhea?

column1: えーと、昨日何か変わったものを食べたりしましたか。
いいえ、昨日はほとんど何も食べていないんです。
column2: Um...  Did you eat something strange yesterday?

column1: おや、痛くて食べられなかったんですか？
column2: No, I hardly ate anything yesterday.

column1: いえ、仕事でちょっとトラブルがあったもので、食欲がなくて。大事なプレゼンの日だったんですけど、遅刻しちゃったんです。職場の人に迷惑をかけた上に、その仕事は結局契約が取れなくて…ほとんど徹夜で頑張ったのに、無駄になっちゃったと思ったら、もう何も喉を通らなくて。
column2: Oh.  You couldn't eat from the pain?

column1: ううーむ。これは、ストレスから来る軽い胃炎かもしれませんなあ。
column2: No, I didn't have any appetite because I was faced with a small problem at work.  I had an important presentation yesterday, and I was late.  Not only did I cause trouble to people at work, but I wasn't able to sign the deal for that job after all...  I got a lump in my throat thinking about how all the work I did staying up almost all night long was for nothing.

column1: もしもし？橋本だけど、アグネスさん、昨日電話くれた？
column2: Hello? This is Hashimoto. Agnes, did you call me yesterday?
Yes. I called about five times.

column1: ゴメンゴメン、この週末は学会で広島に来ているんだ。
column2: Sorry about that. I'm in Hiroshima this weekend for an academic conference.

column1: 昨日も一日研究発表があって…それさえなければすぐ連絡できたんだけど、何か大事な用事だった？
column2: Yesterday I had a presentation all day...If it weren't for that, I would have been able to call you right away. Was it something important?

column1: もう用事は済んだからいいの。
column2: No. It's okay. I already took care of it.
What? What did you take care of?

column1: 雄介さん、病院勤務だって言ってたでしょ。だからお医者さんを紹介してもらおうかと思ったの。
column2: You said that you were working at a hospital, right, Yusuke? So I was hoping you could introduce me to a doctor. But I couldn't get in touch with you so I went to a local clinic.
My stomach hurts. The doctor said it was gastric inflammation caused by stress. I got much better after taking my medications. But I'll be home all day today.

column1: 胃が痛いの。ストレス性胃炎だって。薬を飲んだら、だいぶよくなったけど、今日は一日家にいるわ。
column2: Gastric inflammation? Hmmnnn. That's bad timing.

column1: 胃炎？そうか、タイミング悪いなあ。

column2: Well, I was thinking of sending you fresh oysters from Hiroshima, but it's not good for your stomach, is it? I'm glad I got in touch with you before I mailed it.

column1: いや、広島から新鮮な牡蠣を送ろうかと思ったんだけど、胃によくないよね。

column2: Um. Well, I was worried about your health as well, Agnes. Are you alright?

column1: あ、いや、アグネスさんの容態も心配だよ。大丈夫？

column2: Damn! I love oysters! If only I didn't have this stupid stomachache! Oh well. I have no other choice. I guess I'll have some rice porridge...

column1: おはようございまーす。あ、アグネスさん、社長がお昼前に社長室へ来るように、って。大丈夫？顔色悪いよ。
column2: Good morning. Oh, Agnes. The president told me he wants to see you in his office before lunch. Are you okay? You look faint.

column1: えー、何だろう…まだ胃も痛いのに、気が重いなあ。
column2: Hmm. I wonder what the president wants to talk about. I still have gastric inflammation. I'm not looking forward to it.
You had a rough week last week, didn't you? But the president wasn't very upset.

column1: 社長、先週のプレゼンは本当に申し訳ありませんでした…って、何なさってるんですか？
何って君、見れば分かるだろう。新鮮な魚介類が手に入ったから、今日は炭火焼にしているんだ。まあ座りなさい。君ならこの味が分かるだろう。
column2: President Fujimoto. I'm really sorry about last week's presentation... What.. what are you doing?

column1: 社長、実は私、今日は胃が…
column2: Can't you tell just by watching? I got some fresh seafood today so I'm char-grilling it. Well, have a seat. I'm sure you'll be able to appreciate this taste.

column1: いやー、先週はゴリの件でだいぶ無理をさせたねえ。あいつは昔から傍若無人なところがあってね。
column2: President Fujimoto. I actually have a stomachache today.
Oh. Last week, we worked you hard on Gori's case. He's always kind of reckless.

column1: まあでも、この世界も弱肉強食だからなあ。ビジネスには強引さも必要なんだ。しかし、それで取引先の信用を失ったら本末転倒だろう、そうは思わないか、君？

column2: But you know. This world is all about the survival of the fittest. You need to be aggressive in business. But if you lose the client's trust, you lose everything. Don't you think?

column1: うんうん、そうなんだ。今度あいつにはよく言っておかないと。あ、ちょうど牡蠣が焼けたぞ。ほら、食べなさい！広島から直送だ！
う、また牡蠣…えーい、いつまでも意気消沈していられないわ！社長、いただきまーす！
column2: Right. Right. I'll tell him next time when I see him. Oh, the oysters are ready. Here, have some! They were sent directly from Hiroshima!

column1: give a try, by way of trial
ねえねえ、アグネスさん、ちょっと相談していい？
column2: Hey Agnes. Can I ask for your opinin on something?

column1: あのね、このポスターなんだけど、クライアントに、全体的に暗いって言われちゃったんだけど。どう思う？
column2: About this poster. A client said it was too dark overall. What do you think?

column1: うーん…この、木の色をもう少し明るい感じにするとか。
column2: Ummm. You could make the color of this tree a bit brighter.

column1: 僕もそう思って、試しにやってみたんだけど、そうするとすごく嘘っぽくなっちゃうの。ほら。
column2: I thought so too, and tried it. But then it looks really fake. See?

column1: あー、ホントだ。なんか、平面的ですねえ。
column2: Oh, you're right. It looks two-dimensional.

column1: でしょう？でも、基本的なデザインは変えられないんだよね。
column2: Right? But we can't change the basic design.

column1: この明るい色のまま、影を濃くしたら子供っぽい感じがなくなりませんか？
column2: If you keep the bright color and make the shadow darker, would it look childish?

column1: あ、そうか。でもそうすると、この背景と合わない感じなんだよね。ここをもう少し黄色っぽい色にしてみようか。
column2: I guess. But then it won't fit this background scenery. We could try making this part a bit more yellowish.

column1: あ、いい感じじゃないですか！
じゃあ、これで出してみるか。あーあ、この会社っていつもこんな感じなんだよね。
column2: Okay. I'll give it a shot. Geez. This company is always like this.

column1: クレームが具体的じゃないですよね。
column2: The complaints aren't very specific, right?

column1: そうなんだよ！この間も、ボランティア活動のポスターを、「もう少し情熱的な感じでお願いします」とか言われてさ。
column2: Right! The other day, a client said that our volunteer events poster needed to be a bit more passionate-looking.

column1: うわー、そういうの、一番困りますよねー。
あ、お母さん。久しぶりねー。
column2: Oh, Mom. It's been a while, hasn't it?

column1: まったくこの子は、ちっとも連絡してこないで。心配していたのよ。
column2: Geez, Agnes. You never call me. I've been worried sick about you.

column1: ごめんごめん、このところちょっと仕事が忙しくて、留守がちだったから。
column2: Oh, I'm sorry. I've been busy with work lately and haven't been home much.

column1: そうだったのね。まだ忙しいの？
column2: Is that right? Are you still busy?

column1: もうそれほど忙しくないから大丈夫よ。
column2: No. I'm not as busy anymore, so it's okay.

column1: ところでアグネス、あなたまだ知らないでしょ？あなたの従姉妹の由美ちゃん、今度子供が生まれるのよ。
column2: By the way, Agnes. You probably don't know yet, do you? Your cousin Yumi is having a baby soon.

column1: ええー！由美ちゃんまだ若いのに、もうママになっちゃうの？
column2: What? Yumi is still so young. She's going to be a mother already?

column1: 何を言っているの。彼女だってもう24歳よ。
column2: What are you saying? She's already 24.

column1: 十分若いわよ。確か結婚したときはまだ学生だったのよね。
column2: That's young enough. If I remember correctly, she was still a student when she got married, right?

column1: そうよ。お姉さんの由紀ちゃんにはもう子供がいるし、由美ちゃんは子育てに関しては心配はいらないわね。それに比べてうちは…。
column2: That's right. Her older sister Yuki already has children,  so Yumi doesn't need to worry about raising children. Compare that with our family...Agnes... Aren't you going to get married yet? You're already 30, aren't you?
I'm only 29! And besides, what's up with marriage all of a sudden? I don't even have a boyfriend.

column1: まだ29歳よ！それに、いきなり結婚って何よー。まだ彼氏だっていないのに。
column2: Okay. But, I can't believe you're saying that at your age...It's pitiful. Your father and I were just saying that we're not that young anymore, and so it would be nice to get some grandchildren soon.

column1: あーあ。いい年してそれじゃあねえ…嘆かわしい。

column2: Do you plan to stay in Tokyo for good without ever coming back?

column1: ちょっとお母さん、気が早すぎ。
column2: I don't know about something that far ahead.

column1: あなた、もうこちらには帰らないでずっと東京にいるつもりなの？
column2: Please settle down as soon as you can and make your father and I feel at ease. Your father is retiring soon.

column1: そんなのまだ分からないわよ。
column2: Yeah, yeah. Is that all you want? I'm hanging up!

column1: Food served during the New Year's Holidays
さぁ、みんなそろったかな。今日から新しい１年が始まるぞ。お屠蘇でお祝いしよう。
column2: So we are all gathered here.  A new year will start as of today.  Let's celebrate it with o-toso. (O-toso is an alcoholic drink which is served with o-sechi and is said to drive out evil spirits.)

column1: さぁ、どうぞ。おじいちゃんから。
column2: Go ahead.  You should drink first, since you're grandpa.

column1: 新年あけましておめでとうございます！
新年おめでとうございます！
新年おめでとうございます！
column2: I want to drink o-toso too!

column1: お屠蘇、ぼくも飲んでみたいなぁー！
column2: Oh, Daichi!  You want to drink some too?  OK, just a little bit.

column1: おっ！大地も飲んでみるか。ちょっとだけだぞ。
column2: Gulp.  Wow!  Mmmm!  It tastes strange, but because it is sweet I wanna drink more!

column1: ごく。。うぁ！ん！！ちょっと変な味だけど、甘いから、もっと飲みたい！！
column2: No, you can't.  It may be sweet but it's still alcohol.  So, let's eat some o-sechi (an assortment of traditional New Year's food).

column1: だめだめ、甘くたってお酒なんだから！さぁさぁ、おせち料理食べましょう！
column2: Wow, it must have taken a lot of work to make this much.

column1: まぁ、こんなにいっぱい作るの、大変だったでしょ。
column2: O-sechi brings good luck.  Please eat some black soybeans (kuromame) so you can stay healthy and you will be able to work diligently (mame) throughout the year.

column1: おせち料理は縁起ものだからね。
column2: Then Grandma and Grandpa should eat this shrimp so they can live a long life.
(Sob sob) Oh, you're such a nice little boy!

column1: じゃぁ、おじいちゃんとおばあちゃんは、この海老食べて長生きしてね。
column2: Well, I want to get my o-toshidama (pocket money given to kids on New Years Day) from you guys for ever!

column1: やさしいねぇー、この子は。。。ううう。。。
column2: Oh!  So you are after o-toshidama, eh?  Oh well,  here it is, your o-toshidama.   This one is for your older brother.  And this one is for you, Daichi.

column1: だって、おばあちゃんとおじいちゃんから、ずーっとお年玉もらいたいんだもん！
なんだ、目当てはお年玉かい！しょうがないねぇ。はい、お年玉。はい、おにいちゃん。はい、大地。
column2: Hey, let me feel my brother's envelope! (Pochibukuro is the name of the small envelope in which o-toshidama is wrapped.) Hey, it's thinner than mine!  Yea!  I have more than he does.  Yea, yea!

column1: ありがとう！！ ねぇ、おにいちゃんのぽち袋触らせて！あれ、僕のより薄いよ！！わーい、僕の方がいっぱい入ってるんだ。わーい、わーい。
column2: Oh dear, Daichi is still a child, isn't he?

column1: to shake off, to shake free from
the first sunrise of the year
そこのバイク今すぐ止まりなさい！！！
column2: You on the motorcycle, pull over immediately!

column1: わかってるよ、けど、ただ、暴走族じゃないのになんで警察が追って来るんだよ～。
column2: I know, I know.  But why are the police after us when we aren't even bosozoku (members of a motorcycle gang).  There are plenty of other motorcycle gangs out there, but why me!  Oh well, what else can I do?  In that case....
Phew, we managed to outrun them.

column1: ふぅ、なんとか振り切った。。。。
column2: Hey, we're not going to make it in time for the first sunrise of the year.  Please hurry.

column1: あ、日の出まで間に合わないじゃない。早くして！
column2: All right, we're gonna burn some rubber. Hold tight till we get to Lake Kawaguchi.

column1: よし、何とか間に合った。

column2: Wow, the first sunrise of the year.  It's beautiful...

column1: あれ？俺のバイクが無いぞ。。。
ああああ！！！！サルが俺のバイクを運転してる。。。。
あれ、もしかしてあれは、、、、太郎じゃないか？！アイツいつの間にバイクの運転ができるようになったんだ。。。。
column2: Aaaah!  A monkey's on my bike...  Hey, is that.....  is that Taro?  Since when did he learn how to ride a bike?   Well, what can I do?  I’ll give that bike to Taro as a New Year's gift.  Happy New Year, Taro!

column1: to be filled with awe, to be surprised, to be sorry, to be grateful
大変お待たせいたしました。矢神でございます。
column2: Thank you very much for waiting. This is Yagami.

column1: 私、札幌堂の松平と申します。
札幌堂の松平様ですね。担当の者とかわりますので少々お待ちください。
column2: Sure. You are Mr. Matsudaira from Sapporo-Do, right? Please hold. I'll get the person in charge on the line right away.

column1: 申し訳ございません。あいにく担当の者は外出しております。
column2: Unfortunately, the person in charge is out of the office right now.

column1: では、お手数ですが折り返しお電話をいただけますでしょうか。
column2: Yes. That would be most appreciated, although it would be an inconvenience to her.

column1: 確かに申し伝えます。私、人事課の矢神が承りました。
column2: I will be sure to give her your message. This was Yagami from the human resources department.

column1: それでは、よろしくお願いいたします。
column2: Thank you very much for your help.

column1: very kind of you, sorry to trouble
すみません。私、札幌堂の松平と申します。人事部の山本様と３時に打ち合わせの約束をしているのですが。
column2: Excuse me, I'm Matsudaira from Sapporo-do.  I have an appointment with Mr. Yamamoto from the personnel division at three.
Okay, Mr. Matsudaira from Sapporo-do, the personnel division is located on the third floor.  Please use the elevator located over there.

column1: 大変お待たせいたしました。私、人事部・派遣担当の山本次郎と申します。（名刺を差し出す）
column2: Sorry for keep you waiting.  I am Jiro Yamamoto from the personnel division.  I am in charge of staff dispatching. (hands his business card).

Thank you very much.  I am Hiroshi Matsudaira from Sapporo-do (hands his business card).  Thank you very much for taking the time out of your busy schedule.Knock-knock (someone knocks on the meeting room door)

column1: では早速、詳細について教えていただけますでしょうか。
column2: Can we go straight into the details?

column1: はい。来たる2008年2月26、27日に国際シンポジウムを開催いたします。
column2: Yes.  On February 26th and 27th of next year, we are going to hold an international symposium.

column1: シンガポール、フランス、イギリス、から研究者を招き、日本人研究者を交えセッションを行う予定になっております。
column2: We are going to invite various researchers from Singapore, France, and Britain.  We are planning to conduct a session including Japanese researchers.
Therefore, we are going to need a simultaneous interpreter and would like to enlist your company for dispatching translators.

column1: 何カ国語の通訳者が必要なのでしょうか。
column2: You need translators for how many languages?

column1: 基本的には英語、フランス語になります。
column2: We mainly need English and French.

column1: はい。フランスから１名、シンガポールから１名、イギリスから２名の予定です。それと、日本人研究者が３名と司会の方が１名です。
column2: Yes.  We are expecting to have 1 person from France, 1 person from Singapore, and 2 from England.  Also, there will be 3 Japanese researchers and we need 1 person as a host.

column1: 全部で８名ですね。会場全体ではどうでしょうか？
column2: So that will be 8 in total.  What will the whole conference be like?

column1: １００名から２００名程度だと思います。
column2: I think it will be from around 100 to 200 people.

column1: 会場全体のおおよその参加者数は、より具体的に教えていただけますか。
column2: Can you tell me more details regarding the number of participants?  This is because the number of headphones for the audience that we have to prepare will be different.
The arrangement of equipment for simultaneous translation will be altered depending on the number of participants, so please let me know.

column1: 同時通訳機材の手配は人数によって変わってきますのでよろしくお願い致します。
column2: Also, please let me know the length of the conference, and the general contents.  The price of the translators will be different depending on the total hours spent at work.

column1: 会議の長さや、おもな内容等もお教えください。通訳者も拘束時間によって料金が違いますので。
column2: Yes, of course.  The details will be sent to you by fax immediately.  Please have a look, and can we also ask for the estimated amount?

column1: はい。わかりました。詳細はすぐにFAXいたします。

column2: Mr. Matsudaira, there's a fax for you.

column1: うーん、まいったなあ。完全に予算オーバーだわ。
同時通訳ってこんなに高いのね。
もしもし。山本様でいらっしゃいますか。
札幌堂の松平でございます。
さきほど、送っていただいた見積書の方を拝見させていただきました。
column2: I went over the written estimate that you have just sent me.

column1: はい。それで、いかがでしょうか。
はい。諸々の諸経費を含めますと、若干予算オーバー気味ですので、もう一度詳細の方を再考いたしまして、再提出させていただきたいのですが。
column2: Yes, when all the kinds of expenses are added, it's a little over our budget. So we will reconsider the details and resubmit them.

column1: あと、同時通訳の料金なのですが、４時間を超えますと料金の方は一日分となるわけですよね。
column2: Also, regarding the simultaneous translation expense...  When it is over 4 hours, the expense is calculated as a whole day expense, right?

column1: はい。そうです。料金に関しましては、やや高く設定させていただいておりますが、我が社の通訳者は実績も実力も申し分ないと自信を持って言わせていただきます。
column2: Yes, that is correct.  Regarding the expense, our company has set it a little high, but we are confident that our company's translators have the experience and ability.

column1: はあ。わかりました。大事な国際会議ですので、どうぞよろしくお願いいたします。
column2: Okay, I understand.  Because it's a very important international conference, I would like your company's assistance.

column1: （こりゃあ、先方と予算組み直しかもな・・・とほほ）
column2: (I probably have to look over the budget with the client again... Oh man...)

column1: 今日はどうしましたか？
先生、私、健康のために禁煙したいんです。
column2: I want to quit smoking to improve my health, Doc.

column1: それなら、禁煙したらいいんじゃないかね。
column2: Okay. Then go ahead and quit smoking.

column1: ええ、でも、14回も禁煙に挑戦したんですが全て失敗しました。
column2: Uhh, yeah but I've tried quitting 14 times and failed every single time. The more I think about not smoking, the more I want to smoke. What should I do?

column1: それじゃ禁煙のガムを。。
column2: I've already tried that!! Gum, filters, all these things marketed for people who want to quit smoking. But I haven't been able to quit...

column1: それはもうやりました！！禁煙ガム、禁煙フィルター、全てやりました。ですが駄目なんです。。。
column2: Okay. Then let's try this. Lie down on the bed.

column1: よし分かった。では、これを試してみよう。ベッドに横になってごらん。

column2: Look at this coin very carefully...You're feeling sleepy...You feel good...You don't want to smoke anymore... Okay. Open your eyes. Now, look at this cigarette. Do you want to smoke it?

column1: それではこのコインをじーっと見なさい。
column2: ...Uh.. No. I don't want to smoke it at all. Wow, Doctor! I don't want to smoke anything at all.

column1: to dye, to colour, to color
心が安定しないんです。そわそわしているって言うか。
column2: I'm emotionally unstable. I can't settle down.

column1: ノリノリでイケイケの時もあれば、どん底に落ちて何もできない時もあるんです。
column2: Sometimes I'm really excited and high. But other times, I'm depressed and can't do anything.

column1: 激しくやってくる感じ？
column2: Do these emotions come in drastic waves?
I think you're slightly manic depressive.

column1: まわりにもそう言われます。
では、薬をだそう。まず一つ目は精神安定剤。そして二つ目はこれ。
column2: Well, let me prescribe some medications. First, a tranquilizer. And the second is this.

column1: うむ。これは、「髪を染めるように性格を染める」と言われているくらい強い薬だ。
column2: Um. This is such a strong drug, it's said to paint your personality the way hair dye dyes your hair. Only use it when you're really depressed.

column1: 先生！あの強い薬また出してください！

column2: Doctor! Please prescribe those strong medications again! Those are great! They clear my mind so well. And they fill me with energy.

column1: 強い薬だから飲みすぎてはいけませんよ。副作用が出てくるかもしれないよ。
column2: Don't take too many. You may get some side effects.

column1: 腕がしびれてくるとか、動悸が激しくなるとか、まあ人によっていろいろ。
column2: Your arms may feel tingly. You may get heart palpitations. It depends on each patient.

column1: 体調が悪いんです。食べても吐いてしまうし。
column2: I don't feel so good. I vomit when I eat.

column1: 顔色が真っ青ですよ。では聴診器をあてるので、上を脱いでください。
column2: Your face is all pale. Okay, take off your shirt. I'm going to put a stethoscope against your chest.

column1: 栄養失調ですね。どうされたんですか。
実は彼女にフラれてから、精神的ショックでほとんど何も食べられなくなってしまって。無理に食べても吐いてしまうんです。
column2: Actually, ever since my girlfriend dumped me, I've been in such shock that I haven't been able to eat. Even when I force myself to eat, I just vomit.

column1: 点滴を打ちましょう。まずは体に栄養を与えないといけません。
column2: Let's give you an IV. First we have to give your body some nutrition.

column1: えーっ！腕に打つんですか。
column2: What? You're going to give me an injection on my arm?

column1: はい。体が衰弱していますから。おーい。点滴の用意をお願い。
column2: Yes, because your body is weak. Hey, get the IV ready.
Wait, wait doctor. I don't like injections.

column1: はい、おとなしくして。君たち、ちょっと体を押さえて。

column2: Hey, quiet down. Everyone, hold him down.

column1: (患者気絶。患者は注射恐怖症だった。）
column2: Yes. It would be awful if the needle broke. Please sit still!

column1: cavity, tooth decay, decayed tooth, caries
to extract, to draw out, to unplug
to hurt, to feel a pain, to be injured,
今日は、どうしましたか。
一週間くらい前からずっと、右の上の歯が痛むんですが…。
column2: My tooth on the upper right side has been hurting since a week ago.

column1: ...はい？すみませんね。耳が遠いんですよ。
column2: What? I'm sorry. I can't hear very well.

column1: 右の　上の　歯が　痛いんです。
column2: Um. My tooth on the upper right side hurts.

column1: ああ。右上の歯ね。見てみましょうか。はい、口を大きく開けて。はい、あーん。
column2: Oh. Your tooth on the upper right side. Okay. Open wide. Ah...

column1: 痛いのはこの歯ですか？（コンコン）
column2: Is this the one hurting? (knocks on tooth)

column1: 違う・・・と思います。
じゃ、この歯かな？　（コンコン）
column2: How about this one? (knocks on tooth)

column1: あのぉ。先生。レントゲンを撮ったり...しないんですか。
column2: Um. Doctor. Aren't you going to take an x-ray or something?

column1: レントゲン？私を誰だと思っているんですか。私は、80年歯科医師をしているんです。80年ですよ。
column2: X-ray? Who do you think I am? I've been a dentist for 80 years. Eighty years! I've been a dentist since before you were even born. I can tell a cavity when I see one.
Doc. Regardless of your experience, please take an x-ray.

column1: 先生、経験があろうがあるまいが、レントゲンは撮ってください。
column2: Ah-ha! It is a cavity. Look at this X-ray. It's really deep. This tooth will have to be taken out. Okay. Open wide. Raise your hands if it hurts. (Eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeek, ggggggg, Grrrrrrrrrrr)

column1: やっぱり虫歯ですね。ほら、このレントゲンを見てください。かなり深いですよ。
column2: Ugh. Ugh. Doctor, doctor. Please use anesthesia. Please!
It'll be over soon. Hang in there. (Eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeek, ggggggg, Grrrrrrrrrrr)

column1: あががががあ。せ、先生痛い！ま、麻酔をしてください。麻酔をお願いします！
column2: Okay. It's out. See, this is the cavity...huh? This isn't the cavity...I made a mistake...Oops! ha ha ha ha

column1: （ウィィイイイーン　キーィイイイイン　ガガガガガ）
to spread out, to lay out
as you see, as you can see
(お花見対決 1)今日は込んでるなあ。すごい人だ。
column2: (Cherry Blossom Showdown 1)It's so crowded today. There are tons of people here.

column1: 絶好の花見日和ですからね。
column2: Today is the perfect day for Hanami.

column1: 場所などもうないのではないか。
column2: I guess all the spots are taken.

column1: 大丈夫です。場所を取っておきましたから。
column2: Don't worry. I reserved our spot.

column1: 昨日、夜中に来てシートを敷いておきました。「大原家」って紙を貼っておきましたから。
column2: Yesterday, at the nidnight, I came here to lay out a sheet and stick a paper that says Ōhara family on it.

column1: たしかあの辺なんですけど・・・あれっ、誰かいますね。
column2: It should be around here…uh-oh, there's someone.

column1: ああ、田島社長ですねえ。（なんで緑山出版の田島社長がいるのよ。大原社長と犬猿の仲じゃん・・・）
column2: Yes, it is President Tajima.(Why is President Tajima of Midoriyama publishing company, here. She and President Ōhara have been fighting like cats and dogs.)

column1: これはこれは田島さん、こんなところで何を・・・。
column2: Well well, Tajima-san. What are you doing here?

column1: 大原さんじゃないですか。見てのとおりお花見ですよ。おたくは？
column2: Oh, it's you, Ōhara-san. As you can see, what we are doing is Hanami. How about you?

column1: われわれもお花見ですよ。
あのー、この辺りにうちのシートが敷いてあったはずなんですけれど。
column2: Excuse me, our sheet should be around here.

column1: シート？おい、山中、シートここに敷いてあったか？
column2: Sheet? Hey, Yamanaka, did you find any sheets here?

column1: いえ。朝６時に来たときは何もなかったです。おたく、場所を間違えてるんじゃないの。
column2: No, I didn't find anything when I came here at six in the morning. Are you sure this is the right place?

column1: たしかにここです。この大きい木が目印でしたから。あっ、あんなところに。
column2: This is definitely the place. I remember this big tree as a landmark. Ah, look over there.

column1: to be worried, to be bothered
occupation, have a room to oneself
(お花見対決 ２、くしゃくしゃになったシートと紙がゴミ箱に捨ててあるのに気がつく。)ひどい。ちょっとひどいじゃないですか。
column2: (Cherry Blossom Showdown 2,Sakurai notices some crunched up pieces of paper in the garbage can.) This is awful. Just awful.

column1: 我々は関係ないよ。我々がやったなんて証拠は？
column2: We have nothing to do with that. What proof do you have that we did it?

column1: ここを占領してるのが、明らかな証拠でしょ。
column2: You occupying this space is clear evidence.

column1: 朝来たときは何もなかったからね。
column2: There was nothing here when we got here this morning.

column1: ウソだ！あなたたちがやったにきまっている！
column2: That's a lie! You guys did it!

column1: 君ィー、言いがかりは困るよ。
column2: Hey, don't make us the bad guys.

column1: 緑山出版の連中はいつも汚い真似を！
column2: The guys at Midoriyama Shuppan Co. are always playing dirty tricks.

column1: まあまあまあまあ。お二人ともせっかくの休日なんですから。
column2: Oh come on. Settle down a bit. Today is a day off for both of you.
Why don't we try and enjoy our time...Why don't we have a drink?

column1: お酒の飲み比べをするんですよ。
column2: Yes. We'll see who can drink more. A sake duel!

column1: 青山出版さんとウチから代表者を一人出して、どちらが飲み続けられるか競うんですよ。
column2: We'll get one representative from our company and Aoyama publishing Co. and see who can continue drinking the longest.
The winner can take this spot.

column1: 青山出版さん、まさか怖じ気づいたんですか。
column2: Aoyama company-san, you're not scared, are you?

column1: 何を～！緑山の連中には負けられん！！受けて立ってやる。
column2: What? We can't lose to the Midoriyama company! We'll take this challenge!

column1: 相手は底なしの山田と恐れられている男らしい。
column2: Our opponent is a guy named Yamada who is known to drink like a bottomless pit. We might lose this battle. What are we going to do?
Let me go and represent our company.

column1: 私にいかせてください。
column2: I have my pride. The hanami spot is ours.
- The first shot of tequila is poured.
First shot. Second shot. Third shot!
The two representatives empty one shot glass after another.

column1: うー、ま、負けられないぞぉ・・・

column2: Ugh. I can't lose this one...I'm gonna win no matter what. (He starts to have difficulty speaking)

column1: ふふ。その程度か。勝てっこないさ。
column2: Ha ha ha. That's it? You can't beat me.
Nope. I can down some more...

column1: 山田さん、まさか酔ってるんじゃないでしょうね。
column2: Hey, Yamada. Don't tell me you are drunk already.

column1: だ、だいじょうぶですよ、ウィッ、ヒック。負けっこないですよ。
column2: I'm aaall right. It is impossible to lose.

column1: 青山出版に負けたら、社長から大目玉ですよ！
column2: You will get a rocket from our president if you lose. I will lose face as well since I brought up this sake duel idea.

column1: 十九杯目！二十・・・杯
column2: hikku...hikku...I've...won...this place now belongs to Aoyama publishing...

column1: ヒック・・・ヒック・・・か、勝った・・・ウィッ、ヒック。

column2: Justice will prevail. This is just what I thought. You did a great job, Sakurai.

column1: overnight, two days and one nights
ありがとうございます。旅館わさびでございます。
column2: Thank you for calling. This is Ryokan Wasabi.

column1: あ、あのぉ…　６月２０日に宿泊をしたいのですが。
column2: He...hello...I would like to make a reservation for Jun 20th.

column1: ありがとうございます。何名様でご宿泊でしょうか。
column2: Thank you, sir. How many people will that be?

column1: 大人二人、子供二人の四名です。あ、全員同じ部屋でお願いします。
column2: Two adults and Two children which makes it four people. oh, we want to share the the same room, please.

column1: 四名様御一室のご利用ですね。
column2: Four people in one room, two days and one night lodging. Is that correct?
Would you wait for a moment, please.

column1: お客様、申し訳ございません。生憎ですが、６月２０日は団体のお客様のご予約が入っておりまして、全室満室でございます。
column2: I am terribly sorry, sir. Unfortunately, we are booked solid on Jun 20th due to the group reservation. The previous day, Jun 19th or the next day, Jun 21st are both available...

column1: あー。前の日も次の日もちょっとダメだなぁ…。
column2: I'm so sorry, you went through all the trouble just to call.

column1: せっかくお電話頂いたのに、大変申し訳ございません。
column2: I see. I understand. Thank you very much.

column1: ダメだって。予約いっぱいだって。せっかく電話したのになぁ。
column2: Not good. There's no vacancy. Even though I made the effort to call.

column1: えー、せっかく良い旅館見つけたのに。
column2: You know, I went through all the trouble just to find a good ryokan. You should have made reservations earlier. Why are you always like this?

column1: to close up, to close a book
to sign up for, to apply for
くのいち旅館　予約担当係　服部でございます。
column2: This is Ryokan Kunoichi. I will be your assistant for making a reservation.

column1: あ、もしもし、６月２０日から一泊二日、四名一室で宿泊を考えているのですが、まだ空いていますか。
column2: Ah, hello. I'm planing on staying for two days and one night on Jun 20th with four people in one room. Do you still have any rooms available?

column1: （カチャカチャカチャ）はい。まだ若干　空室がございます。
column2: (clackety-clack) Yes, we still have some rooms available.

column1: ホームページを見てお電話しているのですが、露天風呂つき一泊二食宿泊プランというのはまだ申し込むことができますか。
column2: I'm looking at you website right now. Can I still apply for the plan with outdoor bath and two meals?

column1: あ、申し訳ございません。そちらのプランは大変人気がございまして、既に締め切らせていただいております。通常のお部屋でしたら、ご用意できるのですが…。
column2: I'm sorry sir. The plan you mentioned is very popular and we have already closed the books. I could book you in a normal room but...

column1: そうですか。じゃ、普通の部屋の予約をお願いします。
column2: I see. I would like a reservation for a normal room then.

column1: ありがとうございます。では代表者様のお名前とご連絡先を伺ってもよろしいでしょうか。
column2: Thank you very much. Could I have your name and number, please?

column1: 伊賀　新太郎です。電話番号は03-6526-6969です。
column2: It's Iga Shintaro. The number is 03-6526-6969.

column1: 四名様御一室のご利用ですね。
column2: One room for four people, is that correct?

column1: はい。大人二人子供二人です。子供は二人とも小学生です。
column2: Yes. Two adults and two children. The kids are both elementary school students. Oh, and as for dinner, could we have it in our room?

column1: seeing off and meeting on return
あと、子供の一人がナッツアレルギーなので、ナッツ類は入れないようにお願いします。
column2: And one of my children is allergic to nuts so please don't put any nuts in the meal.

column1: はい。かしこまりました。
電車で行くつもりなのですが、下田の駅まで迎えに来てもらうことは可能ですか。
column2: We are going to take the train. Can you come down to Shimoda Station and give us a ride?

column1: はい、二時、三時、四時、五時に送迎サービスがございます。
column2: Yes, we have transportation services at 2, 3, 4, and 5 o'clock.

column1: つまり、それ以外の時間ならば、タクシーで行いくしかないんですね。
column2: So that means we need to take a taxi at any other time. Am I right?

column1: 左様でございます。下田の駅から二十五分くらいかかるとおもいます。
column2: Exactly. It will take about 25 minutes from Shimoda Station.

column1: ちなみに、チェックインは何時からでしたっけ。
column2: By the way, what time should I check in?

column1: チェックインは三時から、チェックアウトは十一時でございます。
column2: Check-in starts at 3 o'clock and the check-out time is 11 o'clock.

column1: わかりました。じゃぁ、二時の送迎サービスを利用します。
column2: I see. I will use the transportation service at 2.

column1: かしこまりました。ではご予約内容を確認させていただきます。
column2: Sure. Let me confirm your reservation. Mr. Shintaro Iga, 2 days and one night on Jun 20th, one room for four people, and your telephone number is 03-6526-6969, dinner in the room, tranportation service at 2 o'clock, and one of your children is allergic to nuts. Is this correct?

column1: 伊賀 新太郎様、6月20日から一泊二日、四名様御一室のご利用。
column2: That is correct. By the way, no pets are allowed, are they?
No. I am afraid customers are not allowed to bring pets.

column1: 大丈夫です。ちなみに、ペットは連れて行っては駄目なんですよね。
そうですね。申し訳ないのですが、ペットは一切お断りしております。
column2: My name is Hattori. I confirmed your reservation. Mr. Iga, all the staff are looking forward to seeing you soon.

column1: Ninja, Japanese secret agent of old
伊賀さま。お待ちしておりました。女将の百地でございます。本日は遠いところまで、足を運んでいただきまして、ありがとうございます。
column2: Mr. Iga, we've been expecting you. I'm Momochi, the provider of this ryokan. Thank you for taking the trouble to come all the way to see us today. Please come in. Your room is ready. Shinobu, please show Mr. Iga to his room. This is Shinobu, who will be taking care of your room. If you need anything, she will be at your service.

column1: さぁ、どうぞ、お上がりください。お部屋の準備もできております。
シノブ、伊賀様をお部屋までご案内して差し上げて。
column2: (walking) The emergency exit is this way. The large common bath is available from 6am to 12pm. The cafe and the kiosk are open until 8pm.
Since we have come all the way here, we want to go for a walk. Can you recommend a good place for a walk around here?
The garden in our ryokan might be a good place for a stroll, but why don't you go a little further and visit the Ninja Temple. ...This is your room, sir.

column1: （歩きながら）非常口はあちらでございます。大浴場のご利用は朝六時から夜十二時までとなっております。喫茶コーナー、売店は夜の八時まででございます。
せっかくだから、散歩したいんだけど、この辺に、お勧めの散歩コースはある。
column2: Wow, this room is so big and beautiful. We can see the ocean!
What time would you like to have dinner at?

column1: ご夕食は何時からになさいますか。
column2: Well, after taking a walk, we are going to take a bath and get relax, so maybe around six.

column1: うーん。散歩して…、お風呂入って…、ゆっくりしてだから…、六時くらいかな。
column2: Certainly. I will get dinner ready at six o'clock. Excuse me.

column1: お客様？何かおっしゃいましたか？
え..いえ、別に。キー…キーがないなぁ。。。なんてハハハ。
column2: Uh...no. nothing. A key...just looking for my key....just kidding, hahaha.

column1: さっきから全然動かないね。
column2: We haven't been moving at all.

column1: あぁ。ゴールデンウィーク最終日だからな。
column2: Yeah, today's the last day of Golden Week.

column1: あぁあー。もっと早く宿を出ればよかったね。
column2: Oh, boy. We should have left the inn earlier, shouldn't we?

column1: …誰だよ。二時間も化粧をしていたのは。
column2: Who was it putting on make-up for 2 hours?

column1: （ボリュームがだんだん上がる）
column2: What? Who could it have been... Oh, Let's listen to the traffic report.

column1: ゴールデンウィーク最終日の今日は、Ｕターンラッシュがピークを迎え、各地で渋滞が相次いでいます。
現在東京へ向かう中央自動車道上りは大月ジャンクションを先頭に断続的に44キロの渋滞となっております。
また、中央道下りは、正午過ぎに相模湖付近で発生したトラック横転事故のため、片側一車線の車線規制が行われております。現場付近を走行する場合は十分に注意してください。
column2: Today, as it's the last day of Golden Week, the U-turn Rush has reached its peak and causing traffic jams one ofter the other in many parts of the country. Currently, there is an intermittent 44 kilometer backup on the Tokyo-bound Chuo Expressway starting at Otsuki Interchange. Also, on the Chuo Expressway leaving Tokyo, there's a one-side lane closure due to an overturned truck which occurred near Sagami lake. Please drive with caution when you pass the area. The accident is also causing an 8 kilometer traffic jam starting from near Hachioji Interchange. Fender benders tend to occur in the middle or the rear of traffic jams, so maintain a safe following distance.... (turns down the volume)
44 kilometer traffic jam on the Tokyo-bound Chuo Expressway? No way! Unbelievable!

column1: 中央道上り渋滞44キロ?　あり得ない…。
column2: Ken-chan, I think I need to go to the little girl's room.

column1: ねぇ、健ちゃん、あたし、トイレ行きたくなっちゃった。
column2: OK, for now, why don't we get off at the next rest stop and grab something to eat?

column1: みんなは、「過労死」という言葉を聞いた事がありますか？新聞やテレビのニュースなどでも話題になっていますね。今日は、この「過労死」についてみんなで考えようと思います。
column2: Have you ever heard of the word Karoushi? You might have seen it on TV or in the newspapers. Today, we are going to talk about this Karoushi together. So, make groups and have a discussions about the current situation and social background of Karoushi for 30 minutes by using textbooks and the internet.
Well, first of all, what's the definition of Karoushi?

column1: うーん、まずさ、過労死の定義って、何?
column2: It's on the textbook. It says that Karoushi is death by fatigue, stress, or other detrimental side effects of working overtime and working without days off which results in brain, heart, and/or respiratory disease. Also, it includes suicide triggered by depression due to overwork and stress, which is called Karou-jisatsu.

column1: 教科書に書いてあるよ。
column2: I see. It just occurred to me that I've heard this word is understandable in English.

column1: 「過労死とは、長時間の残業や休日なしの勤務を強いられた結果、過労やストレスが原因の一つとなって、脳や心臓、呼吸器などの疾患を発病し、死亡に至ることを意味します。

column2: It says that in 2002, the word appeared for the first time in English dictionaries which brought Karoushi to international recognition as symbolism of Japanese lifestyle.

column1: なるほどね。そういえば、英語でも、そのまま 「Karoshi」で通じるって聞いたことがあるよ。
column2: I think many people from foreign countries can't understand working so hard until to die..

column1: ちょっと待って。。。（カチャカチャ）
column2: But my dad told me that his business partners in America work till midnight or sometimes until morning everyday. I don't think not only Japanese do the prolonged work.

column1: to do unfinished business after going home
見て、この国別の労働時間のグラフ。
column2: Look at this chart of labor hours for each country. In 1988, labor hours of western countries were between 1600 hours and 1800 hours, whereas Japanese labor hours are over 2000 hours. But since then, Japanese labor hours have been getting shorter and American labor hours are are getting  longer than Japanese.

column1: 1988年頃は、欧米各国の年間労働時間が1600時間から1800時間なのに対して、日本は2000時間を越えている。
column2: But I wonder if those are the actual numbers. My dad was complaining that he doesn't get paid for overtime work ever since he got a management position. Also I heard Hiroshi's brother works at home every night after he gets home even though he doesn't get paid for that. I think that in many cases employees don't report actual numbers even though they work overtime.
It looks like there's a word for doing unfinished work after going home which is called furoshiki-zangyou. That's what it says here.

column1: でも、これ、本当の数字なのかなぁ。
column2: My uncle was grumbling that his company sets No Overtime Work Days in an effort to cut down overtime hours, but it doesn't actually reduce the workload. So he has no choice but to work overtime. Since the company is trying to reduce overtime hours it pains him to apply for overtime wages so he just ends up working without getting extra pay.

column1: 僕の親父は、管理職になったら、残業代が払われないってぼやいてたし、
column2: I see. I think the fact that doing overtime work for free is just expected is one of the contributing factors to karoshi.

column1: そういえば、時々、ニュースで「過労死の労災認定」の話を耳にするよね。
column2: Well, we often hear about Approval of Worker's Compensation for Death from Overwork.
What exactly are you talking about?

She's talking about approval of the labor insurance. If you get injured, get sick or die during work or commute to the work, you will be eligible for the labor insurance coverage. But in case of Karoshi, it's rare that you get the approval for the coverage.

column1: 仕事や通勤の途中で怪我をしたり、病気になったり、死亡してしまった場合は、労働災害として保険金が払われるんだ。

column2: First off, Karoshi often happens not at the moment of the cause or right after but a month or months afterwards. Plus, overworking life-style often leads to brain or heart disorders so it's really hard to prove that overwork specifically caused death. And the company side can take advantage of that, and may try to escape from their responsibilities.
Now, that makes me sick! Oh wait, there's a chart of transition of the approvals on page 25 in the textbook.

column1: まず、過労死は、激務の最中や直後ではなくて、一ヵ月後から数ヵ月後に起こる事が多い。
column2: Let's take a look at the number of applicants. It's 676 in the year of 1988, and 869 in 2005. No remarkable increase there. But if you look at the number of approvals, it's 29 in 1988, and 330 in 2005. The increase is more than ten times. I wonder what happened between 2001 and 2002 where you see the significant increase.

column1: 加えて、生活習慣が原因で脳や心臓の病気になることもあるから、なかなか激務が原因で死に至ったということを証明するのが難しいんだ。
column2: Looks like it's worth looking into.

column1: to consider, to take ~ into account
2001年と2002年の間で認定数が大きく伸びた理由がわかったよ。
column2: Look what I found out about the increase of approvals of Karoshi between the year 2001 and 2002. In December 2001, the criteria for Karoshi were revised and it was decided that if the overtime work met a monthly average of 80 hours in the past 6 months, a strong link between the death and overwork could be recognized. The previous criteria only referred to overtime work a week before death. So the criteria were mitigated quite a lot.

column1: 2001年12月に、認定基準の改正があって、「過去6ヶ月間、月平均80時間の残業が続いていれば、過労と発病との関連性が強い」と判定することになったらしいんだ。
column2: I see. It'd be better to be approved than not, but that wouldn't make an ultimate solution for Karoshi.

I think when I grow up, I wouldn't want to do unpaid overtime work. But it's more likely that I won't be able to say No when I start working in real life. I will probably feel like I have to, if co-workers do it or just to avoid troubles with my boss.

column1: なるほどねぇ。認定されないより、された方がいいけど、過労死を減らすための根本的な解決策にはならないよね。
column2: That type of thinking may be leading Japanese to this problem.

column1: 僕も、今は、大人になったら、絶対サービス残業なんかしないぞって思うよ。でも、実際に会社で働くようになったら、ノーとは言えないだろうな。
column2: Courageous people are suing companies to stop unpaid overtime work and are winning the reparation of the hours of unpaid work. I think it's important that each one of us takes actions to change the system.
That's right! It's too late after you die from overwork.

column1: (テレビ)「朝まで話さナイト」のお時間です。
column2: (TV) Ladies and gentlemen, it's time for Asa-made-hanasa-naito (gotta talk from night till morning).
Did you know that three seat bikes, which means bikes that can have children on the front and back is against the law? Tonight, we are going to talk about these three seaters with our guests.
Our first guest is the author of the best selling novel Dandyism. Usui Joe.(Applause)

column1: こんばんは。薄井　ジョー（うすいじょう）です。

column2: I'm categorically-opposed to three seaters because I bad a bad experience with a mama-chari. It was when I was--

column1: 薄井さん、薄井さん、そのお話は後ほどゆっくりお願いしますね～。
column2: Mr. Usui, Mr. Usui! We'll have enough time for your story later.
Our next guest is Iino Kana who is the chairperson of a support group for mothers.(Applause)

column1: よろしくお願いいたします。

column2: It's true that three seater bikes are dangerous, but for parents with more than two kids, it's the only choice they have.

column1: 「やむを得ない」って何ですか！「やむを得ない」って。
column2: What do you mean the only choice.
Riding a mama chari with three people is illegal! Illegal means a violation of law! Don't you get it?

column1: 薄井さんが先ほどから、繰り返し使っておられる、「ママチャリ」というのは自転車の前の部分にカゴのついた買い物用自転車のことですね。
column2: The word mama chari that Mr. Usui has been using means a shopping bicycle with a basket in the front. Is that correct?

column1: そうですね。「ちゃりんこ」というのは自転車のことなので、ママの自転車という意味なんです。
column2: That's right.  Charinko means bike, so it means a bike for mothers.
It comes in very handy for mothers.
We interviewed people on the street to find out if they knew that three-seat bikes were illegal.

column1: え？駄目なんですか？知りませんでした。

column2: What? It's illegal? I didn't know that. But then, how am I supposed to go to a nursery school?

column1: へぇー。駄目なんだ。でも、よく見かけますよね。
column2: Oh, really? It's illegal, eh?  But I see it all the time.

column1: はぁ？ガソリンの値上げよりも困りますよ！子育て中の母親達のことをまったく考えていないですよね。
column2: Are you kidding? It would be more of problem than increasing gas prices! Child-raising mothers are never taken into consideration. I'll keep riding mine in spite of the penalties.
As a matter of fact, riding a mama-chari with kids is dangerous. They wobble and look ready to fall down. I agree with the regulation.

column1: いかがでしょうか。インタビューをした人の半数は自転車の３人乗りが違法だということを知らなかったそうです。
column2: Well, what did you think? Half of the people we interviewed didn't even know three-seaters were illegal.

column1: 都内は保育園への車での送迎が原則的に禁止のため、2人の子供を持つ親は、3人乗りせざるを得ないんです。
column2: In the Tokyo Metropolitan Area, driving kids to nursery school is prohibited as a general rule, so mothers who have 2 children have no other choice but to use a three-seat mama-chari.  Politicians and the government should think of making an environment that is friendly to child-raising mothers before lamenting things like Oh, No! We have a declining birthrate. At this rate, our country is doomed!”
But riding a mama-chari with three people is REALLY dangerous!  The other day, I almost got hit by a mama-chari.

column1: でも、ママチャリの３人乗りは本当に危険です。

column2: Yes. One day, when I was walking down the street, a mama-chari with a child on the back seat came straight toward me.

column1: もちろん、運動神経抜群の僕はひらりと身をかわして、そのママチャリをさけました。
column2: Of course I dodged the mama-chari because I have good reflexes. And then, a mama-san riding on a bike with two kids in the front and the back was coming at me.
Kids in the front and back seat? You mean a three seater, right?

column1: 自転車の前と後ろと？つまり３人乗りですね？
column2: That's right, and from the opposite direction, a mama-san riding a bike with two kids on the front and back seat. What's more, she was carrying a baby piggy bag too.

column1: そうです。そして反対方向からは、子供を自転車の前と後に乗せ、さらに赤ちゃんをおんぶした、ママさんが猛スピードで迫ってきていました。
column2: Wait a minute. A bike with kids in the front and back and piggy bag. You mean a four seater.

column1: ちょっと待ってください。自転車の前と後ろとおんぶ？つまり４人乗りですか？
column2: Yes. On my left was the one, on my right was the other, and behind me was the wall. And in front of me, coming right at me was…

column1: はい。右からママチャリ、左からもママチャリ。後ろは壁です。そして、前からは…

column2: A track was backing up really quickly.

column1: 前からは何が来たんですか？
column2: Oh, my, truck. What happened next?

column1: トラックが猛スピードでバックして来ました。
column2: Well, fortunately, the driver saw me and stopped properly so I was spared.
What abut the mother and children?

column1: 幸い運転手が僕に気づいて、急ブレーキを踏んだので、助かったって訳です。
column2: Everyone was all right because the truck was carrying mattresses. Inertia made the mattresses fall out of the truck and they worked as cushions.

column1: お母さん達と子供達は？
column2: Thanks to the law of inertia.

column1: 全員無事。というのもそのトラックが運んでいたのはマットレスだったんです。
でもねぇ、薄井さん。じゃぁ、お母さん達はどうしたらいいんでしょうね。赤ちゃんを一人家において外出した方が安全ですか。
column2: But, Mr. Usui. What should we do with the mothers? Is it safer for them to leave their babies at home? What if they have two children who are'nt yet walking? How should they bring them to nursery school?
They should go by car. If they don't have cars, they should live near a train station.

column1: 車で行けばいいでしょ。車がないなら、駅の近くに住めばいいんですよ。
column2: As I said before, many nursery schools in Tokyo forbid parents from bringing their children by car because they don't have parking spaces. And you just said that people should live near a train station. Well, that's obviously ideal, but rent is really expensive if you live near a station. Don't you think that's a financial burden for families with children?

column1: さっきも申し上げましたが、都内では車の送迎を禁止する保育園が多いんですよ。駐車スペースがありませんからね。
column2: If you don't have the money to buy a car or live near a train station, you shouldn't have kids.

column1: それから、先程「駅の近くに住むめばいい」っておっしゃいましたね。
column2: What? What are you talking about? That's awful! Do you know what you're saying? Are you insane?

column1: 勿論、駅の近くに住めるに越したことはありませんが、駅から近いところは家賃が高いんです。

column2: The police say they have banned the practice of three people riding on one bicycle. But for families with multiple children, it can be difficult not to. The police said that if you can ride a bicycle safely with three people, they'll allow it.

column1: 車を買う経済力も、駅の近くに住む経済力もないなら、子供を作らなければいいんですよ。
column2: It's obviously best if mothers can get three people on a bicycle safely. But these so-called safe bikes cost more than 60,000 yen.

column1: はぁ？あなた、なんて事言うんですか！！ひどいにも程があります！
column2: 60,000 yen? A regular bicycle costs 10,000 yen to 20,000 yen. So that's triple the price of ordinary bikes.
So, if you can't afford it....

column1: 警視庁は「自転車の三人乗りは危険で認められない。しかし複数の幼児を持つ家庭の大変さは理解できる。

column2: Well, I hope they come up with a cheaper safe bike soon. That's it for today. Good-bye.

column1: and what is more, in addition
クミ、そんなに、テレビを近くで見たら目が悪くなるぞ。
column2: Kumi, your eyes will go bad if you watch sitting too close to the TV.

column1: では、全国の明日のお天気です。
column2: Here's tomorrow's national weather forecast. Tomorrow, we are expecting a sunny day in many places because of high pressure overlying Japan. However, it's likely to rain on the Pacific side from Shikoku to the Kantou area, and it's going to rain before noon in Osaka and Nagoya, after noon in Tokyo. So don't forget to bring your umbrellas even if it's not raining in the morning. Okinawa appears to continue to overcast.

column1: 明日は、日本付近を覆う高気圧の影響で、晴れるところが多い見込みです。
column2: Oh, man. It's going to rain tomorrow.

column1: ただし、四国から関東の太平洋側では雨が降りやすくなるでしょう。
大阪や、名古屋は昼前から、東京は昼過ぎから雨となるので、朝、雨が降っていなくても、忘れずに傘をお持ちください。
column2: Ah, this clown. We were classmates in university. He's smart and cool, and furthermore, his father is a politician and super rich. This world is so unfair.

column1: …ねぇ、健ちゃん、この人、カッコいいね。
column2: I'm joking. You are the only one for me.

column1: a face of a document, messages
優香ちゃんから、年賀状もらっちゃったよ。（鼻歌）
column2: I got a New Year’s postcard from Yuka-chan. (humming)

column1: じゃ、お前、あんなかわいい子から年賀状もらえるものなら、もらってみろよ！しかも、この文面、見てくれよ。
column2: So, if you think you can get postcards from cute girls like her, then go ahead. Plus, look at what she wrote, I very much would like to play golf with you this year! Which means it's rude if I don't invite her to golf, right?!

column1: 「今年は、ぜひ、上原さんと一緒にゴルフさせて頂きたいです！」だぜ～！
column2: Man, did you break out into a fever? If you really think it's that easy, go ahead and invite her.

column1: これで、誘わないのは、失礼だよなっ！
column2: OK, watch me. Check it out, she's on Skype. Yuka-chan, thanks for the postcard. I didn't know you play golf. I know it's kind of soon, but how about this coming Sunday? Send!

column1: はぁ、お前、熱でもあるんじゃないのか？！
本当に、あの優香ちゃんを誘えるもんなら、誘ってみろよ。
column2: Oh, she replied. Thank you for the invitation...I appreciate the offer, but next Sunday is not good for me. Sorry. OK, So how about Sunday next week? Send!

column1: お～、見てろよ。さっそく、スカイプ、スカイプ。
「優香ちゃん、年賀状ありがとう。ゴルフするなんて、知らなかったよ。さっそくだけど、今度の日曜日は、どう？」　送信！
column2: I'm busy that day, too......Sooo, So what about the week after that?...
Hey, hey. Take a hint, will you? She was just being polite in the postcard!

column1: to butt in, to interfere with
to eat, to drink a bit
なぁ、どうしたんだよ。いい加減、口をきいてくれよ。飲み物にも料理にも全然口をつけないし。
column2: Hey, what's wrong with you? Get it together! Say something, will you? You haven't touched your drink or your food. Ah, I see, you're thinking, This food is too cheap for my tastes, aren't you?

column1: あ、「こんな安い料理は私の口に合いません。」なんていうのか？
・・・先週の・・・先週の日曜日どこに行ってたのよ….

column2: When I asked you where you were going, you went on mumbling, so I got curious and followed you.

column1: 行き先を聞いたときに、口ごもっていたから、気になって、あなたの後をつけたのよ。
column2: You did what?! I can't believe it!!

column1: お前！　そんなことしたのか？！　信じられない！！！
column2: You shouldn't have done that, miss. It's better to turn a blind eye to that sort of thing.

column1: そりゃいけないよ、奥さん。
column2: Huh? Who are you? Don't butt in this.  This doesn't involve you.

column1: そういうことは、目をつぶっていた方がいいと思いますよ。
column2: I'm the one who can't believe it. I don't want to talk to you anymore.

column1: は？あなた誰ですか。関係ない方が口をはさまないでください。
column2: It's a misunderstanding I tell you, a misunderstanding. You're the only one I love.

column1: 信じられないのはこっちよ。もう、あなたとは口もききたくないわ。
誤解だよ。誤解。俺が愛しているのは、君だけなんだからさ。
よっ、旦那さん。口がうまいねぇ。
だから！口出ししないでください！！！って言ったでしょ！
column2: Miss, talking back will just have the opposite effect.

column1: あっ、ひなこちゃん、かわいいひざ掛けしてるね！
column2: Right, it's warm biz time after all.

column1: はい、ウォームビズですからね。
column2: I've heard of cool biz, but what's warm biz?

column1: クールビズは知ってるけど。ウォームビズってなんだっけ？
column2: You're behind on the times, Mr. Uehara. Warm biz season lasts from November to March, and during this time it is recommended to lower the thermostat from 23 to 20 degrees in order to reduce CO

column1: 上原さん、遅れてますよ。
column2: So that's why the office has been cold lately. I, of all people, should have known that.

column1: 11月から3月は、ウォームビズ期間で、二酸化炭素の排出量削減のために、オフィスの暖房を23度から20度に下げて設定することが推奨されているんです。
column2: They say that your body temperature rises 2.5 degrees if you use a lap blanket. Men should wear long johns.

column1: だから、最近、オフィスが寒いんだなぁ。
column2: Huh?! A cool guy like me does

column1: 僕としたことが、知らなかったなぁ～～。
column2: What are you talking about? They sell Calvin Klein and other brand-name long johns at the department store. It's no longer an old-man thing.

column1: ひざ掛けをすると、体感温度が2.5度も上がるそうですよ。
