column2: Huh, really? I, of all people, got behind on the current fashion trends. I'm going to check it out right away!

column1: two-handed, to hit with both hands
to result in, to lead to
to get angry despite one's own fault
to refrain from-, to stay back from-; V2
「優先席付近では、携帯電話の電源はお切りください。
column2: Please turn off your mobile phones when you are near the priority seats. In other areas, please set your phone to vibrate, and please refrain from talking on the phone.

column1: それ以外の場所では、マナーモードに設定の上、通話はお控えください。」
column2: Ugh, this guy is sitting in the priority seats as if it’s nothing, although he's young, and on top of that, he's sending text messages on his phone; the nerve! I'm going to give him a piece of my mind. But…he looks like a bad lot, and he might flip out on me... But it's behavior like that that brings Japanese manners down. I have to be brave.

column1: 全く、この人、若いくせに堂々と優先席に座って、その上、携帯メールまでしてるなんて、許せないわ！
column2: (Clears her throat) These are the priority seats, so please turn off your phone.

column1: 一言、言ってやろうかしら。
あっ、でも、目つきが悪いし、逆切れされるのが落ちかな。
column2: But it looked like you were typing something this whole time.

column1: だめだめ、そんなことだから、日本人のマナーが悪くなる一方なのよ。
column2: I was just practicing two-hand typing.

column1: ここは、勇気を出さなくちゃ。
column2: Oh, I'm sorry. But to be able to use both hands on this tiny phone, young people these days are amazing. If an elderly person gets on, though, give up your seat, okay?

column1: to be proud, to blow one's (own) horn
to have a good nose for, to notice something quickly
at most, as hard as one can
people who entered an organization at the same time
the top salesman (salesman who sells the most)
to knock someone down a peg, to beat down to size
どうしたんだ？珍しいな。鼻歌なんか歌って。
column2: What’s with you? I never hear you humming!

column1: 今度、俺、ベストセールスマンに表彰されるんだ。
column2: I’m getting the award for best salesman.

column1: へぇえええ。す、すごいなぁ。俺も、同期として、鼻が高いよ。おめでとう。
column2: Wha… Wow. Th… That’s great. As someone who entered the company at the same time, that makes me proud. Congratulations.

column1: ま、上原も、せいぜい頑張れよ。お前、鼻が利くだろ。
column2: Well, you should try your hardest too Uehara – you’ve got a great sense of smell.

column1: だって、買ってくれそうな客を見つけるの得意じゃないか。
column2: Yeah, you’re really good at sniffing out customers who’re ready to buy. Sniff, sniff, buy, buy! Woof, woof, woof! Hahaha!

column1: クンクンクンクン。買ってください。ワン！ワン！ははは！
column2: Well you don’t have to say it that way! That really ticks me off… Just because you’re “best salesman,” you don’t have to get all cocky.

column1: 何だ、その言い方。鼻につくな。
column2: Hey come on, don’t get steamed. If you think you can be best salesman then go ahead and try. That would be the perfect way to outwit me. Hahaha!

column1: ベストセールスマンになったからって、そんなに鼻にかけるなよ。
column2: You watch, I'll knock you down a peg! (lit- I’m gonna snap your nose off!)

column1: ミートミートの斉藤社長、辞任するらしいぞ！
column2: I heard that President Saito of Meet Meat is resigning!

column1: え？今回の不祥事の責任を取って辞任するっていうこと？
column2: What? Do you think the resignation is meant as a way to take responsibility for that recent scandal?

column1: 斉藤社長は、責任を持って今後の対策を立てるべきよ。
column2: I think Mr. Saito should take responsibility by working to implement measures for the future. A company president has that responsibility, too. He could always resign after that, and it wouldn’t be too late would it?

column1: 社長にはそういう責任があると思うわ。それから辞めても遅くないんじゃない？
column2: Yeah, that’s certainly one way of taking responsibility.

column1: 確かに、そういう責任の取り方もあるな。
column2: The president of Amakara Confectioneries didn’t just quit when they ran into trouble a little while ago – he worked hard to rebuild the company didn’t he? I think that is what truly responsible behavior for a company president should look like. The president of Amakara said, “I will do everything in my power to ensure this incident gets resolved. This is my way of taking responsibility for what happened.”

column1: この前の甘辛製菓の社長は、すぐに辞任せずに、頑張って会社を建て直したじゃない。
column2: But, in the case of Meet Meat, Mr. Saito was directly involved in the scandal. Resigning is probably the best way of taking responsibility.

column1: それが、社長としての責任ある態度だと思うわ。
column2: Yeah, maybe… What does “taking responsibility” really mean anyway?

column1: to get separated, to stray away
to be lost, to go missing
to get through on the phone
the outskirts of town, the edge of town
まり子ちゃん、片思いしているって言っていたよね？　好きな人ってどんな人？
column2: Hey Mariko-chan, you said you had a case of unrequited love right? Who’s the lucky guy?

column1: えっ？う～ん、実は、名前、知らないんだぁ。
column2: Huh? Well… The truth is… I don’t know his name. We actually only met once.
(Only met once… She really is an odd one. But, could this mean that there’s still a chance for me?) Well, what do you mean by that?

column1: （一度会ったきりか…。さすが不思議ちゃん。
ということは、まだ、俺にも可能性があるってことか？）
それって、どういうこと？
column2: Well as a matter of fact, it all happened when I was in high school. I went hiking in the mountains once with some friends but we got separated and I got almost completely lost. I was high up in the mountains, so of course my phone didn’t work either. It wasn’t long before I drank all the liquids I had with me and had eaten all my food, and then I was really in trouble. But that’s when he appeared suddenly out of nowhere.
Without a word, he took my hand and we began walking. He had such big, warm hands… But the next thing I knew, I was lying alone on a road at the edge of town.

column1: 実はね、高校生のとき、友達と山へハイキングに出かけたんだけど、友達とはぐれちゃって、遭難しそうになったことがあるの。
column2: What? What happened to the guy?

column1: 山奥だから、当然電話もつうじないでしょ。
column2: He was nowhere to be found.

column1: そのうち、飲み物は飲みきってしまうし、食べ物も食べきってしまって、本当に困りきっていたときに、突然、彼が、どこからか現れたのよ。
column2: (Oh, she just had a hallucination from the exhaustion.) Hey, do you think that guy was actually a magical raccoon dog?
What?! Oh Saburo, you are so terrible!

column1: to leak out (a secret), to be exposed
パパ、まずは、キーンと冷えたビールでもどうぞ。
column2: Well Hun, why not have an ice cold beer?

column1: どうしたんだよ？いやにサービスがいいなぁ。
column2: What’s up with you? Your service is uncannily good.

column1: あら、人聞きの悪いことは言わないで！いつも、サービスいいでしょ。
column2: Oh, don’t say that – you might bruise my reputation! I always give good service right?

column1: え～そうかぁ？？まっ、そういうことにしておくよ。
column2: What?! Hmm, well I’m not going to touch that one.

column1: ゴクゴクゴク。あぁ～、風呂上りは冷えたビールに限る！！
column2: (Gulp, gulp, gulp) Ah, there’s nothing better than a cold brew after a good bath!

column1: おっ！サンキュウ～。やっぱり、ビールのつまみは、枝豆に限るよな～。
column2: Oh, thank you. There’s no better snack to go with beer than edamame! So by the way, what was it you wanted to talk about?

column1: えっ！　何でわかったの？！
column2: Well, any time the service around here gets this good, you always seem to want something.

column1: だって、君がサービス良くしてくれるときは、必ず何か頼みごとがあるじゃないか。
column2: Oh well, I guess you got me. The truth is that the new Vuitton bag is so dreamy! Buy it for me!!

column1: ばれちゃ、しょうがないわ。
column2: Wow, what is with that silky voice? Next you’re going to be telling me ‘there’s no better bag than a Vuitton bag!’ (Yawn) Hmm, I think the beer has gotten to me… zzzz…

column1: 実はねぇ、今度のヴィトンの新作バック、とっても素敵なのよ～～。買って～。
column2: Hey, don’t you pretend to fall asleep now!

column1: 昨日、家で、手巻き寿司を食べたとき、ちょっと面白いゲームをやったよ。
column2: Yesterday, when we were eating hand-rolled sushi at home, we played a kind of fun game.

column1: えっ！どんなゲームですか。
column2: Really? What kind of game was it?

column1: 他の人が作った手巻き寿司を目をつぶったまま食べて、中身の具を当てるというゲームだ。
column2: You eat sushi that someone else has rolled and try to guess what’s in it.

column1: だろう？目をつぶっているから、舌触りとか、におい、食感が大切なんだ。
column2: Yeah, doesn’t it? Your eyes are closed, so the scents and textures become really important.

column1: 結構、むずかしそうですね。
column2: That sounds like it could be really hard. Hey, the idea of eating with your eyes closed is kind of similar to ‘blind restaurants.’

column1: 目をつぶって食べるという点では、ブラインドレストランに通じるものがありますね。
なんだ、そのブラインドレストランっていうのは？
column2: They’re restaurants where you eat blindfolded. They started in Europe as a way to help spread understanding of the blind community.

column1: 目隠しをして食事するレストランのことですよ。
column2: Hmm… Wow Uehara, you’re surprisingly well-informed.

column1: 視覚障害を持つ人に対する理解を深めることを目的にヨーロッパで始められたものなんです。
column2: Oh no, not really…. But don’t you think that the two are kind of related in that they force you to rely on your senses of smell, taste and touch instead of your sense of sight to enjoy the meal?

column1: ほ～。上原、意外と物知りじゃないか。
column2: I suppose so. It is true that when you play this game, your other senses seem heightened without the visuals getting in the way.

column1: to go a little bit further
明日は、孝雄くんとデートだ～。
column2: Tomorrow is my big date with Takao! Oh, I feel like I’m dancing on the ceiling! Okay let’s see, what kind of lunchbox should I make for tomorrow? Ooh, Takao likes salmon roe, so maybe I’ll have a salmon roe rice ball. Ah, but on second thought salmon roe spoils easily so maybe I shouldn’t ...

column1: わくわくするな～！なんだか、足が地に付かない感じ！
column2: So tomorrow is my big date with Norika… She said she wanted to see the ocean, so maybe Yokohama would be nice. But then again we could always travel just a little further and have a nice time in Kamakura. Hmm… But my budget is about 10,000 yen. If we go all the way out to Kamakura, the extra travel expense will probably put me over budget.

column1: さぁて、お弁当は、何にしようかな～。孝雄君、イクラ好きだから、イクラのおにぎりにしようかな。
column2: There is a high chance that Typhoon No. 16 will hit the Tokyo Metropolitan Area tomorrow morning. Commuter transport delays are expected, and caution is advised.

column1: あ、でも、いくらは、足が早いから、やめておいた方がいいわね。。。
column2: Aw, man! I went to all the trouble to take a paid holiday and everything! I’ll just have to rethink the plan… What should we do… Oh, an indoor activity like an aquarium could be good. It sure has been a while though. Ever since my ex broke up with me at an aquarium, I’d kind of been staying away from them.

column1: as I recall, if I am right
to stand up, to start up (a computer), V1
上原さん、おはようございます。
column2: Good morning, Mr. Uehara. Umm, I can’t seem to open an attachment I got. Would you mind taking a look at it for me?

column1: あのぉ、添付ファイルが開けられないんですが、見ていただけますか。
column2: Could you put it in the department’s shared folder? Just when I thought my computer had started up, it froze and I’ve had to restart it.

column1: じゃぁ、課の共有フォルダに入れておいてよ。
column2: Your PC isn’t working too well lately, is it Mr. Uehara?

column1: 今、パソコンが立ち上がったと思ったら、フリーズしちゃって、再起動しているところなんだ。
column2: Yeah, I think I need to defragment more often. By the way, what is the extension on that file?

column1: 最近、上原さんのコンピュータ、調子悪いですね。
うん、まめに、デフラグしないといけないな。
column2: Oh, well then it's a video file. You should be able to open it with QuickTime.

column1: ところで、そのファイルの拡張子は何だった？
column2: Ah, I don’t think I have that on my PC. I guess I’ll have to download it then.

column1: 確か、m4vだったと思います。
column2: Oh, hang on. It looks like my computer is finally back up again. Let’s see here…

column1: なんだ、それなら、動画ファイルだから、QuickTimeで開くはずだよ。
column2: What is this? It’s a video love letter to Hinako from Taguchi. Well, I can’t let her see this drivel.

column1: それ、私のPCに入ってないと思います。じゃぁ、ダウンロードしなくちゃいけないんですね。
column2: It looks like this file is corrupt. QuickTime starts up and starts playing the file, but then it just generates an error message.

column1: あ、ちょっと待って。やっと、パソコンが立ち上がった。どれどれ。。。
column2: Oh really? Well, that’s okay. I think maybe it wasn’t work-related anyway. Thanks for your help, and sorry to bug you.

column1: to intercede, to fix someone up with (someone else)
あれ？あそこにいるの、健と綾香じゃない？！
column2: Hmm? Isn’t that Ken and Ayaka over there?!

column1: あ！腕なんか組んじゃって、あの二人、付き合ってるっての？
column2: Oh! What are they doing all arm in arm like that? Are they together?

column1: 道理で、綾香、最近付き合いが悪くなったわけだ。
column2: Well that explains why it’s been so hard to get Ayaka to come out lately. Even if we invite her out, lately it seems there’s always some reason why she can’t come. But it’s pretty stand-offish of her to keep it all a secret.

column1: 私たちが誘っても、理由をつけて、断っていたのには、こういう訳があったのね。
column2: Yeah. But well… I guess it can’t be helped…

column1: でも、内緒にするなんて、水臭いよねぇ。
column2: Why do you say that? Is there some special situation?

column1: そうだね。でも、まぁ・・・仕方ないか・・・。
column2: Well, as it happens, Sayuri has been smitten with Ken for some time now. And Sayuri actually asked Ayaka to help her get Ken by acting as a go between.

column1: なんでよ？何か訳があるの？
column2: What?! Really?!! So, Ayaka knows that Sayuri likes Ken?!

column1: 実は、さゆりも健のことがずーっと好きだったんだよね。
column2: Well, yeah that seems to be the case…. It looks like Ayaka’s stabbed Sayuri in the back.

column1: それで、さゆりは、綾香に、「健との仲を取り持って」って頼んでいたのよ。
column2: Okay, that could really make it tough to bring the subject up.

column1: to catch sight of, to (happen to) see
to fret over, to take oneself seriously
綾香、健と付き合ってるの？
column2: Ayaka, are you and Ken dating? I saw you with him yesterday.

column1: 昨日、健と一緒にいるところ見かけたんだけど。
column2: Well, yeah. I mean… I was planning to… to tell you, but I just couldn’t think of the right way to say it…

column1: う、うん。実はね。。。言おう言おうと思ってたんだけど、なかなか言い出せなくて。。
column2: What’s this all about? Did you stab Sayuri in the back?

column1: どういうことなの？さゆりを裏切ったってわけ？
column2: I didn’t mean to. To tell the truth, I’ve liked Ken myself for a long time now. But when Sayuri confessed her feelings for Ken to me, I just couldn’t tell her the truth…. It seemed like Sayuri was taking herself very seriously and I thought I’d better just give up.

column1: 裏切るつもりはなかったの。
column2: So then why are you dating him?

column1: 実は、私もずっと健のことが好きだったのよ。でも、さゆりから健のことを打ち明けられたとき、本当のことが言えなくて。。。
column2: Well, when I went to tell Ken about Sayuri’s feelings for him, he confessed that he actually had feelings for me. I just couldn’t hide it anymore…

column1: さゆりも、思いつめていたみたいだったから、健のことはあきらめようって思ったわけ。
column2: I see… So you were suffering, caught between love and friendship. If that’s the case you should just be honest with Sayuri.

column1: それで、何で付き合うことになったのよ？
column2: Do you think Sayuri will understand?

column1: 健に、さゆりの気持ちを伝えに行ったら、逆に、健から告白されちゃって。
column2: Hmm… I’d say it’s questionable. Oh, it’s Sayuri!

column1: もう自分の気持ちにうそをつけなくて。。。
column2: Hey, what are you doing over here?

column1: そう。。綾香も、愛情と友情の板ばさみって苦しんでたってわけね。
column2: Ah, well… um, I wanted to talk to you… about the favor you asked me to do about you and Ken… well it’s just that…

column1: それなら、さゆりに正直に話した方がいいよ。
column2: Oh, that was all made up! To tell you the truth, it was Ken who asked me to create a good excuse for the two of you to talk. It was all sort of rigged from the beginning.

column1: あのー、高齢の両親と幼児を連れて、1泊2日の旅行に行きたいんだけど。。。
column2: Excuse me, I'd like to go on a one night and two day vacation with my elderly parents and small children...
How many people will it be altogether?

column1: えっと、両親と、姉の家族4人と、僕の家族4人だから、全部で10人だね。
column2: Well let's see, there's my parents, the four people in my older sister's family and the four people in my family. That makes 10.

column1: ご親戚ご一同で行かれるんですね。
column2: So all the relatives will be traveling together?

column1: うん、そう。だから、三世代の家族旅行向きのプランがいいんだよね。
column2: Yes, so we'd really like a travel plan made for three generations of family going on a family vacation.

column1: そうですね。近場で、箱根はいかがですか。
やっぱり、箱根かね。じゃ、ホテルは、どこかお勧めある？
column2: Yeah, I’ve thought of Hakone. Can you recommend a hotel?

One moment please. (The sound of keystrokes) What do you think of Ashinoko no Yu hotel? They just recently put in a playroom there for small children. And they even serve special meals for the elderly.

column1: （キーボードをたたく音）ホテル芦ノ湖の湯は、いかがでしょうか。
column2: Hmm, that sounds pretty good. What are the rooms like?

column1: ここは、最近、お子様向けにプレイルームを新設したばかりなんです。
column2: (the sound of more keystrokes) It looks as though they have connected rooms for customers in large groups.

column1: それに、ご年配のお客様向けのお食事も用意されています。
column2: Hey, that sounds great. This hotel really is perfect for large family vacations.

column1: もしもし、水漏れの修理をお願いしたいんですが。
column2: Hello, I'm calling about getting a leak repaired.

column1: はい、どういった症状ですか。
column2: Alright, what seems to be the problem?

column1: 台所の蛇口の根元のあたりから、水がピューピュー漏れるんです。
column2: There's water leaking from around the base of the faucet in our kitchen sink. At first I tried to ignore it and used the sink as usual, but it just kept getting worse. Could you please send someone right away?

column1: 最初のうちは、何とか我慢して使ってたんですけど、だんだんひどくなってきてしまって。。。
column2: All of our repair men are out at the moment..., The soonest we could get someone out there would be tomorrow afternoon.

column1: 今すぐに来てもらえませんか。
column2: Tomorrow afternoon.... Is there any way they can come during the morning?

column1: 今、作業員が出払っていまして。。。早くても、明日のお昼過ぎになってしまいます。
column2: Well, okay. I'll see what I can do.

column1: 明日の午後ですか。。。何とか、朝のうちに来てもらえませんか。
column2: Thank you. You'll be able to fix it right away tomorrow won't you?

column1: うーん、わかりました。じゃ、何とか、調整してみます。
column2: Well that depends on the situation... there may be some cases where we wouldn't be able to fix it.

column1: お願いします。それで、明日すぐ直るんですよね。
column2: Well do you know how much the repair fees will cost?

column1: はぁ、それは、状況によりますから。。。その場で直せない場合もあります。
column2: Like I said, we'll have to see the situation first before we can provide you with an estimate... if it's just a problem with the seals you may only end up paying 3000 yen.

column1: じゃ、修理代は、大体いくらくらいかかりますか。
column2: So it'll be 3000 yen - I see. See you tomorrow morning.

column1: ですから、現物を拝見しないと、お見積もりもできないのですが、、、
column2: Uh, but I didn't say that it would be 3000 yen... (click as the phone hangs up)

column1: to arrive at, to get to, to come to
あ～、これは、特殊な水栓ですね。
column2: Oh, this is a special type of faucet.

column1: 部品交換では直らないです。
column2: I won't be able to fix it by just replacing parts.

column1: 水栓を全部取り替えることになりますね。
column2: We'll have to replace the whole unit.

column1: え～、パッキンの交換だけで済むと思ってたんだけど？！
column2: What? I thought you said you would only have to replace the seals.

column1: いえ、現物を拝見してからでないと、わからないと申し上げたと思いますが。。。
column2: No, I believe I told you I wouldn't know anything before having a look at the actual problem.

column1: それで、全部取り替えたら、いくら位かかるの？
column2: Well, how much will it cost to replace the whole unit?

column1: そうですね。ざっくり見積もって、7-8万円くらいになると思います。
column2: Let me see. I think a rough estimate would be around 70 to 80,000 yen.
It's going to cost that much?!

column1: 主人と相談してからでないと、決められないわ。
column2: I'll have to discuss it with my husband before I decide on anything.

column1: 後で、正式な見積書送ってくださいね。
column2: Please send us an official estimate later, okay?

column1: じゃ、今日は、出張点検代として3000円頂きます。
column2: And for the house visit today, it'll be 3000 yen.

column1: は？！そんなの聞いてないわよ。
column2: What?! Nobody told me about that.

column1: 修理に至らなかった場合は、点検代を頂くことになっていますので。
column2: In cases where no repairs were made, we only charge for the inspection.

column1: まったく！！しっかりしてるわね！
column2: Oh for goodness sake!! You have a real racket going here!

column1: 実は、点検代だけで儲けてるんじゃないの？
column2: You probably make all your money on the inspection fees alone, don't you?

column1: この水漏れ、水栓を全部取り替えなきゃ直らないって。
column2: They say they'll have to replace the whole faucet unit to repair this leak.

column1: しかも、7-8万もかかるって！
column2: And it's going to cost us 70 to 80,000 yen.
Oh is that what they said?

column1: その手の業者は、すぐに、取り替えないと直らないって、言うらしいぞ！
column2: Yeah those places always say they have to replace the whole unit or they can't fix it.
What, you've got to be joking!

column1: to tie up, to bind up
to support, to raise, to cultivate
to fight, to battle, to combat

column2: Well, I've made up my mind.
What's this all of a sudden?

column1: 会社の不正融資を告発することにした。
column2: I’ve decided to indict the company over fraudulent loans.

column1: えぇ！　何？不正融資？告発？
もうちょっと詳しく説明してよ。
column2: You're going to have to give me a few more details than that.

column1: この前、経理の資料を見てたら、経理担当の役員が不正融資をしていることに気づいたんだよ。
column2: Recently, when I was looking over some accounting paperwork. I realized that the board member in charge of accounting was making fraudulent loans.

column1: それで、部長に相談しようとしたら、「腹を割って話そう」って言われたんだ。
column2: When I tried to bring it to the attention of the section chief he asked, Can I speak frankly?

column1: 部長も知ってたらしい。
column2: The section chief already knew about it.

column1: だから、俺にも目をつぶっているように説得しようとしたんだよ。
column2: He tried to convince me to turn a blind eye to it as well,

column1: そのうち、「このことは、僕の腹にしまっておくから。
column2: and soon he was saying things like, I'll just keep our little conversation to myself.

column1: あ、確か、君は海外赴任を希望していたねぇ・・・」なんて言い出して・・・。
column2: Oh, didn't I hear you saying that you were after a new appointment overseas....

column1: きっと、僕を転勤させる腹なんだ。
column2: I'm sure he's got his mind made up to have me transferred.

column1: しかも、こういうことは、初めてじゃないんだ。
column2: Yeah, and this isn't the first time this kind of thing has happened either.

column1: だから、今回こそ、事実を明らかにしないと、俺の腹の虫がおさまらないんだよ。
column2: If I don't get the facts out into the open this time I just won't be able to control my anger.

column1: わかった。私も腹を決めたわ。
column2: Okay, then I've made my mind up, too.

column1: あなたが、会社と闘う間、私があなたを養うからね！
column2: I'll support you while you're fighting the company.

column1: よし、そうと決まったら、「腹が減っては戦が出来ぬ」って言うから、おいしいものでも食べに行こう！
column2: Great! But you know they say, an army marches on its stomach, so let's go get something good to eat.

column1: 今日は、東都大学の草柳教授をお招きして、先生の最近の著書「近い将来、日本が飢える！」について、お話をお伺いしたいと思います。
column2: Today, we’ve invited Professor Kusayanagi of Toto University to speak about his recent book Japan will starve in the near future.

column1: 草柳先生、よろしくお願いします。
はい、こちらこそよろしくお願いします。
column2: Thank you very much for having me.

column1: 早速ですが、このタイトル、かなり衝撃的ですね。
column2: Without any further ado, this is quite a shocking title.

column1: この豊かな国が飢えるということが、実際に起こりうることなのでしょうか。
column2: Do you actually think that it may be possible for such a prosperous country to starve?

column1: 私は、起こりえると考えています。
column2: Yes, I think it may well be possible.

column1: 日本の食糧自給率は、1965年の73％から下がり続け、今は40％しかないんです。
column2: The amount of food that Japan produces for itself has continued to decline, dropping from seventy-three percent in 1965 to forty percent at present.

column1: ですから、万が一、食料を輸入できなくなるような事態になったら、日本人は、今の4割の食料で生きていかなければならないのです。
column2: If for some unforeseen reason we became unable to import food from the outside, the Japanese people would be forced to live on the remaining forty percent of their food supplies.

column1: なるほど。。。そういう事態が起きないとも限らないですね。
column2: I see… So you’re saying there’s no guarantee that such a situation won’t occur.

column1: 天候不順で、輸入先の国で作物が不作にならないとも限らないですし。。。
column2: Crops could be lost to poor weather conditions in the exporting country…

column1: それに、いつまでも平和が続くとは限らないですからね。
column2: and there are no real guarantees that peace will last either.

column1: ところで、自給率の低下の主な原因は、何なんでしょう？
column2: By the way, to what do you attribute the decline in self-supporting food production?

column1: やはり日本人の食生活の洋風化です。
column2: I believe it is due to the westernization of the Japanese diet.

column1: 米の自給率は100％なのに比べ、パンの材料である小麦粉の自給率は、10％程度しかありません。
column2: Although Japan produces one-hundred percent of its own rice, it only produces about ten percent of the flour we use to make bread.

column1: ですから、パン食が多くなればなるほど、自給率は下がることになります。
column2: As a result, the more bread we eat, the lower the rate of self-supported food production drops.

column1: to rebuke strongly, to tell off
愛沙、あなた、最近、仕事ばっかりしてない？
column2: Aisa, haven’t you been working a lot lately? I thought you said that, A job is just to hold you over until you get married?

column1: 就職するとき、「仕事なんて、結婚するまでの腰掛けだ」って言っていたのに。
column2: Well, that’s what I thought when I first entered the company. But I decided I’d really better put my back into the job.

column1: 入社当初は、そのつもりだったんだけど、この会社で腰を据えてがんばることにしたんだぁ。
column2: Why is that? Did something happen?

column1: なんで、また？何かあったの？
column2: At first, I was just a sales assistant, but recently they haven’t had enough people to go around and I’ve gotten to do a bit of sales myself. It’s made me realize that I’m actually pretty good at it.

column1: 最初は、営業アシスタントをしていたんだけど、最近の人手不足で営業もさせられるようになったわけ。
column2: And that’s why you’ve decided to put your back into it.

column1: で、私、結構、営業向きだってことに気づいたんだよ。
column2: It's surprising how many people go all soft at the first sign of trouble with a client. But it doesn’t bother me a bit. And I’m light on my feet so I don’t mind at all being away from the office often.

column1: それで、本腰を入れて働くことにしたってわけか。
column2: Yeah, you always have been strong willed. You did used to tell off the cowardly boys in the class.

column1: 営業先でちょっと怒られると、腰が引けちゃう人って、案外多いのよね。でも、私は、全然平気。
column2: And…the company president is pretty cool. He’s very humble, good humored, and oh so dreamy…and, he’s single!

column1: それに、腰が軽いほうだから、外回りも苦にならないし。
column2: Oh what, so that’s the real reason is it?!

column1: to undertake, to take on responsibility
to reach (a certain stage), to row (a boat) up to --
to honored with, to be granted
goal reached, get married, make the goal
愛沙さんから、結婚式の招待状が来てるよ。
column2: You got a wedding invitation from Aisa.

column1: 来た来た！いよいよ、愛沙も社長とゴールインか！
column2: This is it! So Aisa finally scored big with the company president!

column1: 愛沙もがんばったかいがあったよね。
column2: It looks like all that hard work finally paid off.

column1: ちょっと見せて。おっ、さすが社長だけあって、一流ホテルでやるんだな。。。
column2: Let me see that. Wow, a wedding at a first class hotel! How fitting for a company president.

column1: あれ、もえに、挨拶を頼みたいっていう紙が入っているぞ。
column2: Wait a minute, there’s a piece of paper in here asking you to give a speech Moe.

column1: 「竹内様には、友人代表としてご挨拶を賜りたく、お願い申し上げます」？？
column2: We request that you, Ms. Takeuchi, do us the honor of giving the official greeting on behalf of the bride's friends!

column1: うっそー！ちょっと愛沙に電話して聞いてみる。
column2: I don’t believe it! I’m going to give Aisa a call.

column1: もしもし、愛沙？あたしだけど、披露宴で挨拶なんて、聞いてないけど？！
column2: Hello, Aisa? It’s me. This is the first I’ve heard about making speeches at your wedding reception!

column1: あ、そうそう、是非お願いよ！
column2: Oh yeah, I really want you to do it!

column1: 招待客300人の盛大な披露宴だから、もえも挨拶のしがいがあるでしょ。
column2: There are 300 people invited, so it should be a grand occasion for you.

column1: それに、もえのアドバイスのかいもあって、結婚まで漕ぎ着けたんだから！よろしくね！
column2: And besides, it’s thanks to your advice that I’ve managed to get married in the first place! C’mon!

column1: 短くていいの。ほかにいっぱ～い挨拶を頼まなくちゃいけない人がいるからさ。手短に頼むわ！
column2: You can make it as short as you want. There are lots of other people who have to give speeches as well, so just something nice and short should be great!

column1: うーん。まぁ、おめでたいことだから、断っちゃいけないよね。・・・わかった。引き受ける。
column2: Oh well, I guess it is a celebration and it would be kind of rude of me to turn you down…okay, I’ll do it.

column1: to honored with, to be granted
to receive, to take part in, to be given
続きまして、新婦のご友人を代表して、竹内様にご挨拶を賜りたいと存じます。
column2: Next, giving the official greeting on behalf of the bride's friends is Mrs. Takeuchi. If you please.

column1: 竹内様、よろしくお願いいたします。
column2: Hello everyone; I am Moe Takeuchi.

column1: ただ今、ご紹介にあずかりました竹内と申します。
column2: On behalf of the bride's friends, I would like to give a short congratulatory greeting.

column1: 新婦の友人を代表して、一言お祝いの挨拶をさせていただきます。
column2: I have been both friends and schoolmates with the bride, Aisa, for the past twenty years, from middle school through university.

column1: 新婦の愛沙さんとは、中学校から大学まで同じ学校に通った20年来の親友です。
column2: Even after we began working, we met and spent time together often.

column1: 就職してからも、よく会って、遊んでおりました。
column2: But, it must have been about three years after we both first got our jobs… Suddenly, Aisa became a real workaholic.

column1: でも。。。確か、就職して、3年目くらいでしょうか。急に、愛沙さんが仕事人間になってしまったのです。
column2: When I asked her what had happened, it seemed that her interests lay more with Takuya, the company president, than with the job itself.

column1: 何かあったのかと思って聞いてみますと、実は、仕事というより、社長の拓也さんがお目当てだったわけです。
ちょ、ちょっと、そんなこと言わないでよ！（心の中）
column2: As long as I have known her, Aisa has always been a very dedicated person. I am sure that Takuya must have been charmed by her enthusiasm on the job.

column1: 愛沙さんは、昔から何事にも一生懸命でした。ですから、熱心に仕事に取り組む姿に、拓也さんも魅かれたのだと思います。
column2: That's it, talk about my good points. Oh, this brings back so many memories. I'm getting all nostalgic…

column1: そうそう、私のいいところを言ってよね。あ～、いろんなことが思い出される。なつかしい～。。
column2: Wait, Moe's speech is about to end, and I wasn't even listening… (internal voice)

column1: あれ、もえのスピーチ、よく聞かないうちに、もう終わっちゃうわ。（心の中）
column2: In closing, I wish the both of them much happiness for many years to come.

column1: お二人の末永いお幸せをお祈りして、私のお祝いの言葉といたします。
sense of duty, debt of gratitude
set out to earn money (with the intention of bringing it back home)
それね、昼間、セールスの人が来て、契約しちゃったの。
column2: Oh, that. This afternoon, a salesman came by and I signed us up.

column1: サーバー代はサービスだって言うし、ペットボトルの水を買うより安上がりだって言うからいいかなって思って。。。
column2: He said he'd give us the water server free of charge, and that it was cheaper than buying water by the bottle. I thought it might be a good idea.

column1: そんな、セールストークに引っかかって、情けないなぁ。
column2: Oh, how pathetic; I can't believe you got duped by that sales talk.

column1: それに、その人、青森から出稼ぎに来ていて、今月あと10件、契約を取らないと、お正月に田舎にも帰れないって言うのよ。
column2: And the man said he had come all the way out here from Aomori to work, and if he didn't get ten more contracts this month, he wouldn't be able to go home for the New Year's holidays.

column1: つい、情に流されちゃってね。
column2: I just felt sorry for him.

column1: 情につけこむのは、押し売りのよく使う手じゃないか。
column2: Well, you know that using emotion to manipulate people is a common forceful sales tactic.

column1: 私、そういう話を聞いちゃうと、どうしても薄情なことできないのよ。
column2: But when I hear things like that, I just can't give people the cold shoulder.

column1: だって、私の父は、特に情に厚い人だったでしょ。
column2: Oh, you know how caring about others my father was.

column1: まぁ、確かに、君の、お父さんは、義理と人情を大切にする人だったな。
column2: Yeah… Well, that's true; your father was someone who placed a lot of importance on duty and compassion.

column1: 不景気になっても、従業員の首を切らずにがんばっていたよね。
column2: Even in bad economic times, he stuck it out and didn't fire his employees.

column1: でも、結局、会社つぶれちゃったじゃないか。情にもろいのも問題だよ。
column2: But in the end, the company did go under. Allowing yourself to be too influenced by emotion is also a problem.

column1: そうね。私も、父に似て、情にもろい面もあるわね。
column2: Yes, I suppose. I may be a little too emotional like my father.

column1: そういえば、あなたと付き合う前、雨の日も風の日も、毎日私の家に花を届けてくれたでしょ。
column2: Hey, come to think of it, before we started dating you used to deliver a flower to my house every day, rain or shine.

column1: その姿をみて、つい、情にほだされて付き合うことにしたんだったわ。。。
column2: I was so moved by the gesture that I decided to start dating you.

column1: one's financial standing, circulation of money
to deposit, to give into custody
響、お前、つい半年前に新車を買ったと思ったら、もう、また車、買い替えたのか？！
column2: Hibiki, you just bought a car six months ago, and now you've already traded it in for a new one?!

column1: なんで、そんなに金回りがいいんだよ。
column2: How do you keep the money flowing like that?

column1: まぁな。この低金利だろ。銀行に預けても、利子がほとんどつかなくて、ばかばかしくてさ。
column2: Yeah, well, it must be the low interest rates. The interest I was getting from the bank was just ridiculously low,

column1: だから最近、株を始めたんだよ。
column2: so I recently started investing in the stock market.

column1: 株？そんなの、どうせ損するのが落ちだろ。
column2: Stocks? But don't you just end up losing money on those things?

column1: そうとも限らないぞ！ちゃんと企業研究や情報収集をすれば、なんとか儲かるもんだぜ。
column2: Not necessarily! If you collect enough information and research the businesses right you can actually make money at it.

column1: へぇ、そうなのか。じゃ、俺もちょっと挑戦してみようかな。
column2: Hmmm, is that so? Maybe I'll try it out myself.

column1: 初心者向きの株で、何かお勧めはあるか？
column2: Can you recommend any good stocks for beginners?

column1: そうだなぁ。環境関連とかバイオテクノロジー関係とかの株がいいんじゃないか。
column2: Well, what about environment or biotech related stocks?

column1: これから成長が見込めそうな業界だからな。
column2: I think either of those industries probably has good prospects.

column1: なるほど。よし、お前が、絶対損しないって保証してくれるなら、1度買ってみようかな。
column2: I see. All right, if you can guarantee me that I won't lose money at it, I think I'll try it at least once.

column1: 何言ってるんだよ。そんな保証、誰ができるか！
column2: What are you saying? Nobody can make that kind of guarantee!

column1: 株は自分の責任で買うもんだよ。
column2: You have to be responsible for the stocks you buy.

column1: 自己責任だなんて、そんな冷たいこと言うなよ。
響は、ぼろ儲けしているんだろう？
column2: You're making gobs of money, right, Hibiki?

column1: 俺だって、いろいろ痛い目にあってるんだよ。
column2: But I've met with plenty of bad luck, too.

column1: 絶対損しない株なんてものがあるなら、俺の方が知りたいよ！
column2: If there were such a thing as a stock that never lost you money, I'd want to be the first one to know about it.

column1: person in charge of cooking and serving a hotpot dish
to put all one's skill to work, to do one's best
おじゃま。お、光一も、来てたのか。
column2: I’m here. Oh, Koichi, you’re here too.

column1: よぉ、新平。男三人で忘年会ってのもさえないけどな。
column2: Hey, Shinpei. A year-end party with just three guys is a bit pathetic, but oh, well.

column1: うまそうなにおいだな。今日は鍋か？
column2: Something smells good. Are we having hotpot tonight?

column1: 忘年会といえば、やっぱり鍋でしょ！俺、鍋にはちょっとうるさいよ。
column2: Well, we couldn’t really have a year-end party without a hot pot now, could we? I’m a bit particular about my hot pots y’know.

column1: いわゆる鍋奉行ってやつか。それは、楽しみだな。
column2: A sort of Shogun of hot pot, huh? I’m looking forward to it.

column1: じゃーん、今日のだしは、俺が腕によりを掛けて、鶏ガラを煮出してとったスープだぞ！
column2: Ta-da! The soup is a chicken stock of my own recipe.

column1: 鶏ガラスープの素は手軽だけど、本格的な味を出すには、やっぱり鶏ガラから煮出すに限るよ。
column2: Using ready-made chicken stock is certainly easier, but to get that real authentic flavor, boiling up your own broth from real chicken parts is the only way to go.

column1: すげぇいいにおい！さっそく、この肉とか野菜、入れていい？
column2: Oh yeah, that smells great! Can I start putting in this meat and veggies?

column1: ちょ、ちょっと待て。入れる順番があるんだ。
column2: Well, hold on now. There is a proper order to all of this. You have to start with the tougher vegetables and meat to make sure they get cooked all the way through. That’s an ironclad rule.

column1: まずは、火が通りにくい野菜と肉類から入れるのが鉄則なんだ。
column2: When the timing is right, then you can put in the white fish and shellfish last. If things get overcooked they can get all tough on you, you know.

column1: 頃合をみて、最後に白身魚とか、貝類を入れるんだ。火が通り過ぎて硬くなっちゃうからな。

column2: All right, it looks like the oysters are just about ready.

column1: さ、そろそろ、この牡蠣は食べごろだぞ。
column2: Oh, oysters go great with white wine don’t they?

column1: 牡蠣といえば、白ワインだよな。
column2: Oh shoot! That is so unlike me. I forgot to buy the white wine!

column1: あっ！しまった、俺としたことが、白ワインを買い忘れた！

column2: Forget about it; just the oysters are great! It's too much trouble putting the oysters in little by little, so let's just throw all of them into the pot.

column1: それより、この牡蠣、最高だぜ！面倒くさいから、ここにある牡蠣、全部鍋に入れちゃおうぜ。
column2: No, no! We can’t put the next bunch of oysters in until after we eat what’s in the pot!

column1: だめだめ！次の牡蠣を入れるのは、今鍋の中にあるのを全部食べきってからだよ！
ユウちゃん？久しぶり。大学はもう夏休みに入ったんでしょ？いつ帰ってくるの？お盆には帰ってくるんでしょ。
column2: Yū? It's been ages! It's already university summer vacation, right? When are you coming home? You're coming home for Obon, surely.

column1: …それがさ、明日から海外に一人旅に行こうと思って…。
column2: ... About that...starting tomorrow, I was thinking about going on a solitary trip abroad...

column1: 明日？まったく、親の心子知らずよね。ユウちゃんが帰ってくるのをお母さん楽しみに待っていたのに…。あ、保険には入っておいてよ。
column2: Tomorrow? Good grief, children really don't know how much their parents love them. I was so looking forward to your coming home too... Make sure and get insurance!

column1: なんだよ、それ。俺が死ねばいいとか思っているわけ？
column2: What the — ? Are you saying it'd be good if I died? (laughs)

column1: 違うわよ。盗難とか、事故とか、テロとか、天災とかあるかもしれないでしょ。空港に保険の代理店があるから、そこで海外旅行傷害保険に入ってから行きなさい。
column2: No! You might get robbed or have an accident, or there might be terrorism or a natural disaster. There's an insurance agency at the airport, so go AFTER you've registered for overseas travel accident insurance.
Huh? It's a waste of money.

column1: そんなこと言わずに加入しなさい。転ばぬ先の杖っていうでしょ。いいわね。
column2: Just register without saying things like that, please. Better safe than sorry, right? Are we clear?

column1: 「はい」は、一回。それから、見知らぬ人に声をかけられてもついて行ったらダメだからね。
column2: Just say yes once. And if a stranger talks to you, you mustn't go with him, all right?

column1: 母さん、もういいかな。親知らずが痛くて、これから歯医者に行くんだけど…。
column2: Mom, that's enough, surely. My wisdom teeth are hurting, so I'm about to go to the dentist.

column1: そうなの。じゃ、早く行ってきなさい。じゃあ切るわよ、またね。
column2: Oh, really? Well, hurry up and go. I'm hanging up. See you later.

column1: Don't tell me that --, surely not, impossible
to swell, to become swollen; V2
あれ、どうしたんだ、優太？ILL島に行ったんじゃないのか。
column2: Huh? What happened, Yūta? Weren't you going to ILL Island?

column1: そのつもりだったんだけど…。
column2: That was the plan, but... The day before my trip I had my wisdom teeth taken out, you know? And then it wouldn't stop bleeding, my face swelled up, I got a fever... So because of all that I couldn't leave.

column1: 旅行の前日に親知らずを抜いたらさ、血は止まらないわ、顔は腫れるわ、熱はでるわ…。それで、出発できなかったんだよ。
column2: Surely you could have changed your flight to a different day.

column1: 別の日の飛行機に変えられただろうに。
column2: It was a cheap ticket, you know, so I couldn't change it to a different flight. The ticket's a dead loss. Well anyway, the fact that I only reserved the flight is some small mercy.

column1: 安い航空券だからさ、他の便への変更はできなくてさ、航空券はぱあだよ。
column2: You're still young, so you'll be able to go again eventually, you know.

column1: ま、飛行機しか予約してなかったのは、不幸中の幸いだったけど。
column2: Dad, it's terrible! It says an undersea volcano near ILL Island has erupted and caused a huge earthquake. It looks like there's also been a tsunami, and... Huh? Yūta, what happened? Didn't you go to ILL Island?

column1: 若いんだから、またそのうち行けるさ。
column2: When I had my wisdom teeth taken out I got a fever, you see, so I ended up not going.

column1: お父さん、大変、ILL島付近の海底火山が噴火して大地震だって。
column2: Thank goodness! Fate works in mysterious ways.

column1: 津波も起きたみたいで、…あら？優太、どうしたの？ILL島行かなかったの？
親知らずを抜いたら熱がでちゃってさ、行くのやめたんだ。
column2: What? Don't tell me even though you're a university student you don't know what that means? It means that disaster can sometimes bring good fortune, and conversely you don't know whether good fortune might sometimes be the seed of disaster. I thought you learned that in middle school.

column1: よかったー。塞翁が馬ね。
shooting to death, shoot and kill
to be separated from, to be a long way away ;V2
お帰りなさい。東京出張はどうだった。
column2: Welcome home. How was your business trip to Tokyo? You didn't contact me after you left, so I was worried, you know!

column1: 出かけたっきり連絡ないから心配してたのよ。
column2: Sorry, I was busy, you know. I want this to be the last business trip I go on.

column1: ごめん、忙しくてさ。出張はこれっきりにしてほしいよ。

column2: Here you go, your souvenir. It's a soft toy Pooh bear, the one that you like.

column1: はい、お土産。貞子の好きな熊のプー様のぬいぐるみだよ。

column2: You can only buy that in Tokyo.

column1: それ、東京だけでしか買えないんだぞ。
column2: Oh my, that's right. It says Only for sale in Tokyo. Do you want something to eat?

column1: あら、ホント。東京でのみ販売って書いてある。何か食べる？

column2: I'll get it for you now.
This afternoon, in a residential area in Yamagata Prefecture's Minato City, a woman was attacked by a bear and suffered serious injuries.

column1: 今日の午後　山形県港市の住宅街にて、女性が熊に襲われ重傷を負いました。
column2: Minato City? That's really close, isn't it?

column1: 港市？すぐ近くじゃないか。
column2: Today at around one-thirty this afternoon, Ms. Kane Mochida, aged eighty-nine, who lived in Yamagata Prefecture's Minato City, was attacked from behind by a bear as she swept the garden of her home.

column1: 本日午後、一時半頃　山形県港市に住む持田金さん89歳が自宅の庭で掃除をしていたところ　背後から熊に襲われました。
column2: Ms. Mochida broke bones in her face, etc., receiving injuries that will take two months to fully heal.

column1: 持田さんは顔の骨を折るなど、全治２ヶ月の怪我を負いました。
column2: Following the incident, the bear was shot and killed while playing in a park one kilometer from Ms. Mochida's home.

column1: 熊はその後、持田さん宅から１キロメートル離れた公園で遊んでいるところを射殺されました。
column2: The bear got killed? Poor thing.

column1: 熊、殺されちゃったの？かわいそう。
column2: It's the person who got attacked that you should feel sorry for!

column1: 人を襲ったら、殺されちゃうのに、どうして熊は人を襲っちゃったんだろう。
column2: Even though bears get killed if they attack people, I wonder why that bear attacked that person?

column1: 熊がそんなこと分かるはずないでしょ。襲われた人こそかわいそうよ。
column2: How would a bear understand that? It's the person who was attacked who's to be pitied.

column1: 熊は山に食料がないから人の住むところに食べ物を探しに来るんだろうね。
column2: Bears come and look for food where people live because there's no food in the mountains, I suppose. It's because they're scared of humans that they attack them, apparently.

column1: 人を恐れていればこそ、襲うらしいよ。
column2: In various places, bears continue to cause damage. In order to attempt to discover the cause of this, we interviewed Professor Kumagai from Forest University.

column1: 各地で熊の被害が続いています。何が原因なのか、森大学の熊谷教授にインタビューをしてみました。
column2: The reason that bears appear in residential districts is because there is hardly any food for them in the mountains. We can also point to the withering of trees caused by global warming and acid rain as one cause of this.

column1: 熊が住宅地に出没するのは熊のえさが山にほとんどないからなんですよ。
column2: So basically, human beings themselves are the originators of all of these causes...

column1: 温暖化や酸性雨のせいで木が枯れてきているのも原因の一つと言えますね。
column2: That's right. If the forests don't come back to life, then the true problem will probably not be solved.

column1: つまり人間こそが全ての原因を作った…。
column2: So bears are suffering from food shortages too... But it's frightening. That park is just a stone's throw away from Sadako's elementary school.

column1: そう。森が再生しないと、本当の意味での問題は解決しないでしょうね。
column2: I'll be fine. I have anti-bear spray. Look.

column1: 熊も食料不足で大変なのね…。でも、怖いわ。あの公園、貞子の小学校から目と鼻の先でしょ。
海外営業部　佐藤元気殿
column2: Overseas Sales Department Mr. Genki Satō

column1: 香港支店転勤を命じる
column2: Order of Transfer to Hong Kong Office

column1: 皆さん、ご無沙汰してます。
column2: Everyone, I apologize that I haven't been in touch for a while.

column1: 突然ですが、会社から辞令が出て、来月から香港に転勤することになりました。
column2: This is rather sudden, but a notice of personnel change has come down from the company, and as of next month I will be transferred to Hong Kong. There's only a month left until I leave, but just as long as it's OK with you all, let's drink!

column1: 出発まであと一ヶ月しかないのですが、皆さんさえよければ、飲みましょう。
column2: Well, Genki, who couldn't even write the alphabet when he was in middle school, is being transferred abroad. I want to propose a toast to Genki both going and coming back home in good spirits. Take care. Cheers!

column1: えー。中学時代はアルファベットすら書けなかった元気が、海外に転勤することになりました。
元気が元気に行って帰ってくることを祈って乾杯したいと思います。行ってらっしゃーい。乾杯！
column2: You're amazing. Can you even speak Chinese?
Nope, not at all. But just being able to speak English is enough for the job.

column1: お前すごいな。中国語まで話せるのか？
column2: I'm so jealous. You did study abroad when you were at university, so you can speak English.

column1: いや、全然。でも、仕事は英語さえできれば大丈夫なんだよ。
column2: For me, even going on an overseas business trip, let alone becoming an overseas employee, is beyond my wildest dreams.

column1: いいなぁ。元気は大学時代に留学したから、英語ができて。
column2: But your company was recently bought out by an American company, right?

column1: 俺には海外駐在員になる事はもちろん海外出張することすら夢の夢だよ。
column2: Yeah. All in-house documents are in English. Lately we've even been having meetings in English.

column1: でも、春樹の会社って最近アメリカの会社に買収されただろ？
column2: Even conversations where everyone is Japanese are in English! Give me a break.

column1: to dump someone, to shake something, to wave (hand) ; V1
to get tired of, to lose interest in; V2
to be worried, to be troubled;V1
香港へは一人で行くの？
column2: Are you going to Hong Kong alone?

column1: ああ。今、彼女いないからね。
column2: Yeah. I don't have a girlfriend at the moment.

column1: 赴任期間はどのくらい？
column2: How long is the appointment term?

column1: さあ。見当もつかないよ。
column2: Good question. I don't have the slightest idea.

column1: 志保ちゃんとは、うまくいっているのか？
column2: How are you getting on with Shiho? I'm totally jealous of you, going out with such a feminine girl.

column1: あんなに女らしい子と付き合っているなんてうらやましいよ。
column2: We broke up. I get bored easily, you know.

column1: 別れたよ。俺、飽きっぽいからさ。
column2: Why? You know I gave up on Shiho because she was going out with you!

column1: なんでだよ！俺...相手がお前だから、志保ちゃんのことあきらめたんだぞ。
column2: So you finally come out with the truth. That's so like you. But I don't need cheap friendship.

column1: やっと本当の事言ったな。お前らしいな。
でも安っぽい友情なんていらないんだよ。
column2: She dumped me. Apparently, there's someone she's liked ever since she was in middle school, and she can't forget him.

column1: 俺、振られたんだ。中学の頃からずっと好きだった人がいて、そいつのことが忘れられないらしいぞ。
column2: Who else would it be but you?

column1: お前以外にいないだろう。
column2: What are you freaking out about? Tonight's your last chance, right? Go for it.

column1: 何を悩んでいるんだよ。今夜が最後のチャンスだろ。当たって砕けろよ。

column2: Thanks. I dressed up because I was going to see Genki, but it's just the worst luck. Even though he was so manly and cool in middle school.

column1: ありがとう。元気君に会えるからおしゃれしたんだけど、残念。
column2: He's argumentative, pompous... He's like an old man. As I thought, Haruki's the one for me.

column1: 中学のときは男らしくて素敵だったのに。
column2: Huh? After all that, back to where you started?

column1: おいしそう。いただきます。
column2: This looks yummy. Don't mind if I do. Huh? Ow, ow!
Miss White, Snow White, please come in.

column1: 白雪さん、白雪姫さん、どうぞお入りください。
column2: What seems to be the trouble?
Since I ate lunch, my stomach hasn't been feeling very good.

column1: お昼を食べてからお腹の調子が悪いんです。
column2: You have diarrhea and stomach pain? Do you have any other symptoms?

column1: 下痢と腹痛ですか。他に症状はありますか。
column2: For example, you feel nauseous, or you have a fever, etcetera.

column1: 例えば、吐き気がするとか。熱があるとか。
column2: I don't know whether I have a fever. Before I came here, I threw up any number of times.

column1: 熱はわかりません。ここに来るまでに何回も吐いてしまいました。
column2: My stomach still feels queasy. I also have chills, and I feel dizzy too.

column1: 胃がまだむかむかします。寒気もしますし、めまいもします。
column2: It seems like a typical case of food poisoning, but let's have a little look.

column1: 典型的な食中毒のようですが、ちょっと調べてみましょう。
column2: So it IS food poisoning? My vision has somehow started flickering...

column1: やっぱり食あたりですか？なんだか、目がちかちかしてきたんですが...。
column2: I think you've eaten something poisonous. What did you eat?

column1: 毒性のあるものを食べたと思うんです。何を食べましたか。
column2: I just ate one bite of this apple.

column1: このリンゴを一口だけ食べたんです。
これは、どこで手に入れたんですか。
column2: An old woman who looked like a fortune-teller gave it to me.

column1: 占い師風のおばあさんにもらいました。
column2: We won't know technicalities until we do tests, but you may have ingested a phosphoric poison.

column1: 専門的なことは、調べてみないとわかりませんが、リン系の毒を食べてしまったのかも知れません。
column2: There is the possibility that your condition may worsen from now on, so just to be on the safe side, please go to the hospital.

column1: examination at the end of term
Kōshien baseball stadium, Japan National High School Baseball Tournament
どうしたんですか？原先生？
見てくださいよ。坂東君の期末テストの答案。
column2: Look at this. Bandō's end-of-term test paper.

column1: 間違いだらけなんですよ。勉強したのかしら。
column2: It's full of mistakes. I wonder if he actually studied?

column1: でも、うちの長島の答案もひどいですよ。
column2: But Nagashima, in my class, his test papers are terrible too.

column1: あら。バツだらけ。どんぐりの背比べね。
column2: Oh, my. It's covered with crosses. You can't tell which is worse, can you.

column1: まあ、彼らは野球部だから仕方ないですよ。
column2: Well, those two are on the baseball team, so it can't be helped.

column1: 朝から晩まで砂まみれ、汗まみれで野球を練習しているんですから。
column2: They practice baseball from morning till night, covered with sand, soaked with sweat.

column1: 甲子園が終わるまでは、勉強どころじゃないでしょうね。
column2: Until the Koshien's over, they won't have the time to study.

column1: これで甲子園に出て活躍してプロに入れればいい事ずくめですからね。
column2: If they take part in the Koshien this time, play an active role, and then go pro - there'll be nothing but good things for them.

column1: 彼らはそんな理由で野球をしているんじゃありませんよ。
column2: Those two aren't playing baseball for those reasons, you know.

column1: プロになれても芽が出るのは一部ですし、プロ選手達は天才だらけです。
column2: Even among those who are able to go pro, the lucky ones are only a small percentage of them.

column1: 第一、坂東や長島のレベルではプロになることも無理です。
column2: There are nothing but genius players in the pro leagues.
Firstly, at Bandō or Nagashima's level, going pro at all is impossible.

column1: でも、先のことを考えずに泥だらけになって一生懸命頑張っている彼らを見ると、僕は、感動するんです。

column2: But when I see them giving it their all, covered in mud, not thinking about what may happen in the future, I feel moved.

column1: 皆さんは「工場夜景」がブームになっていることをご存知ですか？
column2: Everyone, did you know that factory night scenery is becoming a craze?

column1: 今回は、夜景評論家の宮沢賢さんに工場を案内してもらいます。
column2: This time we'll have a night scenery critic, Ken Miyazawa, show us around a factory.

column1: よろしくお願いします。
さて、工場夜景ですが、どのような点が人気なのでしょうか。
column2: Now, speaking of factory night scenery, what sort of points are popular?

column1: 百聞は一見にしかず。こちらへどうぞ。
column2: Seeing for yourself would be better than any explanation of mine. Please come this way.

column1: うわ。きれい…。とても人工的で、幻想的な風景ですね。
column2: Wow! It's beautiful. It's a very artificial, fantastical scene, isn't it?

column1: 近未来の都市にいるみたいです。
column2: It's like we're in a city of the near future.

column1: 人気の理由は色々あるでしょうが、工場夜景はＳＦのような風景をみることができるという点で人気があるのだと思います。
column2: There are probably many reasons why factory night scenery is popular, but I think it's popular due to the point that it allows you to see science-fiction-like scenery.

column1: 工場ってマイナス面ばかりが強調されてきましたよね。環境汚染とか。
column2: Factories have always had their negative aspects highlighted up until now, haven't they? Environmental pollution and such.

column1: 今の工場は環境面を考えているから安全ですし、工場はわれわれの生活に必要なものです。
column2: The factories of today are safe, as they think from an environmental perspective, and factories are necessary for our day-to-day lives.

column1: 工場全体のイメージをよくするという点でも、工場夜景見学は効果的なんですよ。
column2: Factory night scenery viewing trips are also effective in improving the image of the entire factory, you see.

column1: なるほど。私も誰か素敵な人とこの夜景を見に来たいと思います。
column2: I see! I'd like to come and see this night scenery with someone special.

column1: すみませんねぇ。今日は私と一緒で…。
column2: Sorry that today you only got me...

column1: あ、そういう意味じゃないです。
unfaithfulness (in a relationship), an (extramarital) affair, cheating (on someone)
大変でしたね。急に呼び出されて。
column2: That was tough, suddenly getting called out like this.

column1: 本当だよ。結婚１０周年だからレストラン予約して舌鼓を打ってたのに、いきなり会社から呼び出しだよ。
column2: Right? It's our tenth wedding anniversary, so I'd made a restaurant reservation, and I'm just getting into my food when I suddenly get a call from work.
Was your wife OK with it?

column1: 舌打ちされたよ。で、何？総理辞任？
column2: She clicked her tongue at me. So what's happening? The prime minister's resigning?

column1: こんな時間に緊急記者会見をするんだから、多分そうだと思いますよ。
column2: For them to call a sudden press conference at this hour, I think that's probably what it is.

column1: 前回の選挙で、「税金は上げない」って言ったのに、その舌の根の乾かぬうちに消費税を10パーセントにするなんていうから、支持率が下がったんだ。
column2: During the previous election, even though he said he wouldn't raise taxes, in the same breath he said he was going to put consumption tax up to 10% or whatever, so his approval rating dropped, you know.

column1: それから、あの人、本当に話すの下手ですよね。
column2: On top of that, that guy is a really poor speaker.

column1: 舌足らずな話し方だし、失言も多いし。
column2: He talks with a lisp, and he's always saying inappropriate things.
What was it—Extramarital affairs are Japanese culture?

column1: そうそう。「北海道の人は怠け者で、メロンも育てられない」とも言ったよな。
column2: Yeah, that was it. He also said People from Hokkaido are lazy, and can't even grow melons properly, didn't he?

column1: 言う事もころころ変えるから、「二枚舌」なんて外国メディアに悪口書かれちゃいましたしね。
column2: The things he says change from moment to moment, so he got called two-faced by the foreign media, didn't he.

column1: ま、舌先三寸なのは日本の首相だけじゃないけどな。
column2: Well, it's not only the Japanese prime minister who's oily, you know.

column1: entering a higher-level school, going on to university
突然のメールにて失礼いたします。私は、現在、羽田大学でEラーニングについて研究しておりますが、さらに研究を深めるべく、貴大学の修士課程への進学を希望しております。
column2: Please excuse my writing to you so suddenly. I am currently researching e-learning at Haneda University, but in order to further my research, I hope to proceed to a Master's course at your university.

column1: 土屋先生の研究テーマである「効果的な遠隔教育の手法」に関心を持っており、先生のご都合のよろしいときに、お会いして研究室や大学院での研究生活についてお話を伺いたいと思っております。
column2: I am very interested in your subject of research, The Techniques of Effective Distance Learning, and so, at a time convenient for you, I would like to meet with you to ask you about your research laboratory and your research activities at the graduate school.

column1: ご多忙のところ恐縮ではございますが、お時間をいただくことが可能かどうかご返信をいただければ幸いに存じます。
column2: I apologize for troubling you when you must be extremely busy, but I would be extremely grateful if you would be so good as to let me know whether or not you can spare the time to meet with me.

column1: よし、書き終えた。でも念には念を入れて、送信する前に間違いがないか誰かにチェックしてもらうべきだな。
column2: Right, it's all written! But just to be one hundred percent safe, I should get someone to check it over before I send it to make sure there are no mistakes.

column1: 先輩に研究室を見に行くべきだって言われたけど、わからないことだらけだよ。
column2: An older student told me I had to go and visit the research lab, but there's so much I don't know...

column1: 第一印象は大事だっていうから、研究室へはスーツで行くべきかなぁ？
column2: They say first impressions are important, so does that mean I should wear a suit to the research lab?

column1: あと、手土産は持っていくべきなのか？
column2: Also, should I take a gift?

column1: essential, fundamental, crucial, vital, main; Adj(na)
よう。研究室訪問どうだった。
column2: Hey. How was your visit to the laboratory?

column1: 先輩のアドバイス通り、スーツで行って手土産を持って行きました。
column2: Just as you advised, I went wearing a suit and took a gift with me.

column1: 肝心な研究内容や入試についても聞いてきたんだろう。
column2: You asked about the fundamentals of the research, the entrance exam, and stuff too while you were there, right?

column1: はい。自分がやりたいＥラーニングのシステムの研究ができそうです。
column2: Yes. It seems like I'll be able to do the research I want to about e-learning systems.

column1: 入試に関しては、天下大以外の大学からでも合格しにくいということはない…って言ってました。
column2: About the entrance exam, he said that it's not especially difficult to pass for those students from universities other than Tenka University.

column1: 研究室の院生を何人か紹介してくれて、院生からも色々聞く事ができました。
column2: He introduced me to several of the graduate students from the lab, and I was able to ask them lots of things too.

column1: 先生には直接聞きづらいことでも、院生には聞きやすいしな。
column2: Things that are hard to ask the professor directly you can ask the graduate students more easily, right.

column1: はい。院生に天下大の大学院に合格するのはかなり難しいから、天下大以外の大学院も受験しておいた方が良いって言われました。
優秀な学生ばかりで選びがたい…って毎年教授も悩むそうです。
column2: The graduate students told me that because it's pretty difficult to get into Tenka University's graduate school, it would be better to take the entrance exams for other graduate schools too, just in case.
Every year it's nothing but gifted students who apply, so the professor apparently has a tough time choosing.

column1: なので、帝国大学の大学院にも願書を出そうと思います。
天下大と帝国大は甲乙つけがたい名門だな。
column2: So I think I'm going to submit an application to Teikoku University too.

column1: 書類の準備と入試対策も頑張れよ。
column2: Tenka University and Teikoku University are both prestigious. It's difficult to say which is better.

column1: あ、何か相談あったら、連絡してこいよ。
column2: Good luck with preparing the documents and your strategy for the entrance exams.

column1: ありがとうございます。
column2: Oh, if there's anything you want to ask me, drop me a line.

column1: 研究計画書、志望理由書、成績証明書…。でも、不備があり得るかも。
column2: Research plan, statement of purpose, academic transcript... But it's possible I've overlooked something.

column1: 念のため、もう一度、チェック…よし！
column2: Just in case, check it one more time... okay!

column1: これを書留で送ってください。あ…速達でお願いします。
column2: Please send this by registered mail. Oh...by express delivery, please.

column1: 明日には届きますよね。
column2: It'll get there by tomorrow, won't it?

column1: ええ、明日の午前中には届く予定ですが、交通などの事情で遅れることもあり得ます。大丈夫ですか。
column2: Yes, it should arrive by tomorrow morning, but it is possible that it could be delayed by traffic conditions and such. Is that all right?

column1: 健二先輩、今、時間、大丈夫ですか？
column2: Kenji, do you have time to talk now?

column1: 先輩に見てもらった研究計画書を送ったんですけど…。
column2: I sent off the research plan you looked at for me.

column1: あとは試験と面接だな。
column2: Just the exam and the interview left, then.

column1: はい…実は、面接が僕苦手で…。
column2: Yes... The truth is, I'm not very good at interviews...

column1: じゃ、聞かれそうなことをすべてリストアップすることだな。
column2: So you should make a list of everything you think you might get asked.

column1: ああ。面接では緊張して、頭が真っ白になる…ってことも起こり得る。
column2: Yeah. It's possible you'll be really nervous during the interview and have your mind go totally blank...so you should practice giving answers.

column1: 答えを言う練習もしておいたほうがいいぞ。

column2: Are you OK for the written exam?
For the time being, I've studied everything that's likely to be on the test.

column1: 出題されそうなものは一応全部勉強しました。
column2: So you're all set! Good luck!

column1: 失礼いたします。羽田大学より来ました佐藤学です。
column2: Excuse me. I am Manabu Satō from Haneda University.

column1: よろしくお願いします。
column2: I am very pleased to make your acquaintance.

column1: まず、本大学院を志望する理由と研究テーマについて簡潔に述べてください。
column2: First, please tell us briefly about why you want to join this university and about your topic of research.

column1: 私の研究テーマは、Ｅラーニングを活用した外国語学習に関するものです。
column2: My topic of research concerns the study of foreign languages through e-learning.

column1: 効率的に外国語をマスターできる学習システムを作りたいと考えています。
column2: I'd like to create a learning system that allows effective mastery of foreign languages.

column1: 大学院では、システム構築の理論を基礎から勉強し、実際にシステムを作る技術を身に付けたいため、教育の充実した天下大学院を志望しています。
column2: In graduate school, I want to study system architecture from the basics and acquire the practical skills for building a system. Thus, I wish to enter Tenka University Graduate School, which is renowned for its teaching.

column1: どんな学習システムを具体的にイメージしていますか？
column2: Do you have a specific idea of what kind of learning system?

column1: 学習者の弱点を把握しながら、学習コンテンツを提示する形です。
column2: I want it to present the study content while understanding the student's weak points.

column1: 要するに、フィードバック機能がついた学習システムということ？
column2: So, in short, you mean a learning system with a feedback function?

column1: はい、そうです。言い換えれば、テストと連携した学習システムです。
column2: Yes, that's correct. In other words, it's a learning system that is linked to tests.

column1: 卒業研究について教えてください。
column2: Please tell us about your research when you were an undergraduate.

column1: はい。学習者が単語を効率的に記憶できるような学習システムを作成しました。
column2: Of course. For my graduation thesis, I created a system that effectively allows learners to memorize vocabulary.

column1: ということは、基本的なプログラミングの知識はあるんですね。
column2: So that means you have basic programming knowledge, then?

column1: in the middle of, in the midst of, at the height of
out of work, waiting for another chance to enter a university
somehow or other, for some reason or another
a staring contest, constant staring at something
Life is full of ups and downs.
よう！パソコンとにらめっこか？
column2: Hey! Staring down the computer screen, are you?

column1: あ、先輩。今天下大学の合格者リストが１１時から大学のホームページで発表される予定なんです。
column2: Oh, Kenji. The list of successful applicants to Tenka University is supposed to be published on the university homepage at eleven o'clock, you see.

column1: あと１分で１１時…。首を長くして待っているところか。帝国大も受験したんだろ？どうだったんだ？
column2: It'll be eleven o'clock in one minute... So you're sitting there waiting eagerly, huh. You took the exam for Teikoku University as well, right? How did that go?

column1: 不合格でした。他にも２つ大学院を受験したんですが、それもダメでした。
column2: I didn't get in. I took the exams for two other universities too, but I failed both of those too.

column1: 今年はどこの大学院も競争率が高かったらしいからな。
column2: Seems the competition for places was really fierce at every graduate school this year.

column1: 面接の雰囲気で何となく合格できないのは分かっていたんですよね。教授達は僕の話の最中に何度も首をひねってたんです。
column2: I somehow knew from the mood of the interview that I wouldn't get in. The professors tilted their heads in confusion however many times during my explanation.

column1: これで、天下大も落ちたらどうしよう。浪人することは親が首を縦に振らないだろうし…。
column2: So now if I don't get in to Tenka University, I don't know what I'll do. My parents aren't likely to agree to me spending a year waiting for another chance to try to get in...

column1: 七転び八起きっていうじゃないか、くよくよすんな。あ、もう１１時だぞ。あ、出てる出てる。合格者一覧。
column2: You know what they say, If at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Don't get so down. Ah, it's already eleven o' clock! It's up, it's up! The list of successful applicants!

column1: え？俺の受験番号は…あった！ありました、先輩。
column2: Huh? My examination number...is there! It's there, Kenji!

column1: 首の皮一枚でつながりました。
column2: By the skin of my teeth.

column1: 俺も首を突っ込んだかいがあったよ。
column2: My sticking my nose into your business paid off.

column1: 10月8日は知事選挙の投票日です。
column2: The eighth of October is polling day for the prefectural governor elections.

column1: 投票時間は朝７時から夜８時までです。必ず投票に行きましょう。
column2: Polling hours are from seven a.m. until eight p.m. Be sure and go and vote!

column1: 10月8日は知事選挙の投票日です。投票時間は…。
column2: The eighth of October is polling day for the prefectural governor elections. Polling hours are...

column1: 来週の日曜日は選挙か。
column2: Next Sunday is an election, huh.

column1: 立候補してるのは４人だったっけ。
column2: Was it four people who were standing for election?

column1: 自民党の阿倍山さんと民主党の菅谷さん、共産党の地位さん。
column2: Mr. Abeyama from the Liberal Democratic Party, Mr. Sugaya from the Democratic Party, and Mr. Chii from the Communist Party.

column1: 政策面では阿倍山さんがいいと思うけど…親の七光りで議員になったお坊ちゃんだからな。
column2: I think in terms of policies Mr. Abeyama is the best, but...he's a privileged rich guy who became a member of the Diet through his father's connections, you know.

column1: 前に大臣をしていたときに「もう疲れた」って言って辞めたんでしょ？
column2: Before, when he was a cabinet minister, didn't he quit saying, I'm tired?

column1: 子供じゃあるまいし…。国民をバカにしているよね。
column2: It's not like he's a little kid... He's making fools of the electorate.

column1: でも、何でもかんでもマスコミに批判されれば嫌になろうってもんだよ。
column2: But surely anyone would get sick of being criticized by the media for every little thing.

column1: 確かに、どうでもいい私生活とか奥さんのこととか面白おかしく報道するのは問題だと思うけど…。
column2: I daresay it is an issue when they put out amusing reports about his private life, which we couldn't care less about, or about his wife...

column1: でも阿倍山さん「サラリーマンの平均年収がどれくらいか知ってるんですか？」という記者の質問に、「さあ、１千万位ですか？」って答えたんだって。
column2: But apparently when a reporter asked him, Do you know how much the average office worker's annual income is? Mr. Abeyama answered, Hmm, about ten million yen?

column1: 一千万？ はぁ…。金持ちのぼんぼんには俺らの気持ちは分かるまい。
column2: Ten million? Sigh... A privileged rich kid can't possibly understand how we feel.

column1: to make noise, to kick up a fuss;V1
to panic, to lose one's cool, to be flustered
「地震・雷・火事・親父」って聞いたことありますか。
column2: Have you ever heard the phrase Earthquakes, thunder, fires, fathers?

column1: これは、昔の人が怖いと思っていた4つのものですが、この中の地震と火事の対処の仕方を覚えておきましょう。
column2: These are four things that people in the past used to be scared of, but let's learn how to deal with two of them…earthquakes and fires.

column1: じゃ、まずグラッと揺れたらどうしますか。
column2: All right, first of all, what would you do if things suddenly started shaking?

column1: そうですね。机がなかったら頭を洋服やカバンで覆います。
column2: That's right. If there isn't a desk, then you protect your head with your clothing, a bag, et cetera.

column1: 窓が割れるかもしれないので、窓から離れます。
column2: The windows might break, so you should move away from them.

column1: そのとおり。逃げ道を確保するためですよね。
column2: Exactly. In order to ensure you have an escape route, right?

column1: うーん。地震が起きている時にすぐに外に飛び出すのはかえって危険ですよ。
column2: Hmm. When an earthquake is going on, it's actually more dangerous to immediately rush outside.

column1: でも、建物が壊れるかもしれないし…。
column2: But the building might collapse, so...

column1: 古い建物はそういうこともあります。
column2: That's a possibility with older buildings.

column1: でも、日本の新しい建物や学校なら中にいた方が外に出るよりむしろ安全なんです。
column2: However, with newer buildings and schools and such in Japan, it's actually safer to be inside them than to go outside.

column1: 大きな街では地震で壊れた看板や窓ガラスなどが、落ちてきます。
column2: In big towns, billboards that have been damaged by the earthquake, as well as window glass and such, can come falling down.

column1: だから、まだ揺れている時に外に出るとかえって危ないんです。
column2: So, to go outside while things are still shaking is actually more dangerous.

column1: 揺れが止まってから、慌てず、騒がずに避難してください。
column2: Once the shaking has stopped, please evacuate without panicking and without making lots of fuss.

column1: それでは、避難訓練を始めましょう。
column2: Now, let's begin the disaster drill.

column1: to get on, to condemn, to blame;V2
はい。いろいろ考えて、それが一番いいかと…。
column2: Yes. Having thought it over, I think that's probably the best...

column1: 君のような優秀な人が辞めてしまうのは残念でならないよ。
column2: Having someone as talented as you quit is a terrible shame.

column1: 参ったよ。ウチの課の子が退職したいって言い出してさ。
column2: I ask you. One of the kids from my division suddenly says she wants to quit.

column1: なんだよ。知りあいか？お前も隅に置けないな。
column2: What? You know her? I shouldn't underestimate you, huh.

column1: 実は俺の従兄弟の嫁さんなんだよ。
column2: Truth is, she's my cousin's wife. She's Gomi's assistant, right?

column1: 彼女は五味のアシスタントだろ？
column2: Gomi lays the blame on and criticizes her for all his own mistakes, and apparently she's completely furious about it.

column1: 五味は自分のミスを全部彼女のせいにして責めるから腹が立って仕方なかったらしい。
column2: Gomi, huh... Come to think of it, his assistants always quit soon after they start, don't they?

column1: 五味か…。そう言えば、あいつのアシスタントはすぐ辞めるな。
column2: Gomi always has a sharp tongue, so apparently she just hated coming to work.

column1: 五味は角のある言い方ばかりするから、彼女は会社に来るのが嫌でならなかったそうだよ。
なんで教えてくれなかったんだよ。
column2: Because she said to me, Don't tell anyone.

column1: 「誰にも言わないで」って言われてたんだ。
column2: But anyway, you know her new job is at one of our client companies.

column1: ま、でも、彼女の転職先はウチの取引先だ。

column2: She's going to work for one of our customers.

column1: 彼女、ウチのお客さんのとこに転職するんだ。
to put together, to cross one's legs or arms, to assemble;V1
この部屋の契約の更新もうすぐでしょ。どうする？
column2: The contract for this room is coming up for renewal soon, isn't it? What shall we do?

column1: 更新していいんじゃないか。
column2: Surely renewing would be a good idea?

column1: 引越してきたときは田舎だったけど、周りに住宅ができるに従ってお店も増えて、便利になってきたし。
column2: When we moved here it was rural, but due to the housing being built all around, the number of shops has increased, and it's become convenient.

column1: でも、子供が大きくなるにつれて部屋が手狭になってきたし、それに、最近、駅前のガラが悪くなったと思わない？
column2: But as the children have got bigger, the room's become more cramped. And besides, don't you think that lately the tone of the area in front of the station has gotten worse?

column1: まあ、確かに飲み屋が増えてくるにつれて、酔っぱらいをよく見かけるようになってきたな。
column2: Well, I dare say as the number of bars has increased, you do see drunks more often now.

column1: でしょ？家賃もったいないし、そろそろ郊外に家を建てようよ。
column2: Right? Paying rent's a waste of money, too. Let's build a house in the suburbs soon.

column1: 住宅ローンを組むなら早ければ早いほどいいでしょ。
column2: If we're going to take out a housing loan, the sooner the better, right?

column1: 都心から離れれば離れるほど土地は安くなるけど、その分通勤が...。
column2: The farther you move away from the city center, the cheaper land gets, but on the other hand, the commute...

column1: あ、偶然なんだけど、うちの親が実家の隣の土地を購入したらしいの。
column2: Oh, coincidentally, my parents have bought the plot of land next to their house, apparently.

column1: お電話ありがとうございます。ILL不動産です。
column2: Thank you for calling. This is ILL Real Estate.

column1: 音声に従って数字をご入力ください。
column2: Please enter a number according to the instructions.

column1: 契約の更新の方は１、契約の解約の方は２を、その他のお問い合わせの方は3を入力してください。
column2: Those who wish to renew a contract, please press 1. Those who wish to cancel a contract, please press 2. For all other inquiries, please press 3.

column1: ２。（ピッ）はあ...。俺もマスオさんになるのか。
column2: 2. (beep) Sigh... So I'm going to become a Masuo-san too, huh.

column1: 「原子力発電の安全性を高めると共に、クリーンエネルギーにも取り組んでいく必要がある」か…。
column2: It is necessary to enhance the safety of nuclear power generation as well as focus on clean energy...Huh.

column1: ねぇ。新聞読みながらご飯食べるのやめて。
column2: Hey. Stop reading the paper while you eat.

column1: ねぇ、パパ。クリーンエネルギーって何？
ん？クリーンエネルギーっていうのは、簡単に言えば環境に優しいエネルギーってことだ。
column2: Hm? To put it simply, clean energy is energy that is kind to the environment.

column1: 太陽光発電とか風力発電とかだな。
column2: Solar power, wind power, that sort of thing.

column1: そうだな、水力もクリーンエネルギーだな。
column2: Yeah, hydroelectric power is also clean energy.

column1: 放射能漏れの事故があったのに原発をやめることはできないの？
column2: Even though there was a radiation leakage accident, why don't they shut down the nuclear power plants?

column1: 原子力は火力や水力と並んで、日本ではメジャーな発電方法だから、今すぐやめるのは無理だろうなぁ。
column2: Along with solar power and hydraulic power, nuclear power is one of the major methods of energy generation in Japan, so it'd probably be impossible to shut them down straight away.
What are the percentages of energy generation?

column1: 確か、火力発電が約６割から7割。原子力が2割。
column2: If I remember correctly, thermal power is about sixty percent to seventy percent. Nuclear power is twenty percent.

column1: 水力は1割弱じゃなかったかな。
column2: Hydraulic power, I think, is below ten percent.

column1: え？じゃ、太陽光とか風力とかは？
column2: Huh? So what about thermal power and wind power and so on?

column1: 全部あわせても、せいぜい1、2パーセントだろう。
column2: Even if you combine them all, at the very most they're only about one to two percent.

column1: 事故さえ起きなければ、原子力は二酸化炭素も出ないし、得られる電力も大きいから、理想的なんだ。事故さえ起きなければね。
column2: As long as there are no accidents, nuclear power is ideal…it produces no carbon dioxide, and the amount of electric power you can get is huge. As long as there are no accidents, though.

column1: to assemble, to set up, to construct;V2
60年に一度、地球に接近するILL彗星（すいせい）ですが、現在最も地球に接近しており、今夜は望遠鏡を使わなくてもはっきり見えると思われます。
column2: The ILL comet, which draws near the Earth once every sixty years, is currently at the point where it is closest to the Earth. It's thought that even without using a telescope this evening you'll be able to see it clearly.

column1: ジャーン！買っちゃった。
値段もろくに見ずに買ったら、高くてさ、何と十万以上したんだよ、この天体望遠鏡。
column2: I bought it without even looking at the price properly, and it was expensive. Believe it or not, this astronomical telescope cost over 100,000 yen!

column1: 宇宙にろくに興味もないくせに、どうしてそんなに高いのを買ったの？
column2: Why did you buy such an expensive one, even though you're not all that interested in outer space?

column1: インテリアにもなると思ってさ。このフォルムいいだろ。
column2: I thought it would make a nice decoration too, you know. It's got a nice shape, right?

column1: あ、それから、これ、おまけでもらった。
column2: Oh, and also, I got this as a freebie.

column1: 宇宙飛行士と人工衛星のフィギュアと宇宙食。
column2: A figurine of an astronaut and a man-made satellite and some space food.

column1: もう！ろくなもの買わないんだから。
column2: For goodness' sake! You just buy rubbish!

column1: 第一、結婚式のために貯金するって昨日約束したばかりじゃん。
column2: First off, we only just made a promise yesterday that we'd start saving for our wedding, didn't we?

column1: カリカリしても、ろくなことがないぞ。
column2: Getting all touchy won't do you any good.

column1: さ、組み立てるぞ。(sounds of setting up)
column2: Right, I'm going to set it up. (sounds of setting up)

column1: よしできた。見てみよう。あれ？真っ暗で何も見えない…。
column2: Okay, done! Let's take a look. Huh? It's pitch black. I can't see a thing...

column1: 説明書もろくに読まずに組み立てるからだよ。
column2: That's because you set it up without even reading the instructions properly.

column1: この望遠鏡なら、月のクレーターや山が見えるって言ってたのに…。
column2: Even though the guy said with this telescope you could see the moon's craters and mountains and stuff...

column1: 不良品を買わされたんじゃない。いいカモにされたんだよ。
column2: He sold you a defective product. You got well and truly suckered!

「不動産を買うなら、低金利の今が買い時」かぁ…。
column2: If you're going to buy property, now is the time to do it when interest rates are low. Huh...

column1: でも、先立つものがなきゃ買えないよ。
column2: But if we don't have the means, we can't buy it at all.

column1: ね、春樹。春樹？あれ？急に耳が遠くなっちゃった？
column2: Right, Haruki? Haruki? Huh? Have you suddenly gone deaf?

column1: 天体望遠鏡なんて買ってないできちんと貯金してよ。
column2: Stop buying stuff like astronomical telescopes and start properly saving up.

column1: はいはい。それは、耳にたこができるほど聞きました。
column2: All right, all right. I'm fed up to the back teeth of hearing that... I'm making my own plans, you know. Investing in land...

column1: …俺だって、色々考えているんだ。土地に投資したり…。
column2: You're joking. You bought land? That's the first I've heard of it.

column1: ジャーン！これ火星の土地の権利書。
column2: What? This is just fraud. Live on Mars, that's ridiculous!

column1: は？こんなの詐欺じゃん。火星になんて住めっこないでしょ。
そうだけど、夢があるじゃん。

column2: I mean, you're buying into dreams too, right? A little bird told me you bought a lottery ticket.

column1: 自分だって、夢を買ってるだろ。宝くじ買ったって小耳に挟んだぜ。
どうして知ってんのよ。

column2: Hi everyone! Welcome to Yuri’s audio blog.
Today we'll be talking about “RED BAR” in Shibuya, Tokyo. RED BAR is a small bar located in an alleyway outside the Miyamasuzaka exit of Shibuya station.

all the walls are bright red, and there are many chandeliers hanging from the ceiling. From the luxurious baroque crystal grapes to the stuffed deer heads, there is plenty on display to tantalize the senses. There are two or three velvet sofas to relax on, but most guests spend their time standing at the bar.
open at 10pm and closed when the last customer leaves. The bar is a popular hidden spot for fashion industry types, such as Japanese and foreign models, journalists, etc.

Customers pay for each drink as it is served, and the bartenders are always ready for special orders too. RED BAR is often so crowded, even on weeknights, that there is an overflow of people trailing out the door.

column1: 店内の壁は、その名の通り真っ赤で、天井には何十個ものシャンデリアが吊るされています。
column2: I sometimes go to RED BAR myself, and no matter what line of work the other customers are in, or their nationality, I always find the place full of really energetic people. Maybe it is these types of chance encounters and candid conversations that make this bar so popular.

column1: ブドウの形をしたもの、ロココ調のクリスタルの豪華なものなど、見ているだけでも楽しいものばかりです。
column2: Another attraction may also be that this peculiar windowless space allows you to forget the passing time. The thought brings a smile to my face, and I can’t remember how many times night has turned into morning before I knew it. Whenever I have friends visiting from abroad, I always take them to RED BAR.

column1: その他、鹿の顔のオブジェなどユニークなオブジェも展示されています。
column2: Well, today's Audio Blog was about RED BAR. How did you like it?
Tonight, as you are drifting off to sleep, try to imagine it; a wonderland where the

column1: 常連の間では、RED　BARの看板ともいえる日本人バーテンダーもっさんに会うために訪れる人も少なくありません。
column2: alcohol flows, animated conversations fly across the room and time seems to slip away…

column2: I have a fever, headache and fatigue. I also have a runny nose.

column1: そうですねぇ。。。この薬とこの薬をご飯の後に飲めば、すぐ治りますよ！
column2: Hmmm. If you drink this medicine and this medicine after a meal, you'll feel better right away!

column1: not picking up the phone, not answering the phone
してみたけど、出ないんだよ。確か、車で来るんだよね。
column2: I did, but he won't answer. If I'm not mistaken, he drives here.

column1: そうそう。車は、白くて、四角くて、黄色いナンバープレートの。そんなに大きくないよ。
column2: Right. His car is white, square, and has a yellow license plate. It's not that big.

column1: うわー、すごい人の数だなあ。
column2: Wow, there are tons of people here.

column1: すごいね。なんでだろうね。
column2: Yeah, it's crazy. I wonder why.

column1: ここが、有名な竹下通りだよ。ほらっ、あそこに書いてあるよ。
column2: This is the famous Takeshita street. Look, it's written over there.

column1: なるほどー。ここなのね。
あの人って、何をする人だろう？
column2: Do you know what she's doing here?

column1: えっ。知らないの。巫女さんだよ。
column2: What? You don't know? She is a miko-san. I don't know the details but miko-san works at shrines.

column1: どんな仕事してるんだろうね。
column2: She takes care of visitors, gives talismans, does dances, and many other things.

column1: 参拝者への対応とか、お守りをあげるとか、舞を踊るとか・・・いろいろじゃないの。
column2: That's my friend, Mamoru! You are so knowledgeable.

column1: さすが、マサル。物知りだなあ。
今日何しようか。。。カラオケ行かない？
column2: What are we gonna do today…you wanna go karaoke?

column1: また？先週も行ったじゃん。
column2: Again? We did it last week, remember?

column1: じゃあ、何したいんだよ。
column2: Then, what do you wanna do?

column1: じゃあ、久しぶりにボーリング行こうよ。
おお、良いね！けどその前に疲れたからお茶しようよ。
column2: Sounds good! But why don’t we get something to drink before it because I’m tired.

column1: Kansai (south-western half of Japan, including Osaka)
ちょっと、雅人、ダメだよ。
column2: Hey, Masato, you can't do that!
Huh? What are you talking about?

column1: 東京では、エスカレーターの左側に立つの。
column2: In Tokyo we stand on the left side of the escalator.

column1: 何を言うとんねん。関西人は右側に立つんや。
column2: What are you talking about?  Kansai people stand on the right side.

column1: to be bothered, to have a problem;V1
to forget, to leave carelessly, to be forgetful of, to forget about, to forget (an article)
メンズカットサロン「サブロー」です。よろしくお願いしま～す。
column2: This is a men’s cut salon “Saburo”. We’re looking forward to seeing you.

column1: （男の人に配りたいんだけどなぁ。まぁ、いいや。）はい、どうぞ。
column2: (I want to give them to men...ah, whatever) Here you are.

column1: ティッシュ忘れちゃって、困っていたの。ちょうどよかったにゃー！
column2: How convenient! I forgot my tissues and was in need of some.

column1: あ、はぁ。。（この季節は、みんな風邪ひいているから　ティッシュを受け取るのか・・・。）
column2: Ah, I see…(In this season, they take tissues because everybody has a cold…)

column1: the place where people wash their hands and mouth before they visit a shrine
shift something from one arm to the other
お母さん、どうしたらいいのー。
お手てとお口をきれいにするのよ。
column2: We're going to wash our hands and mouths.

column1: お参りする前は、ちゃんとお清めしないといけないの。
column2: Before visiting a shrine, you have to properly purify yourself.

column1: ひしゃくって言うのよ。
column2: It's called a hishaku (ladle). First you take it in your right hand and purify your left hand.  Then you switch it to your left hand and purify your right hand.  After that, you rinse your mouth.

column1: まず右手にひしゃくを持って、左手を清めて、
